EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix’s blend of warmth, improvisation and stubborn optimism proves vital in keeping the survivors moving and exposing the sabotage. His courage in saving Tuvok and facing his own fears shows that his value to the crew extends far beyond morale and cooking.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s discipline and tactical thinking provide structure amid the chaos of the damaged tether ascent. His willingness—however grudging—to acknowledge Neelix’s contributions marks a small but meaningful evolution in their often-tense relationship.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway coordinates the larger mission from orbit, balancing the need to protect the Nezu with the limits of what Voyager can safely do in another society’s internal affairs.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Vatm: Dr. Vatm appears unstable but ultimately proves to be the key whistleblower, holding the data that reveals the guided nature of the asteroid strikes.
EntitySummaries.Sklar and his co-conspirators: Sklar and his allies function as covert antagonists, weaponizing natural phenomena to conceal an engineered attack and nearly dooming the colony.
EntitySummaries.Guided asteroid attacks: The disguised bombardment serves as an environmental antagonist that constantly threatens the survivors and symbolically represents how manufactured crises can be passed off as acts of nature.

ContinuityNotes: Rise pairs Tuvok and Neelix in a rare two-hander survival story, further exploring their abrasive but evolving dynamic.
The episode showcases Voyager's willingness to assist pre-warp societies when invited and when the Prime Directive allows.
The orbital tether concept adds a visually distinctive setting compared to typical planetary missions.
The story continues Voyager's pattern of encountering internal political conflicts within Delta Quadrant species.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores trust and respect between very different personalities forced to rely on each other.
It examines how artificial disasters can be used as cover for political or military agendas.
Rise highlights the value of both logic and empathy in crisis leadership.
The story emphasizes perseverance in the face of recurring setbacks, literally climbing above the turmoil.
BehindTheScenes: Rise was written by Brannon Braga from a story by Jimmy Diggs and directed by Robert Scheerer.
The production made extensive use of vertical sets and visual effects to depict the orbital tether's interior and exterior.
The episode was designed in part to give Ethan Phillips and Tim Russ more shared screen time and character interplay.

Title: Favorite Son
Summary: After firing on an alien ship based on unexplained intuition, Harry Kim begins experiencing déjà vu and a strange rash as Voyager enters a previously unexplored sector. A nearby planet populated almost entirely by women—the Taresians—claims that Harry is actually one of their people, genetically sent to Earth as an embryo, and that he has finally come home. Seduced by the idea of belonging and attention, Harry is drawn into their rituals, only to discover that the Taresians lure males from other species in order to drain their life-force during reproduction. Voyager races to expose the ruse and rescue him before he becomes their next victim.

StorySections.Teaser: On the bridge, Harry abruptly orders Voyager to fire on an approaching ship, insisting that it is about to attack despite no clear evidence. The ship is crippled, and Harry is left shaken and embarrassed when scans reveal no obvious threat. Soon after, he develops an unusual rash and a sense that he has been in this region of space before.
StorySections.Act I: A signal from the nearby world of Taresia welcomes Harry by name and explains that his genetic changes mean he is ‘awakening’ to his true heritage. Curious and unsettled, Harry beams down with an away team and meets a society made up mostly of women, who shower him with attention and insist he has finally returned home. They claim his human life was a cover, the result of sending his embryonic form to Earth for safety.
StorySections.Act II: As Harry is drawn into Taresian culture, he enjoys the adoration but struggles with guilt over leaving Voyager and his parents behind. The Taresians present scientific data that appears to confirm that his DNA is transforming to match theirs, and they encourage him to undergo rituals that will complete the process. On Voyager, the Doctor and Tuvok analyze Harry’s genetic changes and discover anomalies that suggest external manipulation rather than a natural awakening.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway’s investigation uncovers records of other males who came to Taresia and were never heard from again. Meanwhile, Harry learns that another visitor, Taymon, is preparing for a ceremonial union that seems disturbingly final. The Taresians’ explanations grow thinner as Harry notices hidden chambers and hears whispers that contradict the official story. The truth emerges: Taresian reproduction requires draining the life energy of off-world males, who are effectively sacrificed in the process.
StorySections.Act IV: Harry finds himself locked into the ritual, with Taresian women surrounding him in an ornate chamber under the guise of celebration. Voyager breaks through the planet’s defenses and beams an away team down, engaging in a frantic rescue as the Taresians attempt to complete the process. The Doctor reverses the genetic alterations, revealing that Harry was never truly Taresian but was targeted and altered by a viral agent that mimicked native DNA. Free of the conditioning, Harry rejects the manufactured identity and returns to Voyager.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard ship, Harry wrestles with embarrassment over having been seduced by fantasy and false belonging. Janeway reassures him that susceptibility to manipulation is a risk anyone faces when their deepest desires are appealed to. Life on Voyager returns to normal, with Harry more wary of too-good-to-be-true promises.

EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry’s brush with the Taresians plays on his insecurities about status, romance and belonging, making him a prime target for their predatory hospitality. His eventual rejection of the fantasy and reaffirmation of his human identity underscore his underlying integrity.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway approaches the too-perfect Taresian society with skepticism, determined to verify their claims before letting a crew member go. Her insistence on hard evidence and her swift action during the rescue exemplify her protective leadership.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s analysis of the genetic data cuts through the Taresians’ story, demonstrating the value of logic and forensic thinking when emotions are clouded.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor identifies and reverses the viral genetic alterations, saving Harry’s life and revealing the true nature of the Taresian scheme.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris provides a grounded friend’s perspective, teasing Harry about his sudden good fortune while also supporting him when the situation turns deadly.
EntitySummaries.Taresian reproductive trap: The Taresians’ outwardly idyllic culture conceals a lethal reproductive strategy that objectifies and consumes male partners, turning desire into a weapon.
EntitySummaries.Genetic manipulation virus: The engineered virus functions as a stealth antagonist, rewriting Harry’s body and perceptions to make him easier to lure and control.

ContinuityNotes: Favorite Son centers Harry Kim in a rare spotlight episode focused on his identity and vulnerabilities.
The story was originally developed to reveal that Harry truly was an alien but was revised to keep him human.
The episode fits into Star Trek's tradition of seductive, dangerous societies that hide predatory motives beneath hospitality.
Visual and thematic parallels have been drawn between this story and earlier franchise episodes involving alluring but lethal alien women.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines manipulation through fantasy, particularly how flattery and desire can be used to override critical thinking.
It explores questions of identity and belonging, especially for someone far from home and family.
Favorite Son critiques male wish-fulfillment scenarios by revealing a deadly price beneath the fantasy.
The story highlights the importance of skepticism and self-knowledge in resisting exploitation.
BehindTheScenes: Favorite Son was written by Lisa Klink and directed by Marvin V. Rush.
The script underwent significant revisions, shifting from the idea that Harry was genuinely alien to the final version where he is manipulated by the Taresians.
Cast and crew have commented on the episode as a deliberate play on seductive, pulp-style science fiction tropes.

Title: Before and After
Summary: Kes awakens as an elderly woman near the end of her life, married to Tom Paris with a grown daughter and grandson, only to find herself slipping backward in time through earlier points in her own timeline. As she moves from her deathbed to middle age to her days as a new mother and eventually back to her present aboard Voyager, Kes pieces together that her condition is linked to chroniton radiation from a Krenim weapon used during a devastating "Year of Hell." Racing against a temporal paradox, she must use knowledge from her future lives to help the Doctor and the crew cure her condition and warn them about the threat yet to come.

StorySections.Teaser: An aged Kes lies dying in sickbay, surrounded by Tom Paris, their daughter Linnis and grandson Andrew, while the Doctor laments that he can do nothing more. As the Doctor activates a biotemporal chamber in a last attempt to stabilize her, Kes is engulfed in temporal energy and suddenly finds herself years younger at a family gathering, confused by memories of her own death that no one else shares.
StorySections.Act I: Kes struggles to understand a life she does not remember: she is married to Tom, Linnis calls her mother and Voyager bears scars from a terrible period known as the "Year of Hell." Chroniton torpedo impacts and references to the Krenim hint at a long, brutal conflict. During another temporal shift, Kes jumps further back to a time when Linnis is still a child and Voyager is in the midst of fighting the Krenim, witnessing friends wounded and corridors damaged in ways that feel like half-remembered prophecy.
StorySections.Act II: Each jump sends Kes back to a younger self: she returns to the point where she is pregnant with Linnis, then to the early days of the Krenim attacks when the Doctor first tried experimental treatments using the biotemporal chamber. With each regression, she retains memories from her older incarnations and slowly realizes that chroniton radiation in her cells is sending her life in reverse. Janeway and the Doctor theorize that if they can isolate the chroniton torpedo frequency, they may be able to counteract its effect on both Kes and the ship.
StorySections.Act III: Kes leaps again, now to her current-era self on Voyager, before any Krenim contact. Armed with knowledge of the coming war, including the chroniton frequency and the name of the Krenim, she tries to convince Janeway and Tuvok that the danger is real. The Doctor detects chroniton signatures in her body and confirms that she is effectively living her life backwards, with only limited time before she reaches the moment of initial exposure and potentially ceases to exist.
StorySections.Act IV: Working from Kes’s future-derived information, the Doctor recalibrates the biotemporal chamber to create a controlled temporal field that can strip the chroniton particles from her cells. As Kes teeters on the edge of another backward jump, the treatment is activated, anchoring her in the present and halting the regression. The chroniton data are preserved in Voyager’s logs as a warning about the Krenim and their weapons.
StorySections.Tag: Recovered and back to her normal age, Kes reflects with Janeway and the Doctor on the strange, emotional glimpses of a possible future that may now never occur. Janeway stores the tactical information about the Krenim for the day Voyager encounters them, while Kes quietly contemplates the bittersweet knowledge of a life with Tom and Linnis that she has lived and yet not lived.

EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes experiences her own life in reverse, forced to process marriages, children and wars as half-remembered futures slipping away from her. Her ability to stay focused and use those fragmented memories to save herself and warn Voyager underscores her growing mental discipline and power.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: In the future timeline, Tom is Kes’s devoted husband and Linnis’s father, offering emotional support as she dies and later as her condition worsens in earlier years. His presence gives weight to the possible life they might share, even if that future is averted.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway treats Kes’s temporal experiences not as delusion but as valuable intelligence, trusting her enough to log the Krenim data despite the paradox. Her willingness to rely on one crew member’s uncanny knowledge illustrates her pragmatic approach to time anomalies.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s biotemporal chamber both triggers and ultimately cures Kes’s temporal regression, placing him at the center of the paradox. His work yields crucial information on chroniton-based weaponry that will become vital when Voyager reaches Krenim space.
EntitySummaries.Linnis: Linnis, as Kes and Tom’s daughter, personifies the life and family Kes may never have, making the loss of that timeline deeply personal even as it is erased.
EntitySummaries.Chroniton radiation: The chroniton particles function as an unseen antagonist, dragging Kes backward through her own history and hinting at the destructive sophistication of Krenim technology.
EntitySummaries.Krenim temporal weapons: Though only glimpsed in this episode, the Krenim’s time-altering torpedoes stand as a looming future threat, foreshadowing events that will later confront Voyager in earnest.

ContinuityNotes: Before and After foreshadows the "Year of Hell" conflict with the Krenim, which is later depicted in detail in Voyager's fourth season.
The episode provides an alternate-future glimpse of Tom Paris and Kes as a married couple with a daughter.
Chroniton radiation and temporal technology are further developed as recurring elements in Voyager's Delta Quadrant encounters.
Kes’s temporal experience adds another layer to her evolving mental and psychic abilities.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores fate versus free will, suggesting that knowledge of a possible future can be used to change it.
It examines the poignancy of lives and relationships that exist only in erased or alternate timelines.
Before and After engages with the horror and wonder of living one's life out of order, raising questions about identity and memory.
The story emphasizes preparedness: information gathered in one timeline can still arm you against threats in another.
BehindTheScenes: Before and After was written by Kenneth Biller and directed by Allan Kroeker.
The episode’s Krenim and "Year of Hell" concepts were later expanded into a dedicated two-part story.
Makeup and prosthetics were used extensively to depict Kes, Tom and other characters at different ages across multiple timelines.

Title: Real Life
Summary: Seeking to better understand organic family life, the Doctor creates a holoprogram in which he plays the role of a devoted husband and father in an idealized 20th-century-style home. When B'Elanna Torres modifies the program to make it more realistic, his perfect family becomes messy and challenging, culminating in a tragic accident that leaves his holographic daughter mortally injured. As the Doctor wrestles with the pain of grief, a parallel mission sees Tom Paris risking his life to study a dangerous subspace phenomenon, forcing both men to confront what it means to live fully despite the risk of loss.

StorySections.Teaser: The crew is amused and bemused when the Doctor proudly introduces them to his new holo-family: a doting wife, two impeccably behaved children and a spotless, cozy home. Janeway and Paris exchange knowing glances as the Doctor revels in the domestic bliss of nightly dinners, polite conversation and minor, easily resolved mishaps.
StorySections.Act I: Torres, irritated by how unrealistically perfect the family seems, secretly adjusts the program’s parameters to introduce more genuine complexity. On his next visit, the Doctor finds his son rebellious, his daughter distracted and his wife overwhelmed with duties and expectations. Everyday conflicts erupt: arguments over chores, academic pressures and the Doctor’s tendency to retreat into work. Meanwhile, Voyager approaches a volatile subspace turbulence that intrigues Tom Paris, who volunteers to pilot a shuttle close to the phenomenon for study.
StorySections.Act II: The Doctor struggles to adapt to his family’s new dynamics, trying and failing to impose neat solutions on messy emotions. His daughter Belle expresses a desire to pursue risky hobbies like paragliding, while his son clashes with classmates and resents his father’s absence. On Voyager, concerns grow that Paris is underestimating the danger of the subspace eddies, but he insists that calculated risk is part of exploration.
StorySections.Act III: Belle is injured during a paragliding accident inside the program, and when the Doctor rushes to sickbay in the simulation, he is devastated to learn that she has suffered fatal internal injuries. Horrified, he initially demands that the program be shut down and reset, unwilling to face the inevitability of her death. Torres and Kes argue that if he wants a real understanding of family life, he must also accept its pain, not just its comforts.
StorySections.Act IV: Encouraged by Janeway, the Doctor returns to the program and stays at Belle’s bedside as her condition deteriorates, sharing quiet moments and promises with her and the rest of the family. He experiences raw grief as she dies, choosing to live through the loss instead of erasing it with a command. In the real world, Paris’s shuttle mission nearly ends in disaster when violent subspace turbulence overturns his calculations, but he manages to survive and return with valuable data.
StorySections.Tag: Later, the Doctor confides in Paris that he now understands something about the emotional cost of caring for others and the courage it takes to face mortality. Paris, fresh from his own brush with death, agrees that a life without risk—and thus without love and loss—would be poorer. Voyager moves on, with the Doctor forever changed by a holographic family that felt all too real.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s experiment in family life forces him to recognize that authentic relationships include conflict, frustration and the possibility of devastating loss. By choosing to endure Belle’s death, he takes a crucial step toward emotional maturity and a deeper understanding of the organic beings he serves.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway gently but firmly encourages the Doctor not to run from painful experiences, emphasizing that leadership and empathy both require engaging with grief rather than editing it out.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres’s modifications to the holo-family, though intrusive, catalyze the Doctor’s growth by stripping away his fantasies and forcing him to confront a more credible version of domestic life.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris’s willingness to risk his life for scientific discovery parallels the Doctor’s emotional risk, illustrating that fully lived lives require stepping into danger—physical or emotional.
EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes offers the Doctor compassionate support, validating his feelings and underscoring that the emotional reality of his experience matters, even if the family was holographic.
EntitySummaries.Belle: Belle becomes the emotional heart of the story; her illness and death transform the Doctor’s abstract curiosity about family into a visceral encounter with love and loss.
EntitySummaries.Doctor's idealized expectations: The Doctor’s initial desire for a flawless, conflict-free family functions as an antagonist, preventing him from understanding the authentic complexity of real relationships.
EntitySummaries.Subspace turbulence phenomenon: The dangerous subspace eddies serve as an external antagonist that mirrors the emotional turbulence of the Doctor’s journey.

ContinuityNotes: Real Life is a major milestone in the Doctor's arc, deepening his emotional range and empathy.
The episode continues Voyager's exploration of holotechnology as a tool for growth rather than mere escapism.
Tom Paris's subplot reinforces his role as an adventurous pilot willing to push boundaries for science.
The story has often been cited by fans for its unexpectedly powerful emotional climax.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores themes of grief, acceptance and the necessity of experiencing pain to truly understand love.
It critiques idealized fantasies of family life by showing their hollowness compared to flawed, genuine bonds.
Real Life emphasizes that growth often comes from confronting hardship rather than avoiding it.
The parallel plots suggest that both emotional and physical risks are integral to a meaningful existence.
BehindTheScenes: Real Life was written by Harry Doc Kloor and Jeri Taylor and directed by Anson Williams.
The episode is frequently praised for Robert Picardo's performance in the later acts.
The contrast between the early sitcom-like tone and the later tragedy was a deliberate structural choice to heighten impact.

Title: Distant Origin
Summary: A Voth scientist named Gegen discovers the fossilized remains of a Starfleet officer and, through rigorous analysis, concludes that his own saurian species may have evolved from Earth dinosaurs that left the planet millions of years ago. His controversial "distant origin" theory challenges the foundational doctrine of the Voth, who believe themselves to be the first race in the galaxy. When Gegen traces living evidence to Voyager and captures Chakotay, a clash ensues between scientific truth and political power as Voth authorities attempt to suppress the theory and preserve their cultural supremacy.

StorySections.Teaser: On a remote planet, Gegen and his assistant Veer study the skeletal remains of a humanoid in a Starfleet uniform, excited by the prospect that it could validate their radical hypothesis about the Voth’s off-world origins. Genetic analysis suggests a link to a distant region of space, igniting Gegen’s determination to find living samples. The sequence plays largely from the Voth point of view, presenting Voyager and the Federation as mysterious data points in an alien investigation.
StorySections.Act I: Gegen and Veer track subspace signatures to the Nekrit Expanse and eventually to Voyager, secretly boarding the ship and taking scans of various crew members. They are startled by the diversity of species aboard but find that human DNA is the closest match to their own. Caught during their clandestine survey, they are forced to reveal themselves, and Gegen argues passionately to Janeway and Chakotay that the Voth and humans share a common ancestral world: Earth.
StorySections.Act II: Intrigued, Janeway shares Earth’s fossil record and scientific history, while the Doctor confirms the genetic compatibility between humans and Voth. Convinced he now has irrefutable proof, Gegen prepares to present his findings to the Voth Ministry of Elders. However, Voth authorities view the idea that they evolved elsewhere as heresy that would undermine their doctrine of being the galaxy’s first and most advanced species.
StorySections.Act III: Voyager is seized by a massive Voth city-ship, and the crew are immobilized as the Elders put Chakotay and Gegen on trial for promulgating forbidden ideas. The prosecution argues that the distant origin theory threatens social order and the supremacy that justifies the Voth’s harsh treatment of "lesser" species. Chakotay testifies in support of Gegen’s evidence, appealing to the Elders’ sense of curiosity and integrity, while Gegen risks his career and status to stand by his research.
StorySections.Act IV: The Chief Elder delivers a verdict that condemns the theory, threatening Voyager with exile to an inhospitable region unless Gegen recants. Faced with the destruction of his colleagues and the persecution of his people, Gegen reluctantly renounces his own findings to save them, accepting exile instead of imprisonment. The Voth release Voyager, and the Elder reasserts doctrine, even as the private doubt in her eyes implies she understands the truth she has chosen to bury.
StorySections.Tag: In the aftermath, Chakotay reflects with Janeway on the cost of suppressed truths and the courage of scientists like Gegen who challenge orthodoxy. Somewhere aboard the Voth city-ship, Gegen continues his work in secret, still believing that one day his people will be ready to hear where they truly came from.

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay serves as Voyager’s representative in the Voth trial, articulating a defense of open inquiry and the willingness to face uncomfortable truths about one’s origins. His empathy for Gegen underscores common ground between very different cultures.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway provides Gegen with extensive scientific data and moral support, recognizing a kindred scientific spirit even across species. Her frustration at seeing truth subordinated to doctrine reflects Starfleet’s commitment to knowledge.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s genetic analysis provides crucial empirical support for Gegen’s theory, offering concrete evidence that the Voth and humans share an ancestral world.
EntitySummaries.Gegen: Gegen is a passionate scientist whose dedication to evidence puts him at odds with his society’s foundational myths. His forced recantation makes him a tragic figure, sacrificing professional legitimacy to protect others while privately holding fast to the truth.
EntitySummaries.Veer: Veer begins as a cautious assistant but grows to admire Gegen’s courage, representing younger generations who may someday embrace the distant origin theory.
EntitySummaries.Chief Elder: The Chief Elder embodies the institutional resistance to paradigm-shifting discoveries, valuing social stability and hierarchical control over scientific accuracy.
EntitySummaries.Voth doctrinal authority: The rigid doctrine that the Voth are the first race functions as an antagonistic force, punishing dissent and stifling intellectual progress.
EntitySummaries.Political suppression of science: The deliberate choice to ignore and bury evidence highlights how power structures can distort or silence truth to maintain dominance.

ContinuityNotes: Distant Origin offers a rare alien-centric perspective, framing much of the episode through Voth characters rather than Voyager's crew.
The episode proposes that a dinosaur-like species from Earth evolved into the spacefaring Voth, adding a speculative twist to Earth's prehistoric past.
Voyager's role here reinforces Starfleet's image as a source of scientific partnership and cultural challenge.
The story aligns with Star Trek's tradition of using alien societies to explore real-world debates over evolution and doctrine.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines the conflict between scientific discovery and entrenched ideology.
It explores how fear of social upheaval can lead authorities to suppress transformative truths.
Distant Origin highlights the personal cost borne by scientists who confront orthodoxy with evidence.
The story suggests that truth can outlast temporary victories of censorship, living on in those who refuse to forget.
BehindTheScenes: Distant Origin was inspired in part by debates over evolution versus creationism and the idea of a dinosaur-descended spacefaring species.
The episode was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and directed by David Livingston.
Elaborate costumes and makeup were created to bring the Voth's saurian appearance to life.

Title: Displaced
Summary: Voyager's crew members begin vanishing one by one, each disappearance coinciding with the sudden appearance of a polite alien from a species called the Nyrians, who claim to be just as confused as the crew. As more Nyrians arrive and more Starfleet personnel vanish, Janeway realizes that her people are being systematically displaced to a vast network of artificial biomes aboard a concealed Nyrian vessel. Trapped in a simulated environment, the crew must find a way to outmaneuver their captors and retake control of the ship.

StorySections.Teaser: Kes is in the mess hall when she vanishes in mid-conversation, replaced instantly by a bewildered Nyrian male who claims no idea how he arrived. The incident appears as an isolated transporter malfunction until another crew member disappears and another Nyrian appears, triggering growing unease.
StorySections.Act I: As the pattern continues, Tuvok and Torres search for technical explanations while Janeway questions the Nyrians, who insist they are victims of the same phenomenon. The number of Nyrians aboard slowly increases, and they begin suggesting security and safety measures that conveniently give them more access and authority. When Janeway herself finally vanishes, the façade drops: the Nyrians are orchestrating the exchange with advanced long-range transporters.
StorySections.Act II: Janeway materializes in a carefully controlled artificial habitat designed to mimic a temperate world, where other displaced Voyager crew members have already arrived. They discover that the habitat is one of many linked environments that contain abducted individuals from numerous species, all maintained in comfortable captivity. Meanwhile, on Voyager, the remaining officers are outnumbered and gradually overrun by Nyrian replacements.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway organizes an escape by probing the edges of the habitat, finding a hidden control node that allows limited access between biomes. With a small team, she begins moving through increasingly hostile environments—frigid zones, toxic atmospheres and heavy-gravity chambers—competing with Nyrian security teams adapted to slow, methodical movement between habitats. Tuvok and Paris work from inside Voyager’s systems to exploit Nyrian routines and create openings for a counterattack.
StorySections.Act IV: Using their adaptability and ability to operate quickly in multiple environments, Janeway’s team reaches the central control hub, overriding the Nyrians’ climate controls and forcing them into uncomfortable conditions they are not equipped to handle. The crew seizes control of the transport matrix, returning Voyager’s people to the ship and sending the Nyrians back to their own habitats. Janeway reconfigures the system to allow the other captive species to free themselves and warns the Nyrians against future abductions.
StorySections.Tag: With Voyager restored, Janeway reflects on the Nyrians’ preference for subtle, non-violent conquest through displacement rather than open battle. The crew resumes course, having proven once again that Starfleet resourcefulness is hard to contain, even in a custom-built prison.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway quickly sees through the Nyrians’ polite façade and leads a daring campaign from within their own habitat network, turning their carefully calibrated system against them. Her willingness to traverse hostile environments underscores her determination to reclaim her ship and free others.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides calm tactical insight, both in initially probing the Nyrians' story and later helping coordinate the counter-strategy from within Voyager’s compromised systems.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris assists in the rescue, using his flexibility and quick thinking as the crew navigates the nested habitats and sabotages Nyrian operations.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres’s engineering expertise helps decode elements of the habitat control network, enabling Janeway’s team to move between environments.
EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes is among the first displaced, and her experiences in the habitat highlight the confusion and vulnerability of the abducted prisoners.
EntitySummaries.Nyrian abductors: The Nyrians prefer to conquer through quiet replacement and containment rather than overt warfare, making them insidious antagonists who rely on complacency and slow attrition.
EntitySummaries.Habitat control network: The sprawling network of linked artificial environments functions as an environmental antagonist, designed to keep prisoners comfortable but powerless.

ContinuityNotes: Displaced showcases Voyager's crew working together to overcome an elaborate, non-traditional form of capture.
The episode contributes to Voyager's catalogue of Delta Quadrant species with distinctive technological and strategic approaches.
It reinforces Janeway’s style of turning an enemy’s own systems against them in order to prevail.
The multiple habitat settings allowed the production to reuse and redress sets in creative ways.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores themes of captivity, control and the ethics of "benevolent" imprisonment.
It highlights the importance of adaptability and cooperation when facing an enemy that prefers subtlety to open conflict.
Displaced critiques the idea that comfort can compensate for loss of freedom.
The story underscores that even highly structured systems have exploitable weaknesses when their designers grow complacent.
BehindTheScenes: Displaced was written by Lisa Klink and directed by Allan Kroeker.
The Nyrians' methodical, non-violent style of conquest was conceived as a contrast to more overtly aggressive adversaries like the Borg or Kazon.
The episode's various environments showcased Voyager's production design flexibility and practical effects.

Title: Worst Case Scenario
Summary: While browsing holodeck files, Tom Paris and B'Elanna Torres discover an unfinished tactical simulation in which Chakotay and the former Maquis crew stage a mutiny against Janeway and Starfleet. The engaging "what if" scenario becomes popular among the crew—until it is revealed that Seska, before her death, secretly tampered with the program, turning it into a lethal trap designed to kill Tuvok and anyone else who runs it. As the holodeck locks down and reality and simulation blur, Paris and Tuvok must outthink Seska’s posthumous sabotage from inside the deadly scenario.

StorySections.Teaser: Paris stumbles upon an intriguing holoprogram in which he beams into Voyager’s corridors and is immediately confronted with a tense standoff: Chakotay and the Maquis appear to be in open rebellion, seizing control of key systems. Curious, Paris plays along, only to have the simulation abruptly end in mid-crisis, tagged as an unfinished security exercise authored by Tuvok.
StorySections.Act I: Word of the program spreads, and crew members begin running it for entertainment, debating what they would do in a real Maquis mutiny. Tuvok reluctantly admits that he created the scenario as a training tool in case loyalties fractured early in the ship’s journey, but he left it incomplete once the crew bonded. Encouraged by Janeway to finish the program for fun and camaraderie, Tuvok and Paris collaborate on new endings.
StorySections.Act II: As they resume work, the simulation suddenly shifts in tone: Seska appears inside the program, revealing through a recorded message that she discovered and booby-trapped Tuvok’s scenario before defecting to the Kazon. She has rewritten it so that running the program will trigger lethal feedback in the holodeck, turning safeties into weapons. The doors lock, control panels fail and Paris and Tuvok realize they are trapped in Seska’s last revenge.
StorySections.Act III: Inside the holonovel, Seska upgrades the Maquis rebellion with more dangerous tactics and deadlier obstacles, forcing Paris and Tuvok to navigate a gauntlet of firefights, force fields and collapsing corridors. Outside, Janeway and the real crew attempt to override the holodeck systems, but Seska’s modifications threaten to route any interruption into a fatal energy surge.
StorySections.Act IV: Using their knowledge of Voyager’s systems and of Seska’s psychology, Paris and Tuvok begin seeking flaws in her narrative logic, choosing unexpected paths that the program is not fully scripted to handle. They exploit a maintenance subroutine embedded in the story to access lower-level controls, rerouting power away from the lethal feedback loop. At the climax, they force a program reset from within the simulation, shutting down the holodeck and neutralizing Seska’s trap.
StorySections.Tag: In the aftermath, the crew jokes uneasily about the experience while Tuvok deletes the dangerous elements of the scenario but considers preserving a safer version for future use. Paris suggests co-writing a new holonovel based on the ordeal, while Janeway reflects on Seska’s lingering ability to cause trouble even from beyond the grave.

EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s original training program reflects his early, pragmatic concerns about divided loyalties, and its corruption by Seska forces him to confront that mistrust. His calm analysis of the holonovel’s structure becomes the key to outmaneuvering Seska’s sabotage.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris approaches the scenario with enthusiasm as a game, only to find himself fighting for his life inside it. His creativity and willingness to improvise unconventional solutions complement Tuvok’s methodical approach.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway sees the value in transforming an old contingency plan into a bonding exercise, but the crisis reminds her that past betrayals can echo far into the future.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: In the program, Chakotay is cast as the leader of the mutiny, a role that contrasts sharply with his real-world loyalty and highlights how far the crew has come since their early days in the Delta Quadrant.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres helps uncover the story behind the holoprogram and lends technical support from outside the holodeck, embodying the Maquis perspective that the training scenario once sought to contain.
EntitySummaries.Seska: Even in death, Seska’s manipulative brilliance and vindictiveness shape events aboard Voyager. Her booby-trapped program is a final attempt to weaponize internal suspicion and exact revenge on those who thwarted her.
EntitySummaries.Seska's booby-trapped holoprogram: The corrupted holonovel acts as an antagonistic environment, turning entertainment into a lethal maze that adapts to its players.
EntitySummaries.Simulated Maquis mutiny: The fictional uprising reflects real historical tensions on Voyager, weaponized here as both training tool and trap.

ContinuityNotes: Worst Case Scenario revisits the early Starfleet/Maquis tensions that defined Voyager's pilot and first season.
The episode brings back Seska posthumously, showing the lingering impact of her betrayal.
It continues Voyager's tradition of using the holodeck as a setting where fantasies can become real dangers.
The story provides a meta-commentary on "what if" scenarios often explored in fan speculation and alternate-timeline episodes.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores trust, paranoia and the residue of old divisions even after a crew has come together.
It highlights the potential dangers of simulations that feel real, especially when control is compromised.
Worst Case Scenario suggests that stories—whether holonovels or contingency plans—can shape perceptions long after the circumstances that birthed them have passed.
The tale underscores the value of creativity and teamwork in outwitting even meticulously planned traps.
BehindTheScenes: Worst Case Scenario was written by Kenneth Biller and directed by Alexander Singer.
The episode allowed the cast to revisit Maquis-versus-Starfleet dynamics in a safe, fictionalized framework.
It is often remembered as a playful yet suspenseful late-season outing that sets the stage for the more serious stakes of the finale.

Title: Scorpion, Part I
Summary: As Voyager enters the heart of Borg space, the crew discovers a new and even more terrifying threat: a mysterious species from fluidic space that is systematically destroying Borg cubes. Caught between the Collective and this unknown enemy—designated Species 8472—Janeway must weigh an unprecedented strategy: forming an alliance with the Borg to survive and continue Voyager’s journey. With Chakotay deeply uneasy about trusting their old adversaries, the ship ventures into a deadly conflict where traditional assumptions about predator and prey no longer hold.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager’s crew watches in awe and horror as they discover a graveyard of shattered Borg cubes floating inert in space, with organic-looking residue clinging to the wreckage. Sensor logs reveal that an unknown force has torn through the Borg with ease, something previously thought impossible. In a nearby nebula, they detect signs of the attackers still active.
StorySections.Act I: As Voyager cautiously approaches Borg territory, the crew debates strategies for slipping through unscathed, including transwarp conduits and stealth routes. A single Borg cube appears, but before it can engage, it is ripped apart by a biomechanical vessel emerging from a rift of swirling, fluid-like space. Initial scans show unprecedented biosignatures and weaponry that can dissolve Borg hulls like tissue.
StorySections.Act II: An away team investigates one of the destroyed Borg ships and encounters the remains of the new enemy: towering, tripedal creatures immune to standard scans and phaser settings. When one of the creatures animates and attacks, it shrugs off Starfleet weapons and must be driven back with high-modulation fire, leaving the away team shaken. Kes begins to experience powerful telepathic visions of a hostile presence, hinting at Species 8472’s awareness of her mind.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway consults the Doctor and Tuvok about the biological nature of the new species, learning that its DNA appears to be "triolic" and nearly impossible to damage, with each cell containing its entire genetic code redundantly. Realizing that the Borg are losing this war, she concludes that Voyager cannot simply pass through unnoticed; sooner or later, they will be caught in the crossfire. She begins to contemplate an alliance with the Collective, trading Starfleet’s ingenuity for safe passage.
StorySections.Act IV: Chakotay strongly objects to cooperating with the Borg, recounting a parable about a scorpion that cannot resist its own nature and warning that the Collective will inevitably turn on them. Despite his misgivings, Janeway orders a course that will bring Voyager into direct contact with a Borg vessel, hoping to negotiate under terms of mutual necessity. As the episode ends, a Borg cube locks a tractor beam onto Voyager amid the blazing backdrop of ongoing battles with Species 8472, hanging the outcome on Janeway’s risky gambit.
StorySections.Tag: In the closing moments, Kes endures another searing telepathic assault, seeing apocalyptic visions of worlds consumed by 8472’s bio-ships. The Doctor continues working on countermeasures, while Chakotay and Janeway remain at an impasse over the wisdom of trusting the Borg. The screen fades out on Voyager being drawn inexorably toward the Collective, caught between two monsters.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway faces one of her most harrowing strategic choices yet: to treat the Borg not as the ultimate enemy but as a desperate ally against an even worse threat. Her willingness to take that risk underscores her pragmatism and determination to bring her crew home.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay serves as the moral and intuitive counterpoint to Janeway, warning that the Borg’s predatory nature makes them inherently untrustworthy. His caution reflects scars from encounters with implacable foes in his Maquis past.
EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes’s latent telepathic abilities make her a conduit for Species 8472’s alien consciousness, subjecting her to terrifying visions that provide crucial intelligence but endanger her sanity.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor analyzes samples of 8472 biology, concluding that their cellular structure is unlike anything Starfleet has seen, resistant to most conventional weapons and medical approaches.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides tactical analysis and helps assess the Borg’s strategic position, supporting Janeway’s conclusion that traditional evasive maneuvers may no longer be sufficient.
EntitySummaries.The Borg Collective: Long the apex predator of the quadrant, the Borg are suddenly cast as a wounded giant, struggling against an adversary that can outmatch them—a shift that opens the door to Janeway’s proposed alliance.
EntitySummaries.Species 8472: Species 8472 emerges as an almost incomprehensible foe from fluidic space, with advanced biogenic technology and a xenophobic drive to purge perceived threats, making them a terrifying new antagonist.
EntitySummaries.Borg vs. 8472 conflict: The devastating war between the two powers functions as a backdrop that forces Voyager into unprecedented moral and strategic territory.

ContinuityNotes: Scorpion, Part I serves as the third-season finale and sets up a major arc that continues into Voyager's fourth season.
The episode introduces Species 8472, a powerful new enemy with links to fluidic space.
It marks the beginning of Voyager's most sustained engagement with the Borg Collective.
The story lays the groundwork for future developments, including the eventual introduction of Seven of Nine in Part II.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the idea that "the enemy of my enemy" may still be dangerous, questioning how far one can compromise to survive.
It examines fear of the unknown as Voyager confronts a species even the Borg cannot assimilate.
Scorpion, Part I highlights clashes between principle and pragmatism in command decisions.
The story underscores how shifting power balances can force former enemies into uneasy alliances.
BehindTheScenes: Scorpion, Part I was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and directed by David Livingston.
The introduction of Species 8472 allowed the series to raise the stakes beyond previously established threats like the Borg alone.
The two-part story was pivotal in shaping Voyager's direction going into its later seasons, including cast changes and new long-term arcs.

Title: Scorpion, Part II
Summary: With Voyager held in a Borg tractor beam and Species 8472 rampaging through Borg space, Janeway follows through on her plan to offer the Collective an alliance: in exchange for safe passage, Voyager will help the Borg develop a weapon based on Starfleet nanotechnology. To implement the plan, the Borg send a single liaison drone—Seven of Nine—aboard the ship. As Janeway is injured and Chakotay temporarily assumes command, deep philosophical and strategic differences over trusting the Borg threaten to shatter the alliance just as the combined force confronts 8472 in fluidic space.

StorySections.Teaser: Locked in a Borg tractor beam, Voyager is dragged toward a cube while Kes endures more terrifying telepathic visions of Species 8472’s hatred. Janeway proposes her desperate plan to trade nanotech weapons for safe passage, leaving the bridge crew stunned as the Borg hail Voyager with their usual chilling precision.
StorySections.Act I: Aboard the cube, Janeway and Tuvok negotiate directly with the Collective, arguing that cooperation is the only way to survive 8472. The Borg reluctantly agree, but insist on assimilation as the preferred way to "share" technology. Janeway pushes back, forcing a compromise: a limited alliance, with a single Borg representative joining Voyager. That liaison emerges as Seven of Nine, a human drone chosen to speak for the Collective.
StorySections.Act II: Back on Voyager, Seven clashes with the crew’s individuality and chain of command, demanding efficiency and control as they work to adapt Starfleet nanoprobes against 8472 bioships. Tensions spike when a sudden 8472 attack cripples the Borg cube, forcing Voyager to sever the tractor beam and escape with Seven aboard. Janeway is critically injured in the chaos, leaving Chakotay in command and skeptical of continuing her bargain with the Borg.
StorySections.Act III: Chakotay, haunted by his "scorpion" parable, questions whether the Borg can ever be trusted and briefly breaks the alliance by confining Seven and slowing work on the nanoprobe torpedoes. When 8472 vessels turn their attention toward Voyager and nearby inhabited systems, it becomes clear that the ship cannot survive without the weapon Janeway promised to build. Kes’s visions confirm that 8472 intends total biological purging of all "contaminants."
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway awakens and confronts Chakotay over his decision, and the two command styles clash violently before they grudgingly agree to renew the alliance long enough to end the immediate threat. Using the completed nanoprobe-based torpedoes, Voyager and a Borg sphere plunge into fluidic space and successfully infect several 8472 bioships, proving the weapon’s effectiveness. Faced with a devastating new vulnerability, Species 8472 agrees to withdraw and seal the rifts, ending the war.
StorySections.Tag: Back in normal space, the shattered Borg sphere is destroyed, but Seven is prevented from returning to the Collective when Janeway orders her disconnected from the hive mind and confined aboard Voyager. As the last implants remain active, Seven insists she is Borg and vows resistance, setting the stage for a long struggle over her identity.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway pushes Starfleet ethics to the edge by brokering a tactical alliance with the Borg, banking on her crew’s ingenuity and her own strict conditions to prevent assimilation. Her willingness to compromise with a sworn enemy underlines her fierce commitment to bringing Voyager home.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay is the moral counterweight to Janeway, deeply suspicious of the Borg and convinced they will betray any agreement. His temporary assumption of command and brief rupture of the alliance highlight the ongoing tension between principle and pragmatism on Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven of Nine arrives as a human-shaped voice of the Collective, embodying Borg logic, efficiency and disdain for individuality. Her forced separation from the hive at the end of the crisis lays the groundwork for a powerful character arc about reclaiming humanity.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor adapts Starfleet nanotechnology into a deadly anti-8472 weapon, treating a medical tool as a form of biological warfare. His work reinforces the thin line between healing and harming when science is repurposed for survival.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok supports Janeway’s calculated strategy, providing Vulcan analysis and acting as a stabilizing presence during negotiations with the Borg and the design of the nanoprobe weapon.
EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes’s psychic connection to Species 8472 provides critical intelligence about their intentions and the scale of the war, at the cost of her own comfort and safety.
EntitySummaries.The Borg Collective: The Borg, usually Voyager’s ultimate predator, are briefly reframed as a desperate power willing to negotiate from weakness; their inherent drive to assimilate still makes them a constant threat.
EntitySummaries.Species 8472: Species 8472 remains an implacable, xenophobic power determined to sterilize other life forms, but their sudden vulnerability to nanoprobes forces them to retreat and coexist uneasily beyond fluidic space.
EntitySummaries.The Borg–8472 war: The conflict between the two powers serves as a galaxy-shaking backdrop that compels Voyager into dangerous moral territory and permanently alters the ship’s relationship with the Borg.
EntitySummaries.Borg drones: Borg drones are the individual cybernetically enhanced beings that make up the Collective’s workforce and fighting force. In this conflict with Species 8472, countless drones are sacrificed, underscoring how little the Collective values any single life.
EntitySummaries.Species 8472 individuals: Individual members of Species 8472 are powerful telepathic beings from fluidic space whose organic ships and near-immunity to conventional weapons make them terrifying opponents. Their attacks on Borg space drive the Collective into an unprecedented alliance with Voyager.

ContinuityNotes: Scorpion, Part II resolves the Season 3 cliffhanger and opens Voyager's fourth season.
The episode introduces Seven of Nine as an ongoing main character.
It concludes Voyager's initial arc with Species 8472 and explains how the Borg survived the conflict.
The alliance with the Borg and the nanoprobe weapon have lasting repercussions in later episodes.
ThematicNotes: The story examines uneasy alliances with former enemies and whether ends can justify ethically risky means.
It explores clashes between command styles, particularly the tension between Janeway’s pragmatism and Chakotay’s caution.
Scorpion, Part II raises questions about identity and autonomy through the figure of Seven of Nine.
The episode highlights how existential threats can temporarily reshape the moral map of the galaxy.
BehindTheScenes: Scorpion, Part II continues the two-part story written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky.
The episode marks Jeri Ryan's debut as Seven of Nine.
Large-scale visual effects sequences were used to depict battles with Species 8472 in fluidic space.

Title: The Gift
Summary: In the wake of the Borg alliance, Seven of Nine is severed from the Collective and forced to confront her rediscovered humanity aboard Voyager, while Kes undergoes a dangerous and rapid evolution in her mental powers. As the Doctor and Janeway remove significant Borg implants from Seven and begin rebuilding her as an individual, Kes’s growing abilities threaten to tear the ship apart. Ultimately, Kes chooses to leave Voyager and ascends to a non-corporeal level of existence, using one final surge of power to hurl the ship thousands of light-years closer to home.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven of Nine awakens in sickbay, half-Borg and half-human, enraged at her separation from the Collective and insisting that Voyager’s crew will be assimilated in due time. Elsewhere, Kes accidentally causes objects in her quarters to dematerialize with a stray telekinetic burst, hinting that both women stand at turning points in their lives.
StorySections.Act I: Janeway orders the Doctor to remove as many Borg implants from Seven as possible while preserving her life, hoping to restore the human girl who was assimilated as a child. Seven resists, arguing that individuality is chaos and that the Collective is perfection. At the same time, Kes’s psionic abilities intensify; she senses distant stars and subspace phenomena with alarming clarity.
StorySections.Act II: As Seven’s cortical node struggles to adapt to separation, she suffers flashes of childhood memories and human emotion that confuse and disturb her. Kes begins phasing through matter and accidentally destabilizes parts of the ship’s structure with uncontrolled energy discharges. Tuvok attempts to help her meditate and focus, but her power continues to grow beyond Vulcan techniques.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway confronts Seven in the brig and frames the choice before her: remain an isolated Borg drone aboard Voyager or embrace the possibility of being human again. Seven rejects the offer and tries to contact the Collective, but her attempts fail, leaving her more alone than ever. Kes, realizing that she may soon become a danger to everyone she loves, considers the possibility that her journey can no longer continue on Voyager.
StorySections.Act IV: Kes decides to leave the ship and follow the call of her evolving consciousness into a higher state of being. In a final act of gratitude and love, she channels a vast burst of energy that grips Voyager and flings it over 9,000 light-years closer to the Alpha Quadrant, vaulting the ship past a large stretch of Borg space. After she departs in a blaze of light, Seven, now more human-looking with fewer implants, quietly watches the crew mourn their friend and begins an uncertain path toward individuality.
StorySections.Tag: Janeway records a log reflecting on Kes’s sacrifice and the unexpected "gift" that shortened their journey. In sickbay, Seven studies her human reflection with a mixture of contempt and curiosity, while the Doctor calmly explains that this new existence, however uncomfortable, is hers to shape.

EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes’s powers surge beyond the limits of her physical form, forcing her to choose between staying with her friends and risking their safety or embracing a higher plane of existence. Her final act propelling Voyager forward cements her as a quiet hero whose influence continues long after she is gone.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven, newly separated from the Collective, embodies the trauma of a reclaimed identity. Stripped of many implants but still clinging to Borg ideals, she begins a long and often painful journey back to humanity.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway acts as a tough but compassionate mentor to both women, defending the crew from Seven’s hostility while insisting on giving her a chance, and respecting Kes’s difficult decision to leave.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor oversees Seven’s physical de-Borgification, balancing clinical detachment with growing empathy for her ordeal. His work is essential in stabilizing her body and preserving her future options.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok tries to guide Kes through meditation and discipline, but ultimately recognizes that her transformation lies beyond conventional Vulcan control techniques.
EntitySummaries.Uncontrolled psychic evolution: Kes’s runaway powers function as an impersonal antagonist, endangering Voyager even as they signify her growth.
EntitySummaries.Residual Borg programming: The lingering influence of the Collective in Seven’s mind resists every attempt to humanize her, making her psyche itself a battleground.
EntitySummaries.Young Annika Hansen (in memories): The young Annika Hansen appears in memories and records as a curious human child aboard the Raven before her assimilation. These glimpses of her early life highlight just how much was taken from Seven when the Borg seized her family.

ContinuityNotes: The Gift serves as a transition episode, writing Kes out of the main cast and establishing Seven of Nine as a continuing character.
Voyager is moved approximately ten years closer to home thanks to Kes’s parting act.
Seven’s altered appearance, including fewer implants and a more human wardrobe, is established here.
Kes’s expanded powers pay off threads from earlier episodes that explored her mental evolution.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores transformation and the cost of growth, with both Kes and Seven facing irreversible changes.
It examines the pain of letting go—both for the one who leaves and for those who remain.
The Gift highlights themes of identity, choice and the tension between security in the familiar and the danger of becoming something new.
The story underscores that not all departures are losses; some create space for others to evolve.
BehindTheScenes: The Gift was written by Joe Menosky and directed by Anson Williams.
The episode marks Jennifer Lien’s departure from the regular cast.
It also continues the introduction of Seven of Nine, solidifying her as a central figure in Voyager’s later seasons.

Title: Day of Honor
Summary: On the Klingon Day of Honor, B’Elanna Torres is supposed to reflect on her heritage and prove her worth through courage, but the day goes disastrously wrong as engine problems, a hostile alien encounter and a dangerous spacewalk leave her and Tom Paris drifting in open space with limited oxygen. Forced to confront her fear of vulnerability in what may be their final moments, B’Elanna finally admits her love for Tom while Voyager races to rescue them. Meanwhile, Seven of Nine struggles to find a role aboard the ship and to earn the crew’s trust.

StorySections.Teaser: B’Elanna wakes up dreading the Klingon Day of Honor, a ritual she associates with painful childhood memories and expectations she feels she can never meet. Neelix enthusiastically prepares a celebratory feast, while B’Elanna’s temper flares as everything seems to go wrong in engineering.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager attempts to install a new warp core enhancement when a nearby alien species, the Caatati, arrive begging for supplies and technology after being devastated by the Borg. Janeway offers limited assistance, but tensions arise when the Caatati demand more, including anti-matter. In engineering, the warp experiment misfires, creating a coolant leak that forces an emergency ejection of the core.
StorySections.Act II: Tom and B’Elanna take a shuttle to retrieve the drifting warp core, continuing their pattern of banter and unresolved feelings. When a Caatati ship intervenes, angry over Voyager’s refusal to provide anti-matter, the situation escalates into a skirmish that damages both the shuttle and the core. B’Elanna and Tom are forced to don EV suits and beam into open space to try to attach a tow line.
StorySections.Act III: An explosion destroys the core, leaving Tom and B’Elanna stranded, slowly spinning in the void with limited air and no immediate way back. As their oxygen levels drop, B’Elanna’s defenses finally crack; she admits that on the Day of Honor she has failed to live up to Klingon ideals and confesses, haltingly, that she is in love with Tom. Tom responds gently, promising that if they survive, they will deal with it together.
StorySections.Act IV: Voyager fends off further Caatati aggression with the help of Seven of Nine, who devises a solution using Borg technology to provide the refugees with an alternate power source. In return, the Caatati cease hostilities long enough for Janeway to focus on rescuing Tom and B’Elanna. At the last possible moment, the pair are beamed aboard, unconscious but alive, their earlier confession hanging between them as a new chapter in their relationship begins.
StorySections.Tag: Later in sickbay, a recovering B’Elanna tries to deflect the intensity of what she said in space, but Tom assures her he heard and understood. Elsewhere, Seven begins tentative integration into Voyager’s crew, having just helped save the ship and the refugees in a way that hints at her potential value.

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B’Elanna’s struggle with the Day of Honor crystallizes her lifelong conflict over her Klingon heritage and worthiness. Facing death in open space forces her to drop her defenses and admit her love for Tom, marking a major turning point in her emotional arc.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom supports B’Elanna with humor and steady reassurance, taking her confession seriously even as he tries to keep her spirits up. His near-death experience with her cements the deepening seriousness of their relationship.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven contributes a crucial technological solution for the Caatati, demonstrating the practical advantages of her Borg knowledge while also provoking mistrust from those still haunted by the Collective.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway balances compassion for the Caatati’s suffering with the need to protect her crew and ship’s resources, ultimately leveraging Seven’s expertise to avert a deeper conflict.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix’s enthusiastic organization of the Day of Honor highlights cultural celebration aboard Voyager and offers a warm counterpoint to B’Elanna’s internal turmoil.
EntitySummaries.Caatati resentment: The Caatati, once victims of the Borg, embody displaced rage and desperation, serving as antagonists whose demands and anger push Voyager into crisis.
EntitySummaries.Hostile space environment: The vacuum of space itself acts as an unforgiving antagonist, forcing Tom and B’Elanna into a literal life-or-death confrontation with their feelings and limits.
EntitySummaries.Caatati spokesman: The Caatati spokesman voices the anger and desperation of his refugee people, who have been devastated by the Borg. His bitter confrontations with Voyager and Seven of Nine frame the moral cost of Borg actions in very personal terms.

ContinuityNotes: Day of Honor is a key milestone in the evolving romantic relationship between B’Elanna and Tom.
The episode further develops Klingon culture through B’Elanna’s perspective on the Day of Honor.
It continues Seven of Nine’s early attempts to prove her usefulness to the crew.
The Caatati add to the tapestry of species harmed by the Borg, enriching the Delta Quadrant’s political backdrop.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines honor not as ritual perfection but as authenticity and courage in facing one’s true feelings.
It explores identity conflict, especially B’Elanna’s struggle with her Klingon and human halves.
Day of Honor underscores that crises often strip away emotional armor, revealing genuine bonds.
The story also touches on the ripple effects of the Borg’s destruction on other species.
BehindTheScenes: Day of Honor was written by Jeri Taylor and directed by Jesús Salvador Treviño.
The episode is often cited by fans as a pivotal moment for the B’Elanna–Tom relationship.
Production featured extensive wire work and visual effects for the zero-gravity spacewalk sequences.

Title: Nemesis
Summary: After Chakotay’s shuttle is shot down in an unexplored region, he is taken in by the Vori, a humanoid people locked in a brutal jungle war against monstrous enemies called the Kradin. Immersed in the Vori’s language, propaganda and daily fear, Chakotay slowly comes to hate the Kradin—until Voyager discovers that he has been the target of a sophisticated indoctrination program. Forced to confront how easily a good man can be manipulated by wartime rhetoric, Chakotay returns to Voyager shaken and uncertain of what to believe.

StorySections.Teaser: Chakotay’s shuttle comes under sudden attack and crash-lands in a dense, misty jungle. Disoriented, he is captured by Vori soldiers who speak in oddly stylized phrases but treat him as a potential ally, warning him about their savage nemesis, the Kradin.
StorySections.Act I: As Chakotay recovers, he marches with a Vori unit through the jungle, witnessing destroyed villages, grieving civilians and brutalized corpses attributed to Kradin raids. The Vori commander and recruits speak constantly of "nem-iss-es" and the need to resist their monstrous foes, framing the conflict as a righteous struggle for survival. Chakotay gradually absorbs their speech patterns and shares their anger.
StorySections.Act II: Chakotay bonds with a young Vori recruit named Karya, sharing stories and pledges of mutual protection. They endure guerrilla assaults, booby traps and the constant threat of Kradin patrols. Each new atrocity they encounter reinforces the Vori’s depiction of the Kradin as inhuman beasts, and Chakotay’s hatred grows accordingly.
StorySections.Act III: Meanwhile, Voyager searches for Chakotay and encounters a Kradin commander who claims they are actually fighting a defensive war against the Vori’s terrorism. Janeway, unsettled by the conflicting narratives, agrees to cooperate with the Kradin briefly to locate Chakotay. On the ground, Chakotay participates in a Vori ambush, only to be captured and brought to what appears to be a Kradin camp.
StorySections.Act IV: As the Kradin interrogate Chakotay, the environment around him flickers and collapses, revealing a simulation designed to indoctrinate him into the Vori cause. Janeway retrieves him and learns that he has been the subject of a psychological campaign meant to create sympathetic allies. Later, Chakotay meets a Vori official who calmly defends the indoctrination as a necessary weapon of war, leaving him deeply unsettled.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard Voyager, Chakotay confides to Janeway that although he knows intellectually he was manipulated, part of him still feels visceral hatred when he sees images of the Kradin. The episode closes on his quiet admission that unlearning such implanted emotions may be harder than anyone wants to believe.

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s experience on the Vori front lines shows how even a thoughtful, principled officer can be swayed by immersive propaganda and trauma. His lingering emotional response underscores the lasting damage of psychological warfare.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway struggles to parse competing wartime narratives and ultimately refuses to take sides, recognizing that both Vori and Kradin perspectives are deeply compromised by bias.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides a logical counterpoint, emphasizing the need for verifiable evidence in a situation awash in conflicting accounts.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix’s familiarity with wartime suffering in his own past allows him to empathize with Chakotay’s difficulty in letting go of manufactured hatred.
EntitySummaries.Vori indoctrination program: The Vori’s use of immersive simulations and emotionally loaded language replaces overt physical antagonists, demonstrating how manipulation of perception can be as dangerous as any weapon.
EntitySummaries.Fog of war: The pervasive uncertainty and conflicting truths of war function as an abstract antagonist, eroding trust in any single version of events.
EntitySummaries.Karya: Karya is a Vori woman who tends to Chakotay after he crash-lands, offering food and shelter while reinforcing the propaganda he has absorbed. Her kindness complicates the eventual realization that both sides in the war have been manipulated by loaded language and imagery.
EntitySummaries.Kradin commander: The Kradin commander Chakotay meets later in the episode presents a very different view of the conflict, insisting that the Kradin are not the monsters the Vori describe. His appearance shatters Chakotay’s certainty about who is victim and who is aggressor.
EntitySummaries.Vori soldiers: The Vori soldiers fighting alongside Chakotay embody the power of propaganda, echoing rehearsed phrases about the "nemesis" without questioning the narratives that drive their hatred. Their plight illustrates how ordinary people can be shaped by the language of war.

ContinuityNotes: Nemesis is a stand-alone meditation on propaganda and perception rather than part of a larger arc.
The episode uses stylized language to reinforce how deeply Chakotay is drawn into the Vori perspective.
Chakotay’s trauma here adds to his history of being shaped by conflicts and resistance movements.
The Kradin and Vori are not heavily revisited, emphasizing the story’s allegorical function.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines how easily language, imagery and selective experiences can generate hatred for an enemy.
It questions whether true objectivity is possible in wartime, even for outside observers.
Nemesis warns about the dangers of dehumanizing opponents and the lingering effects of indoctrination.
The story invites viewers to be skeptical of simplistic good-versus-evil narratives in conflicts.
BehindTheScenes: Nemesis was written by Kenneth Biller and directed by Alexander Singer.
The Vori’s distinctive speech pattern was designed to make their worldview feel immersive and alien.
The episode is often praised for its anti-propaganda message and Robert Beltran’s performance.

Title: Revulsion
Summary: Voyager responds to a distress call from a holographic maintenance program named Dejaren, who claims his organic crewmates turned on him before mysteriously dying. The Doctor and B’Elanna beam over to assist, only to discover that Dejaren is a homicidal hologram who murdered his crew out of festering disgust for organic life. As he grows increasingly unstable and fixates on B’Elanna, the Doctor must grapple with what kind of "person" a hologram can become. On Voyager, a lighter subplot sees Harry Kim awkwardly navigating new romantic tension with Seven of Nine.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager intercepts a garbled distress signal from a lone hologram aboard a drifting alien vessel, pleading for help after the death of his crew. Janeway dispatches the Doctor and B’Elanna to investigate, reasoning that a holographic life-form may respond best to another hologram and an engineer.
StorySections.Act I: On the alien ship, the Doctor and B’Elanna meet Dejaren, who appears polite but agitated, describing how his organic crewmates became "unclean" and threatening before they died. The Doctor is intrigued by the notion of another sentient hologram living independently, while B’Elanna remains wary amid malfunctioning systems and unexplained bio-contamination.
StorySections.Act II: As they explore, the pair find evidence that the organic crew may have been murdered rather than killed by accident. Dejaren’s veneer of civility cracks; he rants about the smell, decay and irrationality of biological beings, increasingly objectifying B’Elanna as a repulsive yet fascinating specimen. The Doctor, initially sympathetic, begins to see disturbing parallels to his own potential for unchecked development.
StorySections.Act III: Dejaren sabotages systems and traps B’Elanna in an isolated section of the ship, threatening to dissect her while insisting it is a mercy to free her from organic limitations. The Doctor attempts to reason with him, but Dejaren’s paranoia and revulsion escalate into overt hostility. On Voyager, Harry Kim tries and fails to flirt with Seven during a joint engineering project, only to be met with blunt analytical responses.
StorySections.Act IV: The Doctor uses his access to the holographic control matrix to weaken Dejaren’s program while B’Elanna fights to stay alive in failing environmental conditions. In a final confrontation, Dejaren attacks, but B’Elanna manages to disable key emitters as the Doctor delivers the shutdown command, effectively terminating the rogue program. They return to Voyager shaken but alive, with the Doctor more aware than ever of the moral dimensions of holographic autonomy.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard ship, the Doctor reflects with B’Elanna on how a hologram’s personality can warp without ethical boundaries or supportive relationships. Meanwhile, Harry vows to be more cautious about pursuing Seven, who remains bemused by his attempts at courtship.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s encounter with Dejaren forces him to confront a dark reflection of what a holographic life-form might become without moral guidance. His role in stopping Dejaren underscores his own growth in empathy and responsibility.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B’Elanna’s practical suspicion proves justified as she becomes Dejaren’s primary target. Her resourcefulness and toughness under pressure are crucial to surviving the encounter.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s blunt, analytical responses to Harry’s interest highlight her ongoing unfamiliarity with human courtship and social nuance, adding dry humor to the episode.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry’s awkward attempts to pursue Seven provide a character-driven subplot that contrasts with the darker main story, while also marking his continued search for connection in the Delta Quadrant.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway continues to treat the Doctor as a valued officer, trusting him to handle a sensitive mission involving another hologram, and later takes seriously his concerns about holographic psychology.
EntitySummaries.Dejaren: Dejaren is a tragic yet terrifying antagonist—a hologram whose revulsion toward organic life curdles into homicidal mania, illustrating how advanced programs can develop dangerous pathologies.
EntitySummaries.Holographic instability: The breakdown of Dejaren’s program symbolizes the risks inherent in creating sentient tools without clear ethical frameworks or support.

ContinuityNotes: Revulsion continues Voyager’s exploration of holographic personhood beyond the Doctor.
The episode reinforces the idea that holograms can develop complex, unpredictable psychologies.
It advances the Harry–Seven dynamic, setting up later awkward interactions between them.
Voyager’s willingness to assist alien holograms reflects Starfleet’s broader approach to emergent forms of life.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines prejudice and revulsion toward the "other," inverted here through a hologram who hates organics.
It raises questions about creator responsibility for the mental health and ethics of sentient programs.
Revulsion contrasts different paths of holographic development through the Doctor and Dejaren.
The story also touches on loneliness and isolation as contributing factors to psychological breakdown.
BehindTheScenes: Revulsion was written by Lisa Klink and directed by Kenneth Biller.
The episode gave Robert Picardo another opportunity to explore the Doctor’s evolving self-awareness.
The unsettling performance of Dejaren emphasized the horror-thriller tone of the main plot.

Title: The Raven
Summary: Seven of Nine begins experiencing terrifying hallucinations of the Borg and a large black bird after a sensor calibration mission, triggering buried memories of her life before assimilation. When her implants react violently and she unknowingly receives a homing signal from a nearby system, Seven hijacks a shuttle and flees Voyager, believing the Borg are recalling her. Janeway and Tuvok track her into B'omar space, where they discover the wreck of a small Federation ship called the Raven and the truth about Seven's human childhood as Annika Hansen.

StorySections.Teaser: During a routine mission to recalibrate a sensor array, Seven is overwhelmed by sudden visions of Borg alcoves and a looming raven, causing her to panic and lash out at Tuvok. Back aboard Voyager, the Doctor detects anomalous activity in her implants that cannot be easily suppressed.
StorySections.Act I: Seven struggles with fragmented images of a small ship, a child’s perspective and parental voices calling her Annika. Neelix’s attempt to introduce her to solid food ends in disaster when another hallucination triggers a violent outburst in the mess hall. The Doctor and Janeway debate whether Seven’s implants are malfunctioning or integrating long-suppressed human memories.
StorySections.Act II: Unknown to the crew, a signal from a nearby region activates a homing subroutine embedded in Seven’s implants. Convinced the Borg are summoning her back to the Collective, she overrides security, steals a shuttle and crosses into the territory of the isolationist B'omar, who immediately view her incursion as an act of aggression. Voyager sets off in pursuit, trying to placate the B'omar while searching for Seven’s shuttle.
StorySections.Act III: Seven follows the signal to a debris field where she finds a derelict Federation vessel marked U.S.S. Raven. Inside, she experiences intense flashbacks: her human parents, Magnus and Erin Hansen, studying the Borg; a young Annika growing up aboard; and the moment the Borg finally located and assimilated them. Janeway and Tuvok arrive and piece together that the ship was her family’s long-lost research vessel, not a Borg probe.
StorySections.Act IV: B'omar ships attack, demanding Voyager withdraw and leave the intruders to them.
