Janeway orchestrates a risky extraction, using evasive maneuvers and a tractor beam to retrieve Seven and Tuvok from the Raven moments before the B'omar destroy the wreck. Back on Voyager, Seven quietly grapples with the revelation that she was once a human child with parents who made controversial choices that brought the Borg down upon them.
StorySections.Tag: In sickbay, Janeway shows Seven files on Magnus and Erin Hansen, offering her the chance to learn about the family she never knew she had. Seven listens in silence, torn between anger, grief and the first fragile stirrings of a personal history that is hers alone.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s hallucinations and flight from Voyager force her to confront the existence of a pre-Borg identity as Annika Hansen. Discovering the Raven and her parents’ research begins the long process of integrating her human past with her Borg-conditioned present.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway risks diplomatic disaster with the B'omar to recover Seven, reaffirming her commitment to helping the former drone reclaim a life beyond the Collective.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok accompanies Seven both as security and as a calm counterweight to her panic, witnessing first-hand the intensity of her resurfacing memories.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s analysis of Seven’s implants reveals how deeply her biology and cybernetics are intertwined with her trauma, underscoring the complexity of restoring her humanity.
EntitySummaries.B'omar authorities: The xenophobic B'omar act as external antagonists whose rigid territorial policies and willingness to use force complicate Voyager’s rescue mission.
EntitySummaries.Residual Borg subroutines: The homing routines in Seven’s implants function as an internal antagonist, driving her actions while blurring the line between free will and programmed compulsion.
EntitySummaries.B'omar patrol commander: The B'omar patrol commander represents a rigidly isolationist government that treats any border violation as an attack. His relentless pursuit of Seven and refusal to compromise highlight how inflexible security doctrines can escalate minor incursions into crises.
EntitySummaries.Erin Hansen: Erin Hansen is Seven of Nine’s mother, a human exobiologist who joined her husband in an unauthorized mission to study the Borg aboard the Raven. Her determination to pursue their research into deep space ultimately helps bring the Borg down on their family.
EntitySummaries.Magnus Hansen: Magnus Hansen is Seven’s father and the driving force behind the Raven’s Borg research mission. His obsession with observing the Collective firsthand leads him to override Starfleet warnings, a choice that indirectly results in his daughter’s assimilation.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: In this episode, Neelix’s attempts to introduce Seven to ordinary social rituals, like sharing a meal, accidentally trigger her traumatic responses. His well-meaning efforts underline how difficult it is for the crew to anticipate the scars left by her time in the Collective.
EntitySummaries.Young Annika Hansen: Young Annika Hansen appears in flashbacks as a bright, inquisitive child living aboard the Raven with her parents. These memories put a human face on the former drone and anchor Seven’s journey in the tragedy of a childhood interrupted.

ContinuityNotes: The Raven provides crucial backstory on Seven of Nine’s parents and her assimilation as a child.
The episode establishes the U.S.S. Raven as a Federation research vessel that had been tracking the Borg years before "Q Who?".
Seven’s visions and flashbacks further develop her struggle with post-assimilation trauma.
References to Borg space and the Hansens’ unauthorized mission tie into broader Borg continuity in the franchise.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores memory, trauma and the challenge of reclaiming a stolen childhood.
It examines the consequences of scientific obsession, as the Hansens’ pursuit of the Borg ultimately dooms their family.
The Raven highlights Seven’s liminal status between human and Borg and the difficulty of forging a coherent identity from fractured pasts.
Territorial politics with the B'omar underscore how fear of the unknown can lead to insular, hostile societies.
BehindTheScenes: The Raven was written by Bryan Fuller from a story by Fuller and Harry Doc Kloor and directed by LeVar Burton.
The episode is often cited as an essential chapter in Seven of Nine’s character development.
Flashback sequences required casting younger actors to portray Annika and her parents aboard the Raven.

Title: Scientific Method
Summary: Voyager’s crew begins suffering bizarre medical symptoms—accelerated pregnancies, painful mutations and sudden personality changes—just as Seven of Nine detects strange phase-shifted anomalies aboard the ship. The Doctor discovers that a group of cloaked aliens are using the crew as experimental subjects in a series of ruthless biomedical trials. As conditions worsen and attempts at resistance are thwarted, Janeway adopts a drastic strategy: steering Voyager directly into the deadly wake of a binary pulsar to force the aliens to break off their experiments or perish with the ship.

StorySections.Teaser: B’Elanna snaps irritably at Tom as he makes romantic advances, complaining of a mysterious headache. Moments later, she collapses with severe pain while other crew members report odd vision problems and mood swings, prompting a flurry of baffled visits to sickbay.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor struggles to find a common cause for the disparate symptoms. Chakotay’s hair turns prematurely gray overnight and he develops rapid vascular aging, while other officers exhibit unexplained physiological changes. Seven begins noticing faint spatial distortions and irregularities in ship’s power flow that do not correspond to any known malfunction.
StorySections.Act II: By using her Borg-enhanced vision, Seven perceives ghostly, phase-cloaked alien figures standing over crew members, adjusting instruments and inserting devices directly into their bodies. She and the Doctor collaborate to briefly retune her optical implants and the EMH’s holo-matrix, allowing them to interact with the intruders long enough to confirm that the aliens are running controlled experiments on pain, stress and genetic manipulation.
StorySections.Act III: Attempts to shield the crew or drive off the aliens fail; each countermeasure is swiftly countered or incorporated into new test variables. Janeway herself begins to suffer as a cluster of experimental implants is lodged near her brain, intensifying her irritability and headaches. As crew morale crumbles and conditions worsen, the Doctor warns that continued experimentation will lead to permanent damage and death.
StorySections.Act IV: Determined to force a resolution, Janeway orders Voyager on a collision course with a nearby binary pulsar system, ignoring pleas to turn away. As the ship is stretched and battered by tidal forces, the aliens panic—if Voyager is destroyed, so are their test subjects and accumulated data. Faced with annihilation, they finally withdraw, removing their implants and vanishing from the ship. Voyager fires thrusters at the last moment and narrowly escapes the pulsars’ deadly grip.
StorySections.Tag: Recovering in sickbay, Janeway muses grimly that, to the alien scientists, Voyager’s crew were nothing more than lab animals. Tom and B’Elanna share a quiet moment, their earlier tensions recast in light of the manipulations they endured, while Seven and the Doctor reflect uneasily on how close they came to remaining invisible victims forever.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway’s decision to risk the entire ship in the binary pulsar’s gravity well demonstrates her willingness to take extreme measures rather than accept her crew’s dehumanization as experimental animals.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s unique perception allows her to uncover the cloaked aliens, once again proving her Borg-derived abilities are invaluable even as she seeks to distance herself from the Collective.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor works closely with Seven to expose and oppose the experimenters, underscoring his growing role as an advocate for crew welfare beyond conventional medical practice.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s rapid aging dramatizes the physical toll of the experiments and underscores how little control the crew has over what is being done to them.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B’Elanna’s induced mood swings and pain exacerbate her fears about vulnerability, testing both her resilience and her budding relationship with Tom.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom provides emotional support to B’Elanna amid his own symptoms, illustrating how their relationship is strained and strengthened by trauma.
EntitySummaries.Cloaked experimenters: The alien scientists embody a chilling disregard for sentient rights, treating Voyager’s crew as disposable test subjects in pursuit of abstract data.
EntitySummaries.Binary pulsar system: The pulsars serve as a natural antagonist that Janeway weaponizes against the experimenters, turning a deadly phenomenon into leverage.
EntitySummaries.Cloaked alien scientists: The cloaked alien scientists conduct ruthless biomedical experiments on Voyager’s crew, treating them as laboratory animals rather than sentient beings. Their cold detachment and reliance on invisibility make them one of the series’ most unsettling examples of unethical science.

ContinuityNotes: Scientific Method continues to develop Seven’s role as a problem-solver whose Borg abilities can reveal hidden threats.
The episode further explores Janeway’s willingness to take drastic action when her crew’s autonomy is violated.
Tom and B’Elanna’s growing relationship is advanced through their shared ordeal under the aliens’ experiments.
The story contributes to Star Trek’s long tradition of critiquing unethical scientific practices.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines the ethics of experimentation and the dehumanizing view of subjects as mere data points.
It explores consent and bodily autonomy, showing how their violation can feel even more horrifying than overt violence.
Scientific Method highlights the thin line between curiosity and cruelty when research is divorced from empathy.
The story also underscores the importance of perspective: to the aliens, Voyager’s crew are lab animals; to themselves, they are people fighting for dignity.
BehindTheScenes: Scientific Method was based on a story by Sherry Klein and Harry Doc Kloor and scripted by Lisa Klink.
The episode was directed by David Livingston.
Visual effects and makeup were used extensively to depict the crew’s bizarre symptoms and the binary pulsar approach.

Title: Year of Hell, Part I
Summary: Voyager enters Krenim space and is drawn into the temporal campaigns of Annorax, a fanatical Krenim scientist commanding a massive time-weapon ship. By selectively erasing species and events from history to restore his people’s lost empire and resurrect his dead wife, Annorax repeatedly alters the timeline, each change reshaping Voyager’s circumstances. Over the course of a brutal year, the ship is battered, crew members are lost and Janeway transforms Voyager into a hardened, half-ruined vessel locked in a grim war of attrition.

StorySections.Teaser: In an otherwise ordinary sector, a colossal Krenim timeship fires a temporal beam that erases an alien colony from history, transforming the landscape below into uninhabited wilderness. Aboard the weapon, Annorax calmly updates a complex temporal calculus, searching for the perfect sequence of erasures to restore Krenim supremacy.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager meets a cordial species called the Zahl, who warn them about the weakened Krenim. A single Krenim warship attacks with ineffective weapons, easily rebuffed by Voyager. Moments later, a temporal shockwave washes over space: the Zahl are erased from history, the once-weak Krenim become dominant and Voyager suddenly finds itself outgunned. New Krenim attacks damage the ship, and Janeway learns that the shifts are the result of deliberate temporal incursions.
StorySections.Act II: Annorax takes a clinical interest in Voyager as an unpredictable variable in his equations. Subsequent incursions further rewrite reality: alliances vanish, borderlines move and Voyager’s damage mounts with each renewed assault. Casualties begin to accumulate, including secondary characters and civilians, and Janeway orders new defensive measures while refusing to abandon Federation principles.
StorySections.Act III: As months pass, Voyager becomes scarred and jury-rigged, its once-pristine corridors darkened and its crew exhausted. Key systems—including the deflector, astrometrics and parts of the sickbay—are damaged or destroyed. Tuvok is blinded, internal resources dwindle and the crew splits into rotating teams to maintain combat readiness, even as hope of quick escape fades.
StorySections.Act IV: Recognizing that conventional tactics cannot defeat a foe that can rewrite causality, Janeway begins planning a direct strike on the Krenim timeship. Meanwhile, Annorax’s first officer Obrist quietly grows disillusioned with endless temporal war as he sees no end to the suffering it creates. The episode builds to a major confrontation in which Voyager is nearly destroyed yet manages to strike a blow against one of the Krenim escorts, setting the stage for a desperate long-term campaign.
StorySections.Tag: In a weary captain’s log, Janeway marks the passage of a year since the nightmare began, vowing not to yield even as the ship bears little resemblance to the vessel that first entered Krenim space. The timeship looms as an almost mythical adversary, its next incursion ready to rewrite everything yet again.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway evolves from explorer to wartime captain, making increasingly hard choices to keep her battered crew alive without abandoning their core values, even as the universe shifts around them.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay supports Janeway but grows concerned about the long-term psychological toll on the crew, foreshadowing the moral conflicts he will face in Part II.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s injury and blindness exemplify the personal sacrifices demanded by the Krenim conflict while he continues to serve as a calm tactical advisor.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven applies her Borg knowledge to help adapt defenses and analyze temporal perturbations, becoming central to Voyager’s survival strategies.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor struggles to provide care as casualties mount and resources dwindle, highlighting the human cost of Annorax’s abstract temporal mathematics.
EntitySummaries.Annorax: Annorax is a tragic antagonist: a brilliant scientist whose grief over his erased wife drives him to commit temporal genocide in pursuit of a mathematically perfect past.
EntitySummaries.Obrist: Obrist acts as a subtle moral counterweight aboard the timeship, his growing doubts hinting that Annorax’s crusade is eroding Krenim honor.
EntitySummaries.Krenim timeship: The timeship itself is a massive antagonist, its temporal weapons giving it godlike power to reshape history and turn battles into equations.
EntitySummaries.Temporal incursions: Each incursion acts as an invisible hand rewriting the rules of the game, demonstrating the terrifying scope of temporal warfare.
EntitySummaries.Krenim commanders: The Krenim commanders of conventional warships enforce Annorax’s shifting territorial claims as the timeline keeps changing. Their presence shows that even outside the timeship, Krenim society has become militarized around the promise of a restored empire.
EntitySummaries.Zahl ambassador: The Zahl ambassador briefly represents a fragile regional balance in which the weakened Krenim have been contained. His abrupt erasure from history when Annorax alters the timeline underscores how casually whole peoples can vanish in temporal warfare.

ContinuityNotes: Year of Hell, Part I pays off earlier foreshadowing from episodes like "Before and After" that referenced a Krenim conflict.
The episode presents one of Voyager’s darkest alternate timelines, though its events are eventually reset.
Changes to Voyager’s structure, crew and technology are depicted in detail, emphasizing long-term attrition.
Annorax’s time-weapon concept ties into Star Trek’s broader explorations of temporal manipulation.
ThematicNotes: The story examines grief, obsession and the dangers of trying to perfect history through force.
It explores how war transforms people and institutions, turning explorers into hardened survivors.
Year of Hell critiques utilitarian justifications for mass suffering framed as mathematical necessity.
The episode raises questions about identity when history itself becomes malleable: what remains constant when the past keeps changing?
BehindTheScenes: Year of Hell, Part I was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and directed by Allan Kroeker.
The two-part story is frequently ranked among Voyager’s best and was originally conceived as a longer arc.
Extensive makeup and set redressing were used to depict Voyager’s progressive damage over the fictional year.

Title: Year of Hell, Part II
Summary: As the temporal war grinds on, Voyager is reduced to a skeletal crew in a shattered hull, while Chakotay and Paris find themselves aboard Annorax’s timeship, each reacting differently to the Krenim leader’s grand design. Janeway refuses to abandon her ship, committing to a final, potentially suicidal plan to ram the timeship and reset the timeline. With Obrist’s help and Chakotay’s change of heart, the remnants of Voyager and allies orchestrate a last strike that erases the entire "year of hell" from existence.

StorySections.Teaser: A heavily damaged Voyager limps through space on minimal power, much of the crew evacuated and key sections sealed off. Janeway, scarred and exhausted, records a log noting that they are down to a skeleton complement but still searching for a way to stop the Krenim timeship.
StorySections.Act I: Chakotay and Paris, having been captured in the previous assaults, live aboard Annorax’s vessel. Chakotay is initially fascinated by the temporal calculations and entertains the possibility that Annorax might be reasoned with, while Paris remains openly hostile, appalled by the casual erasure of entire civilizations. Annorax shares his backstory, insisting that one more set of adjustments will restore his lost wife and empire.
StorySections.Act II: Voyager forms an alliance with a small coalition of races harmed by the Krenim incursions. Seven and Tuvok devise a way to disrupt the timeship’s temporal shields, but the plan will require precise coordination and a willing inside accomplice. Obrist secretly contacts Janeway’s allies, revealing his growing disillusionment and offering to sabotage the timeship from within.
StorySections.Act III: Chakotay gradually realizes that Annorax’s quest is endless; each temporal adjustment spawns new unforeseen variables, moving the Krenim further from their original timeline. When Annorax proposes erasing Voyager itself as a troublesome anomaly, Chakotay, spurred by Paris’s warnings, finally rejects the scientist’s logic and throws his support behind Obrist’s sabotage plan.
StorySections.Act IV: As Obrist disrupts the temporal core and drops the timeship’s shields, Voyager and allied vessels launch a coordinated attack despite their inferior firepower. Severely outgunned and with systems failing, Janeway orders the remaining crew to abandon ship while she stays behind. In a final, defiant act, she rams Voyager directly into the Krenim timeship’s temporal core, triggering a massive feedback that erases the weapon from history and restores the original timeline.
StorySections.Tag: Time resets to Voyager’s first passage through Krenim space, with the ship pristine and the crew unaware of the year of suffering they narrowly avoided. A routine encounter with a small Krenim patrol ends uneventfully as Janeway simply adjusts course, while Annorax, now a quiet civilian, enjoys a peaceful day with his wife, never having built the timeship.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway embodies defiance and sacrifice, choosing to go down with a ruined Voyager in order to end the temporal threat and restore a more just timeline, even if no one will remember her choice.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s arc from intrigued collaborator to active saboteur illustrates how seductively rationalized atrocities can appear until their human cost becomes undeniable.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris remains a moral anchor aboard the timeship, refusing to excuse Annorax’s actions and pushing Chakotay to recognize the insanity of endless temporal revisions.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s technical expertise is crucial in devising a method to breach the timeship’s defenses, reaffirming her value as Voyager’s de facto systems strategist.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok coordinates the alliance’s attacks and maintains discipline aboard the beleaguered Voyager, exemplifying Vulcan resolve even at the apparent end.
EntitySummaries.Annorax: Annorax’s downfall comes from his inability to accept that some losses cannot be undone; his obsession collapses along with the timeship and is quietly erased from history.
EntitySummaries.Obrist: Obrist’s decision to betray Annorax provides the necessary opening for Janeway’s final strike, showing that conscience can emerge even within a deeply compromised system.
EntitySummaries.Krenim timeship: The destruction of the timeship symbolizes the rejection of absolute control over history and the restoration of natural temporal flow.
EntitySummaries.Temporal warfare: The erasure of the entire "year of hell" critiques the temptation to treat time as a battlefield and underscores the moral hazards of rewriting reality.
EntitySummaries.Allied alien captains: The allied alien captains join forces with Voyager after their own peoples suffer under Krenim temporal incursions. Their willingness to fight alongside a battered Starfleet ship illustrates how shared oppression can forge unlikely coalitions.

ContinuityNotes: Year of Hell, Part II completes one of Voyager’s most ambitious time travel narratives.
Despite the reset ending, character beats—particularly Janeway’s willingness to sacrifice everything—resonate with viewers as an exploration of her core nature.
The Krenim and their timeship are not revisited in depth, enhancing the story’s self-contained, almost mythic quality.
Elements of the "Year of Hell" concept were originally considered as a longer-season arc before being condensed into a two-parter.
ThematicNotes: The episode interrogates the desire to erase pain through retroactive change, arguing that such attempts can cause greater harm.
It emphasizes sacrifice and leadership, showcasing Janeway’s readiness to pay the ultimate price for her crew and the timeline.
Year of Hell, Part II highlights the futility of perfectionism applied to history and relationships.
The reset ending underscores the paradox that some of the most meaningful struggles may go unremembered, yet still matter.
BehindTheScenes: Year of Hell, Part II was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and directed by Mike Vejar.
The two-part story has often been cited by critics and fans as a high point of Star Trek: Voyager.
Model work and visual effects for the ruined Voyager and the timeship were among the most elaborate in the series.

Title: Random Thoughts
Summary: When Voyager visits the peaceful telepathic Mari homeworld, B’Elanna Torres experiences a fleeting moment of anger after being jostled in the marketplace. Soon after, the same man who bumped her savagely assaults another citizen and the Mari authorities blame B’Elanna’s violent thought for triggering the act. Under a legal system that criminalizes "provocative" ideas, B’Elanna faces invasive mental reconditioning, and Tuvok must uncover a black market in illicit violent imagery to clear her name.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager orbits the Mari homeworld as the crew enjoys shore leave among a society that proudly claims to have abolished violence through strict mental discipline. While negotiating for a resonator coil in a crowded market, B’Elanna is bumped by a passerby and briefly imagines punching him before dismissing the thought.
StorySections.Act I: Moments later, the same man erupts into a brutal attack on another Mari citizen, shocking B’Elanna and Janeway. Mari security chief Nimira investigates and, through telepathic analysis, traces the origin of the violent impulse back to B’Elanna’s momentary fantasy. B’Elanna is arrested and informed that her thought violated Mari law against broadcast aggression.
StorySections.Act II: Janeway protests that punishing private thoughts violates Federation concepts of civil rights, but Nimira insists that the Mari’s strict control of violent imagery has kept their society peaceful for generations. B’Elanna faces a procedure called "enforcement" that will scrub her mind of aggressive impulses, potentially altering her personality. Tuvok begins his own investigation, seeking logical inconsistencies in the case.
StorySections.Act III: Tuvok discovers an underground trade in violent thoughts and imagery, curated by a Mari named Guill who profits from exposing bored citizens to forbidden aggression. Guill has been amplifying and distributing stray violent impressions—like B’Elanna’s angry moment—for recreational consumption, increasing the risk of outbursts. Working with Nimira, Tuvok goes undercover and participates in a mind-meld to track the flow of illicit thoughts.
StorySections.Act IV: The mind-meld nearly overwhelms Tuvok with a barrage of brutal images, but he perseveres and gathers enough evidence to expose Guill’s operation. Confronted with proof that B’Elanna’s thought was exploited and magnified by an illegal network, Nimira agrees to drop the charges and cancel the enforcement, though she remains committed to Mari laws governing mental content. Voyager departs, leaving the Mari to confront the contradictions in a society that must criminalize thoughts to preserve outward peace.
StorySections.Tag: Back on the ship, B’Elanna reflects uneasily on how one angry impulse nearly cost her autonomy, while Tuvok contemplates the lingering impact of the violent images he absorbed. Janeway notes that the visit has reminded them that even the noblest goals can lead to troubling methods when fear shapes the law.

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B’Elanna’s quick temper and vivid inner life place her at the center of a legal system that punishes thoughts, forcing her to confront how much of her identity is bound up in the emotions the Mari want to erase.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok applies Vulcan discipline to navigate a minefield of weaponized thoughts, ultimately risking his sanity in a mind-meld to expose the true source of the violence.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway’s negotiations with Nimira highlight sharp differences between Federation values and Mari law, underscoring her role as defender of her crew’s rights.
EntitySummaries.Nimira: Nimira embodies the Mari belief that censoring violent ideas is necessary for peace, yet she is forced to acknowledge that her society’s system can be exploited and misdirected.
EntitySummaries.Guill: Guill profits from trafficking in forbidden thoughts, illustrating that attempts to suppress certain impulses can create underground markets that are even more dangerous.
EntitySummaries.Mari censorship laws: The legal framework that criminalizes violent thoughts functions as an abstract antagonist, pitting collective safety against individual liberty.
EntitySummaries.Guill's thought black market: The illicit network of shared violent imagery shows that repression can drive dangerous desires into the shadows rather than eliminating them.
EntitySummaries.Mari citizens: The Mari citizens pride themselves on having eliminated violence from their society, but rely on intrusive mental laws to maintain that peace. Their shocked reactions to the marketplace assault reveal how fragile their supposed utopia really is.
EntitySummaries.Talli: Talli is a friendly Mari who initially guides B'Elanna through the marketplace and seems to embody the world’s harmony. Her involvement in the investigation shows how ordinary people can become entangled in systems that criminalize even fleeting thoughts.

ContinuityNotes: Random Thoughts continues Voyager’s exploration of telepathic cultures and the ethical complexities of mind control.
The episode offers further insight into B’Elanna’s temper and self-image, deepening her ongoing character arc.
Tuvok’s mind-meld is used here as an investigative tool with real psychological risks.
The Mari and their legal system provide an allegorical lens on contemporary debates over censorship and harmful content.
ThematicNotes: The story examines the tension between public safety and freedom of thought.
It questions whether a society can truly eradicate violence by policing imagination rather than addressing underlying causes.
Random Thoughts highlights how fear of dangerous ideas can lead to overreaching laws that endanger civil liberties.
The episode also explores the persistence of darker impulses and the ethics of controlling them through external force.
BehindTheScenes: Random Thoughts was written by Kenneth Biller and directed by Alexander Singer.
The episode’s focus on censorship and thought-crime has been noted as particularly topical and allegorical.
Guest performances, especially Gwynyth Walsh as Nimira, were praised for adding depth to the Mari society.

Title: Concerning Flight
Summary: When raiders strip Voyager of key technology, including the main computer processor and the Doctor’s mobile emitter, Janeway tracks the stolen equipment to a bustling alien trade world where her holographic Leonardo da Vinci program has been living independently under the patronage of an arms dealer named Tau.

StorySections.Teaser: Janeway tests a glider with Leonardo da Vinci on the holodeck, but their flight is cut short when Voyager is attacked and vital systems begin vanishing in brilliant transporter beams.
StorySections.Act I: The crew discovers that the main computer core and other components have been stolen, and they trace the theft to a nearby planet filled with scavenged technology from dozens of worlds. Janeway and Tuvok beam down in disguise and are shocked to find Leonardo roaming the streets, convinced he has been carried to a marvelous new land by pirates.
StorySections.Act II: Leonardo proudly shows Janeway his workshop and his patron, Tau, who traffics in stolen hardware. Posing as a wealthy buyer, Janeway attends a reception where Tau displays Voyager’s computer core for sale, while Tuvok and Seven work to locate the shielded storage site that hides it from transporters.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway enlists Leonardo’s help to reach the facility and "improve" the strange devices inside, giving her access to the processor. Tau overhears her contacting Voyager and turns a weapon on her, but Leonardo unexpectedly knocks him out, allowing Janeway to overload the core’s power systems to create a transporter lock.
StorySections.Act IV: With Tau’s guards in pursuit, Janeway and Leonardo flee into the hills and launch in a fixed-wing glider he has constructed, finally achieving the flight he always dreamed of as Voyager maneuvers close enough to beam up the recovered processor and the two fugitives.
StorySections.Tag: Back in his recreated workshop, Leonardo struggles to grasp Janeway’s explanation that he is a creation of light and mathematics, but he accepts that there are realms of knowledge beyond him and resolves to keep designing wonders for this strange future world.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway treats Leonardo as both mentor and student, guiding him through the reality of the 24th century while risking herself to reclaim Voyager’s stolen systems.
EntitySummaries.Leonardo da Vinci: The holographic Leonardo revels in what he believes is a new continent, interpreting starship technology through Renaissance eyes until Janeway reveals his true nature.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides tactical support on the surface and from orbit, analyzing the theft as a security problem even as Janeway pursues a more personal solution.
EntitySummaries.Tau: Tau is a calculating arms dealer who profits from stolen technology and sees Voyager’s computer core as just another lucrative commodity.
EntitySummaries.Alien merchants: The alien merchants crowding the trade world live by scavenging and reselling advanced hardware with little concern for origin or ethics. Their stalls full of mixed technologies show how powerful Federation components can be reduced to just another commodity far from home.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay manages Voyager’s limited resources while Janeway operates on the surface, coordinating the recovery mission and keeping the ship functional without its primary computer core. His steady leadership ensures that Janeway’s risky gambit has support from orbit.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven lends her expertise to locating the shielded storage site that contains Voyager’s processor, applying Borg-honed analytical skills to a world of black-market trickery. Her work helps make Janeway’s daring retrieval plan possible.
EntitySummaries.Technology raiders: The technology raiders who initially strike Voyager specialize in hit-and-run thefts that strip valuable systems without destroying their targets. They exemplify the opportunism of the Delta Quadrant, where even a starship’s core functions can be stolen in seconds.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is left without his mobile emitter after the raid, abruptly confined once more to sickbay. His loss of newfound autonomy underscores how precarious his status as more than just a program still is.

ContinuityNotes: Leonardo da Vinci previously appeared as Janeway’s holodeck mentor in the Borg two-parter "Scorpion."
The theft of the Doctor’s mobile emitter underlines the unique value of this 29th-century device onboard Voyager.
The episode adds to Voyager’s pattern of encountering scavengers and traders dealing in salvaged starship hardware.
ThematicNotes: The story contrasts Renaissance wonder with futuristic pragmatism, asking how genius adapts to a world beyond its original context.
It explores mentorship in both directions, with Janeway and Leonardo each challenging the other’s assumptions.
The episode raises ethical questions about the black-market trade in advanced technology.
BehindTheScenes: Concerning Flight was written by Joe Menosky from a story by Jimmy Diggs and Menosky and directed by Jesús Salvador Treviño.
John Rhys-Davies reprises his role as Leonardo da Vinci, returning after his appearance in "Scorpion, Part I."
Location work and a practical glider prop were used to realize Leonardo’s flying machine sequence.

Title: Mortal Coil
Summary: Neelix is killed during a shuttle mission to collect protomatter from a nebula, then revived nearly a day later when the Doctor uses Borg nanoprobes at Seven’s suggestion, and his brief death shatters his lifelong Talaxian faith and sends him into a profound crisis of meaning.

StorySections.Teaser: Neelix eagerly prepares for a shuttle trip into a protomatter nebula, hoping to demonstrate his usefulness, but an unexpected energy discharge strikes the craft and kills him instantly, leaving Chakotay and Paris to return his body to Voyager.
StorySections.Act I: The crew gathers in sickbay as the Doctor solemnly declares that Neelix has been dead for many hours. Seven proposes an experimental procedure using reprogrammed Borg nanoprobes to repair the cellular damage, and against all odds Neelix suddenly gasps back to life, surrounded by relieved friends who celebrate what they see as a miracle.
StorySections.Act II: Privately, Neelix is unsettled that he experienced no afterlife, no Great Forest or departed family, despite everything his people believe. The more others speak of second chances, the more hollow his stories sound to him, and he confides to Chakotay and Janeway that he feels he has been spreading comforting lies.
StorySections.Act III: Chakotay guides Neelix through a vision quest, hoping a spiritual encounter will help him reconcile faith and reality, but Neelix’s visions turn dark as his sister Alixia crumbles to dust and distorted versions of his shipmates insist that life is meaningless. He emerges convinced that his beliefs were illusions and that his existence no longer has purpose.
StorySections.Act IV: Despairing, Neelix plans to end his life by transporting himself into the nebula, but on his way to the transporter room he meets Samantha Wildman, who explains that Naomi is frightened and only Neelix can comfort her. Realizing that this child needs him, Neelix abandons his plan and instead visits Naomi, telling her gently that he has chased away the monster she fears.
StorySections.Tag: Later, Neelix tells Chakotay that his doubts remain but he no longer sees them as a reason to die, choosing instead to live for the people who depend on him even if he never again believes exactly as he once did.

EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix’s death and resurrection destroy his certainty about the afterlife and nearly drive him to suicide before he rediscovers purpose in the everyday lives he touches.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s idea to use Borg nanoprobes saves Neelix’s life, illustrating how Borg technology can repair a body even as it leaves deeper spiritual wounds untouched.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor wrestles with the medical and ethical consequences of reviving a patient who then struggles to cope with the experience.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay offers Neelix a path of inner exploration through a vision quest rather than prescribing what he should believe.
EntitySummaries.Naomi Wildman: Naomi’s simple fear and trust in Neelix remind him that meaning can be found in being there for others, even when cosmic answers are unclear.
EntitySummaries.Alixia: Alixia, Neelix’s beloved sister, appears in his vision quest as both comfort and torment, embodying the family he expected to see in the Great Forest after death. When she turns on him and crumbles to dust, she personifies the collapse of the religious certainty he has carried for years.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway offers Neelix practical compassion, making it clear that he is valued for who he is rather than for any particular belief. She cannot repair his faith, but she quietly insists that his life still matters to the Voyager family.
EntitySummaries.Neelix's despair: Neelix’s despair functions as an internal antagonist, convincing him that his life and past beliefs are meaningless after his near-death experience. Left unchecked, it nearly drives him to suicide before he reconnects with his responsibilities to others.
EntitySummaries.Protomatter nebula discharge: The protomatter nebula discharge that kills Neelix is a violent reminder of the unpredictable dangers of space exploration. It serves as the catalyst for his resurrection and subsequent crisis of faith.
EntitySummaries.Samantha Wildman: Samantha Wildman’s trust in Neelix as a caregiver becomes a lifeline when she turns to him for help with Naomi. Her simple request cuts through his despair and reminds him that he still has a role only he can fill.

ContinuityNotes: The episode delves into Neelix’s Talaxian beliefs, expanding on earlier references to his culture and family.
Borg nanoprobes continue to be used as versatile medical tools following their introduction in prior Borg storylines.
Naomi Wildman’s relationship with Neelix is strengthened, reinforcing his role as a surrogate uncle.
ThematicNotes: Mortal Coil confronts grief, resurrection and the loss of religious certainty in a direct, character-focused way.
It suggests that faith may change or fail while the need for connection and responsibility endures.
The story addresses suicidal ideation with unusual frankness for the series, emphasizing how relationships can counter despair.
BehindTheScenes: Mortal Coil was written by Bryan Fuller and directed by Allan Kroeker.
Ethan Phillips has cited this as one of his favorite Neelix episodes due to its emotional depth.
The title alludes to Shakespeare’s phrase "mortal coil" from Hamlet, underscoring the focus on life and death.

Title: Waking Moments
Summary: Voyager’s crew begins suffering vivid nightmares that all feature the same silent alien, and when several officers slip into a hyper-REM state and cannot be awakened, Chakotay must use lucid dreaming techniques to confront a species that lives primarily in the dream realm and is holding the ship hostage with a planetary neurogenic field.

StorySections.Teaser: Tom Paris dreams that he walks onto the bridge in his underwear to the crew’s amusement, but the scene turns sinister when a strange alien appears and stares at him without speaking, a figure that will soon haunt others as well.
StorySections.Act I: Janeway and Chakotay compare notes and realize that multiple officers have had nightmares ending with the same alien visitor. Harry Kim fails to report for duty, and the Doctor finds him locked in a state of hyper-REM sleep that resists all attempts to rouse him, soon joined by other affected crewmembers.
StorySections.Act II: Chakotay explains his training in lucid dreaming and proposes entering the dream deliberately to confront the intruder. Using the image of Earth’s moon as a trigger, he hunts an illusory deer through Voyager’s corridors, recognizes the dream and seizes control just as the alien appears, demanding answers.
StorySections.Act III: The alien claims that his people live in dreams and are simply defending their territory, but when the crew fails to awaken after following his instructions, Chakotay realizes they have been lured deeper into a region saturated with neurogenic energy. Soon most of the crew are unconscious and trapped together in a warped dream version of the ship.
StorySections.Act IV: With chemical help from the Doctor, Chakotay forces himself awake in sickbay and resists sleep long enough to locate the planet generating the field. He beams into a cavern full of slumbering aliens and threatens to have Voyager destroy the chamber unless they free the crew, a warning he repeats inside the dream when exhaustion drags him back under until the aliens finally relent.
StorySections.Tag: The crew slowly return to normal routines, joking about pulling extra duty after their enforced "nap," while Chakotay quietly reflects on the strange borderland between waking and dreaming that Voyager has just crossed.

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay turns his spiritual and mental discipline into a tactical tool, fighting for the crew on the internal battlefield of the dreamscape.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway authorizes an unconventional plan when conventional tactics fail, trusting Chakotay to navigate a threat that cannot be fought with phasers.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry’s early slide into unending sleep personalizes the danger and raises the stakes for finding a solution.
EntitySummaries.Dream-dwelling alien species: The dream-based aliens redefine territorial space in terms of consciousness rather than physical borders, making ordinary sleep a potential hazard.
EntitySummaries.Neurogenic field: The planetary field weaponizes the crew’s need for rest, turning sleep itself into a trap.
EntitySummaries.Affected crewmembers: The many affected crewmembers trapped in hyper-REM sleep show that the dream attack is not limited to the senior staff. Their helplessness raises the stakes for Chakotay’s mission into the dreamscape, as the entire ship’s survival hangs in the balance.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna’s own unsettling dreams reveal that even a strong-willed engineer is vulnerable when her mind is invaded. Her presence in the shared nightmare emphasizes how deeply the alien intrusion has penetrated Voyager’s community.
EntitySummaries.Dream alien: The dream alien who appears at the end of multiple nightmares is the most visible representative of a species that lives primarily in a shared dream state. His eerie silence and shifting claims about territory make him an ambiguous mix of victim and aggressor.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor monitors the crew’s deteriorating condition and provides Chakotay with the stimulants needed to operate on the knife-edge between waking and sleep. His medical support makes it possible for Chakotay to act in both realms long enough to save the ship.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s embarrassing bridge nightmare is played for humor but also illustrates how the aliens hijack ordinary anxieties to gain a foothold. As the crisis deepens, his experience becomes one more clue that the crew’s dreams are not entirely their own.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s disturbing dream of losing emotional control shows that even a disciplined Vulcan mind can be unsettled by invasive psychic forces. His vulnerability underscores the severity of the threat.

ContinuityNotes: The episode continues Voyager’s tradition of exploring non-humanoid and non-physical forms of life.
Chakotay’s lucid dreaming builds on earlier stories involving his vision quests and spiritual practices.
The shared dream imagery makes heavy use of familiar sets altered just enough to feel unsettling.
ThematicNotes: Waking Moments examines the boundary between reality and dream and what it means to be attacked in the realm of the mind.
It highlights the power of self-awareness and discipline as forms of resistance against psychological threats.
The story suggests that even very alien forms of life may have understandable motives once their nature is grasped.
BehindTheScenes: Waking Moments was written by André Bormanis and directed by Alexander Singer.
The production relies on subtle lighting and camera changes to distinguish dream sequences from waking scenes.
The episode is often remembered for its eerie nightmare imagery and focus on Chakotay.

Title: Message in a Bottle
Summary: When Seven of Nine detects a vast, ancient communications relay network stretching from the Delta Quadrant to the Alpha Quadrant, Voyager seizes the chance to contact Starfleet by transmitting the Doctor’s program to an advanced Federation warship, the U.S.S. Prometheus, where he and an EMH Mark II must outwit Romulan hijackers to send word of Voyager’s survival home.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven discovers faint but regular transmissions crossing enormous distances, revealing an alien relay network that appears to bridge the gap between quadrants and offering Voyager its first real hope of reaching Starfleet.
StorySections.Act I: Tests show that the network cannot sustain a live two-way conversation but might carry a compressed holographic program, prompting Janeway to send the Doctor as a data stream. He dematerializes from sickbay and rematerializes aboard a strange Federation vessel under attack.
StorySections.Act II: The Doctor learns he is on the U.S.S. Prometheus, an experimental multi-vector assault ship whose crew have been killed or captured. Romulans control the bridge and are trying to pilot the unfamiliar vessel home, so the Doctor activates the ship’s EMH Mark II, who initially dismisses his story and treats Voyager’s plight as an oddity.
StorySections.Act III: Forced to cooperate, the two holograms sabotage the Romulans’ control of the ship, lock out key systems and experiment with the Prometheus’s ability to split into multiple sections, using Starfleet procedures in unorthodox ways. Their clashing personalities underscore how far Voyager’s Doctor has evolved beyond his original parameters.
StorySections.Act IV: As Starfleet vessels converge on the rogue Prometheus, the Doctors trigger internal countermeasures that incapacitate the Romulans and restore control just in time. They convince the approaching ships and Starfleet Command of their identities and finally deliver a clear report that Voyager is stranded in the Delta Quadrant but still operational.
StorySections.Tag: Transmitted back through the relay, the Doctor returns to Voyager with the news that Starfleet has received their "message in a bottle" and now knows they are alive, giving the crew a powerful morale boost despite the vast distance that still separates them from home.

Antagonists: Voyager's isolation in the Delta Quadrant

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor becomes both action hero and ambassador, retaking the Prometheus and finally establishing direct contact between Voyager and Starfleet.
EntitySummaries.EMH Mark II: The Prometheus’s EMH Mark II starts as a smug, by-the-book program but learns from Voyager’s Doctor that adaptability is as important as protocol.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s discovery and analysis of the relay network make the entire mission possible and reinforce her value as Voyager’s systems specialist.
EntitySummaries.Romulan hijackers: The Romulans use the chaos aboard the Prometheus to seize an advanced Federation weapon, turning Voyager’s attempt at communication into a tactical crisis.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry Kim helps Seven analyze the alien relay network and works to stabilize the fragile connection to the Alpha Quadrant. His technical efforts on Voyager’s end complement the Doctor’s improvisation aboard the Prometheus.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway authorizes the risky decision to transmit the Doctor’s program, temporarily depriving Voyager of its chief medical officer for the chance to contact Starfleet. Her choice reflects both tactical calculation and a deep desire to let home know they are alive.
EntitySummaries.Romulan boarding party: The Romulan boarding party seizes the Prometheus and attempts to steal it, turning Voyager’s hopeful communication attempt into a security crisis. Their ignorance of the ship’s advanced systems gives the two EMHs a crucial advantage.
EntitySummaries.Starfleet admiral: The Starfleet admiral who speaks with the Doctor becomes Voyager’s first confirmed link to home, reacting with shock and concern at news of the ship’s fate. His acknowledgment that Starfleet will respond gives Voyager renewed hope.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom Paris participates in planning the relay experiment and later reacts with relief when the Doctor returns with news from home. His excitement mirrors that of many crewmembers who have long wondered whether Starfleet even knows they are alive.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok offers tactical input on how to exploit the relay network without exposing Voyager to undue risk. His caution balances the crew’s eagerness to seize any chance at communication.
EntitySummaries.Voyager's isolation in the Delta Quadran: Voyager’s isolation in the Delta Quadrant is the long-standing circumstance that has cut the crew off from Starfleet, friends and family. In this episode, that isolation is briefly pierced, showing how heavy a burden it has been on everyone aboard.

ContinuityNotes: Message in a Bottle marks the first time Voyager makes direct, real-time contact with Starfleet Command after being stranded.
The U.S.S. Prometheus introduces multi-vector assault mode, a technology later referenced in other Star Trek media.
The alien relay network will be revisited in "Hunters" as part of the Hirogen story arc.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the emotional and strategic impact of finally being able to tell loved ones and superiors that Voyager is alive.
It contrasts rigid programming with creative problem-solving through the interplay between the two EMHs.
The story shows that reaching out across vast distances can bring both danger and hope.
BehindTheScenes: Message in a Bottle was written by Lisa Klink from a story by Rick Williams and directed by Nancy Malone.
Andy Dick guest stars as the EMH Mark II, playing off Robert Picardo’s established portrayal of the original Doctor.
The episode is frequently ranked among Voyager’s best for its mix of humor, action and franchise-significant developments.

Title: Hunters
Summary: Using the alien relay network first accessed in "Message in a Bottle," Voyager begins receiving long-delayed letters from Starfleet and family, even as the ship is drawn into Hirogen-controlled space and Tuvok and Seven are captured by towering hunters who regard all other species as prey.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven reestablishes a link to the relay network, and a flood of encoded messages begins arriving from the Alpha Quadrant, revealing that Starfleet has been trying to reach Voyager for some time.
StorySections.Act I: Neelix becomes an enthusiastic "postmaster," hand-delivering letters and witnessing reactions that range from joy to devastation as crew members learn of wars, deaths, promotions and lost opportunities back home. The emotional temperature aboard ship rises sharply.
StorySections.Act II: Sensor analysis shows that one of the relay stations ahead is damaged and throttling the data flow. Janeway chooses to approach it, even though the network lies in territory claimed by a species known as the Hirogen, in the hope of salvaging more messages before the fragile link collapses.
StorySections.Act III: Tuvok and Seven take a shuttle to the relay to attempt repairs, but a Hirogen vessel arrives and boards the station. The towering hunters quickly overpower them, treating the captives as prizes and speaking clinically about their anatomy and potential for sport.
StorySections.Act IV: Refusing to abandon her officers, Janeway uses the station’s quantum singularity power source against the Hirogen by triggering an antithoron burst that destabilizes the relay. The resulting energy surge disables the Hirogen ship long enough for Voyager to beam Tuvok and Seven to safety, but the station and much of the network are destroyed in the process.
StorySections.Tag: In the quiet aftermath, the crew reflect on the messages they received and the countless ones now lost, while Janeway and Chakotay acknowledge that the connection to home, however brief, has renewed their determination even as they brace for future clashes with the relentless Hirogen.

GuestCharacters: Starfleet correspondents and family members (in messages)

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway weighs the risk of provoking the Hirogen against the value of more news from home and ultimately chooses to endanger the ship to rescue her captured officers.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok endures Hirogen captivity with Vulcan composure, analyzing their hunting culture even as he is treated as prey.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s technical skill both enables the message link and draws Voyager into conflict with the Hirogen, personalizing the threat when she is captured.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: As postmaster, Neelix sees firsthand how hope and pain arrive together in the crew’s mailbags, deepening his understanding of their ties to the Alpha Quadrant.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen hunters: The Hirogen are introduced as nomadic hunters who define themselves by the pursuit and display of trophies, seeing other species primarily as quarry.
EntitySummaries.Hazards of the relay network: The unstable, singularity-powered relays serve as both a lifeline to home and a dangerous structure that may have to be sacrificed in battle.
EntitySummaries.Alpha Hirogen: The Alpha Hirogen is the dominant leader of the hunting pair that captures Tuvok and Seven, viewing them purely as challenging prey. His conversations reveal a culture that defines honor and identity through the pursuit and display of trophies.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna’s reaction to news from home—especially regarding the Maquis and her past—shows how the incoming letters reopen old conflicts in her sense of identity. Her mixed emotions reflect the double-edged nature of long-delayed contact.
EntitySummaries.Beta Hirogen: The Beta Hirogen serves as the Alpha’s subordinate, eager to prove himself worthy in the hunt. His deference and brutality illustrate how the Hirogen hierarchy reinforces their violent traditions.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay confronts painful updates about the Maquis, learning that many former comrades have died while he has been stranded far away. The letters force him to revisit politics and loyalties he has tried to set aside on Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry Kim’s letters underscore how much time and change he has missed in the Alpha Quadrant, from family milestones to the larger Dominion War. His responses capture both the comfort and the ache that come with delayed news.
EntitySummaries.Starfleet correspondents and family memb: The Starfleet correspondents and family members whose messages arrive through the relay network give the crew long-sought answers about events at home. Their words carry promotions, condolences, and fragments of the Dominion War, reconnecting Voyager to the larger Federation story.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom Paris’s mail from home touches on his complicated past and the life he left behind when he joined Voyager. His reactions, especially in scenes with B'Elanna, show how the crew tries to integrate news from home into lives that have moved on without it.

ContinuityNotes: Hunters continues the relay network plotline from "Message in a Bottle."
The episode formally introduces the Hirogen, who will recur as major antagonists in subsequent stories.
Letters from Starfleet provide updates on the Dominion War and establish how much time has passed since Voyager vanished.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how news from home can reopen wounds even as it offers comfort and connection.
It contrasts the Hirogen’s trophy-based culture with Starfleet ideals regarding the value of sentient life.
Hunters underscores the cost of maintaining communication over vast distances, sometimes measured in destroyed infrastructure and new enemies.
BehindTheScenes: Hunters was written by Jeri Taylor and directed by David Livingston.
The story begins a multi-episode Hirogen arc, expanding Voyager’s roster of recurring Delta Quadrant foes.
Extensive prosthetics and costuming were used to realize the imposing Hirogen hunters.

Title: Prey
Summary: Voyager rescues a critically injured Hirogen hunter whose elusive quarry—a lone member of Species 8472—has boarded the ship, forcing Janeway into an uneasy stand-off with the Hirogen while Seven of Nine pushes for a more ruthless solution.

StorySections.Teaser: A damaged Hirogen warship drifts in space, its lone surviving hunter beamed to Voyager in critical condition while his unidentified "prey" escapes into a nearby debris field.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor stabilizes the hunter, who demands to be allowed to resume his chase, while sensors detect an unidentified lifesign hiding aboard Voyager. Janeway hopes aiding the Hirogen might ease tensions with their hostile species.
StorySections.Act II: The intruder is revealed to be a wounded member of Species 8472, still dangerous despite its injuries. While Janeway insists on trying to communicate and return it to fluidic space, the Hirogen view it only as a trophy to be taken at any cost.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway strikes a fragile deal to cooperate with the Hirogen in capturing 8472 alive, but their methods clash with Starfleet ethics and compromise ship’s safety. Seven, convinced the alien will destroy them if given the chance, secretly prepares a more lethal option.
StorySections.Act IV: As multiple Hirogen ships surround Voyager and demand the prey, the 8472 breaks loose in the Jeffries tubes and savages the hunter. Seven defies Janeway’s orders and beams the alien into space directly into the Hirogen’s crosshairs, ensuring their survival but shattering the captain’s trust.
StorySections.Tag: In the aftermath, Janeway dresses Seven down for her disobedience, warning that there must be consequences, while Seven coolly insists that her choice was the only logical way to protect the ship.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway tries to balance compassion for a wounded enemy with her duty to protect Voyager, hoping that helping the Hirogen will open the door to less violent dealings in the future.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven views both the Hirogen and Species 8472 through a cold tactical lens, ultimately defying Janeway’s orders to sacrifice the 8472 and revealing how far her instincts still diverge from Starfleet ideals.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides calm tactical analysis and attempts to reach the telepathic 8472, briefly bridging the gap between hunter, prey and Voyager’s crew.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay oversees security operations and voices concern that Janeway’s attempts at diplomacy are placing the ship between two relentless enemies.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor works to save the Hirogen’s life despite his brutality, exemplifying Starfleet medical ethics even when the patient is openly hostile.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen hunter: The injured Hirogen hunter is obsessed with completing his kill, seeing the 8472 as the ultimate trophy and refusing to consider any outcome other than victory or death.
EntitySummaries.Species 8472 individual: This lone 8472 is wounded, frightened and still lethally dangerous, representing a being that may not be purely monstrous yet is almost impossible for Voyager to accommodate safely.
EntitySummaries.Additional Hirogen captains: The other Hirogen commanders surrounding Voyager treat the ship as interlopers on their preserve and are fully prepared to destroy it to reclaim their prey.
EntitySummaries.Alpha Hirogen leader: The Alpha Hirogen leading the pack embodies his species’ absolutist hunting code, rejecting Janeway’s pleas and caring only about the glory of the kill.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen hunting ethos: The Hirogen hunting ethos functions as a cultural antagonist, elevating the pursuit of prey above all other values and making compromise nearly impossible.

ContinuityNotes: Prey continues the Hirogen story arc that began in "Hunters," further developing their culture and methods.
The episode brings back Species 8472 from the Borg conflict introduced in "Scorpion," linking two of Voyager’s most dangerous recurring foes.
Seven’s decision to disobey Janeway has repercussions for their relationship and for her integration into the crew.
Voyager’s encounters with the Hirogen set up later developments in which their culture is forced to change.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines competing ethics of mercy and survival when caught between two implacable enemies.
It questions whether Starfleet compassion can coexist with the harsh realities of the Delta Quadrant.
Prey highlights the tension between individual judgment and the chain of command through Seven’s controversial choice.
The story explores how cultures built on the hunt can become trapped by their own code of honor.
BehindTheScenes: Prey was written by Brannon Braga and directed by Allan Eastman.
The episode continues Voyager’s use of elaborate prosthetics and suits for both the Hirogen and Species 8472.
Guest star Tony Todd brought additional gravitas to the role of a Hirogen Alpha in the Hirogen arc.

Title: Retrospect
Summary: After an altercation with an Entharan arms dealer named Kovin, Seven of Nine begins experiencing disturbing flashes that the Doctor interprets as repressed memories of a traumatic medical assault, prompting Janeway to pursue charges that may rest on uncertain evidence.

StorySections.Teaser: During a test of Kovin’s powerful isokinetic cannon, Seven loses her temper when he touches her implants and hurls him across the room, leaving the trader furious and threatening to cancel the deal.
StorySections.Act I: Later in sickbay, Seven suffers anxiety and involuntary reactions when the Doctor approaches her with a hypospray. Curious about these uncharacteristic responses, he uses hypnosis and holodeck reconstruction to probe her memories.
StorySections.Act II: Guided by the Doctor, Seven recalls fragmented images of being restrained in Kovin’s lab and having nanoprobes forcibly extracted from her arm. Concluding she was violated, the Doctor urges her to report the incident to Janeway.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway confronts Kovin, who vehemently denies the accusation and insists Seven’s memories are false. As Entharan authorities become involved and Voyager’s crew reexamines their assumptions, questions arise about the reliability of recovered memories and the consequences of acting on them.
StorySections.Act IV: Physical evidence proves ambiguous, but Kovin’s business collapses under the weight of suspicion and fear. When an accident destroys his ship during a desperate flight, Janeway and the Doctor realize they may never know the full truth, and that their rush to judgment may have helped push him over the edge.
StorySections.Tag: Haunted by the outcome, the Doctor asks Janeway to delete the behavioral subroutines that led him to explore psychology, but she refuses, insisting that growth sometimes includes painful mistakes. Seven is left to wrestle with doubts about both her memories and her own emerging humanity.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven confronts the possibility that she has been violated, but must also face the uncertainty of whether her memories are accurate, sharpening her discomfort with the vulnerabilities of being human.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor expands his role into psychotherapy, only to see his confidence shaken when his interpretation of Seven’s memories may have helped ruin an innocent man’s life.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway tries to support Seven while following procedure and respecting Entharan law, later agonizing over whether she placed too much faith in contested evidence.
EntitySummaries.Kovin: Kovin is a proud, temperamental arms dealer whose business collapses under suspicion; whether guilty or not, he becomes a tragic figure destroyed by allegations and fear.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok remains skeptical of the recovered memories and urges careful investigation, providing a rational counterweight to the crew’s emotional response.
EntitySummaries.Entharan magistrate: The Entharan magistrate represents a legal system more worried about trade and stability than the nuances of trauma and memory, amplifying the consequences of Voyager’s accusations.
EntitySummaries.Entharan technicians: Kovin’s assistants are drawn into the investigation, illustrating how an accusation against one person can ripple through a community.
EntitySummaries.Ambiguous recovered memories: The murky nature of Seven’s recovered memories functions as an intangible antagonist, driving the story’s conflict without ever yielding clear answers.
EntitySummaries.Mob suspicion on Enthara: Public suspicion on Enthara turns quickly against Kovin, showing how rumor and fear can condemn someone long before the facts are known.
EntitySummaries.Kovin's temper: Kovin’s quick anger and defensiveness make him look guilty even when proof is lacking, complicating both the investigation and the audience’s perception of him.

ContinuityNotes: Retrospect continues Voyager’s exploration of Seven’s psychological adjustment after life in the Collective.
The episode further develops the Doctor’s desire to grow beyond his original medical programming.
Questions about memory reliability echo other franchise stories dealing with altered or implanted recollections.
Entharan technology, including the isokinetic cannon, illustrates the risks of arms trading in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: The episode tackles the complexity of trauma, false or uncertain memories and the real-world consequences of acting on them.
It explores how good intentions can still lead to injustice when evidence is incomplete.
Retrospect raises questions about trust between survivors, advocates and institutions when truth is elusive.
The story emphasizes that growth—personal or ethical—often involves painful self-examination after mistakes.
BehindTheScenes: Retrospect’s teleplay was written by Bryan Fuller and Lisa Klink from a story by Andrew Shepard Price and Mark Gaberman, and it was directed by Jesús Salvador Treviño.
The episode was conceived in the context of 1990s debates about recovered memories and their impact on legal cases.
Jeri Ryan and Robert Picardo both cited the story as challenging due to its emotionally fraught subject matter.

Title: The Killing Game, Part I
Summary: After Voyager is captured by the Hirogen, the hunters convert the ship into an enormous holodeck arena and overwrite the crew’s identities, forcing them to play out brutal simulations—including a World War II resistance scenario—without remembering who they really are.

StorySections.Teaser: A Klingon warrior is cut down in a chaotic battle, only for the corpse to dissolve into a dead Starfleet officer as safeties disengage, revealing Voyager’s corridors transformed into a sprawling holodeck battleground under Hirogen control.
StorySections.Act I: The Hirogen Alpha and his subordinates have seized the ship and fitted it with extra holo-emitters, using neural interfaces to lock the crew into roles as prey. Janeway, Seven, Tuvok and others live as French resistance fighters in Nazi-occupied France, unaware that their true identities are being suppressed.
StorySections.Act II: As "Katrine," Janeway runs a café that doubles as a resistance headquarters; Seven is a glamorous singer and munitions expert; Tuvok is a stoic bartender. The Hirogen take on Nazi roles, hunting the crew through the streets while occasionally pausing the program to adjust tactics or patch up damaged prey.
StorySections.Act III: Neelix, the Doctor and a handful of others retain or recover their memories and begin plotting to free the crew, working around the Hirogen’s restrictions and tampering with the holodeck grid. Meanwhile, the Alpha resists suggestions to end the game, seeing Voyager as the key to preserving and expanding his people’s hunting culture.
StorySections.Act IV: As the resistance escalates attacks inside the program, damage spills into the real ship, threatening systems the Hirogen depend on. The Alpha orders the games intensified rather than curtailed, even as cracks begin to form in both the holonarrative and the crew’s imposed personas.
StorySections.Tag: Janeway and Seven prepare for a major strike against the "Nazis" in the holosimulation, unaware that their rebellion could also be the first step toward reclaiming Voyager from its new masters.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway spends much of the episode believing she is Katrine, a French resistance leader, yet her core defiance and tactical sense still shine through the false identity imposed on her.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: As a nightclub chanteuse and explosives expert, Seven channels both her Borg precision and her growing individuality into acts of sabotage against the occupying "Nazis."
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok plays a loyal bartender and resistance ally whose Vulcan discipline manifests as quiet steadiness, hinting that his true nature persists beneath the neural conditioning.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay appears in another holosimulation as a Klingon warrior, embodying the Hirogen’s desire for varied and challenging prey across multiple programs.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s holodeck persona as an Allied soldier and resistance ally lets his natural daring and improvisation emerge even without his real memories.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna participates in the simulations as a fierce combatant whose ferocity remains intact despite the neural overlay, making her a particularly valued target for the Hirogen.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix, partially outside the main holoprograms, becomes a key figure in ferrying information and helping coordinate the nascent effort to subvert the Hirogen’s control.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: Protected by his holographic nature, the Doctor retains his identity and is forced to treat both Hirogen and injured crew, all while secretly helping the resistance plan.
EntitySummaries.Alpha Hirogen: The Alpha Hirogen views Voyager as a means to create endless new hunting scenarios, seeking to transform his people’s nomadic culture into one based on curated, archival kills.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen officers: The subordinate Hirogen officers are torn between their Alpha’s ambitious vision and the practical risks of overextending their control of Voyager and its systems.
EntitySummaries.Nazi officer holograms: The Nazi officer holograms serve as masks for the Hirogen, providing them with roles through which to humiliate and terrorize the crew inside the World War II simulation.
EntitySummaries.French civilians (holodeck): The French civilian holograms populate the occupied town, heightening the realism and moral stakes of the game the Hirogen treat as mere sport.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen hunters: The Hirogen hunters function as the primary external antagonists, repeatedly rewriting the crew’s identities to satisfy their desire for ever more elaborate hunts.
EntitySummaries.Holodeck control grid: The expanded holodeck grid allows programs to spill across multiple decks, transforming Voyager into a hunting preserve and making it harder to regain control.
EntitySummaries.Neural interfaces: The neural interfaces that overwrite the crew’s memories are a technological antagonist, trapping them in roles where they cannot easily recognize their true situation.

ContinuityNotes: The Killing Game, Part I continues and intensifies the Hirogen arc established in "Hunters" and "Prey."
The episode revisits World War II imagery, a recurring motif across Star Trek holodeck stories.
Voyager’s holodeck systems are shown to be extensible across multiple decks via added emitters.
The story sets up character beats that pay off in Part II, particularly for Janeway and Seven.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the dehumanizing effects of treating sentient beings as prey and props in someone else’s game.
It examines identity and memory, showing how core traits can persist even when surface details are overwritten.
The Killing Game critiques cultures that glorify war and hunting by turning historical atrocities into entertainment.
The story raises questions about how far a society will go to preserve its traditions when those traditions become unsustainable.
BehindTheScenes: The Killing Game two-parter was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky, with Part I directed by David Livingston.
Extensive sets and costumes were created to depict Nazi-occupied France within Voyager’s corridors.
The production used added holo-emitter props and visual effects to sell the notion of holoprograms spilling beyond a single room.

Title: The Killing Game, Part II
Summary: As holodeck damage causes programs to bleed together, Janeway and the partially deconditioned crew fight on multiple fronts—inside Nazi-occupied France, among Klingon warriors and in Voyager’s real corridors—to overthrow the Hirogen and end their deadly games.

StorySections.Teaser: The resistance’s latest attack escalates the World War II simulation, and a stray explosion tears through a bulkhead, revealing starship corridors and briefly shocking Janeway and Seven out of their imposed personas.
StorySections.Act I: The Alpha Hirogen insists on continuing the hunts despite increasing system failures, while some of his underlings fear they will lose control of Voyager entirely. The Doctor and Neelix step up their sabotage, freeing key crewmembers from their neural conditioning.
StorySections.Act II: As holoprograms overlap, Klingon battles spill into the French town, and Nazi troops appear in unexpected corridors. Janeway and Seven begin to piece together that they are more than their roles, using that insight to coordinate a real resistance against both Nazis and Hirogen.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway strikes a risky bargain with the Alpha, proposing that the Hirogen adopt holotechnology as a new way to hunt without driving species to extinction. At the same time, Chakotay, Paris and others fight to regain control of engineering and the bridge.
StorySections.Act IV: When negotiations falter and fighting erupts, the crew and sympathetic Hirogen work together just long enough to shut down the holoprograms and disable the neural interfaces. The Alpha dies in the final conflict, leaving a younger Hirogen to consider Janeway’s proposal.
StorySections.Tag: With Voyager back in their hands, the crew tends to their wounds while Janeway reflects on whether the alternative she offered the Hirogen will truly change their culture—or merely give them new tools for the same old bloodsport.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway juggles battlefield leadership inside the holosimulation with a bold plan to redirect Hirogen culture toward safer hunts, even if she doubts they will embrace it.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven, increasingly aware that something is wrong, becomes a crucial link between the artificial personas and the crew’s real identities, helping coordinate resistance on both levels.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay leads efforts to reclaim key ship systems, turning chaos in the overlapping programs into opportunities to outmaneuver the Hirogen.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s tactical insight remains vital once his true self resurfaces, allowing him to turn confused battle lines to Voyager’s advantage.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom uses his combat experience and familiarity with holoprograms to navigate the surreal mix of scenarios and support Janeway’s bid to retake the ship.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna fights both in the simulations and in engineering, working to keep the ship from tearing itself apart as the grid overloads.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix continues to move between programs as a courier, smuggling equipment and information to where it is most needed.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor disables neural interfaces and treats the wounded on both sides, embodying Starfleet medical values even as he works in the midst of carnage.
EntitySummaries.Alpha Hirogen: The Alpha clings to his vision of endless hunts on Voyager, refusing compromise until his death, which becomes a turning point for his people.
EntitySummaries.Young Hirogen: The younger Hirogen who survives is left holding Janeway’s offer of holotechnology, symbolizing the uncertain future of a culture at a crossroads.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen officers: The other Hirogen officers are forced to choose between blind loyalty to the Alpha and pragmatic survival as the ship disintegrates around them.
EntitySummaries.Nazi officer holograms: The Nazi holograms continue to play their roles even as the programs collapse, underscoring how historical atrocities are being used as backdrop for sport.
EntitySummaries.Klingon warrior holograms: Klingon holograms represent yet another layer of manufactured violence, complicating the battlefield and reflecting the Hirogen appetite for varied prey.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen hunters: The Hirogen hunters remain the primary external antagonists, their obsession with the chase pushing Voyager and themselves to the brink of destruction.
EntitySummaries.Runaway holodeck programs: The malfunctioning holoprograms become their own threat, eroding the line between fiction and reality as they damage critical ship systems.
