EntitySummaries.Neural interfaces: The neural interfaces keep pulling crewmembers back into their roles, threatening to erase hard-won gains in awareness whenever they remain active.

ContinuityNotes: The Killing Game, Part II concludes the two-part story and marks a turning point in Voyager’s relationship with the Hirogen.
Janeway’s offer of holotechnology as an alternative to traditional hunts is referenced in later Hirogen appearances.
The extensive damage to Voyager underscores how costly the Hirogen capture has been for the ship and crew.
The two-parter is frequently cited as one of Voyager’s more ambitious holodeck-based stories.
ThematicNotes: Part II deepens the critique of cultures that turn war and oppression into entertainment.
It explores whether a violent tradition can be redirected rather than destroyed, and at what moral cost.
The episode emphasizes that identity can reassert itself even after prolonged psychological manipulation.
The story also highlights the toll of constant conflict on Voyager’s crew, physically and emotionally.
BehindTheScenes: The second half of The Killing Game was directed by Victor Lobl, continuing the script by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky.
The production reused and expanded World War II sets, blending them with Klingon and starship environments for the chaotic final battles.
Cast and crew have often cited The Killing Game as a technically demanding but memorable production.

Title: Vis à Vis
Summary: Restless and bored with routine, Tom Paris befriends an affable pilot named Steth and becomes entangled in a series of body swaps when his new acquaintance turns out to be a shape-shifting alien who steals identities to escape the consequences of its past.

StorySections.Teaser: Tom throws himself into restoring a 1969 Camaro in a holodeck program, avoiding duty and B'Elanna as he grumbles about the predictability of life on Voyager.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager encounters Steth’s advanced ship, and the charming alien asks for help fixing a problematic propulsion system. Tom bonds with Steth over fast engines and the thrill of change, seeing in him the adventurous life he thinks he wants.
StorySections.Act II: Alone with Tom, Steth suddenly swaps bodies with him using a strange device, leaving Tom trapped in Steth’s stolen form on the alien ship while the impostor Tom returns to Voyager and begins behaving erratically.
StorySections.Act III: The fake Tom’s odd personality shifts and disregard for protocol unsettle B'Elanna, Janeway and the Doctor, who gradually piece together that something is wrong. Meanwhile, the real Tom meets Daelen, another victim of the body thief, and learns that "Steth" has been jumping from host to host for some time.
StorySections.Act IV: Working together, Tom and the real Steth regain control of the alien ship and race back to Voyager as the impostor steals Janeway’s body in a further attempt to escape. A confrontation in space forces the entity to reverse the swaps, restoring everyone to their rightful forms.
StorySections.Tag: Back in his own body, Tom recommits to his life aboard Voyager and to B'Elanna, realizing that chasing novelty for its own sake nearly cost him everything he actually values.

GuestCharacters: Additional victims of the body thief

EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s boredom and craving for excitement leave him vulnerable to a charismatic stranger, but the ordeal of losing his identity forces him to recognize how much he values his place on Voyager and his relationship with B'Elanna.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna is the first to sense that something is wrong with "Tom," reading the subtle ways the impostor fails to match the man she loves and becoming a key voice of suspicion.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway is briefly overtaken by the body thief, a violation that underscores how dangerous the entity is and how quickly it can compromise command structures.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor observes behavioral anomalies in "Tom" and provides the medical perspective that helps confirm that body swapping, not simple stress, is at work.
EntitySummaries.Steth: Steth is revealed to be a prior victim trapped in a stolen body, his name used as a mask by the true body thief until he helps Tom reclaim their identities.
EntitySummaries.Daelen: Daelen is another wronged party whose body has been misused, helping Tom piece together the entity’s long trail of theft and deceit.
EntitySummaries.Additional victims of the body thief: Other unseen victims emphasize that the entity has been repeating this pattern for some time, leaving a wake of disrupted lives across its travels.
EntitySummaries.Body-swapping alien entity: The true antagonist hides behind the faces it steals, dodging responsibility by abandoning each life once it becomes inconvenient.
EntitySummaries.Tom's restlessness and dissatisfaction: Tom’s own dissatisfaction functions as an internal antagonist, blinding him to the risks of inviting a stranger into his orbit until it is almost too late.

ContinuityNotes: Vis à Vis continues Voyager’s exploration of identity and bodily autonomy through science fiction metaphors.
Tom’s holodeck Camaro project reflects his long-standing fascination with 20th-century culture.
The episode contributes to the ongoing development of Tom and B'Elanna’s relationship.
Body-swapping and mind-transfer concepts echo similar stories across the Star Trek franchise.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines the allure of constant change versus the value of commitment and stability.
It explores identity and ownership of one’s body, raising questions about accountability when forms are mutable.
Tom’s arc highlights how dissatisfaction can make people susceptible to manipulation.
The story suggests that real growth comes from facing one’s responsibilities rather than running from them.
BehindTheScenes: Vis à Vis was written by Robert J. Doherty and directed by Jesús Salvador Treviño.
Actor Dan Butler’s performance as Steth required him to play both the original character and the body thief’s shifting persona.
The episode’s premise has been compared to the film "Face/Off" due to its focus on stolen identities and swapped appearances.

Title: The Omega Directive
Summary: When Voyager detects the ultra-dangerous Omega particle, a classified Starfleet protocol overrides all other orders and forces Janeway to lead a secret mission to destroy it, while Seven of Nine—awed by the particle’s perfection—pushes to study and preserve it instead.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager shutters under a distant explosion and every console locks, displaying a mysterious omega symbol that even senior officers do not recognize, while Janeway alone receives a coded confirmation of a top-secret directive.
StorySections.Act I: Janeway isolates herself in her ready room to review the Omega Directive, then quietly orders a change of course toward a remote world where the phenomenon has been detected. She summons Seven, aware that the Borg once encountered Omega and consider it the key to ultimate power.
StorySections.Act II: Janeway finally briefs her senior staff on the Omega Directive’s ruthless priority—destroy all Omega at any cost—shocking the crew. On the surface of the alien world, they discover scientists who have been manufacturing Omega to free their people from dependence on subspace corridors.
StorySections.Act III: While Janeway prepares a containment and destruction plan, Seven becomes increasingly captivated by the particle’s apparent perfection and begs for time to stabilize and study it. Tension escalates as the unstable molecules threaten to tear subspace apart for light-years around.
StorySections.Act IV: Seven reluctantly uses Borg techniques to help gather and detonate the Omega molecules in a controlled blast, saving the region but losing the one thing she regards as a glimpse of pure perfection. Just before the explosion, she witnesses the particles stabilize for a few seconds, an experience she cherishes despite their destruction.
StorySections.Tag: Later, Janeway and Seven reflect on the mission: Janeway on the burden of carrying such a secret directive, and Seven on having seen something transcendent that no collective—Borg or Federation—will ever fully grasp or record.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway is forced to set aside even the Prime Directive to carry out the Omega Directive, wrestling with the morality of destroying a discovery that could transform space travel but poses an existential threat to warp travel.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven regards Omega as a manifestation of perfection and resents Starfleet’s insistence on destroying it, yet ultimately applies her Borg expertise to neutralize the particles, deepening the conflict between her scientific awe and her duty to Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay challenges Janeway’s secrecy and the severity of the directive, pressing her to trust the crew even while accepting that she has burdens he can neither share nor fully understand.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok supports the logic of the directive’s priorities, focusing on the tactical and long-term dangers of Omega while helping Janeway maintain discipline in the face of crew unease.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry contributes to the complex containment and targeting scans, exemplifying the crew’s willingness to follow Janeway’s orders despite not knowing the full classified context.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna works with Seven to adapt Borg and Starfleet technology into a workable annihilation array, chafing at the risk to Voyager’s systems but recognizing the stakes if they fail.
EntitySummaries.Alien scientist: The alien scientist represents a desperate civilization willing to gamble on Omega to secure independence, embodying the temptation to use dangerous shortcuts to solve deep-rooted problems.
EntitySummaries.Omega particles: The Omega particles themselves function as an almost abstract antagonist, a miraculous yet deadly form of energy that could permanently shatter subspace if allowed to escape control.
EntitySummaries.Omega Directive itself: The Omega Directive acts as an institutional antagonist, forcing Janeway into morally gray decisions by prioritizing the destruction of Omega above all other Starfleet values.
EntitySummaries.Unstable alien experiment: The alien experiment to harness Omega is a situational antagonist, endangering the region through hubris and incomplete understanding of the particle’s catastrophic potential.

ContinuityNotes: The Omega Directive introduces a previously unmentioned Starfleet protocol that supersedes even the Prime Directive.
Seven’s knowledge of Omega stems from the Borg, who sought to harness the particle as a path to perfection.
References are made to the wider implications of Omega on subspace and warp travel across the galaxy.
The episode reinforces Janeway’s reputation for bearing heavy command burdens alone until she can trust her crew with classified information.
ThematicNotes: The story pits scientific curiosity and the quest for perfection against the necessity of caution and sacrifice.
It explores secrecy in command and the ethical cost of leaders who must act on information they cannot fully share.
The episode reflects on faith, with Seven’s near-religious reverence for Omega contrasted against Janeway’s pragmatic duty.
It questions whether certain forms of knowledge are too dangerous for any civilization to pursue.
BehindTheScenes: The Omega Directive was written by Lisa Klink from a story by Jimmy Diggs and Steve J. Kay and directed by Victor Lobl.
The episode expanded Voyager’s mythology by introducing a new top-secret Starfleet protocol never mentioned in earlier series.
Visual effects emphasized the alien, almost spiritual appearance of the Omega molecules to underscore Seven’s fascination.

Title: Unforgettable
Summary: A mysterious alien woman named Kellin boards Voyager claiming a deep past romance with Chakotay that he cannot remember, and the crew soon learns that her species’ biochemistry erases them from the memories of those they leave behind.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager intervenes in a skirmish between cloaked ships and beams aboard a lone pilot—Kellin—who shocks everyone by greeting Chakotay as an old lover and requesting asylum from her people.
StorySections.Act I: Kellin insists that she and Chakotay met months earlier and fell in love before she was forcibly returned home, at which point his memories of her were chemically erased. Skeptical but curious, the crew investigates her ship and story while Kellin quietly demonstrates knowledge of Voyager and its routines.
StorySections.Act II: As Kellin recounts their supposed shared adventures, Chakotay feels flickers of recognition he can’t quite trust. Janeway reluctantly agrees to grant Kellin temporary asylum, even as a tracker from her world arrives and warns that Kellin’s people will not tolerate her defection.
StorySections.Act III: The alien pursuers attempt to capture Kellin and administer another memory-erasing agent, but Voyager drives them off. Chakotay helps Kellin record logs and personal notes in case his memory is altered again, giving their rekindled relationship a fragile foothold in the future.
StorySections.Act IV: Kellin decides to remain on Voyager and start a new life, but an unseen intruder sneaks aboard and injects her with the same neurochemical agent. Her presence and records begin to unravel as the biochemical effect spreads, wiping all but the faintest traces of her from the crew’s minds.
StorySections.Tag: Later, Chakotay finds a lonely note and a half-finished carving he cannot fully place, leaving him with only a vague sense of loss and the knowledge that someone important has slipped beyond his ability to remember.

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay is torn between rational doubt and an emotional pull toward Kellin, ultimately choosing to believe in a love story he can barely remember and trying to anchor it in tangible records.
EntitySummaries.Kellin: Kellin is a determined defector from a secretive culture who risks everything to reclaim a relationship that her own people have literally erased, knowing she may be forgotten again.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway balances caution with compassion, granting Kellin limited trust while recognizing the disturbing implications of a society that can edit itself out of other peoples’ memories.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok remains skeptical, focusing on security risks and the lack of corroborating evidence, yet he respects Chakotay’s choice to pursue the truth of his feelings as far as logic allows.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven observes the fragile nature of memory-based relationships with her usual cool detachment, contrasting Kellin’s romantic idealism with a Borg’s preference for objective data.
EntitySummaries.Curneth: Curneth personifies Kellin’s homeworld’s rigid enforcement of anonymity, committed to retrieving her and upholding a system that depends on others never truly knowing them.
EntitySummaries.Other members of Kellin's species: Kellin’s people are quiet antagonists whose ability to erase memories allows them to move through the galaxy unseen, raising unsettling questions about consent and accountability.
EntitySummaries.Kellin's government's erasure program: The government’s erasure program functions as an institutional antagonist, prioritizing secrecy over individual autonomy and treating personal connections as security breaches.
EntitySummaries.Memory-altering biochemistry: The engineered biochemistry that wipes surface memories is an invisible antagonist, undermining trust, history and the very possibility of lasting bonds.
EntitySummaries.Alien trackers: The trackers sent after Kellin enforce her world’s policies, presenting a persistent external threat to her attempt to build a new life on Voyager.

ContinuityNotes: Unforgettable centers Chakotay in a romantic plot, adding to his history of cross-species relationships in the Delta Quadrant.
The alien species’ memory-wiping technology introduces another example of advanced biochemistry in Voyager’s travels.
The episode highlights Voyager’s willingness to offer asylum to individuals fleeing oppressive regimes.
Themes of altered memory echo other Star Trek stories dealing with mind control and consent.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how love and identity persist—or fail—when memory cannot be trusted.
It raises questions about the ethics of state-imposed anonymity and the cost of perfect secrecy.
Unforgettable suggests that some emotional truths may linger even when specific recollections are gone.
The story examines the tension between personal freedom and the collective fear that drives oppressive security measures.
BehindTheScenes: Unforgettable was written by Greg Elliot and Michael Perricone and directed by Andrew J. Robinson, best known to fans as Garak from Star Trek: Deep Space Nine.
Guest star Virginia Madsen plays Kellin, bringing a grounded intensity to the role of a woman fighting to preserve a love no one else remembers.
The story’s premise allowed the production to emphasize performance and atmosphere over heavy visual effects.

Title: Living Witness
Summary: Seven centuries after Voyager’s visit to a divided world, a backup copy of the Doctor is reactivated in a museum that portrays the ship as a genocidal warship, forcing him to confront a distorted history and fight to correct the record.

StorySections.Teaser: On the "warship Voyager," a brutal Janeway orders devastating attacks that slaughter alien rebels—until the scene abruptly freezes and is revealed as a historical simulation in a Kyrian museum hundreds of years later.
StorySections.Act I: Quarren, the curator, proudly explains this version of events to visitors, presenting Voyager as an ally of the dominant Vaskans who helped exterminate Kyrian resistance. When he discovers and reactivates a backup of the Doctor, the hologram is horrified by the twisted narrative.
StorySections.Act II: The Doctor insists that Voyager tried to mediate peace and that the alleged atrocities never happened. Skeptical but intrigued, Quarren allows him to present an alternate account, leading to a clash between established dogma and newly unearthed evidence.
StorySections.Act III: As the Doctor’s testimony spreads, tensions erupt between Kyrians and Vaskans who have built their identities around competing histories. Some accuse the Doctor of being a war criminal; others see him as a key to reconciliation—and the museum becomes a flashpoint for renewed conflict.
StorySections.Act IV: Risking his own freedom, the Doctor helps uncover forensic proof that exonerates Voyager and reveals the true events of the long-ago incident. The truth forces both societies to reconsider centuries of resentment and propaganda.
StorySections.Tag: A later curator explains that the Doctor’s intervention eventually led to peace, and that after serving for years as a respected mediator, the hologram departed in search of his distant home—his story now an integral, if once-contested, part of their shared history.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is confronted with a grotesque, villainized version of Voyager’s past and must decide whether trying to correct the record is worth the risk of reigniting old hatreds, ultimately choosing truth over his own safety.
EntitySummaries.Quarren: Quarren begins as a well-meaning but biased curator, proud of his exhibit, and gradually becomes an ally of the Doctor as he realizes that his life’s work may rest on false assumptions.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway appears primarily in reconstructed flashbacks that exaggerate her into a ruthless warlord, highlighting how leaders can be mythologized or demonized by later generations.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay is likewise depicted in both distorted and more accurate forms, underscoring how nuance is often lost when history is simplified into heroes and villains.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s calm, measured presence in the Doctor’s true recollections contrasts sharply with the caricatured enforcer shown in the museum’s initial simulation.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s portrayal in the false history as a menacing enforcer emphasizes how the Kyrians have turned Voyager’s uniqueness into justification for their grievances.
EntitySummaries.Vaskan Arbiter: The Vaskan Arbiter represents those in power who fear that revising history will undermine their authority and narratives of victimhood or righteousness.
EntitySummaries.Kyrian Arbiter: The Kyrian Arbiter embodies the difficulty of admitting that a foundational story of oppression and heroism may be incomplete or inaccurate.
EntitySummaries.Tedran: Tedran is memorialized as a martyr in Kyrian history, and the revelations about his death complicate the simplistic legend built around him.
EntitySummaries.Distorted historical narrative: The entrenched false history serves as the main antagonist, shaping generations of belief and conflict long after the original facts have faded.
EntitySummaries.Kyrian-Vaskan prejudice: Mutual prejudice between Kyrians and Vaskans keeps both societies locked in cycles of blame that resist even hard evidence to the contrary.
EntitySummaries.Political manipulation of history: The politicized use of history—by both sides—stands as an institutional antagonist, showing how power structures can weaponize the past.

ContinuityNotes: Living Witness uniquely takes place primarily in the far future relative to Voyager’s main timeline.
A backup copy of the Doctor’s program explains how he could survive for centuries beyond the crew’s journey.
The episode reinforces Star Trek’s recurring theme that historical accounts are often shaped by those who tell them.
Voyager’s role in the original Kyrian-Vaskan dispute is shown to have been far more limited than legend suggests.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines historical revisionism and the difficulty of challenging narratives that define national identity.
It explores the idea that truth can be both dangerous and necessary for reconciliation.
Living Witness reflects on the responsibility of archivists, educators and witnesses to present complex reality rather than myth.
The story suggests that even deeply rooted conflicts can be transformed when societies confront uncomfortable facts.
BehindTheScenes: Living Witness was written by Brannon Braga with teleplay contributions from Bryan Fuller and Joe Menosky and directed by Tim Russ, who also plays Tuvok.
The episode allowed the cast to portray darker, alternate versions of their characters in the museum’s initial simulation.
Critics and fans frequently cite Living Witness as one of Voyager’s strongest stand-alone episodes for its commentary on history and memory.

Title: Demon
Summary: Desperately low on deuterium, Voyager lands on a so-called "demon class" planet to refuel, only to discover a mutable liquid lifeform that copies the crew and ultimately creates an entire duplicate Voyager.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager limps through space on minimal power, its deuterium reserves nearly exhausted, forcing Janeway to order strict energy rationing and consider risky options for resupply.
StorySections.Act I: Seven detects rich deuterium deposits on a hostile Y-class world whose surface conditions are supposedly lethal to humanoids. Despite the danger, Janeway approves a limited mission after the planet appears to adapt to their initial probe.
StorySections.Act II: Harry Kim and Tom Paris beam down in environmental suits and discover pools of strange, metallic "silver blood" that mimics their physiology. When contact with the substance causes their life signs to vanish, Voyager is forced into an emergency landing to search for them.
StorySections.Act III: On the surface, the crew encounters eerily accurate copies of Harry and Tom formed by the liquid entity, which has become sentient by imitating them. The organism pleads for more patterns to emulate, yearning for identity and consciousness beyond its original amorphous state.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway negotiates an uneasy bargain: Voyager supplies genetic and neural templates so the silver blood can create stable duplicates of the crew, in exchange for deuterium and the safe return of the originals. The arrangement allows Voyager to leave, but leaves an entire duplicate crew behind on the planet.
StorySections.Tag: As Voyager departs with full tanks, the original crew contemplates the moral implications of leaving their doppelgängers behind, unaware that these copies will one day believe themselves to be the real Voyager.

GuestCharacters: Silver blood duplicates of Voyager crew
Antagonists: Silver blood's desperate need for identity

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must weigh the risk of landing on a hostile world against Voyager’s imminent power failure, ultimately striking a controversial deal that trades crew templates for survival.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry’s contact with the silver blood accelerates its evolution, and his duplicate embodies the organism’s first attempt at independent sentient existence.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s adventurous nature makes him an ideal candidate for the surface mission, and his duplicate forms part of the nascent community of copies left behind.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven provides crucial analysis of the silver blood’s adaptive behavior, recognizing that it is more than a simple hazard and pushing for it to be treated as a lifeform.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay questions the wisdom of trusting an alien substance that can copy them perfectly, voicing the crew’s unease about the long-term consequences.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna strains Voyager’s systems to manage a difficult landing and later helps configure the refueling process, underscoring the technical risk of the mission.
EntitySummaries.Silver blood duplicates of Voyager crew: The silver blood duplicates begin as imitations but quickly gain self-awareness, raising questions about whether they possess the same rights and authenticity as the originals.
EntitySummaries.Deuterium shortage: Voyager’s fuel crisis acts as a circumstantial antagonist, pushing the crew into decisions they might otherwise reject outright.
EntitySummaries.Demon-class planet environment: The planet’s extreme heat and toxic atmosphere are environmental antagonists that endanger the crew and complicate any rescue efforts.
EntitySummaries.Silver blood's desperate need for identi: The entity’s longing to become something more than formless matter drives it to copy the crew, creating a moral dilemma as it blurs the line between mimicry and personhood.

ContinuityNotes: Demon introduces the silver blood duplicates of Voyager’s crew, whose fate is revisited in the later episode "Course: Oblivion."
The episode highlights Voyager’s ongoing resource struggles in the Delta Quadrant, particularly its dependence on deuterium.
Demon-class planets are established as extremely hostile environments rarely visited by Starfleet vessels.
The existence of duplicates raises long-term continuity questions about which Voyager the audience is following in later stories.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores identity and authenticity through the creation of living duplicates.
It examines the ethical implications of making deals with an alien lifeform that gains sentience through imitation.
Demon reinforces Voyager’s recurring theme of survival choices made under extreme scarcity.
The story raises unsettling questions about whether consciousness depends on origin or on lived experience.
BehindTheScenes: Demon was written by Kenneth Biller from a story by André Bormanis and directed by Anson Williams.
The episode’s location work and visual effects created a distinctive molten, toxic landscape for the demon-class planet.
Fan and critical reaction to Demon has been divided, but its premise enabled the later, more experimental sequel "Course: Oblivion."

Title: One
Summary: When a highly radioactive nebula forces the crew into stasis for weeks, Seven of Nine must pilot Voyager alone with only the Doctor for company—until isolation, radiation and her own subconscious begin to blur the line between reality and hallucination.

StorySections.Teaser: While charting a dense nebula that blocks their path, Voyager is suddenly hit with debilitating radiation that kills one crewman and leaves the rest in danger if they remain awake.
StorySections.Act I: Seven remains unaffected by the radiation and the Doctor proposes that the crew go into stasis while she and his holographic program manage the ship. Janeway reluctantly agrees, entrusting Voyager and everyone aboard to Seven’s care for the long crossing.
StorySections.Act II: Alone on a silent ship, Seven adopts a rigid routine of diagnostics and patrols while the Doctor, limited by his mobile emitter’s instability, urges her to embrace small moments of recreation. Mechanical glitches and the emptiness of the corridors begin to weigh on her.
StorySections.Act III: As radiation seeps further into the ship, systems malfunction and Seven starts experiencing vivid hallucinations: distorted crewmembers, an intruding alien, and reminders of the Borg collective that make her doubt her own perceptions.
StorySections.Act IV: When the Doctor’s emitter fails, leaving her truly alone, Seven struggles to keep the ship on course while her sanity frays. Ultimately she forces herself to continue, sacrificing her own comfort and risking madness until Voyager finally emerges from the nebula and the crew awakens.
StorySections.Tag: Afterward, rattled by her ordeal, Seven quietly joins Paris, Kim and Torres in the mess hall, acknowledging for the first time her need for companionship beyond the Collective or pure duty.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced into a level of autonomy and solitude she has never experienced, confronting her fear that she cannot function without a collective while discovering a fragile capacity for independent resilience.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor serves as Seven’s only companion and emotional support, using humor and bedside manner in a bid to keep her grounded—even as his own technical limitations leave her increasingly on her own.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway’s decision to entrust Seven with the ship underscores the captain’s growing faith in her, while also highlighting the immense pressure she places on a still-recovering ex-Borg.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s claustrophobia adds a human detail to the crew’s vulnerability in stasis and gives Seven another responsibility to manage as she keeps watch over their well-being.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry serves as one of the faces in Seven’s hallucinations, symbolizing her fear of failing those who have welcomed her aboard.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna’s engineering work prior to stasis helps prepare the ship for the crossing, and her later camaraderie offers Seven a quiet place to reconnect with others.
EntitySummaries.Trajis Lo-Tarik (hallucination): Trajis appears as a menacing intruder who turns out to be a manifestation of Seven’s anxieties and the nebula’s effects rather than a real threat.
EntitySummaries.Nebula radiation: The nebula’s radiation acts as an environmental antagonist, forcing the stasis plan and gradually undermining both systems and sanity.
EntitySummaries.Seven's isolation: Seven’s isolation functions as a psychological antagonist, challenging her self-image as a detached former drone who supposedly does not need others.
EntitySummaries.Psychological hallucinations: The hallucinations embody Seven’s internal fears and the corrosive effects of loneliness, nearly sabotaging the mission from within.

ContinuityNotes: One centers Seven’s ongoing journey from Borg drone to individuated human, building on her character arc throughout season 4.
The episode references Voyager’s continuing need to cross hostile regions that test the crew in unconventional ways.
Seven’s choice at the end to seek company foreshadows her gradual integration into the crew’s social life.
The backup Doctor and stasis technology feature again in later Voyager stories dealing with long transits and emergencies.
ThematicNotes: The story is a meditation on isolation and the psychological toll of prolonged solitude.
It explores self-reliance versus the need for community, especially for someone conditioned to exist only in a collective.
One highlights the fragility of perception under stress and how easily fear can shape reality when there is no one to offer perspective.
The episode ultimately affirms that seeking companionship is a sign of growth, not weakness.
BehindTheScenes: One was written by Jeri Taylor from a premise by James Swallow and directed by Kenneth Biller.
The episode required extensive sequences with Jeri Ryan acting alone on mostly empty sets to convey Voyager’s eerie stillness.
Critics have praised One as one of Voyager’s standout character studies for Seven of Nine.

Title: Hope and Fear
Summary: A linguistically gifted alien named Arturis helps decode a long-awaited Starfleet message that appears to offer Voyager a new ship and a quick route home, but the apparent gift conceals a trap born of vengeance for Janeway’s earlier alliance with the Borg.

StorySections.Teaser: Struggling to break an encrypted message from Starfleet, Janeway is frustrated by her lack of progress when Neelix returns with a new friend—Arturis—who casually demonstrates an uncanny talent for languages.
StorySections.Act I: Arturis swiftly decodes the transmission, revealing coordinates and instructions that lead Voyager to a sleek, unmanned Starfleet vessel equipped with quantum slipstream drive: a ship that could take the crew home in mere months.
StorySections.Act II: As the crew tours the Dauntless and runs tests, Seven remains uneasy, suspicious of both the too-perfect opportunity and Arturis himself. Janeway and Chakotay debate whether to abandon Voyager to take the faster route home.
StorySections.Act III: Further analysis exposes inconsistencies in the message and the ship’s design, and Janeway confronts Arturis just as he activates the vessel’s true controls, revealing it to be his own ship disguised as Starfleet technology.
StorySections.Act IV: Arturis kidnaps Janeway and Seven aboard the reconfigured Dauntless and reveals his motive: his world was assimilated by the Borg in part because Janeway brokered peace between the Borg and Species 8472. Voyager pursues in an unstable slipstream and rescues them, leaving Arturis to face the Borg alone.
StorySections.Tag: Though the slipstream drive proves too dangerous for Voyager to replicate, the ship has gained several hundred light-years on its journey—and Janeway and Seven, having confronted the consequences of past choices, share a wary but deeper understanding.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway is forced to confront the long-term fallout of her alliance with the Borg, realizing that decisions she made to save her crew contributed to another species’ destruction and inspired Arturis’s elaborate revenge.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s suspicion of Arturis and the Dauntless underscores her Borg-honed instinct for deception, while her refusal to return to the Collective affirms her commitment to individuality despite feeling partly responsible for what happened to Arturis’s people.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay weighs the emotional pull of a shortcut home against trust in Janeway’s caution, ultimately backing her instinct that the Dauntless is too good to be true.
EntitySummaries.Arturis: Arturis is a brilliant, grief-stricken alien who blames Voyager for the assimilation of his world and uses his gift with languages and technology to lure them into a revenge plot he believes to be justice.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom studies the slipstream technology with enthusiasm, then frustration, as he realizes that Voyager cannot safely sustain it—embodying the crew’s hope and disappointment.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix innocently brings Arturis aboard, later horrified to learn that his friendly contact has nearly delivered the crew into the hands of the Borg.
EntitySummaries.Admiral Hayes (in message): Admiral Hayes and the forged Starfleet transmission symbolize the crew’s continued connection to home—and how that hope can be exploited.
EntitySummaries.Quantum slipstream trap: The Dauntless’s slipstream drive acts as a technological antagonist, a powerful lure designed to carry Voyager not home, but into Borg space.
EntitySummaries.Consequences of the Borg–8472 alliance: The repercussions of Janeway’s earlier alliance with the Borg serve as a background antagonist, manifesting in the loss of Arturis’s world and his burning need for retribution.

ContinuityNotes: Hope and Fear serves as the season 4 finale and pays off the encoded Starfleet message first received in "Hunters."
The episode revisits Janeway’s alliance with the Borg and Species 8472 from "Scorpion" and its impact on others in the Delta Quadrant.
Quantum slipstream technology introduced here returns in later episodes, including "Timeless."
The episode advances the evolving relationship between Janeway and Seven, emphasizing mutual responsibility and hard-earned trust.
ThematicNotes: The story examines unintended consequences, showing how choices made in one crisis can devastate unseen others.
It explores revenge versus justice through Arturis’s elaborate scheme and Janeway’s refusal to surrender her crew to his pain.
Hope and Fear contrasts the crew’s longing for home with the danger of accepting easy answers without scrutiny.
The episode deepens the theme of found family as Voyager chooses to continue its journey together rather than risk everything on an unproven shortcut.
BehindTheScenes: Hope and Fear was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky from a story by Rick Berman, Braga and Menosky, and directed by Winrich Kolbe.
Guest star Ray Wise portrays Arturis, bringing nuance to a villain motivated by grief as much as anger.
The Dauntless sets were designed to appear plausibly Starfleet at first glance, then reveal their alien nature as the story unfolds.

Title: Night
Summary: Voyager enters a starless void that isolates the crew for weeks, amplifying Janeway’s guilt over stranding them in the Delta Quadrant and forcing her to confront both her depression and a moral choice about a species being poisoned by alien freighters.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager travels through an eerie, lightless region of space with no stars or sensor contacts, leaving the crew restless and unsettled as the usual distractions vanish.
StorySections.Act I: With no external stimuli, minor tensions aboard ship flare and some officers retreat into holodeck escapism, while Janeway isolates herself in her quarters, obsessed with reports and avoiding contact as she broods over the original decision that brought them to the Delta Quadrant.
StorySections.Act II: Paris and others discover strange radiation pockets and finally detect an alien freight vessel under attack by unseen assailants. When the freight captain is beamed aboard, he reveals that his people are using the void as a dumping ground for toxic antimatter waste, poisoning an indigenous species that lives there.
StorySections.Act III: The indigenous "Night Aliens" attack Voyager, furious at all intruders. Janeway sees an opportunity to atone by using Voyager to block the waste freighters and help the aliens destroy the hazardous dumping infrastructure, even though doing so could leave Voyager trapped in the void indefinitely.
StorySections.Act IV: Over the objections of her crew, Janeway plans to stay behind with the freighter and hold the aliens’ enemies off while Voyager escapes. Chakotay, Tuvok and others refuse to accept her self-sacrifice and devise a strategy that both protects the aliens and brings Voyager safely out of the darkness.
StorySections.Tag: As stars finally return to the viewscreen, Janeway re-emerges from isolation to share a quiet moment with Chakotay on the bridge, acknowledging that she still carries guilt but will face it with her crew instead of alone.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway sinks into a severe depressive spell in the oppressive darkness, haunted by the belief that she doomed her crew by destroying the Caretaker’s array, but ultimately channels that guilt into a determination to protect the indigenous species exploited by the Malon.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay recognizes that Janeway is trying to punish herself and patiently, firmly draws her back toward the crew, arguing that they have chosen to stand with her and that she doesn’t get to decide her fate alone.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok offers quiet counsel to Janeway, acknowledging her guilt while reminding her of the logic behind her original choice and urging her to remain in command rather than retreat into isolation.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom, bored and restless, throws himself into holodeck adventures and later the investigation of the Malon freighter, reflecting the crew’s need for distractions when they are cut off from any sense of progress.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix tries to keep morale up with games and entertainment, but also confides that the absolute darkness frightens him, echoing the crew’s deeper fear that they could be stuck in the void forever.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is unsettled by the lack of external stimuli but remains focused on analyzing the void and the aliens’ attacks, once again providing essential tactical insight even as she adjusts to the crew’s psychological strain.
EntitySummaries.Emck: Emck, the Malon captain, is a pragmatic polluter who sees dumping toxic waste into the void as a necessary evil of his trade and dismisses the indigenous lifeforms as collateral damage.
EntitySummaries.Malon crew members: The Malon crew represent an industrial culture willing to endanger others for profit and convenience, clinging to their waste-dumping operations despite Voyager’s objections.
EntitySummaries.Night Aliens representative: The Night Aliens’ emissary channels centuries of pain and anger at the Malon’s poisoning of their home, lashing out at any outsiders and forcing Janeway to confront the cost of looking away from such suffering.
EntitySummaries.Malon waste dumping: The Malon’s toxic dumping practices are a systemic antagonist that threaten an entire ecosystem, personifying environmental exploitation in the Delta Quadrant.
EntitySummaries.Janeway's depression and guilt: Janeway’s guilt and depression act as internal antagonists, sapping her will to lead and nearly driving her to a fatal act of self-sacrifice.
EntitySummaries.The starless void: The lightless region itself is an environmental antagonist, magnifying isolation, boredom and despair as weeks pass without stars, contact or visible progress.

ContinuityNotes: Night introduces the Malon, a recurring Delta Quadrant species built around industrial waste disposal.
The episode revisits Janeway’s decision from the pilot to destroy the Caretaker’s array, making her guilt and its impact on her mental health explicit.
The starless "Void" concept foreshadows later episodes about empty or dangerous regions of space that test Voyager’s morale.
Janeway’s willingness to risk herself alone continues a pattern seen in earlier seasons, while the crew’s resistance to that pattern shows how their relationships have evolved.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores depression, isolation and leadership burnout under extreme conditions.
It examines environmental exploitation and the ethics of using "empty" spaces as dumping grounds when unseen life may be affected.
Night emphasizes the importance of shared responsibility, challenging the idea that one leader alone should bear all blame for hard decisions.
The story suggests that hope and connection can return even after a period of emotional darkness.
BehindTheScenes: Night was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and directed by David Livingston.
The episode serves as the season 5 premiere and re-centers Janeway’s internal conflict as a major character thread.
The Malon, introduced here, were designed as a visually striking species tied to themes of pollution and industrial waste.

Title: Drone
Summary: A transporter accident merges Seven of Nine’s Borg nanoprobes with the Doctor’s 29th-century mobile emitter, creating a highly advanced Borg drone who rapidly matures, latches onto Seven as a mentor and must choose between individuality and the Collective when the Borg come to claim him.

StorySections.Teaser: During a routine away mission, a malfunction exposes the Doctor’s 29th-century mobile emitter and some of Seven’s nanoprobes to a transporter buffer, quietly setting off an uncontrolled assimilation process in a nearby science lab.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager’s crew discovers that lab equipment has been reconfigured into a gestation chamber for a Borg maturation pod. Before they can shut it down, an infant drone forms inside—a hybrid built from Seven’s DNA and 29th-century technology.
StorySections.Act II: The child grows at an accelerated rate into a fully grown drone who calls himself "One" and instinctively recognizes Seven and the Collective. Seven is reluctant to take on a parental role, but Janeway insists that she help this new being learn individuality aboard Voyager.
StorySections.Act III: As One’s advanced technology broadcasts his existence, a Borg sphere homes in on Voyager. The Collective demands his return, seeing him as a valuable asset, while One slowly realizes that his very presence endangers the crew who raised him.
StorySections.Act IV: When the Borg attack, One transports himself and the sphere into a nebula, sacrificing his life to protect Voyager. Dying in sickbay, he tells Seven that he was never truly alone because he had her and the crew, leaving her with a painful but profound lesson about family.
StorySections.Tag: Seven sits quietly in a cargo bay, grappling with her grief and the knowledge that she helped bring a new life into the world—even if it existed only briefly—before returning to her duties with a slightly deeper understanding of what it means to care for another.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced into a quasi-maternal role she never wanted, teaching One about individuality and boundaries even as she fears that he will choose the Collective over the difficult path she herself is walking.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor feels responsible for One’s existence because his mobile emitter provided the advanced technology that shaped the drone, and he advocates for treating One as a patient and a person rather than an experiment.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway sees in One an opportunity to prove that even a Borg-born life can be guided toward free will and compassion, and she stands firm in refusing the Borg’s demand that they surrender him.
EntitySummaries.One: One is a uniquely advanced drone whose accelerated growth leaves him with childlike questions and adult capabilities; he ultimately chooses self-sacrifice over assimilation, demonstrating the very individuality the Borg fear.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok helps instruct One in discipline and control, using Vulcan meditation techniques to manage the overwhelming sensations that come with his advanced senses.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry interacts with One as a colleague and friend, showing how quickly some crewmembers accept the new drone as part of their community.
EntitySummaries.Borg sphere: The Borg sphere that responds to One’s inadvertent signal serves as the main external antagonist, representing the Collective’s relentless desire to reclaim and exploit him.
EntitySummaries.Collective's call to One: The psychic pull of the Collective is an intangible antagonist that tempts One with belonging and power while threatening to erase his emerging self.
EntitySummaries.Uncontrolled nanotech maturation process: The unintended maturation pod illustrates the dangers of mixing alien technology and future hardware, creating a lifeform no one planned for and cannot easily protect.

ContinuityNotes: Drone builds on Seven’s arc by having her guide another being away from the Borg, reflecting her own journey toward individuality.
The episode reuses the Doctor’s 29th-century mobile emitter from the earlier story "Future's End."
Borg technology and maturation chambers seen in previous episodes are incorporated into Voyager’s context.
One’s sacrifice reinforces Voyager’s recurring theme of individuals choosing loyalty to the crew over the Collective.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores parenthood and responsibility through Seven’s reluctant bond with One.
It examines free will versus predestination, as One must decide whether he is bound to the Borg by design.
Drone raises questions about the ethics of creating life unintentionally and then trying to shape its path.
The story underlines that even a brief existence can have meaning when defined by choice and sacrifice.
BehindTheScenes: Drone was written by Bryan Fuller and Harry Doc Kloor and directed by Les Landau.
Actor J. Paul Boehmer portrays One, giving the character a mix of innocence and formidable presence.
The episode is often praised as one of Voyager’s strongest Borg-focused character pieces.

Title: Extreme Risk
Summary: As Voyager races to retrieve a new "Delta Flyer" shuttle from dangerous atmosphere-skimming tests before the Malon can steal its technology, B'Elanna Torres secretly engages in increasingly self-destructive holodeck programs, forcing her friends to confront her unresolved grief and depression.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager detects a probe that could lead to valuable new technology, but while the crew works, B'Elanna runs a holodeck program with the safeties off, calmly allowing herself to be pummeled and nearly killed in a simulated engineering accident.
StorySections.Act I: Tom and Chakotay notice B'Elanna’s injuries and strange detachment, but she brushes off concern and hides behind sarcasm. At the same time, the crew decides to design and build a new specialized shuttle, the Delta Flyer, to tackle the turbulent atmosphere where the probe has fallen.
StorySections.Act II: As the engineering team works on the Flyer, B'Elanna withdraws emotionally and sabotages her own integration into the project, skipping meals and secretly returning to punishing holodeck programs that border on suicidal behavior.
StorySections.Act III: Chakotay confronts B'Elanna, uncovering that news of the Maquis’ annihilation by the Dominion—which the crew learned about earlier—has left her numb and self-destructive. He forces her to acknowledge that she is deliberately courting death instead of grieving.
StorySections.Act IV: When the mission to retrieve the probe and test the Delta Flyer turns dangerous, B'Elanna must push through her depression to make critical repairs under extreme pressure, relying on her friends instead of rejecting their help. Her choice to live and fight alongside them marks the first step toward healing.
StorySections.Tag: After the Flyer’s successful mission, B'Elanna joins Tom and the others in celebrating in the mess hall, still hurting but more present, quietly committing to keep working on her emotional wounds instead of running from them.

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna numbs herself to the grief of losing the Maquis by flirting with death in dangerous holodeck programs and reckless behavior, only beginning to heal when she admits her pain and allows others to help her carry it.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom senses that something is wrong with B'Elanna and tries to reach her through banter and shared work on the Delta Flyer, revealing how much he cares even as she pushes him away.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay, who also lost friends in the Maquis, confronts B'Elanna directly, recognizing the signs of self-destructive behavior and offering a tough but compassionate intervention.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway backs the ambitious Delta Flyer project and implicitly trusts B'Elanna’s abilities, later supporting Chakotay’s efforts to address the chief engineer’s dangerous coping strategies.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry throws himself into designing the Flyer, serving as a reminder of the enthusiasm and camaraderie that B'Elanna is temporarily shutting out.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven contributes technical expertise to the Flyer and provides blunt, unvarnished observations about B'Elanna’s erratic behavior, underlining that even someone as direct as Seven can see she is in trouble.
EntitySummaries.Malon captain: The Malon captain represents the external competition and danger, willing to risk deadly atmospheric conditions to claim the probe and its technology for profit.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna's depression and self-harm: B'Elanna’s depression and penchant for self-harm are internal antagonists, nearly costing Voyager a brilliant engineer and costing her the relationships that might help her heal.
EntitySummaries.Malon competitors: The Malon serve as opportunistic antagonists, more concerned with their own gain than the safety of Voyager’s crew or the environmental damage they cause.
EntitySummaries.Gas giant atmospheric turbulence: The chaotic atmosphere of the gas giant is a physical antagonist that tests the limits of the Delta Flyer and B'Elanna’s willingness to fight for her own survival.

ContinuityNotes: Extreme Risk pays off earlier revelations that the Dominion destroyed the Maquis, connecting B'Elanna’s emotional arc to wider Star Trek continuity.
The episode introduces the Delta Flyer, a customized shuttle that becomes a recurring feature on Voyager.
B'Elanna’s struggle with depression adds depth to her long-standing internal conflict about identity and belonging.
The Malon continue to appear as recurring industrial antagonists introduced earlier in the season.
ThematicNotes: The episode deals directly with depression and self-harm, showing how trauma can manifest as emotional numbness and reckless behavior.
It emphasizes the importance of confronting grief rather than burying it under work or risk-taking.
Extreme Risk explores how friends and comrades can intervene with a mix of empathy and honesty when someone is in danger from their own choices.
The story contrasts technological innovation with emotional stagnation, suggesting that progress in one area cannot substitute for healing in another.
BehindTheScenes: Extreme Risk was written by Kenneth Biller from a story by Andre Bormanis and directed by Cliff Bole.
The episode was notable at the time for tackling depression and self-harm more explicitly than many Star Trek stories.
Designing and introducing the Delta Flyer allowed the production to showcase a new hero shuttle set and model.

Title: In the Flesh
Summary: Voyager discovers that a seemingly ordinary Starfleet training facility is actually a sophisticated simulation run by Species 8472, who are studying humans in preparation for a possible invasion, forcing Janeway to attempt an unprecedented peace with beings who once nearly destroyed the Borg.

StorySections.Teaser: An away team beams down to what appears to be Starfleet Academy, complete with cadets in uniform and San Francisco scenery, only to learn that Voyager is supposedly in the Alpha Quadrant—something Janeway knows is impossible.
StorySections.Act I: Tuvok and Chakotay infiltrate the facility and discover minute errors in procedure and behavior, eventually revealing that the "humans" are actually 8472 operatives in painstaking human disguise, practicing for covert infiltration of Earth.
StorySections.Act II: One of the trainees, posing as a young man named "Raymond Booth," befriends Chakotay, while Voyager learns that the facility is one of many such simulations. Seven of Nine warns that Species 8472 still regards all other life as a potential threat after their near-war with the Federation’s ally, the Borg.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway decides that another war with 8472 would be catastrophic and opts for diplomacy, arranging a clandestine meeting where she offers to prove that Starfleet has no intention of invading fluidic space. Tension rises as both sides suspect a trap.
StorySections.Act IV: After a standoff in which weapons are drawn and 8472 momentarily reverts to its true form, cooler heads prevail. Janeway and the 8472 commander agree to end their respective infiltration and biological weapons programs, establishing a wary truce.
StorySections.Tag: As the 8472 training base is dismantled, Booth says a guarded farewell to Chakotay, leaving Voyager with the knowledge that an unimaginably powerful species now has at least one channel of communication instead of only mutual fear.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway chooses diplomacy over preemptive strikes against a species capable of annihilating entire Borg cubes, believing that honest communication may resolve a conflict built on mutual misunderstanding and fear.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s rapport with Booth turns a spy mission into a genuine connection, demonstrating how personal relationships can soften even the hardest strategic stances.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok keeps a cautious eye on security during the infiltration and negotiations, underscoring how fragile the situation is when both sides are prepared for war.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s knowledge of 8472 from the Borg perspective frames them as an existential threat, making her initially skeptical of Janeway’s diplomatic gamble.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor assists in analyzing 8472’s human disguises and offers medical insights into the strain of maintaining such forms, adding another layer to their motives and vulnerabilities.
EntitySummaries.Raymond Booth / 8472 operative: Booth is an 8472 field agent who has immersed himself in human guise and customs; his evolving respect for Chakotay helps nudge his commander toward accepting a truce.
EntitySummaries.8472 trainees: The trainees at the faux Starfleet Academy illustrate how seriously 8472 takes the perceived threat of the Federation, dedicating resources to perfectly mimicking humans for potential infiltration.
EntitySummaries.Species 8472 invasion plans: The covert preparations for possible invasion serve as the main external antagonist, built on the assumption that the Federation is a future enemy.
EntitySummaries.Mutual mistrust between 8472 and Federat: Deep-seated mistrust functions as an abstract antagonist, making every gesture appear suspect and nearly derailing talks before they begin.
EntitySummaries.Biological weapons projects: The biological weapons research on both sides stands as a disturbing reflection of how fear can justify extremism, even among societies that see themselves as honorable.

ContinuityNotes: In the Flesh revisits Species 8472, first seen in the two-part story "Scorpion."
The episode references the earlier Borg–8472 war and Janeway’s controversial alliance with the Borg.
Species 8472’s ability to mimic human forms is shown in detail for the first time.
The fragile truce established here helps explain why 8472 does not appear as a major antagonist later in the series.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the dangers of preemptive paranoia, showing how both sides nearly escalate to war based on worst-case assumptions.
It emphasizes the value of cultural understanding and person-to-person diplomacy in defusing existential threats.
In the Flesh critiques militarized training that dehumanizes the perceived enemy, even when done in the name of defense.
The story suggests that even the most alien beings can find common ground if they are willing to question their own narratives.
BehindTheScenes: In the Flesh was written by Nick Sagan and directed by Terry Windell.
The faux Starfleet Academy sets allowed the production to revisit familiar visual territory within Voyager’s Delta Quadrant context.
The episode gave actors a chance to portray 8472 operatives wrestling with human mannerisms and emotions.

Title: Once Upon a Time
Summary: When a shuttle carrying Samantha Wildman and other officers disappears in a turbulent atmosphere, Neelix struggles to support Samantha’s daughter Naomi through the crisis by immersing her in a holodeck fairy-tale world, all while confronting his own unresolved trauma about losing family.

StorySections.Teaser: On the holodeck, Neelix joins Naomi Wildman in a colorful children’s program starring the whimsical character Flotter, laughing and playing until a red alert forces him to leave abruptly.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager loses contact with a shuttle piloted by Paris and carrying Samantha Wildman during a survey of a storm-wracked planet. While search efforts begin, Janeway and Chakotay decide to delay telling Naomi the full truth, asking Neelix to keep her distracted.
StorySections.Act II: Neelix throws himself into extended Flotter adventures with Naomi, struggling to keep the game light while his own anxiety mounts. Flashbacks reveal his memories of losing his family on Rinax, explaining why the thought of Naomi becoming an orphan terrifies him.
StorySections.Act III: As Naomi senses that something is wrong, Neelix begins to falter under the strain of lying to her. Meanwhile, the shuttle crew fights to stay alive long enough for Voyager to lock onto their position through the planet’s storms.
StorySections.Act IV: Voyager finally locates and rescues Samantha and the others, but Neelix’s guilt over hiding the situation from Naomi leads him to an emotional confession. Naomi, hurt but resilient, insists that she wants to know the truth in the future and accepts Neelix’s promise to be honest with her.
StorySections.Tag: Back in the holodeck forest, Neelix and Naomi resume their adventures with Flotter, this time with a new understanding between them about fear, honesty and the fact that stories can help them face hard realities together.

EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix is torn between protecting Naomi from pain and his promise to be honest with her, and his attempts to shield her force him to relive the loss of his own family before he learns to trust her strength.
EntitySummaries.Naomi Wildman: Naomi idolizes Neelix and throws herself into Flotter’s stories, but she is perceptive enough to sense when adults are hiding something, demonstrating a child’s capacity to face difficult truths when treated with respect.
EntitySummaries.Samantha Wildman: Samantha’s peril on the shuttle underscores Naomi’s vulnerability, and her determination to survive is driven in part by the desire to return to her daughter.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must balance her protective instincts with the need for honesty, ultimately supporting Neelix’s choice to tell Naomi the truth once the immediate danger has passed.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom pilots the imperiled shuttle and uses piloting skill and improvisation to keep the crew alive in the storm until Voyager can lock onto them.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok participates in the rescue effort and later offers Neelix a calm perspective on fear and parental responsibility, as only a Vulcan can.
EntitySummaries.Flotter T. Water III: Flotter is a whimsical holodeck character who initially functions as pure escapism but becomes part of how Naomi processes the concepts of danger and loss.
EntitySummaries.Trevis: Trevis, another holodeck character, adds friction and humor to the fairy-tale world, highlighting Naomi’s imagination and resilience.
EntitySummaries.Other holodeck characters: The supporting holodeck figures populate Naomi’s fantasy realm, illustrating how stories and play can help children navigate real-life anxieties.
EntitySummaries.Rinax trauma in Neelix's past: Neelix’s unresolved trauma from the loss of his family on Rinax is an internal antagonist, driving his overprotectiveness and his fear of failing Naomi.
EntitySummaries.Atmospheric storms on the planet: The fierce storms around the shuttle are environmental antagonists that make rescue difficult and heighten the stakes of Naomi’s potential loss.
EntitySummaries.Fear of losing family: The shared fear of losing loved ones, both for Neelix and Naomi, is a psychological antagonist that shapes their choices throughout the episode.

ContinuityNotes: Once Upon a Time revisits Neelix’s backstory, particularly the loss of his family during the Metreon cascade on Rinax.
Naomi Wildman, previously seen as a younger child, is further developed as an ongoing presence on Voyager.
The Flotter holoprogram becomes a recurring element associated with Naomi’s childhood on the ship.
The episode adds emotional depth to Neelix’s role as a surrogate uncle and caregiver to children aboard Voyager.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how adults use stories to protect children from harsh realities—and when that protection becomes dishonest.
It examines grief and survivor’s guilt through Neelix’s difficulty in facing the possibility of another child becoming an orphan.
Once Upon a Time highlights children’s resilience and their need for truthful, age-appropriate communication during crises.
The story underscores that fantasy and play can be tools for processing trauma, not just escaping it.
BehindTheScenes: Once Upon a Time was written by Michael Taylor and directed by Allan Kroeker.
The Flotter character and holodeck forest were created to give Voyager a unique children’s program distinct from Next Generation’s educational holodecks.
The episode is often cited as a key installment for understanding Neelix’s growth as a caregiver and mentor.

Title: Timeless
Summary: Fifteen years in the future, a guilt-ridden Harry Kim and Chakotay risk everything to alter history after a failed quantum slipstream test leaves Voyager frozen in ice and her crew dead, forcing Harry to confront his greatest mistake and attempt to save the ship through a temporal message to his younger self.

StorySections.Teaser: On an icy world, an older Chakotay and Harry Kim uncover Voyager buried beneath the surface, its crew frozen where they died years earlier, while Harry obsessively scans for signs that his long-planned temporal rescue can still work.
StorySections.Act I: Flashbacks reveal Voyager’s attempt to use stolen quantum slipstream technology to get home, with Harry calculating the flight path that was supposed to keep the ship stable in the dangerous slipstream corridor. In the altered future, Harry blames himself for miscalculations that caused Voyager to crash while he and Chakotay escaped in the Delta Flyer.
StorySections.Act II: In the future, Chakotay and Harry steal the recovered Doctor’s program and a Federation ship, determined to transmit a phase-corrected message back along a Borg data conduit to Harry’s younger self. Captain Geordi La Forge of the USS Challenger pursues them, ordered to stop their unauthorized time-tampering.
StorySections.Act III: As Starfleet closes in, future-Harry refines the correction that might save Voyager, all while haunted by memories of the day the ship died and the friends he abandoned. On past-Voyager, the crew prepares for the slipstream flight, unaware that a temporal intervention is about to rewrite their fate.
StorySections.Act IV: Under fire from the Challenger, future-Harry successfully sends the corrected phase data into the past. Young Harry receives the anomalous transmission mid-flight, realizes his original calculations were wrong and convinces Janeway to break Voyager out of the slipstream before it crashes, sacrificing the shortcut home but preserving the ship.
StorySections.Tag: In the restored timeline, Harry and Chakotay review the mission’s disappointing results, unaware of the erased future—until Harry receives a mysterious, garbled log from his older self, leaving him with a vague sense of gratitude and renewed determination to earn his place on the bridge.

EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Future-Harry is consumed by guilt over the slipstream disaster he blames on his miscalculations, driving him to break every rule to send a corrective message back in time and redeem both himself and Voyager; his younger self gains an unexpected second chance from a man he will never fully remember being.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay partners with Harry in the altered future, supporting the younger man’s quest for redemption while refusing to let his own grief over Voyager’s loss harden into bitterness, and ultimately risks his freedom to see the plan through.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway, in the past timeline, embraces the risky slipstream test as a possible route home but remains flexible enough to abort the attempt when Harry presents new data, exemplifying her willingness to sacrifice opportunity for her crew’s safety.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor spends fifteen years as a salvaged program in the future, then joins Harry and Chakotay’s mission as both conscience and accomplice, later resuming his role aboard the restored Voyager with no memory of the lost timeline.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven assists with the original slipstream calculations and later helps interpret the strange data coming from the future, once again acting as the bridge between human intuition and cold Borg-enhanced analysis.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom co-pilots the slipstream flight and becomes one of the many casualties in the erased timeline, his death serving as a particularly painful memory that drives future-Harry’s determination.
EntitySummaries.Geordi La Forge: Now a Starfleet captain, Geordi represents the Federation’s cautious stance on temporal meddling, pursuing Harry and Chakotay even as he sympathizes with their desire to undo a tragic mistake.
EntitySummaries.USS Challenger officers: The officers of the Challenger support Geordi’s efforts to stop unauthorized time travel, embodying Starfleet’s institutional resistance to altering history.
EntitySummaries.Future Chakotay's partner Tessa Omond: Tessa aids Chakotay and Harry despite knowing their plan may erase her relationship with Chakotay from existence, underscoring the personal sacrifices made in the name of restoring Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Quantum slipstream instability: The inherent instability of the slipstream corridor is a technological antagonist, turning Voyager’s hope for a quick journey home into a deadly trap when even minor errors cascade into disaster.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim's guilt and perfectionism: Harry’s unresolved guilt and need to correct his own failure are internal antagonists that almost push him too far, yet also fuel the courage needed to attempt a temporal fix.
EntitySummaries.Temporal regulations and Starfleet pursu: Starfleet’s temporal regulations and the Challenger’s mission to enforce them serve as institutional antagonists, creating a tense conflict between preserving the timeline and correcting a terrible but localized tragedy.

ContinuityNotes: Timeless revisits the quantum slipstream technology first seen in "Hope and Fear" and shows its continued dangers.
The episode features a future cameo by Geordi La Forge, linking Voyager to The Next Generation era of Starfleet.
Harry’s altered-future guilt and redemption arc add depth to a character often portrayed as inexperienced and unlucky.
The final, partial message from future-Harry nods to Star Trek’s broader tradition of time-bending moral dilemmas.
ThematicNotes: The story explores survivor’s guilt and the obsessive need to fix a single catastrophic mistake.
It examines the ethics of altering the timeline, weighing personal redemption against larger temporal stability.
Timeless emphasizes that accepting a longer, harder road can be nobler than seizing a dangerous shortcut.
The episode underscores that sometimes the greatest acts of heroism are erased from history, known only to those who briefly lived them.
BehindTheScenes: Timeless was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and directed by LeVar Burton, who also plays Geordi La Forge.
The episode is widely regarded as one of Voyager’s best, particularly for its focus on Harry Kim and its cinematic visuals of the frozen Voyager.
Burton’s direction and the ambitious visual effects helped give the episode a feature-film quality within a television budget.

Title: Infinite Regress
Summary: When a dormant Borg vinculum begins broadcasting nearby, Seven of Nine is overwhelmed by the personalities of drones once linked to the Collective, causing her to cycle through dozens of conflicting identities while the crew races to save her mind and shut down the device.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager encounters a derelict ship filled with dead aliens whose technology bears Borg assimilation scars, and soon after, Seven abruptly shifts behavior and speech patterns, insisting she is a frightened child seeking her parents.
StorySections.Act I: Seven continues to change personas without warning—becoming a Klingon warrior, a Bolian engineer, a terrified girl and more—baffling the crew. The Doctor and Tuvok determine that multiple dormant Borg imprints are surfacing in her mind.
StorySections.Act II: Scanning the region, Voyager discovers a Borg vinculum at the heart of a debris field, still functioning and broadcasting a signal meant to purge individuality from the Collective. For Seven, however, it is doing the opposite, flooding her with the residual identities of assimilated drones.
StorySections.Act III: As Seven’s psyche frays under the onslaught of hundreds of voices, the Doctor proposes severing the connection through a risky neural interface, while an alien species whose ship was destroyed by the vinculum arrives seeking to capture or destroy it themselves.
StorySections.Act IV: Tuvok joins Seven in a mind-meld-assisted interface to help her navigate the chaotic identities. With his guidance and the Doctor’s adjustments, Seven isolates and rejects the foreign personas, reasserting her sense of self as the vinculum is finally deactivated.
StorySections.Tag: Recovering in sickbay, Seven expresses lingering unease at how fragile her individuality proved to be, while Janeway and Tuvok reassure her that the very act of choosing who she is marks how far she has come from the Collective.

GuestCharacters: Alien commander from the destroyed species

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced to confront the literal voices of those assimilated by the Borg, her sense of self nearly drowned by a chorus of stolen lives until she learns to assert her own identity over the chaos.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor acts as Seven’s primary physician and advocate, devising medical and technological strategies to disentangle her from the vinculum’s influence while respecting her emerging individuality.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok employs a mind meld to anchor Seven’s consciousness, using Vulcan discipline to help her navigate and compartmentalize the invading personalities.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway balances the need to help Seven with the danger posed by the vinculum and the vengeful aliens, ultimately committing Voyager’s resources to saving her crewmate rather than simply destroying the device and fleeing.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay offers tactical support and provides a calm presence as Seven cycles through disruptive personas, reinforcing the crew’s commitment to her as one of their own.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix helps manage the crew’s unease and provides comfort during Seven’s episodes, reinforcing his role as morale officer even in bizarre circumstances.
EntitySummaries.Alien commander from the destroyed speci: The alien commander is driven by rage at the Borg technology that destroyed his people, viewing Seven and the vinculum as acceptable collateral damage in his quest for vengeance.
EntitySummaries.Various assimilated personas (via Seven): The many personas that manifest through Seven personify the countless lives consumed by the Borg, each briefly reclaiming a voice at the cost of Seven’s stability.
EntitySummaries.Borg vinculum: The vinculum is a central antagonist: a device meant to suppress individuality in the Collective that instead weaponizes it against Seven by flooding her with incompatible identities.
EntitySummaries.Residual Borg personalities: The lingering imprints of assimilated drones are psychological antagonists, threatening to fragment Seven’s consciousness beyond repair.
EntitySummaries.Alien faction seeking revenge: The alien faction complicates Voyager’s efforts, seeing the vinculum’s destruction—and Seven’s potential death—as just retribution rather than tragedy.

ContinuityNotes: Infinite Regress deepens the lore of Borg infrastructure by introducing the vinculum, a core processing unit for drone consciousness.
The episode continues Seven’s journey toward stable individuality by testing how easily it can be disrupted.
The variety of personas Seven exhibits lets the series showcase the breadth of species assimilated by the Borg.
Tuvok’s use of a mind meld reflects ongoing Vulcan traditions carried into the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores identity as something constructed and maintained rather than guaranteed, especially for someone shaped by the Borg.
It examines the psychological fallout of assimilation, suggesting that the victims’ echoes persist even after physical control ends.
Infinite Regress deals with the ethics of revenge, contrasting Voyager’s desire to save Seven with the aliens’ willingness to sacrifice her.
The story underscores the power of discipline, friendship and choice in reclaiming one’s sense of self.
BehindTheScenes: Infinite Regress was written by Robert J. Doherty and directed by David Livingston.
Jeri Ryan’s performance cycling through multiple personas is frequently cited as a standout showcase of her range.
The episode’s concept allowed the production to explore different alien mannerisms without building full new guest casts for each.

Title: Nothing Human
Summary: When an alien parasite entwines itself around B'Elanna Torres’s vital organs and no one knows how to remove it safely, the Doctor creates a holographic consultant based on a brilliant but notorious Cardassian exobiologist, sparking a moral crisis over whether knowledge born of atrocities can be ethically used.

StorySections.Teaser: A routine first-contact mission turns deadly when an energy-based lifeform latches onto B'Elanna and infiltrates her nervous system, leaving her writhing in pain and unresponsive in sickbay.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor and Paris are unable to treat the alien parasite with standard methods without killing B'Elanna. To gain insight, the Doctor constructs a hologram patterned on renowned Cardassian scientist Crell Moset, whose research once saved countless lives.
StorySections.Act II: As Moset assists with the case, Bajoran and Maquis crewmembers recognize his name and accuse him of having conducted horrific experiments on prisoners during the Occupation, making his very presence in sickbay an affront to their memories and beliefs.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway faces protests from the crew, particularly from Torres’s friends, who argue that using Moset’s techniques legitimizes his crimes. The Doctor, however, sees Moset’s program as a purely informational tool, separate from the man who inspired it.
StorySections.Act IV: With B'Elanna’s life hanging in the balance, Janeway authorizes the Doctor to proceed but insists that any treatment derived from Moset’s work be fully documented and ethically scrutinized.
