After the procedure succeeds, the Doctor chooses to delete the Moset program, unwilling to keep a copy of a persona built on suffering.
StorySections.Tag: B'Elanna recovers, disturbed to learn that her life was saved by knowledge born of atrocities, while the Doctor contemplates the moral weight of his decision and vows to consider the origins of medical data as carefully as its applications.

Antagonists: Legacy of Crell Moset's war crimes

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is torn between his duty to save B'Elanna and the moral implications of using knowledge derived from torture, ultimately saving her life but deleting Moset’s program in recognition that clinical detachment cannot erase the origins of the data.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna lies unconscious for much of the crisis, but her identity as a former Maquis and ally of Bajor makes her the focal point of a debate over whether she would want to be saved by techniques developed through atrocities.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must make a captain’s choice under pressure, weighing the crew’s outrage against her responsibility to protect B'Elanna’s life, and later insists on confronting the ethical fallout rather than pretending it did not happen.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom works desperately to assist in B'Elanna’s treatment while wrestling with the knowledge that her salvation may come from a source he finds repugnant.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides a logical perspective on separating data from its origins, even as he acknowledges the emotional weight of the crew’s objections.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay voices the Maquis perspective, arguing that using Moset’s legacy is a betrayal of those who died under Cardassian cruelty.
EntitySummaries.Crell Moset hologram: The holographic Moset exudes charm and scientific curiosity while embodying the moral blindness of a war criminal who sees his victims as mere data points, forcing the crew to question whether such a persona deserves any place on Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Energy-based alien lifeform: The alien organism is a biological antagonist whose method of "bonding" nearly kills B'Elanna, yet it remains an ignorant creature rather than a willful villain.
EntitySummaries.Alien parasite: As a medical antagonist, the parasite provides the life-or-death urgency that makes Moset’s unethical expertise tempting despite its horrific origins.
EntitySummaries.Legacy of Crell Moset's war crimes: The enduring trauma of Moset’s victims and those who remember them functions as a moral antagonist, challenging the crew to reconcile survival with principle.
EntitySummaries.Ethical conflict among Voyager's crew: The crew’s divided opinions are a social antagonist, threatening cohesion as they argue over whether ends can justify means when those means are stained by atrocity.

ContinuityNotes: Nothing Human draws on the larger Star Trek backstory of the Cardassian Occupation of Bajor and the atrocities committed there.
The episode continues Voyager’s tradition of exploring medical ethics through the Doctor’s evolving understanding of personhood and morality.
B'Elanna’s Maquis history gives added weight to the question of whether she would consent to Moset’s involvement.
The story echoes debates in Deep Space Nine about Cardassian war crimes and accountability.
ThematicNotes: The episode directly tackles the ethics of using data derived from unethical or criminal experimentation.
It examines whether separating information from its source is morally possible or if origins permanently taint its use.
Nothing Human explores the limits of utilitarian reasoning in medicine—saving one life versus honoring countless others who suffered.
The story challenges the idea that scientific brilliance excuses moral depravity.
BehindTheScenes: Nothing Human was written by Jeri Taylor and directed by David Livingston.
The Crell Moset character invited comparisons to real-world figures like Nazi doctors whose research sparked ongoing ethical debates.
The episode is often noted for pushing Voyager into more morally ambiguous territory than usual.

Title: Thirty Days
Summary: Tom Paris is stripped of rank and sentenced to thirty days in the brig after disobeying orders to carry out an unauthorized mission to save an ocean world from ecological collapse, and he spends his confinement writing a reflective "letter" to his father that recounts how he chose principle over protocol.

StorySections.Teaser: Tom sits alone in Voyager’s brig, beginning a personal log addressed to his father, Admiral Paris, to explain how he—once again—ended up in a cell.
StorySections.Act I: Flashbacks reveal Voyager’s arrival at an unusual planet composed almost entirely of a vast ocean, where the crew meets a bureaucratic government that has been exploiting an ancient reactor at the world’s core, destabilizing the environment.
StorySections.Act II: Fascinated by the ocean and its mysterious deep-dwelling lifeforms, Tom leads a mission in the Delta Flyer to investigate the reactor and confirms that its continued use will eventually destroy the planet. The ruling council downplays the danger and refuses to change course.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway orders Tom to stand down and respect the planet’s sovereignty, but he cannot accept watching an entire world die from preventable negligence. He defies orders, steals the Delta Flyer and attempts to sabotage the reactor to force a shutdown.
StorySections.Act IV: Voyager stops Tom’s unauthorized mission before he can complete it. The local government agrees only to minimal reforms, leaving the planet’s long-term fate uncertain. Janeway, bound by Starfleet principles, demotes Tom and sentences him to thirty days in the brig for his actions.
StorySections.Tag: After serving his sentence, Tom delivers his finished "letter" log to be transmitted when possible, uncertain how his father will react but quietly proud that, this time, his imprisonment came from standing up for something he believed in.

EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s love of the sea and sense of environmental responsibility drive him to defy Starfleet protocol in a bid to save an ocean world, leading to his demotion but also marking a turning point where his rebellion is rooted in conscience rather than selfishness.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway sympathizes with Tom’s motives but enforces Starfleet discipline, punishing his insubordination to preserve the chain of command and the principle of non-interference.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven provides analysis on the reactor and the planet’s future, offering a cold cost-benefit view that contrasts with Tom’s emotional response.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok oversees Tom’s confinement, maintaining Vulcan calm and providing a sounding board for Tom’s reflections during his time in the brig.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry is caught between loyalty to his friend and his duty to the captain, helping highlight the broader impact of Tom’s choice on the crew.
EntitySummaries.Admiral Owen Paris: Though only present through Tom’s imagined responses, Owen Paris looms large as the father whose approval Tom has long sought, making the "letter" in the brig a key step in Tom defining himself on his own terms.
EntitySummaries.Planetary council leader: The council leader embodies bureaucratic inertia, more concerned with short-term stability and political optics than long-term environmental survival.
EntitySummaries.Environmental minister: The minister recognizes the seriousness of the crisis but is constrained by the council’s reluctance to act, illustrating the challenges of effecting change within a cautious government.
EntitySummaries.Ocean-dwelling lifeform (via scans and i: The mysterious lifeforms in the deep ocean serve as silent victims of the reactor’s damage, reinforcing the stakes of Tom’s unauthorized intervention.
EntitySummaries.Planetary government's complacency: The government’s refusal to act decisively is a systemic antagonist, showing how denial and convenience can doom an entire world.
EntitySummaries.Ocean reactor instability: The failing reactor is a technological antagonist whose hidden danger threatens to trigger a catastrophic chain reaction in the planet’s core.
EntitySummaries.Tom's impulsive defiance of orders: Tom’s decision to ignore Janeway’s command is an internal antagonist, creating consequences for himself and testing the boundaries of acceptable disobedience in Starfleet.

ContinuityNotes: Thirty Days further develops Tom’s relationship with his father, previously referenced in earlier seasons.
The episode cements Tom’s demotion to ensign and his loss of bridge privileges, changes that persist for a significant stretch of the series.
Environmental themes echo earlier Trek stories dealing with ecological negligence on a planetary scale.
The Delta Flyer continues to serve as Voyager’s go-to specialized shuttle for hazardous missions.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores civil disobedience and the moral tension between obeying orders and following one’s conscience.
It examines environmental responsibility and the frustration of dealing with governments that prioritize short-term comfort over long-term survival.
Thirty Days highlights personal growth, contrasting Tom’s present principled defiance with his earlier, more self-centered rebellions.
The framing device of the letter underscores themes of legacy, parental expectations and self-definition.
BehindTheScenes: Thirty Days was written by Scott Miller and directed by Winrich Kolbe.
The underwater visuals and sets were designed to give the episode a distinct aquatic feel within Voyager’s usual spacefaring palette.
The decision to demote Tom Paris provided the writers with new character dynamics to explore in subsequent episodes.

Title: Counterpoint
Summary: Traversing the territory of a telepath-hostile regime, Voyager must repeatedly submit to intrusive inspections while secretly hiding its telepathic crew members, and Janeway enters a tense, ambiguous relationship with the charismatic inspector Kashyk, never fully sure whether he is ally or enemy.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager is intercepted by Devore warships enforcing strict laws against telepaths. Inspector Kashyk boards, charmingly authoritarian as he announces that his teams will search for any hidden telepathic passengers.
StorySections.Act I: Janeway plays the cooperative captain while secretly concealing Tuvok, Vorik and a group of telepathic refugees in a transporter suspension stream that Devore scanners cannot easily detect. Kashyk seems impressed by Voyager but leaves without finding anything.
StorySections.Act II: Kashyk soon returns—this time alone, claiming to have defected from the Devore and offering to help Voyager smuggle the refugees out of Devore space. Janeway cautiously accepts his help, and the two grow closer as they work together.
StorySections.Act III: As Voyager nears a wormhole that could offer safe passage for the telepaths, Kashyk provides detailed information on Devore patrol patterns and helps refine the transporter concealment strategy. Janeway and Kashyk share personal conversations that hint at mutual attraction and trust but remain edged with uncertainty.
StorySections.Act IV: At the rendezvous, Devore ships pounce for another inspection. Janeway reveals that she anticipated Kashyk’s likely betrayal and had already moved the telepaths beyond Devore reach, leaving Voyager apparently "clean" when the Devore scan the ship. Kashyk, having gambled on catching them, is left outmaneuvered and forced to depart empty-handed.
StorySections.Tag: On the bridge, Janeway quietly reflects on the game of trust and deception she played with Kashyk, acknowledging to Tuvok that, despite herself, a part of her had hoped he might truly have changed.

Antagonists: Risk of exposure for Voyager's telepaths

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway engages Kashyk in a sophisticated battle of wits wrapped in flirtation, carefully weighing how much to trust him while orchestrating a plan that safeguards the telepaths even if he turns on her.
EntitySummaries.Kashyk: Kashyk is a polished, intelligent Devore inspector whose apparent defection and genuine chemistry with Janeway make his motives opaque until the end, when his loyalty to the Imperium appears to trump any personal connection.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok submits to hiding and the indignity of Devore laws with Vulcan composure, trusting Janeway’s strategy even as he embodies the quiet anxiety of those being hunted for what they are.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven assists with the technical side of concealing the telepaths and scrutinizes Kashyk with Borg-honed skepticism, often voicing the doubts Janeway keeps to herself.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix helps care for the hidden refugees and frets over the repeated inspections, providing a civilian perspective on life under an oppressive regime’s scrutiny.
EntitySummaries.Vorik: Vorik is among the teleplay crew members forced into hiding, representing the personal cost of Devore policies for Voyager’s own officers.
EntitySummaries.Devore inspectors: The inspectors enforce the Imperium’s anti-telepath laws with invasive searches and smug certainty, embodying systemic prejudice and authoritarian control.
EntitySummaries.Telepathic refugees: The refugees are the vulnerable center of the story, trusting Voyager to deliver them from persecution even as their presence endangers the ship.
EntitySummaries.Devore Imperium's anti-telepath laws: The Imperium’s laws are an institutional antagonist, codifying fear and hatred of telepaths into a system that justifies constant violation of privacy and basic rights.
EntitySummaries.Kashyk's duplicity: Kashyk’s shifting loyalties function as a personal antagonist, forcing Janeway to plan around the assumption that his charm may mask betrayal.
EntitySummaries.Risk of exposure for Voyager's telepaths: The constant danger of discovery is a situational antagonist, ratcheting up tension each time Devore ships appear and inspections begin.

ContinuityNotes: Counterpoint adds the Devore Imperium to Voyager’s roster of Delta Quadrant powers, characterized by institutionalized telepathophobia.
The episode further explores Janeway’s capacity for calculated deception when protecting those under her care.
Telepathic species and their persecution echo broader Star Trek themes about prejudice and civil rights.
Janeway’s ambiguous connection with Kashyk adds to the series’ collection of complex, one-off relationships for the captain.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines trust and betrayal in the context of authoritarian power and clandestine resistance.
It explores how prejudice can be written into law, turning ordinary inspections into instruments of oppression.
Counterpoint highlights the moral weight of using deception for a just cause.
The story suggests that even sincere personal connections can be poisoned by loyalty to an unjust system.
BehindTheScenes: Counterpoint was written by Michael Taylor from a story by David Weddle and Bradley Thompson and directed by Les Landau.
The episode’s structure, with repeated inspections and evolving exchanges between Janeway and Kashyk, has often been compared to a chess match or spy thriller.
Music and staging in Counterpoint emphasize the almost romantic tension between Janeway and Kashyk while keeping the audience uncertain about his true intentions.

Title: Latent Image
Summary: The Doctor uncovers evidence of a medical procedure on Harry Kim that he has no memory of performing, leading him to a buried trauma: a past triage decision between two dying patients that shattered his matrix so badly Janeway ordered his memories erased, forcing the crew to confront whether a hologram can be allowed to live with psychological pain.

StorySections.Teaser: During a routine physical, the Doctor discovers that Harry Kim once underwent complex neurosurgery—work that only the EMH could have done—yet there is no record of the procedure and no memory of it in his program.
StorySections.Act I: Puzzled, the Doctor backtracks sensor logs and finds a missing block of time in sickbay’s records. Further investigation reveals an erased patient file for Ensign Jetal, a young science officer who apparently died under mysterious circumstances after a shuttle accident.
StorySections.Act II: Haunted by fragmentary images of Jetal on the biobed, the Doctor pushes past security blocks, triggering cascading glitches as his suppressed memories fight to reassert themselves. Janeway and Tuvok reluctantly reveal that the Doctor once had a breakdown after being forced to choose which of two critically injured friends to save—Harry or Jetal.
StorySections.Act III: Re-experiencing the event, the Doctor remembers selecting Harry based on medical probabilities, then obsessively replaying the choice until his ethical subroutines collapsed under guilt. To keep the EMH functional, Janeway ordered all memories of Jetal’s treatment and death deleted, a decision she still defends as necessary at the time.
StorySections.Act IV: Rejecting the idea that his pain should be edited away, the Doctor demands the right to remember, even if it means suffering. Janeway ultimately agrees to restore his memories and commits to a long, difficult course of counseling rather than another shortcut that denies his emerging personhood.
StorySections.Tag: In sickbay, the Doctor quietly files a holoimage of Ensign Jetal alongside the rest of Voyager’s medical records, determined to honor her memory as part of his own imperfect, evolving history.

Antagonists: The limits of his holographic programming
Janeway's earlier decision to erase his memories

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is forced to relive a suppressed triage decision that cost Ensign Jetal her life and nearly destroyed his program, and he ultimately insists on bearing the psychological consequences rather than living as a carefully edited tool.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must confront the morality of having tampered with the Doctor’s memories for the sake of keeping him functional, and she moves from paternalistic protection to a hard-won respect for his right to experience pain and growth.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry unwittingly benefited from the Doctor’s life-or-death choice and struggles with survivor’s guilt when he learns that the EMH sacrificed his own mental stability to save him.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides a logical framework for evaluating the Doctor’s breakdown, yet ultimately supports Janeway’s decision to treat the EMH’s trauma rather than suppress it again.
EntitySummaries.Ensign Ahni Jetal: Jetal exists mostly in fragments of memory and reconstructed logs, representing all the lives that can be lost in war and triage and the ethical weight such choices place on those who make them.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor's unresolved guilt: The Doctor’s obsession with replaying and second-guessing his choice functions as an internal antagonist, threatening to destabilize his matrix as thoroughly as any external virus.
EntitySummaries.The limits of his holographic programmin: Safeguards meant to protect the EMH from overwhelming contradiction become a structural antagonist, forcing janitorial deletions instead of allowing organic coping.
EntitySummaries.Janeway's earlier decision to erase his: Janeway’s prior intervention becomes a moral antagonist, raising the question of whether sparing a sentient program from trauma justifies denying it the experience that shapes identity.

ContinuityNotes: Latent Image further develops the Doctor’s status as a sentient being by depicting him experiencing post-traumatic stress and ethical guilt.
The episode raises questions similar to those explored with Data and other artificial lifeforms in The Next Generation, but framed through medical ethics.
Janeway’s earlier decision to alter the Doctor’s memories echoes prior instances where she has taken drastic measures to protect the crew.
The focus on triage and medical choice ties into Star Trek’s long-standing interest in the burdens faced by starship doctors.
ThematicNotes: The story explores whether erasing trauma is an act of mercy or a violation of personhood.
It examines the psychological cost of triage in medicine, especially when the doctor cannot distance themselves from the outcome.
Latent Image questions what it means to be sentient if one’s memories and pain can be edited at will.
The episode highlights the tension between practicality and principle in command decisions about artificial life.
BehindTheScenes: Latent Image was written by Joe Menosky from a story by Eileen Connors, Brannon Braga and Menosky, and directed by Mike Vejar.
Robert Picardo’s performance as the increasingly unstable Doctor is often singled out as one of his best on Voyager.
The episode’s structure—slowly uncovering a hidden past event—gives it the feel of both a medical drama and a psychological mystery.

Title: Bride of Chaotica!
Summary: When Voyager is trapped in a subspace "sandbar" and photonic aliens mistake Tom Paris’s Captain Proton holoprogram for reality, Janeway must play the role of Arachnia, Queen of the Spider People, in an over-the-top holodeck melodrama to end an interdimensional war and free the ship.

StorySections.Teaser: Paris and Kim enjoy another campy chapter of "The Adventures of Captain Proton" on the holodeck when the program glitches, strange energy readings appear and the ship shudders under the influence of a mysterious spatial anomaly.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager becomes stuck in a subspace rift that behaves like a sandbar, limiting their ability to maneuver or access full systems. At the same time, photonic lifeforms from another dimension enter the holodeck and are attacked by the villainous Dr. Chaotica, who assumes they are invaders.
StorySections.Act II: The offended photonic aliens retaliate, regarding Chaotica’s aggression as a real act of war. Conventional attempts to communicate fail, so the crew realizes their only viable option is to treat the holoprogram as a genuine battlefield and negotiate from within its pulp-fiction rules.
StorySections.Act III: Paris gleefully recruits Janeway to portray Arachnia, Queen of the Spider People, whose supposed alliance with Chaotica can be used to lower his lightning shield. Janeway throws herself into the role, trading barbed flirtations and grand speeches with the preening villain while Seven and others work behind the scenes.
StorySections.Act IV: As Janeway-as-Arachnia sabotages Chaotica’s defenses from within, Paris—back in his Captain Proton persona—fires the "destructo beam" that destroys Chaotica’s death ray and convinces the photonic aliens the war has ended. With the anomaly’s effects subsiding, Voyager pulls free of the subspace snare.
StorySections.Tag: Back on the real bridge, Janeway dryly warns Paris that their next "outing" to the Captain Proton program will not involve interdimensional diplomacy, leaving him both delighted and slightly wary of her enthusiasm for melodrama.

Antagonists: Dr. Chaotica and his holographic army

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway embraces the absurdity of the Captain Proton holonovel, using her intelligence and theatrical flair to outwit Chaotica and broker peace with the photonic aliens from within the fiction.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris, in his element as Captain Proton, helps translate real-world stakes into the program’s pulp logic, while also learning that his "harmless" hobby can have unexpected consequences when it collides with strange phenomena.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Kim plays faithful sidekick Buster Kincaid and assists with the technical work needed to keep the holoprogram stable while Voyager is trapped.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven initially views the entire situation with Borg-style disdain, but contributes valuable analysis on the photonic aliens and helps ensure the holodeck solution stays under control.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor observes the events with a mixture of bemusement and professional concern, highlighting the potential danger of treating sentient photonic beings as entertainment.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Chaotica: Chaotica is a bombastic holodeck villain whose exaggerated evil inadvertently triggers a genuine interdimensional conflict, forcing the crew to treat him as a real tactical problem.
EntitySummaries.Satan's Robot: The clunky, melodramatic Satan’s Robot serves as both comic relief and a reminder of how crude the program is compared to the sophisticated real-world technology around it.
EntitySummaries.Constance Goodheart: Constance fits the damsel-in-distress archetype of the serial, underscoring how stylized and artificial the Captain Proton world is compared to Voyager’s reality.
EntitySummaries.Photonic aliens' representative: The photonic beings act as misunderstood antagonists, responding rationally to what they perceive as unprovoked aggression from Chaotica’s forces.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Chaotica and his holographic army: Chaotica’s forces provide the fictional threat that becomes dangerously real once the photonic aliens arrive, turning camp into crisis.
EntitySummaries.Photonic aliens provoked into war: The aliens’ reprisal is a situational antagonist, as their reaction is understandable yet perilous for Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Subspace \"sandbar\" anomaly: The anomaly traps Voyager and keeps them entangled with the photonic realm long enough for the conflict to escalate, making it an environmental antagonist.

ContinuityNotes: Bride of Chaotica! revisits Tom Paris’s Captain Proton holoprogram, previously seen as lighthearted recreation, and shows how it can intersect disastrously with real phenomena.
The episode continues Voyager’s exploration of photonic lifeforms, a theme also touched on in other holotechnology-centric stories.
Janeway’s willingness to dive into role-play foreshadows later instances where she uses deception and theater to outmaneuver foes.
The story echoes earlier Star Trek episodes where fictional or simulated worlds bleed into reality with unintended consequences.
ThematicNotes: The episode plays with the boundary between fiction and reality, asking what responsibility creators have when pretend violence affects real beings.
It celebrates the camp and fun of retro science fiction while gently critiquing its clichés and gender roles.
Bride of Chaotica! shows that creative, unconventional thinking can resolve crises that brute force cannot.
The story highlights Star Trek’s ability to mix comedy with genuine stakes without undermining either.
BehindTheScenes: Bride of Chaotica! was developed by Bryan Fuller, with teleplay by Fuller and Michael Taylor, and directed by Allan Kroeker.
The episode is widely regarded as one of Voyager’s most entertaining outings, often cited among the best holodeck episodes in the franchise.
Black-and-white photography and retro set design were used to evoke 1930s serials like Flash Gordon and Buck Rogers.

Title: Gravity
Summary: After a shuttle crash strands Tuvok, Tom Paris and the Doctor on a planet inside a time-dilated gravity well, they spend months surviving alongside an alien woman who falls in love with Tuvok, while Voyager—experiencing only hours—fights to retrieve them before the region collapses.

StorySections.Teaser: A shuttle carrying Tuvok, Paris and the Doctor is pulled into a gravimetric sinkhole and crashes on a harsh desert planet, where an alien scavenger watches from a distance as they struggle from the wreckage.
StorySections.Act I: The stranded officers set up a makeshift camp and attempt to contact Voyager, but their signals fade into static. The alien woman, Noss, steals vital equipment before being attacked by hostile hunters, forcing Tuvok and Paris to choose between pursuing her or recovering their gear.
StorySections.Act II: Tuvok rescues Noss and brings her back to the camp, where Paris and the Doctor begin treating her injuries. Communication barriers slowly fall as they learn each other’s languages, and the trio realize that time is passing much faster for them than for Voyager outside the sinkhole.
StorySections.Act III: As months go by, Noss becomes attached to Tuvok, who responds with reserved kindness but maintains Vulcan emotional discipline. Flashbacks to Tuvok’s youth show his struggle to master his feelings, mirroring his present conflict as he gently rejects Noss’s romantic interest.
StorySections.Act IV: Voyager locates the distortion and, with help from an alien salvage team, opens a narrow window for rescue. Tuvok, Paris, Noss and the Doctor fight their way through hostile forces to reach the extraction point as the sinkhole destabilizes around them.
StorySections.Tag: Once safely aboard Voyager, Noss must be returned to her people; before leaving, she and Tuvok share a brief mind meld, silently acknowledging the bond they formed and the emotions he will never fully express aloud.

EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok serves as the calm center of the stranded group, balancing efficient survival tactics with a quietly compassionate response to Noss’s affection, while his flashbacks reveal how hard-won his emotional control truly is.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris provides ingenuity and humor in a dire situation, working with the Doctor to keep everyone alive while growing frustrated at their apparent abandonment by Voyager.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor adapts his program to the primitive conditions, treating injuries and monitoring the time distortion, highlighting the flexibility—and limitations—of a holographic physician stranded without full facilities.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway, from Voyager’s perspective of only a few days, refuses to give up on the missing team and orchestrates a risky collaboration with local aliens to crack open the gravity well and retrieve her crew.
EntitySummaries.Noss: Noss is a survivor hardened by years trapped on the planet, who gradually opens up to Tuvok and develops unrequited feelings for him, embodying both the hope and heartbreak of connection in extreme circumstances.
EntitySummaries.Vulcan Master (in flashback): The Vulcan master who mentors young Tuvok in emotional discipline represents the cultural forces that shape his current restrained demeanor.
EntitySummaries.Alien hunters: The hunters are local antagonists who treat newcomers as prey or resources, heightening the physical danger of the environment.
EntitySummaries.Salvage team leader: The salvage leader’s pragmatic interest in the sinkhole complicates Voyager’s rescue attempt, illustrating how differing priorities can collide in crisis.
EntitySummaries.Gravimetric sinkhole and time dilation: The sinkhole itself is a scientific antagonist, warping time so that emotional bonds and survival struggles play out at a different pace than Voyager’s rescue efforts.
EntitySummaries.Hostile hunters on the planet: The hunters serve as immediate physical threats that force cooperation between the stranded officers and Noss.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok's suppressed emotions: Tuvok’s tightly controlled feelings are an internal antagonist, preventing him from reciprocating Noss’s affection even as he clearly values her.

ContinuityNotes: Gravity delves deeper into Tuvok’s backstory and the Vulcan approach to emotional control through flashbacks.
The episode revisits Star Trek’s recurring fascination with time dilation and its impact on relationships.
Tom Paris’s improvisational skills and piloting expertise continue to define his role in off-ship crises.
The Doctor once again demonstrates that his holographic nature does not shield him from isolation and frustration.
ThematicNotes: The story explores unrequited love and the difficulty of reconciling emotional needs with cultural or personal discipline.
It examines how different species experience time and attachment under extreme circumstances.
Gravity highlights the loneliness of those trapped out of sync with the rest of their world—literally and figuratively.
The episode underscores that compassionate honesty can be kinder than offering a love one cannot genuinely return.
BehindTheScenes: Gravity was written by Nick Sagan and Bryan Fuller from a story by Jimmy Diggs, Fuller and Sagan, and directed by Terry Windell.
Guest star Lori Petty’s performance as Noss drew praise for giving the character a blend of toughness and vulnerability.
The desert planet setting and time-dilation premise offered a visually distinct change of pace from Voyager’s usual shipboard environment.

Title: Bliss
Summary: When Voyager discovers what appears to be a wormhole directly back to the Alpha Quadrant, most of the crew fall under the influence of a telepathic space-dwelling creature that feeds on their deepest desires, leaving Seven of Nine, Naomi Wildman and a grizzled hunter named Qatai to save the ship from being digested.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager detects a narrow wormhole whose terminus appears to be near Earth, and a flood of positive sensor data and long-awaited messages from home convinces the crew they may finally have a way back.
StorySections.Act I: Seven of Nine grows suspicious when the evidence seems too perfect and strangely tailored to everyone’s hopes. Her doubts deepen as the crew becomes euphoric and dismissive of any contradictory readings.
StorySections.Act II: An alien ship emerges from the "wormhole", badly damaged and crewed by a lone, embittered hunter named Qatai, who insists that the anomaly is actually a gigantic creature that lures in starships by projecting illusions of what they most desire before consuming them.
StorySections.Act III: As Voyager is drawn deeper into the creature’s gullet, the crew are fully enthralled by fantasies of home and refuse to listen to Seven’s warnings. Only Seven, Naomi and the Doctor remain mostly immune, due in part to their unique neural or photonic status.
StorySections.Act IV: Working with Qatai, Seven seizes partial control of the ship and devises a plan to induce the creature to expel Voyager by giving it "indigestion"—overloading it with a feedback pulse while faking compliance with the illusions.
StorySections.Tag: Voyager breaks free, and Qatai, whose life has become a single-minded crusade against the beast, chooses to re-enter the anomaly to continue his hunt, leaving Seven to contemplate the seductive power of hope and the discipline needed to question it.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s skepticism and resistance to fantasy make her the natural foil to the creature’s illusions, forcing her into an unlikely alliance with Qatai to save a crew that would rather believe in a dream.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway, under the influence of the creature, becomes a symbol of how even the most disciplined Starfleet captain can be blinded by the prospect of finally getting her people home.
EntitySummaries.Qatai: Qatai is a gruff, Ahab-like figure whose life has been consumed by hunting the creature that devoured his ship, serving as both a warning about obsession and a crucial ally against the shared enemy.
EntitySummaries.Naomi Wildman: Naomi’s youth and bond with Seven help keep her partially grounded, and her perspective emphasizes how the illusions manipulate even a child’s simple wish for home and family.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: As a hologram, the Doctor is less susceptible to the creature’s manipulations and aids Seven in countering the shipwide delusion.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay represents the earnest, hopeful part of the crew that eagerly embraces the apparent shortcut to Earth, demonstrating how dangerous collective optimism can become when uncritically accepted.
EntitySummaries.Space-dwelling illusion creature: The vast, pitcher-plant-like organism is an environmental and psychological antagonist that survives by luring prey with hallucinatory promises tailored to their deepest desires.
EntitySummaries.Crew's wishful thinking: The crew’s eagerness to believe they have finally found a way home functions as a social antagonist, making Seven’s warnings harder to heed.
EntitySummaries.Qatai's obsession: Qatai’s fixation, while useful in this instance, serves as an internal antagonist for him, trapping him in an endless cycle of hunting even when escape is possible.

ContinuityNotes: Bliss continues Voyager’s tradition of confronting the crew with tempting shortcuts home that prove dangerous or illusory.
Seven’s role as skeptic and protector of the crew underscores her growing integration and responsibility aboard Voyager.
Naomi Wildman’s presence builds on her recurring role as Voyager’s resident child and Seven’s young friend.
The episode echoes earlier Trek stories involving space-dwelling organisms mistaken for astronomical phenomena.
ThematicNotes: The story explores the seductive nature of wish fulfillment and the importance of questioning good fortune that seems too perfect.
It examines how hope, normally a virtue, can be weaponized against people when it overrides critical thinking.
Bliss highlights the loneliness of those who see through comforting illusions and must act against the majority’s desires.
The episode suggests that surviving long journeys sometimes means rejecting the easy answer, even when everyone desperately wants it to be real.
BehindTheScenes: Bliss was written by Robert J. Doherty from a story by Bill Prady and directed by Cliff Bole.
The massive space creature’s design drew comparisons to the energy amoeba from the Original Series episode "The Immunity Syndrome."
Actor W. Morgan Sheppard’s performance as Qatai added a memorable, world-weary presence to the episode.

Title: Dark Frontier, Part I
Summary: After Voyager destroys a Borg probe and discovers a crippled Borg sphere nearby, Janeway plans a daring heist to steal its transwarp coil and shave years off their journey, forcing Seven of Nine to confront haunting logs from her parents’ Borg research even as the Borg Queen quietly maneuvers to reclaim her.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager engages a Borg probe and, in a stunning tactical move, destroys it with a transported torpedo, recovering debris that includes tantalizing Borg navigational data.
StorySections.Act I: Analysis of the wreckage reveals the location of a heavily damaged Borg sphere limping home with a functioning transwarp coil. Janeway proposes infiltrating the sphere and stealing the coil, a theft that could cut decades off Voyager’s trip to Earth.
StorySections.Act II: To prepare, Seven is ordered to study the Hansen family’s logs—records of her own parents’ ill-fated expedition to shadow the Borg Collective. The childhood memories they awaken stir buried trauma and unresolved feelings about her assimilation as Annika Hansen.
StorySections.Act III: Voyager modifies the Delta Flyer with Borg-inspired shielding and tactics gleaned from the Hansens’ data. Despite Chakotay’s misgivings about provoking the Collective, Janeway commits to the heist, assigning Seven to the away team over her own reservations.
StorySections.Act IV: The heist initially goes as planned: the away team beams aboard the crippled sphere, navigates past inattentive drones and secures the transwarp coil. But as they attempt to return, Seven begins hearing the Collective’s call and, believing she must sacrifice herself to save Voyager, refuses transport and remains behind as the sphere jumps to Borg space.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, Janeway realizes Seven deliberately allowed herself to be taken, while in the Collective, the Borg Queen welcomes Seven back and hints that Voyager’s apparent victory was part of a larger design.

Antagonists: Risky heist plan against the sphere

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is torn between her loyalty to Voyager and the gravitational pull of her Borg past, reliving her parents’ dangerous fascination with the Collective even as she chooses to remain behind to protect the ship.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway orchestrates a high-stakes raid that blurs the line between survival and aggression, driven by a fierce determination to get her crew home faster and to keep Seven from slipping back into the Borg’s grasp.
EntitySummaries.Borg Queen: The Borg Queen emerges as a personal antagonist for Seven, revealing that the Collective has been subtly influencing events to draw Seven back, seeing her as an invaluable link to humanity.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay voices the pragmatic concern that antagonizing the Borg for a single piece of technology may cost more than it gains, underscoring Janeway’s willingness to gamble.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris pilots the modified Delta Flyer during the heist, representing Voyager’s daring ingenuity in the face of a vastly superior enemy.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres helps adapt Borg tech for the mission, wrestling with the ethical line between using enemy technology and becoming too dependent on it.
EntitySummaries.Magnus Hansen: Magnus, seen in logs, embodies scientific obsession, willing to risk his family to study the Borg, a choice that directly leads to Annika’s assimilation.
EntitySummaries.Erin Hansen: Erin shares her husband’s curiosity but displays more concern for Annika, highlighting the family tensions within the doomed expedition.
EntitySummaries.Young Annika Hansen: Annika’s childhood scenes deepen the tragedy of Seven’s origin, contrasting a curious, open child with the hardened ex-drone she becomes.
EntitySummaries.Various Borg drones: The drones on the crippled sphere are background antagonists whose very presence underscores the danger of infiltrating even a damaged Borg vessel.
EntitySummaries.The Borg Collective: The Collective remains an implacable, ever-present antagonist whose long reach makes even a successful heist feel like stepping into a larger trap.
EntitySummaries.Borg Queen's manipulation: The Queen’s unseen influence—calling to Seven, allowing certain outcomes—functions as a strategic antagonist, suggesting Voyager’s actions may be anticipated.
EntitySummaries.Risky heist plan against the sphere: The heist itself acts as a narrative antagonist, posing logistical and ethical challenges that strain Voyager’s resources and unity.

ContinuityNotes: Dark Frontier, Part I builds on Borg lore established in The Next Generation and earlier Voyager episodes like "Scorpion" and "The Raven."
Seven’s parents, Magnus and Erin Hansen, are shown in detail for the first time, expanding her backstory.
The episode reinforces Voyager’s ongoing entanglement with the Borg and the risks of relying on their technology to shorten the journey home.
The introduction of the Borg Queen into Voyager’s narrative deepens the personal nature of Seven’s struggle with the Collective.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the allure and danger of technological shortcuts, especially when they involve stealing from an implacable enemy.
It examines how childhood trauma and parental choices shape adult identity, particularly in Seven’s case.
Dark Frontier, Part I interrogates the line between courageous risk and reckless endangerment in command decisions.
The story introduces the idea that even apparent victories over the Borg may be part of the Collective’s own strategic calculations.
BehindTheScenes: Dark Frontier was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky and originally aired as a feature-length episode later split into two parts.
Susanna Thompson takes on the role of the Borg Queen, previously portrayed by Alice Krige in Star Trek: First Contact.
The episode won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Special Visual Effects for a Series, reflecting its ambitious Borg visuals and space sequences.

Title: Dark Frontier, Part II
Summary: Held in the Borg Queen’s chamber, Seven of Nine is pressured to help the Collective devise a new strategy to assimilate humanity while Janeway leads a rescue mission using the stolen transwarp coil and multi-adaptive shielding, culminating in a high-risk extraction deep in Borg space that tests Seven’s loyalty to her found family.

StorySections.Teaser: Aboard a Borg vessel, Seven is reintroduced to the Collective not as a drone but as a valuable intermediary, while the Borg Queen taunts her with the claim that the Borg allowed Voyager to "steal" her in the first place.
StorySections.Act I: The Queen assigns Seven to analyze tactical data on humanity as a potential target, asserting that Seven’s unique perspective can make assimilation more efficient. Seven outwardly complies while quietly resisting the loss of her hard-won individuality.
StorySections.Act II: On Voyager, Janeway refuses to accept Seven’s apparent defection and launches a rescue mission using the stolen transwarp coil. The Delta Flyer is outfitted with multi-adaptive shielding based on the Hansens’ research to slip through Borg space undetected.
StorySections.Act III: As Seven accompanies the Queen on an assimilation mission, she secretly sabotages parts of the process and helps a small group of aliens escape, behavior the Queen labels as a lingering human weakness. The Queen counters by threatening to use Seven as a tool in a plan to seed Earth’s atmosphere with nanoprobes.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway’s message reaches Seven through her interplexing beacon, revealing the rescue plan. In a climactic showdown within the Queen’s chamber, Seven disables a key power node on the Queen’s orders, allowing Janeway and Seven to be beamed aboard the Delta Flyer just as Borg ships close in.
StorySections.Tag: Voyager collapses the transwarp conduit behind the fleeing shuttle, destroying a pursuing Borg vessel; the stolen coil burns out after gaining the ship roughly fifteen years on its journey, and Seven quietly re-commits herself to Voyager, fully aware that the Collective will not easily forget her defiance.

GuestCharacters: Erin Hansen (in flashback or implied memory)
Antagonists: Dangerous rescue mission in Borg space

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven walks a razor’s edge between outward compliance and inner rebellion, using the access the Queen grants her to subvert assimilation efforts and ultimately choose Voyager over the Collective a second time, this time with full awareness of the cost.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway stakes the ship and much of her senior staff on a near-suicidal rescue, signaling how deeply she views Seven as part of her family and how far she is willing to go to reclaim those she believes the Borg have stolen.
EntitySummaries.Borg Queen: The Queen is a manipulative, almost parental figure who tries to break Seven’s loyalty by invoking her past and promising a grand purpose in the assimilation of humanity, revealing the Collective’s interest in Earth as more than a distant target.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay coordinates Voyager’s end of the operation and serves as the voice of caution, but ultimately stands behind Janeway’s decision once the mission is underway.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris pilots the Delta Flyer through transwarp conduits and Borg patrols, making split-second maneuvers that keep the fragile multi-adaptive shielding from being overwhelmed.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres helps integrate the transwarp coil and shielding technologies, embodying Voyager’s willingness to borrow from Borg science while remaining wary of its corrupting influence.
EntitySummaries.Magnus Hansen (as a drone): The revelation that one of the drones beside Seven is her assimilated father underlines the personal horror of the Borg and the stakes of her refusal to rejoin them.
EntitySummaries.Erin Hansen (in flashback or implied mem: Erin’s presence in Seven’s recollections reinforces the human family ties the Queen can never fully erase.
EntitySummaries.Alien species targeted for assimilation: The doomed aliens represent the countless civilizations on the brink of being consumed by the Collective, sharpening the urgency of Seven’s small acts of sabotage.
EntitySummaries.The Borg Queen: As a singular face of the Collective, the Queen functions as the primary antagonist, combining psychological manipulation with the raw power of the Borg fleet.
EntitySummaries.Plan to assimilate humanity: The proposed nanoprobes-in-the-atmosphere scheme is a strategic antagonist, making clear that the stakes of Seven’s cooperation extend all the way to Earth.
EntitySummaries.Dangerous rescue mission in Borg space: The rescue mission is a situational antagonist that subjects Voyager and the Delta Flyer to overwhelming odds and constant risk of detection.

ContinuityNotes: Dark Frontier, Part II deepens Seven’s personal conflict with the Borg and the Queen, foreshadowing later Borg-centric episodes like "Unimatrix Zero" and "Endgame."
The episode confirms that the Borg have concrete plans for assimilating humanity, tying Voyager more directly into the wider Borg narrative.
Voyager’s use of the transwarp coil to cut years off its journey continues the series’ pattern of incremental progress toward home.
Susanna Thompson’s portrayal of the Borg Queen would later be revisited in future Voyager stories.
ThematicNotes: The story explores loyalty, showing Seven caught between her origin in the Collective and the chosen family she has found on Voyager.
It examines how abusers weaponize the past and a sense of belonging to regain control over those trying to break free.
Dark Frontier, Part II grapples with the ethics of risking many lives to save one, even when that one may hold the key to a greater threat.
The episode underscores that reclaiming one’s autonomy is not a single moment but an ongoing series of choices in the face of relentless pressure.
BehindTheScenes: Dark Frontier, Part II shares writing credits with Part I, with Braga and Menosky crafting the full feature-length story.
Different directors—Cliff Bole and Terry Windell—handled the two halves of Dark Frontier, contributing to the episode’s mix of heist and psychological drama.
The two-parter’s production pushed Voyager’s visual effects team, resulting in some of the series’ most elaborate Borg space and interior shots.

Title: The Disease
Summary: When Voyager forms a temporary alliance with a massive generational ship whose people are secretly trying to break away from their rigid, unified society, Harry Kim falls in love with an alien engineer named Tal and violates Starfleet medical regulations, becoming literally and emotionally bonded to her as political unrest and biological consequences spiral out of control.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager rendezvous with a vast generational vessel whose modular sections travel locked together as one community. As the ships link, Harry Kim excitedly assists with integration work and catches the eye of Tal, a gifted young Varro engineer.
StorySections.Act I: While Janeway negotiates a cooperative arrangement with the Varro leadership, Harry and Tal work closely on repairing the failing hull structures between segments, discovering that a faction of Varro secretly wants to detach their modules and live independently. Against regulations, Harry and Tal begin a clandestine romantic relationship.
StorySections.Act II: Harry collapses after another secret encounter with Tal, and the Doctor discovers a biochemical bond forming between them: an exchange of neurochemicals that is both physiological and emotional. Janeway is furious to learn Harry ignored Starfleet protocols requiring medical clearance for intimate contact with new species.
StorySections.Act III: As internal sabotage accelerates the Varro ship’s structural failures, Harry’s growing dependence on Tal compromises his judgment. He defies direct orders to stay away from her, insisting that their connection is more than a "disease" even as the Doctor struggles to stabilize his condition.
StorySections.Act IV: Tal chooses to join the separatists and detaches with a breakaway group of Varro, while Voyager helps minimize casualties as segments tear free from the main structure. Harry, forced to let her go, begins an agonizing detox from their bond and faces disciplinary action for his choices.
StorySections.Tag: Demoted in spirit if not in rank, Harry endures a formal reprimand from Janeway and reflects on a love that felt real yet left him weakened, resolving to rebuild both his health and his professional standing.

EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry falls into an intense cross-cultural romance that violates medical regulations, leaving him chemically addicted to his partner and forcing him to balance genuine feeling against his duty to Starfleet and Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Tal: Tal is a brilliant Varro engineer drawn to Harry’s idealism, torn between loyalty to her people’s separatist movement and the powerful bond she forms with him.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway represents Starfleet discipline, reprimanding Harry for his recklessness while quietly recognizing that emotional needs do not vanish just because a ship is stranded far from home.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor diagnoses the biochemical "disease" binding Harry and Tal, treating it as both a medical problem and an ethical dilemma about how much autonomy patients have over risky relationships.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay helps manage the alliance with the Varro and offers Harry counsel, seeing in the young officer’s actions echoes of the passion that once drew him to the Maquis.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok approaches the Varro schism and Harry’s behavior with Vulcan detachment, emphasizing protocol even as he quietly acknowledges the emotional component driving events.
EntitySummaries.Varro first minister: The conservative Varro leader fights to preserve unity and social control, seeing the separatists as existential threats to their way of life.
EntitySummaries.Varro separatist leaders: The separatists seek freedom from a hierarchical, closed system and use sabotage to force separation, embodying the strain between tradition and self-determination.
EntitySummaries.Harry and Tal's biochemical bond: The induced neurochemical bond is a biological antagonist that amplifies emotion into compulsion, blurring the line between love and addiction.
EntitySummaries.Varro political schism: The growing divide between loyalists and separatists is a social antagonist that destabilizes both the Varro ship and Voyager’s temporary alliance.
EntitySummaries.Starfleet regulations versus personal de: The clash between strict Starfleet protocols and human longing acts as an institutional antagonist, framing Harry’s actions as both understandable and unacceptable.

ContinuityNotes: The Disease further develops Harry Kim’s tendency to fall deeply and sometimes unwisely in love, a trait seen in earlier seasons.
The episode reinforces Starfleet’s strict rules about intimate contact with new species, echoing medical and first-contact protocols mentioned elsewhere in the franchise.
Voyager’s assistance with the Varro ship continues the series’ pattern of encountering and temporarily partnering with unusual forms of spacefaring civilizations.
Harry’s reprimand leaves a lingering mark on his record and relationship with Janeway.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the tension between personal desire and professional duty in an isolated, high-pressure environment.
It examines how love, addiction and biology can intertwine in ways that challenge notions of consent and responsibility.
The Disease deals with generational conflict and the desire of a younger faction to break away from a rigid, inherited system.
The story raises questions about how far authority figures should go in policing the intimate lives of those under their command.
BehindTheScenes: The episode makes extensive use of new alien ship interior designs to portray the Varro generational vessel.
Harry Kim’s emotional arc here is one of his more prominent spotlight stories in the middle seasons of Voyager.
The concept of a biochemical bond provided a way to literalize the idea of a "dangerous" relationship in science-fiction terms.

Title: Course: Oblivion
Summary: Months after a seemingly normal stretch of their journey, Voyager’s crew begin to suffer mysterious illnesses and hull degradation, leading to the horrifying realization that they are actually biomimetic duplicates created on a distant "demon" world, and their ship is slowly losing cohesion far from the planet that gave them life.

StorySections.Teaser: Tom Paris and B'Elanna Torres celebrate their recent wedding aboard Voyager, while routine operations continue and the crew prepares to use their enhanced drive systems to shorten the trip home.
StorySections.Act I: An engine malfunction kills a crewman in an unusual way, his body literally dissolving. B'Elanna falls suddenly ill, her cellular structure destabilizing. The Doctor cannot find a conventional medical cause as more crew begin to exhibit similar symptoms.
StorySections.Act II: Engineering teams discover that Voyager’s hull and systems are actually composed of an exotic biomimetic substance slowly losing structural integrity. Janeway orders a full investigation, and records eventually reveal that this Voyager is the duplicate ship formed on a demon-class planet visited months earlier.
StorySections.Act III: The crew grapple with the existential shock of learning they are copies with implanted memories, not the original Voyager they believed themselves to be. Janeway refuses to accept that this makes their lives any less real and orders a course back to the demon planet in the hope of stabilizing the ship and crew.
StorySections.Act IV: As the duplicate Voyager deteriorates en route—crew and equipment alike liquefying into metallic goo—the ship loses the ability to maintain warp or structural cohesion. Janeway stubbornly pushes ahead until she finally collapses, her last act an order to preserve a data capsule with their story.
StorySections.Tag: The real Voyager later detects a momentary sensor anomaly and faint debris from the duplicate ship, but fails to recover the capsule, leaving the doppelgänger crew’s struggle and identities unknown to anyone but the audience.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: The duplicate Janeway clings fiercely to her identity and mission, insisting that being a copy does not diminish her duty or the value of her crew’s lives, even as her body literally dissolves around her.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Duplicate Tom’s marriage to B'Elanna underscores how real the crew’s relationships feel, making their impending dissolution all the more tragic.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna’s early illness becomes the first clear sign of the crew’s unstable nature, and her meltdown forces everyone to confront the truth they would rather ignore.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The duplicate Doctor struggles to treat a condition that is not disease but fundamental structural failure, and he must face the reality that he himself is a mimicked program running on mimicked hardware.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay supports Janeway’s push to reach the demon planet while quietly recognizing that they may never arrive, functioning as both first officer and spiritual sounding board in their final days.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry represents the crew’s denial and then acceptance, moving from trying to find technical fixes to quietly helping preserve whatever record of their existence they can leave behind.
EntitySummaries.Biomimetic \"demon\" planet (offscreen i: The distant demon-class world is an unseen antagonist whose conditions are necessary for the duplicate matter’s stability; without it, the ship and crew simply cannot endure.
EntitySummaries.Background duplicate crew: The slowly melting crew, many of whom never learn the truth before they die, emphasize the scale of the tragedy and the fragility of their borrowed lives.
EntitySummaries.Biomimetic matter instability: The progressive breakdown of the ship and crew is a physical antagonist that cannot be reasoned with or fully repaired.
EntitySummaries.Distance from the demon planet: The sheer distance from the world that created them is a situational antagonist ensuring that, even with full knowledge, the duplicates cannot return in time.
EntitySummaries.Existential crisis of being duplicates: The knowledge that they are copies rather than originals is a psychological antagonist that challenges the crew’s sense of purpose and reality.

ContinuityNotes: Course: Oblivion is a direct follow-up to the earlier episode where a demon-class planet created biomimetic duplicates of Voyager and her crew.
The episode offers an alternate, tragic "what if" life path for the duplicates, separate from the prime Voyager’s ongoing story.
The brief appearance of the real Voyager at the end ties the duplicate narrative back into the main continuity without altering it.
Janeway’s determination and the crew’s relationships mirror those of the originals, reinforcing the theme that their experiences are no less authentic.
ThematicNotes: The story wrestles with questions of identity, asking whether copies with the same memories and feelings are any less "real" than their originals.
It explores mortality and meaning, as the duplicate crew confronts an unavoidable, premature end.
Course: Oblivion examines the value of legacy, with the crew’s desperate attempt to leave behind a record that ultimately goes unnoticed.
The episode underscores the idea that what defines a life is not its origin or duration, but the choices made and bonds formed along the way.
BehindTheScenes: Course: Oblivion is known for its bleak twist and for killing an entire set of main characters while leaving the originals untouched.
Extensive visual effects were used to depict the progressive breakdown of the biomimetic ship and crew.
The episode has remained one of Voyager’s more divisive entries, praised for its audacity and criticized by some for its "it never really happened" structure.

Title: The Fight
Summary: As Voyager becomes trapped in a region of violently shifting "chaotic space," Chakotay is plagued by hallucinations centered on his boxing holoprogram and his grandfather’s hereditary neural disorder, eventually discovering that telepathic aliens are using his altered perceptions to warn the ship before it is destroyed.

StorySections.Teaser: In a stylized boxing ring, Chakotay is pummeled by an opponent who suddenly morphs into the Doctor and then into an alien figure, while voices shout cryptic warnings. He wakes in sickbay, disoriented and angry.
StorySections.Act I: Voyager enters chaotic space, where normal physical laws are distorted and sensors become unreliable. Simultaneously, Chakotay begins seeing strange symbols and hearing a voice urging him to "fight" and "listen," symptoms the Doctor initially attributes to a latent genetic predisposition toward a neurological disorder.
StorySections.Act II: Despite treatment, Chakotay’s visions intensify, blending his boxing program with surreal images of the bridge, the alien and collapsing starship corridors. He insists the hallucinations are messages, not illness, but Janeway worries his condition could compromise the ship’s safety.
StorySections.Act III: Guided by the visions, Chakotay realizes that an alien intelligence native to chaotic space is trying to communicate through his altered brain patterns. The aliens warn that Voyager’s conventional attempts to escape will only pull the ship deeper toward destruction.
StorySections.Act IV: Risking permanent neural damage, Chakotay re-enters the enhanced hallucination state in the boxing ring and agrees to "go the distance" with the alien messenger. Interpreting metaphors from the fight, he relays a counterintuitive course that allows Voyager to ride a shifting current out of chaotic space.
StorySections.Tag: With the ship safe, Chakotay returns to the gym and starts another simulated match, choosing to keep boxing as a way to honor both his grandfather’s struggle and the strange brush with telepathic contact.

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay is forced to confront both his fear of inheriting his grandfather’s mental decline and his role as an intuitive conduit for an alien message, ultimately embracing the confusing visions as a bridge rather than a curse.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway balances concern for Chakotay’s health with the need to escape chaotic space, reluctantly allowing him to risk his mind on the chance that his visions truly carry the key to survival.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is caught between viewing Chakotay’s symptoms as a treatable disorder and acknowledging that something genuinely anomalous is happening in his patient’s brain.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris offers support as Chakotay’s sparring partner and friend, grounding the boxing sequences in their ongoing camaraderie.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides a logical counterpoint, questioning the wisdom of trusting hallucinations while acknowledging that not all forms of communication fit comfortable categories.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay's grandfather (in visions): The grandfather appears in dreamlike sequences as both inspiration and warning, embodying Chakotay’s fear of losing himself to a condition that once plagued his family.
EntitySummaries.Boxing trainer hologram: The trainer pushes Chakotay to keep fighting in the ring, acting as a metaphorical conscience that encourages him to face rather than flee the visions.
EntitySummaries.Telepathic alien in chaotic space: The alien presence is a non-humanoid intelligence struggling to be understood, inadvertently harming Chakotay’s mind even as it tries to save Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Chaotic space: Chaotic space is an environmental antagonist where the usual rules of navigation and physics collapse, making typical Starfleet strategies dangerously ineffective.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay's deteriorating neural conditio: The onset of neurological symptoms is an internal antagonist that threatens Chakotay’s sense of self and his ability to serve as first officer.
EntitySummaries.Miscommunication with the alien: The initial failure to understand the alien’s contact attempts is a conceptual antagonist, nearly turning a warning into a death sentence for the ship.

ContinuityNotes: The Fight expands Chakotay’s backstory by introducing a hereditary neural disorder in his family line.
The episode continues Voyager’s exploration of unusual spatial phenomena that challenge conventional starship operations.
Chakotay’s interest in boxing, previously mentioned as a recreational activity, becomes central to the narrative structure.
The story contributes to Star Trek’s broader tradition of non-verbal or metaphorically framed first contacts.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines fear of illness and inherited vulnerability, particularly regarding mental health.
It explores the idea that communication across radically different modes of perception can resemble madness before it is understood.
The Fight uses the metaphor of the boxing ring to depict perseverance, resilience and the willingness to endure discomfort for a greater good.
The story suggests that intuition and altered states of consciousness, while risky, can sometimes access truths logic alone cannot reach.
BehindTheScenes: The Fight uses stylized lighting and sound design in the boxing-ring sequences to convey Chakotay’s distorted perceptions.
The episode gave Robert Beltran one of his more unusual showcases as Chakotay, blending physical performance with psychological drama.
Production reused and redressed existing sets to create the surreal hybrid of ring, corridors and alien environment.

Title: Think Tank
Summary: Hunted by relentless Hazari bounty ships, Voyager seeks help from a mysterious "think tank" of hyper-intelligent beings who specialize in solving impossible problems—for a price—only to discover that the think tank itself orchestrated the crisis in order to acquire Seven of Nine as payment.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager is under siege from coordinated Hazari attacks that seem to anticipate every tactical move, forcing the crew into a running battle with no clear way to negotiate or escape.
StorySections.Act I: As the situation worsens, a representative named Kurros appears with an offer from an enigmatic think tank that operates outside normal political structures, claiming they can end the Hazari threat in exchange for a suitable "reward."
StorySections.Act II: Kurros and his associates demonstrate their abilities by instantly diagnosing Voyager’s strategic weaknesses and suggesting ingenious, if unsettling, fixes to shipboard problems. Janeway entertains their proposal while wary of their transactional, almost predatory attitude toward problem-solving.
StorySections.Act III: The think tank reveals its true desired payment: Seven of Nine, whose unique mind and Borg-enhanced abilities they consider a priceless addition to their collective. Janeway refuses, and Seven herself is repulsed by the idea of becoming an intellectual trophy, even as Kurros tempts her with promises of endless exploration and challenge.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway, Seven and the crew devise a counter-plan, secretly enlisting the Hazari once they learn that the think tank hired the hunters in the first place. Using misdirection and hacked communications, they turn the Hazari against the think tank, trapping its vessel in a web of its own manipulations.
StorySections.Tag: With the attackers withdrawn and the think tank disabled, Voyager resumes its course. Seven reflects on the seductive appeal of pure intellect divorced from morality and reaffirms her choice to remain among the imperfect but principled crew.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is the think tank’s primary target, valued for her analytical abilities and Borg experience; she must weigh the lure of joining a community of peers against the loss of autonomy and emotional connection it would entail.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway recognizes the danger of accepting help from those who treat sentient beings as bargaining chips and orchestrates a clever reversal that uses the think tank’s own tactics against it.
EntitySummaries.Kurros: Kurros serves as the charming, unsettling face of the think tank, presenting their manipulations as elegant solutions and seeing people like Seven as pieces in a grand intellectual collection.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay helps coordinate defense against the Hazari and provides tactical support for Janeway’s counter-plan, emphasizing teamwork over detached calculation.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is fascinated and disturbed by the think tank’s clinical approach to sentient life, highlighting the gap between healing as service and problem-solving as commerce.
EntitySummaries.Hazari commander: The Hazari leader exemplifies a professional hunter bound by contract; once the truth about their employer is revealed, they are willing to redirect their efforts as long as the terms are met.
EntitySummaries.Other think tank members: The think tank’s unusual members—ranging from telepaths to non-humanoid intelligences—embody a diversity of minds united by a shared indifference to the moral cost of their arrangements.
EntitySummaries.Hazari bounty hunters: The Hazari as a group act as formidable external antagonists, their efficiency heightened by the think tank’s strategic guidance.
EntitySummaries.The think tank collective: The collective’s cold, transactional mindset is a central antagonist, representing intellect decoupled from empathy or ethics.
EntitySummaries.Transactional ethics of problem-solving: The philosophy that every solution must be compensated—regardless of what or who is traded—is a conceptual antagonist that clashes with Starfleet ideals.

ContinuityNotes: Think Tank introduces the Hazari and the think tank itself as new Delta Quadrant players motivated by profit and intellectual challenge rather than ideology.
The episode continues Seven’s ongoing exploration of where she belongs, contrasting life among humans with the promise of a purely cerebral existence.
Janeway’s willingness to partner temporarily with the Hazari highlights her pragmatic streak when faced with superior adversaries.
The story fits into Voyager’s broader pattern of encountering morally ambiguous allies whose help comes at an unacceptable cost.
ThematicNotes: The episode questions the ethics of commodifying problem-solving and treating sentient beings as tradable assets.
It explores the tension between intellectual fulfillment and emotional connection in Seven’s character arc.
Think Tank contrasts Starfleet’s ideal of service with a purely transactional, almost mercenary view of intelligence.
The story underscores that cleverness without conscience can be as dangerous as any overtly hostile force.
BehindTheScenes: The episode features a memorable guest performance as Kurros, whose calm demeanor masks the think tank’s predatory nature.
Designers created distinct visual and audio motifs for the think tank’s environment to emphasize its alien intellect and detachment.
Think Tank is often remembered for its cat-and-mouse plotting and for giving Seven another major character-defining choice.

Title: Juggernaut
Summary: When a malfunctioning Malon waste freighter threatens to explode and contaminate an entire sector with deadly theta radiation, Voyager sends a small team—led by B'Elanna Torres and accompanied by Malon specialists—into the ship’s toxic interior to stabilize the engines, forcing B'Elanna to confront both a mysterious "monster" stalking the corridors and the fury she carries inside herself.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager responds to a massive radiation surge and discovers a crippled Malon freighter venting theta waste, its core counting down toward a catastrophic breach that could poison space for light-years.
StorySections.Act I: Malon representatives Fesek and his crew explain that their ship is a "scow" hauling industrial waste and that their captain ordered it scuttled, but the self-destruct failed. Janeway agrees to help avert disaster, and B'Elanna reluctantly joins an away team outfitted with heavy radiation gear.
StorySections.Act II: Inside the freighter’s decaying corridors, the team battles failing systems and rising radiation. Rumors spread among the Malon about a deformed worker—"the Vihaar"—who supposedly haunts the ship. Strange attacks and equipment failures make it unclear whether they are facing superstition or a real threat.
StorySections.Act III: B'Elanna’s simmering anger toward the Malon for their careless dumping flares as Fesek admits they routinely sacrifice laborers to theta exposure. When Pelk is killed by a hulking, mutated figure, B'Elanna must balance her rage against the need to keep the mission on track before the core blows.
StorySections.Act IV: The "monster" turns out to be a Malon worker horribly altered by years of exposure, now attacking anyone he blames for his suffering. B'Elanna fights past him to reach the engine controls, improvising a solution that vents waste safely and stabilizes the core, while Fesek sacrifices himself to buy her time.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, B'Elanna reflects on how her own unchecked anger nearly doomed the mission, taking tentative steps toward healthier ways of channeling it even as the Malon vow they will continue dumping waste until they find a better option.

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna leads the hazardous away mission, forced to keep her temper in check as she confronts Malon negligence, a lethal mutation and her own tendency to let rage dictate her choices.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway brokers cooperation with the Malon despite disgust at their waste practices, committing Voyager to a risky intervention to protect an entire sector from environmental devastation.
EntitySummaries.Fesek: Fesek is a hardened Malon engineer who openly acknowledges the grim costs of his trade and ultimately redeems some of his complicity by sacrificing himself to help B'Elanna stop the core breach.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris supports B'Elanna on the mission and bears witness to how deeply the situation stirs her unresolved issues with anger and self-worth.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides calm tactical oversight, urging B'Elanna to control her emotions in an environment where impulsive actions could be fatal.
EntitySummaries.Pelk: Pelk’s death at the hands of the mutated worker underlines the human cost of Malon waste-dumping and raises the stakes of the mission.
EntitySummaries.Dremk: Dremk embodies the Malon culture of denial and superstition, more willing to believe in monsters than confront systemic exploitation.
EntitySummaries.Mutated Malon worker (the \"Vihaar\"): The so-called Vihaar is a tragic antagonist—a worker twisted by radiation and abandonment into a vengeful figure who lashes out at the very people trying to prevent a larger catastrophe.
EntitySummaries.Malfunctioning Malon freighter core: The unstable core is a ticking environmental bomb, an impersonal antagonist that will devastate a region of space if not brought under control.
EntitySummaries.Theta radiation contamination: The pervasive radiation creates a deadly backdrop for every decision, turning minor errors into potentially fatal mistakes.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna's uncontrolled anger: B'Elanna’s temper functions as an internal antagonist that threatens to derail a delicate mission that demands focus and restraint.

ContinuityNotes: Juggernaut revisits the Malon, previously introduced as a waste-dumping culture in "Night."
The episode further explores B'Elanna’s struggles with anger and self-control, themes seen throughout Voyager.
Voyager’s role as a reluctant environmental mediator echoes other stories where the crew confronts harmful industrial practices.
The mission showcases Starfleet’s willingness to risk itself to prevent large-scale ecological disasters, even for species with troubling ethics.
ThematicNotes: The story examines environmental responsibility and the unseen costs of industrial pollution.
It explores how anger can be both a motivating force and a dangerous liability in crisis situations.
Juggernaut highlights the way marginalized workers bear the brunt of hazardous labor practices.
The episode suggests that confronting systemic harm requires more than heroics; it demands structural change the Malon are not yet ready to make.
BehindTheScenes: Juggernaut was written by Bryan Fuller (story) with teleplay by Fuller, Nick Sagan and Kenneth Biller, and directed by Allan Kroeker.
The episode features extensive prosthetic makeup and environmental effects to depict Malon radiation burns and the freighter’s toxic interiors.
Roxann Dawson’s performance as B'Elanna emphasizes the character’s volatility and growth under extreme pressure.

Title: Someone to Watch Over Me
Summary: When the Doctor bets Tom Paris that he can teach Seven of Nine the subtleties of romance and socializing, he coaches her through a series of awkward dates and lessons in human courtship, only to realize he has fallen in love with her himself as their latest diplomatic reception threatens to turn her experiment into heartbreak.

StorySections.Teaser: As Voyager hosts the devoutly ritualistic Kadi, Neelix struggles to manage their gluttonous ambassador while Seven clinically observes the chaos in the mess hall, prompting the Doctor to comment on her lack of social graces.
StorySections.Act I: Tom wagers that the Doctor cannot turn Seven into a convincing dinner companion. Intrigued, the Doctor takes on the challenge, creating a structured "curriculum" of etiquette, small talk and dance lessons while Seven approaches the project as another efficiency problem to solve.
