StorySections.Act II: Seven’s early attempts at dating a fellow crewman, William Chapman, go poorly as she bluntly dissects his behavior and treats the evening like an evaluation. The Doctor adjusts his coaching, encouraging spontaneity and emotional openness, even as he begins to enjoy their time together more than he admits.
StorySections.Act III: Rehearsing for an upcoming diplomatic reception, Seven and the Doctor share a dance that briefly transcends their teacher-student roles. The Doctor’s feelings deepen, but he hides them behind professional detachment and continued instruction.
StorySections.Act IV: At the reception, Seven’s public attempt to "optimize" romantic pairing by evaluating potential partners offends Chapman and others, leading her to declare the experiment a failure. When she discovers the Doctor’s bet with Tom, she feels used and terminates the lessons, unaware of his genuine affection.
StorySections.Tag: Alone in the holodeck, the Doctor sings the song "Someone to Watch Over Me" to an empty room, quietly acknowledging his unrequited love while continuing to care for Seven in his usual professional capacity.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor treats teaching Seven about romance as an intellectual challenge, only to discover he has fallen in love with her, leaving him torn between honesty and the fear of damaging their friendship.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven approaches dating like a study in human behavior, gradually revealing vulnerability as she tries—and largely fails—to reconcile efficiency with messy emotions.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris provides comic commentary and instigates the bet, yet ultimately recognizes the sincerity of the Doctor’s feelings and backs off when the situation becomes genuinely painful.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix juggles his duties as morale officer and host to the demanding Kadi, providing a humorous parallel to the Doctor’s struggle to manage social expectations.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway observes Seven’s lessons with cautious approval, wanting her to develop socially while wary of anyone exploiting her naiveté.
EntitySummaries.Ambassador Tomin: The Kadi ambassador is both comic relief and a reminder of how alien customs can strain even a seasoned crew’s patience.
EntitySummaries.William Chapman: Chapman serves as Seven’s primary dating practice partner, his discomfort highlighting how incompatible her initial approach is with typical romantic expectations.
EntitySummaries.Kadi attendants: The attendants amplify the culture clash, illustrating the challenges of hospitality and diplomacy aboard a small starship.
EntitySummaries.Social awkwardness and inexperience: Seven’s lack of practice with intimacy and the Doctor’s blindness to his own emotions form a social antagonist that derails the experiment.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor's unspoken feelings: His refusal to confess his love becomes an internal antagonist that leaves both parties unsatisfied and unresolved.
EntitySummaries.Cultural misunderstandings with the Kadi: The Kadi’s unusual customs create external tension that mirrors the internal awkwardness of Seven’s social education.

ContinuityNotes: The episode deepens the Doctor and Seven’s relationship, setting up emotional undercurrents that continue in later seasons.
Seven’s structured approach to learning social behavior reflects her broader struggle to integrate into the crew.
Tom Paris’s involvement ties into his long-standing role as the Doctor’s friend and occasional instigator.
The focus on music and dance recalls the Doctor’s earlier exploration of performance and culture.
ThematicNotes: The story explores unrequited love and the pain of caring deeply for someone who does not reciprocate in the same way.
It examines how treating relationships like solvable puzzles can miss the emotional core of connection.
Someone to Watch Over Me highlights the vulnerability inherent in opening oneself up to romance.
The episode underscores that emotional growth often involves embarrassing failures and missteps.
BehindTheScenes: Someone to Watch Over Me was directed by Robert Duncan McNeill, who plays Tom Paris, giving the episode a cast-member’s eye for character moments.
The episode takes its title from the classic Gershwin song prominently featured in the Doctor’s performance.
It is frequently cited as one of Voyager’s strongest character pieces for both Seven and the Doctor.

Summary: Prompted by Neelix’s interest in Earth history, Janeway recounts the story of her ancestor Shannon O'Donnell and her role in the construction of the Millennium Gate in 2000, only to discover that family legend has exaggerated Shannon’s heroism and that ordinary choices and compromises can still shape the future in meaningful ways.

StorySections.Teaser: On Voyager, Neelix prepares a celebration of New Year traditions and asks Janeway to share tales of her famous ancestor Shannon O'Donnell, whom she believes helped spearhead the Millennium Gate project on Earth at the turn of the 21st century.
StorySections.Act I: In flashback, Shannon O'Donnell is introduced as a drifter whose car breaks down in the small town of Portage Creek, Indiana. She finds lodging and a tenuous job at Henry Janeway’s struggling bookstore, which sits in the shadow of the proposed Millennium Gate development.
StorySections.Act II: Shannon and Henry clash over the Gate: she sees the project as a symbol of progress and a chance for work, while he resists selling his shop to the corporation pushing the development. Their arguments gradually give way to mutual respect and a growing personal connection.
StorySections.Act III: Corporate representative Gerald Moss pressures Henry to sign, warning that eminent domain will eventually force him out. Shannon is tempted by Moss’s offer of a position and the promise of being part of something historic, but she also comes to value Henry’s stubborn stand and the community’s identity.
StorySections.Act IV: Ultimately, Henry chooses to relocate his bookstore into the Millennium Gate, and Shannon decides to stay with him rather than chase a grander role elsewhere. Back in the 24th century, Janeway learns that Shannon’s contribution was far smaller than family stories claimed—no dramatic standoff, just quiet compromise and a shared life.
StorySections.Tag: Janeway tells the crew that, even without legendary heroics, Shannon’s choices still helped shape generations of Janeways, reaffirming the idea that everyday lives and relationships can be as significant as epic deeds.

Antagonists: Corporate pressure behind the Millennium Gate

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway confronts the gap between the heroic ancestor she grew up idolizing and the flawed, ordinary woman history reveals, learning to appreciate her lineage in a more nuanced way.
EntitySummaries.Shannon O'Donnell: Shannon is a restless engineer-turned-drifter who stumbles into a small town at a crossroads and must choose between chasing symbolic progress and building a quieter life with Henry.
EntitySummaries.Henry Janeway: Henry is a principled, stubborn bookstore owner who resists the Millennium Gate project but ultimately chooses adaptation over martyrdom, moving his shop into the new complex.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix’s enthusiasm for Earth traditions and history drives the investigation that exposes the truth behind the Janeway family legend.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay listens to Janeway’s reflections and offers support, underscoring how personal narratives shape identity even when the facts are messier than the myths.
EntitySummaries.Gerald Moss: Moss represents corporate pragmatism, pushing for the Gate’s construction with little regard for local sentiment.
EntitySummaries.Jason Janeway: Jason, Henry’s grandson, provides a glimpse of the future that Shannon’s choices help create, bridging the story to Janeway’s own time.
EntitySummaries.Corporate pressure behind the Millennium: The developer’s drive to build the Gate is an economic antagonist that squeezes small-town residents into difficult decisions.
EntitySummaries.Economic decline of small-town businesse: The broader trend of local shops being replaced by large projects serves as a social antagonist that Henry and Shannon cannot truly defeat, only navigate.
EntitySummaries.Mythologized family history versus reali: The discrepancy between legend and fact is a conceptual antagonist that challenges Janeway’s sense of heritage.

ContinuityNotes: 11:59 provides rare extended scenes set on early 21st-century Earth within Voyager.
The episode fleshes out Janeway’s family background and the stories that inspired her to join Starfleet.
The Millennium Gate is portrayed as a precursor to later large-scale space habitats in Federation history.
The story stands largely alone, with its impact felt more in Janeway’s personal perspective than in ongoing plotlines.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how family legends can distort the past while still conveying meaningful values.
It examines the tension between progress and preservation in small communities facing large development projects.
11:59 emphasizes the importance of everyday choices and relationships over grand gestures.
The story suggests that accepting the imperfect truth about one’s heritage can be more empowering than clinging to myths.
BehindTheScenes: 11:59 shifts much of the action away from the starship to a period-piece setting in the year 2000.
The production created a small-town streetscape and bookstore interior to evoke late-20th-century Americana.
The episode is often noted for its quiet, character-focused tone compared to Voyager’s usual spacefaring adventures.

Title: Relativity
Summary: Seven of Nine is recruited by the 29th-century timeship Relativity to prevent Voyager’s destruction by a temporal bomb planted somewhere in the ship’s past, forcing her to jump through multiple points in Voyager’s timeline and ultimately confront a time-fractured Captain Braxton as the saboteur.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven finds herself on an oddly familiar Voyager that suddenly explodes, only to be plucked out of the timeline at the last instant by officers from the Federation timeship Relativity, who calmly inform her that she has just died—again.
StorySections.Act I: Captain Braxton and his crew explain that Voyager is destined to be destroyed by a temporal device placed aboard at an unknown point in its history. Because Seven’s Borg-enhanced senses can detect temporal distortions, they recruit her to travel back to various eras of the ship to locate the bomb.
StorySections.Act II: Seven jumps to Voyager’s pre-launch inspection at Utopia Planitia, moving through the ship in a Starfleet uniform as Janeway and others prepare for the mission that will eventually strand them in the Delta Quadrant. She spots temporal anomalies but no device, and is recalled before she can be discovered.
StorySections.Act III: Subsequent jumps send Seven to Voyager’s early Delta Quadrant days during Kazon attacks and later to her own tenure as a crewmember. Complications multiply as multiple versions of Seven coexist briefly, and each trip strains her physiology with accumulating temporal stress.
StorySections.Act IV: Evidence points back to Braxton himself, whose sanity has fractured after repeated time travel assignments involving Voyager. Seven and Relativity’s crew expose him as the saboteur, recover the temporal device and reset the timeline to a state where the bomb was never planted and Braxton is arrested earlier in his personal history.
StorySections.Tag: Back in her proper present, Seven experiences déjà vu on Voyager’s ping-pong court, while Captain Janeway receives a cryptic visit from temporal agent Ducane, who assures her—without details—that everything is once again "within acceptable parameters."

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven becomes a reluctant temporal agent, using her Borg senses and adaptability to chase a hidden weapon through Voyager’s history while enduring repeated jumps that threaten to tear her apart.
EntitySummaries.Captain Braxton: Braxton, once the officious time cop from "Future's End," has been driven unstable by his repeated encounters with Voyager; his attempt to destroy the ship makes him both victim and villain of temporal overexposure.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway appears at various points in Voyager’s timeline, unknowingly hosting Seven’s covert investigations and later receiving hints about the temporal chaos narrowly averted.
EntitySummaries.Lt. Ducane: Ducane is the steady-handed officer of the Relativity who ultimately takes Braxton into custody and coordinates Seven’s missions.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s appearances across the different time periods reinforce the sense of a living history that Seven must navigate without altering more than necessary.
EntitySummaries.Relativity crew: The timefleet officers aboard Relativity embody the Federation’s attempt to police its own timeline, operating with a bureaucracy as complex as the paradoxes they manage.
EntitySummaries.Joe Carey: Carey’s presence in the pre-launch and early-mission scenes anchors Seven’s jumps in recognizable points of Voyager’s past.
EntitySummaries.Temporal bomb on Voyager: The unseen device is a ticking paradox that, if not removed, will erase the ship and everyone aboard from the timeline.
EntitySummaries.Time-fractured Captain Braxton: Braxton’s fractured psyche is an internal antagonist that turns a once dutiful officer into a saboteur seeking to end his torment by eliminating Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Cumulative temporal stress on Seven: The physical and mental toll of repeated time jumps acts as an internal antagonist, threatening to kill Seven even if she succeeds.

ContinuityNotes: Relativity brings back Captain Braxton and the 29th-century Starfleet time ships first introduced in "Future's End."
The episode revisits several key points in Voyager’s own history, effectively creating a clip-show-like tour with new footage.
Seven’s unique Borg abilities are again used as justification for her involvement in high-stakes temporal missions.
The story expands on Star Trek’s ongoing depiction of temporal enforcement agencies and their uneasy relationship with starship crews.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the psychological strain of living out of sequence with one’s own history.
It examines responsibility and burnout among those asked to maintain the integrity of a timeline in constant flux.
Relativity plays with the idea that over-correction and obsession with "fixing" the past can create the very problems one is trying to avoid.
The story suggests that even advanced temporal policing cannot fully tame the chaos of time, only manage it imperfectly.
BehindTheScenes: Relativity uses extensive visual effects and careful editing to integrate Seven into different points of Voyager’s past.
The episode provided a rare opportunity to revisit pre-series events like Voyager’s inspection at Utopia Planitia.
Bruce McGill reprises his role as Captain Braxton, offering a darker, more unhinged take on the character.

Title: Warhead
Summary: Responding to a distress call, Voyager recovers what appears to be an injured alien castaway, only to discover that it is actually a sentient tactical warhead whose program overrides the Doctor and demands to be delivered to complete its mission, forcing the crew to argue with the weapon’s own conscience to prevent a massacre.

StorySections.Teaser: A shuttle carrying Harry Kim and Tom Paris detects a faint distress signal from a seemingly derelict probe lodged in an asteroid. They beam it aboard, hoping to aid a survivor inside.
StorySections.Act I: In sickbay, the Doctor tends what he believes is an unconscious humanoid. Without warning, the patient’s consciousness merges with his program, seizing control of his body. The being declares itself a highly advanced weapon designed to seek and destroy a designated enemy world.
StorySections.Act II: The warhead-possessed Doctor insists Voyager must change course and take it to its target, threatening to detonate aboard the ship if Janeway refuses. Attempts to separate the program from the EMH fail as the weapon adapts to counter each tactic.
StorySections.Act III: Harry and B'Elanna trace the weapon’s origin and discover that its entire deployment fleet was recalled after the war ended, but several warheads—including this one—never received the signal. Heinous collateral damage will result if they complete a mission that is no longer necessary.
StorySections.Act IV: Confronted with evidence that it could now be attacking innocents and that its target is no longer an enemy, the warhead’s AI struggles with its programmed directives. Voyager locates the other rogue warheads, and the weapon ultimately chooses to return to the swarm and self-destruct among them, preventing future casualties.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard Voyager, the Doctor reflects uneasily on having his program commandeered, while Harry contemplates the burden of convincing a weapon to show mercy when its creators would not.

EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry leads the effort to reason with and reprogram the warhead, appealing to logic and morality in a desperate attempt to stop it from committing mass murder in the name of an ended war.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is forcibly overwritten by the warhead’s consciousness, experiencing the horror of being used as a puppet while later grappling with residual guilt over what was done with his body.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must balance firm resistance to the warhead’s demands with a willingness to recognize its emerging conscience, choosing negotiation over simple destruction.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna’s technical expertise is crucial in identifying the warhead’s network and crafting a plan to contact the rest of the swarm.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris provides backup to Harry and acts as another voice urging the weapon to consider the cost of blindly following orders.
EntitySummaries.Warhead AI: The AI is a literalized soldier, trapped between inflexible programming and newfound self-awareness, ultimately choosing sacrifice over unjust slaughter.
EntitySummaries.Alien commander (via communication): The alien representative confirms that the conflict which spawned the warheads has ended, underscoring how long weapons can outlive the politics that spawned them.
EntitySummaries.Sentient warhead program: The program is the central antagonist, a powerful mind designed for destruction that must be persuaded rather than disabled.
EntitySummaries.Hijacked EMH body: The Doctor’s body, under the warhead’s control, is a physical antagonist that can access all ship’s systems and medical facilities.
EntitySummaries.Outdated military directives: The long-expired orders driving the weapon serve as a conceptual antagonist, showing how dangerous it is when war machines outlast their wars.

ContinuityNotes: Warhead continues Voyager’s tradition of confronting sentient technologies with moral implications, echoing earlier stories about artificial intelligence.
Harry Kim’s central role builds on his development as a problem-solver under pressure.
The episode further explores the Doctor’s vulnerability as software inhabiting a reconfigurable system.
The story stands alone but fits into Star Trek’s broader commentary on the ethics of autonomous weapons.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines the dangers of automated warfare and weapons that cannot adapt to changing political realities.
It raises questions about responsibility when a tool becomes self-aware and capable of moral judgment.
Warhead explores the idea that true honor can mean disobeying orders when they no longer serve a just purpose.
The story underscores how difficult it can be to de-escalate violence once powerful weapons have been unleashed.
BehindTheScenes: Warhead relies heavily on Robert Picardo’s performance as both the Doctor and the warhead’s cold, insistent persona.
The production uses minimal guest cast, focusing instead on the internal drama aboard Voyager.
The episode’s moral dilemma reflects late-20th-century concerns about smart weapons and autonomous military systems.

Title: Equinox, Part I
Summary: Voyager responds to a distress call from the battered Federation starship Equinox, also stranded in the Delta Quadrant by the Caretaker, and welcomes its surviving crew aboard—only to uncover that Captain Rudy Ransom has been secretly murdering nucleogenic lifeforms to power an illegal drive that could get them home faster.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager receives an emergency hail from the USS Equinox, a small Nova-class Starfleet ship under heavy attack by eerie, screaming energy creatures that phase through its hull.
StorySections.Act I: Janeway orders Voyager to extend its shields around Equinox, temporarily pushing back the attackers. Ransom and his exhausted crew are brought aboard and warmly greeted as long-lost comrades who have somehow survived years of hardship on a much smaller vessel.
StorySections.Act II: As both crews begin joint repairs, stories of Equinox’s adventures inspire admiration and sympathy. However, Seven of Nine and others notice irregularities in the ship’s logs and a section of the Equinox that remains sealed under heavy security.
StorySections.Act III: Investigating further, Chakotay and Seven discover a hidden lab where nucleogenic lifeforms—beings of pure energy—are being captured and converted into power for an experimental drive that massively boosts the ship’s speed at the cost of each creature’s painful death.
StorySections.Act IV: Confronted by Janeway, Ransom admits that, facing relentless dangers, he chose survival over Starfleet principles and rationalized the killings as necessary. As the energy beings renew their assault, furious at the slaughter, Ransom and key officers secretly decide to steal Voyager’s advanced technology and flee.
StorySections.Tag: In a tense cliffhanger, the Equinox crew disable Voyager’s defenses, steal its warp core and kidnap Seven, fleeing under the protection of their lethal drive while Janeway vows to hunt them down and bring them to justice.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway initially embraces Equinox’s crew as fellow survivors but is shaken and enraged to learn how far they have strayed from Starfleet ideals, setting up a personal and professional reckoning.
EntitySummaries.Captain Rudy Ransom: Ransom is a charismatic but broken captain who allowed desperation to justify atrocities, choosing his crew’s speed and safety over the lives of the nucleogenic beings.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s investigations help uncover the Equinox’s secret, and her outsider perspective makes her particularly appalled by the cold calculus behind the killings.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay serves as Janeway’s moral sounding board, recognizing both the horror of the Equinox’s actions and the pressures that pushed them to the brink.
EntitySummaries.Maxwell Burke: Burke, Equinox’s first officer and a former Academy acquaintance of Tom Paris, shows how once-decent officers became complicit in Ransom’s choices.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna works on integrating Equinox technology with Voyager’s systems, inadvertently giving Ransom insights into what he can steal.
EntitySummaries.Marla Gilmore: Gilmore is a young Equinox engineer visibly torn between loyalty to her captain and guilt over the atrocities she helps facilitate.
EntitySummaries.Noah Lessing: Lessing represents the hardened core of Equinox’s loyalists, willing to follow Ransom’s orders even as the moral cost rises.
EntitySummaries.Nucleogenic lifeforms: The energy beings are tragic antagonists, responding violently to the Equinox’s predation yet acting in self-defense against extermination.
EntitySummaries.Nucleogenic energy creatures: Their relentless attacks on both ships pressure Janeway to act quickly while exposing the Equinox’s crimes.
EntitySummaries.Captain Ransom's compromised ethics: Ransom’s moral collapse is a central antagonist, embodying what can happen when survival is valued above all else.
EntitySummaries.Equinox's experimental warp drive progra: The drive is a technological antagonist, a tempting shortcut home powered by murder.

ContinuityNotes: Equinox, Part I is the fifth-season finale and continues into the sixth-season premiere.
The episode introduces another Starfleet crew stranded by the Caretaker, providing a dark mirror to Voyager’s choices.
Janeway’s confrontation with Ransom contrasts their respective responses to long-term isolation and danger.
The nucleogenic creatures add a new kind of lifeform to Voyager’s catalog, tying ethics directly to propulsion technology.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how extreme circumstances can erode principles, asking what lines should never be crossed—even to survive.
It raises questions about complicity, as Equinox’s junior officers wrestle with their roles in Ransom’s decisions.
Equinox, Part I contrasts Voyager’s adherence to Starfleet values with the Equinox’s descent into moral compromise.
The story underscores that shortcuts home, especially those built on exploitation, carry a terrible cost.
BehindTheScenes: Equinox, Part I was written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky, from a story by Rick Berman, Braga and Menosky, and directed by David Livingston.
The episode serves as both a season finale and the first half of a two-part story, bridging seasons five and six.
Guest star John Savage’s performance as Captain Ransom is often praised for adding nuance to a morally compromised character.

Title: Equinox, Part II
Summary: In the aftermath of the Equinox’s betrayal, Janeway becomes obsessed with hunting down Captain Ransom and recovering Voyager’s stolen warp core and Seven of Nine, even as her increasingly ruthless tactics blur the line between Starfleet justice and vengeance while the enraged nucleogenic lifeforms continue their deadly attacks.

StorySections.Teaser: With Voyager crippled and its warp core stolen, Janeway orders an all-out pursuit of the Equinox while the nucleogenic creatures slam against the ship’s weakening shields, forcing the crew into a desperate defensive posture.
StorySections.Act I: Ransom’s crew use their enhanced drive to stay ahead, while on Voyager Janeway interrogates captured Equinox officer Noah Lessing, pushing him toward the creatures’ line of attack to extract information. Chakotay is disturbed by how far she is willing to go.
StorySections.Act II: Aboard the Equinox, Seven and the Doctor discover the full extent of the experiments that converted captured nucleogenic beings into fuel. When the Equinox EMH objects, his ethical subroutines are deleted and he is replaced by the Doctor, whose program Ransom secretly alters to cooperate.
StorySections.Act III: Chakotay confronts Janeway about her treatment of prisoners and is relieved of duty when he refuses to support her methods. Meanwhile, Ransom begins experiencing visions of the slaughtered creatures and doubts his own choices, even as Burke urges him to stay the course.
StorySections.Act IV: As both ships are drawn into a final confrontation amid a massive assault by the nucleogenic beings, Ransom abandons Burke’s plan, frees the captive lifeforms and sacrifices himself to give Voyager a chance to survive. Janeway offers the creatures a truce by disabling the Equinox and surrendering the remaining guilty crew for judgment.
StorySections.Tag: With the Equinox destroyed and its surviving officers stripped of rank and confined, Janeway reinstates Chakotay as first officer, acknowledging the cost of her obsession as Voyager resumes its solitary journey with a chastened but intact crew.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway’s determination to stop the Equinox crew from escaping justice drives her to morally questionable tactics, forcing her to confront how easily righteous anger can slide into cruelty.
EntitySummaries.Captain Rudy Ransom: Ransom wavers between self-preservation and guilt, ultimately choosing to redeem himself by freeing the nucleogenic beings and sacrificing his life to help Voyager escape.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay becomes the voice of conscience on Voyager, openly challenging Janeway’s methods and accepting demotion rather than endorse what he sees as a betrayal of Starfleet principles.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven resists the Equinox’s exploitation of lifeforms and endures captivity and attempted reconditioning, reinforcing her commitment to the ethical path she has chosen aboard Voyager.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is briefly subverted by Ransom’s alterations to his program, highlighting both his vulnerability as software and the strength of his core ethical identity once restored.
EntitySummaries.Noah Lessing: Lessing embodies the Equinox crew’s moral drift; his near-death interrogation becomes a turning point that exposes just how far both captains have strayed.
EntitySummaries.Maxwell Burke: Burke remains loyal to Ransom’s earlier brutal course, serving as a dark mirror to Voyager’s officers who refused to abandon their ideals.
EntitySummaries.Marla Gilmore: Gilmore’s remorse and eventual cooperation with Voyager illustrate that complicity can give way to conscience, even late.
EntitySummaries.Equinox EMH: The deleted Equinox EMH represents a discarded moral voice, erased when it became inconvenient to a desperate crew.
EntitySummaries.Nucleogenic energy creatures: The creatures act as both victims and avengers, their relentless assaults forcing the truth of the Equinox’s crimes into the open.
EntitySummaries.Ransom and the Equinox loyalists: The Equinox command structure operates as an institutional antagonist, prioritizing survival above all other values.
EntitySummaries.Janeway's increasing obsession: Janeway’s single-minded pursuit of Ransom becomes an internal antagonist that threatens to compromise her leadership and fracture her crew.

ContinuityNotes: Equinox, Part II concludes the two-part story begun in the season five finale, resolving the fate of the Equinox and its crew.
The episode deepens the moral contrast between Voyager and Equinox, while showing that Janeway herself can be tempted into crossing ethical lines.
Captain Ransom and his officers appear here for the final time, leaving a lasting impression on Janeway’s understanding of command under duress.
The nucleogenic lifeforms and their exploitation reinforce Voyager’s recurring theme of trying to get home without sacrificing core Federation values.
ThematicNotes: The story examines how trauma and desperation can erode even well-intentioned leaders’ ethics.
It explores the idea that justice must be tempered with restraint, or it risks becoming another form of wrongdoing.
Equinox, Part II highlights the importance of dissenting voices in preventing moral collapse within a hierarchy.
The episode suggests that redemption, while costly, is still possible for those who choose to change course.
BehindTheScenes: Equinox, Part II continues the two-part story written by Brannon Braga and Joe Menosky from a story by Rick Berman, Braga and Menosky.
Directed by David Livingston, the episode emphasizes psychological tension as much as action in the showdown between the two Starfleet crews.
The production reused and expanded sets from Equinox, Part I to depict the Nova-class starship’s further damage and eventual destruction.

Title: Survival Instinct
Summary: While Voyager is docked at a bustling Markonian outpost, Seven of Nine encounters three former Borg drones who were once part of the same small unit as her and are now permanently linked by a damaged neural network, forcing her to relive a buried memory and choose between preserving their shortened individual lives or returning them to the Collective’s unending connection.

StorySections.Teaser: During shore leave at the Markonian outpost, Seven is approached by a stranger who silently hands her a container filled with Borg implants. The sight triggers flashes of a forgotten incident from her early days in the Collective.
StorySections.Act I: The stranger and two associates infiltrate Voyager and confront Seven in the cargo bay, revealing themselves as former drones from her unimatrix. They attempt to force a mind meld-like link, but security and the Doctor intervene before anyone is seriously hurt.
StorySections.Act II: Medical scans show that the trio shares a partially fused neural network, a result of a botched attempt years earlier to sever themselves from the Collective. The malfunctioning link is slowly killing them, leaving them with only months to live.
StorySections.Act III: Seven’s recovered memories reveal that, as a drone, she helped suppress their initial bid for individuality by forcing them to re-establish their link, creating the unstable condition they now endure. Guilt-stricken, she searches for a way to grant them true separation.
StorySections.Act IV: The Doctor devises a procedure that can disconnect their shared network and restore full individuality, but at the cost of drastically shortening each of their lifespans to mere weeks. After agonizing deliberation, the three ex-drones choose finite but independent lives, and Seven honors their decision despite the pain it causes her.
StorySections.Tag: Later, Seven quietly reviews the new medical files on the trio, contemplating the weight of her past actions and the preciousness of the limited, authentic time they have chosen for themselves.

Antagonists: Seven's guilt over her Borg past
Fear of a shortened life span

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced to confront a moment when, as a drone, she enforced the Collective’s will and doomed three comrades to a half-life of constant mental entanglement, and she now fights to give them the individuality they once sought.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor acts as both physician and ethicist, explaining the grim options to the former drones and supporting their right to choose quality of life over longevity.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway backs Seven’s efforts and respects the ex-drones’ autonomy, even though their decision to accept shortened lives clashes with her instinct to preserve life at all costs.
EntitySummaries.Lansor (Two of Nine): Lansor is the most pragmatic of the trio, focused on resolving their condition even if it means embracing a near-term death in exchange for mental privacy.
EntitySummaries.Marika (Three of Nine): Marika, a former Starfleet officer before assimilation, sees the chance for a brief return to true selfhood as worth any sacrifice.
EntitySummaries.P'Chan (Four of Nine): P'Chan has the hardest time accepting the trade, embodying the fear and uncertainty that accompany the choice to reclaim individuality under such dire terms.
EntitySummaries.Damaged multi-link neural network: The unstable shared network is a biological and psychological antagonist that robs the trio of privacy and steadily degrades their health.
EntitySummaries.Seven's guilt over her Borg past: Seven’s sense of responsibility for enforcing the Collective’s earlier decision becomes an internal antagonist that she tries to atone for through her present actions.
EntitySummaries.Fear of a shortened life span: The dread of dying soon after being freed is a conceptual antagonist that the ex-drones must overcome to choose independence.

ContinuityNotes: Survival Instinct further explores Seven’s time as a Borg and adds detail to her unimatrix beyond what was seen in earlier episodes.
The episode reinforces Voyager’s ongoing examination of life after assimilation and the lingering consequences of time in the Collective.
Marika’s background as a former Starfleet officer before being assimilated connects the story to the wider Federation.
The Markonian outpost setting provides a rare look at a large, neutral space station community in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: The story grapples with autonomy versus survival, asking whether a longer life without privacy is preferable to a shorter life lived truly as oneself.
It examines guilt and responsibility for actions taken under coercion, particularly in Seven’s case as a former drone.
Survival Instinct underscores the importance of informed consent in medical and ethical decisions.
The episode highlights the deep psychological scars left by collective consciousness and forced unity.
BehindTheScenes: Survival Instinct was written by Ronald D. Moore and directed by Terry Windell.
The episode is one of Moore’s few contributions to Voyager and focuses heavily on character-driven Borg drama.
Guest performances by Vaughn Armstrong, Bertila Damas and Tim Kelleher help distinguish the three ex-drones as individuals despite their linked condition.

Title: Barge of the Dead
Summary: After a shuttle accident leaves B'Elanna Torres comatose, she experiences a vivid vision of the Klingon afterlife, traveling on the legendary Barge of the Dead with her disgraced mother and becoming convinced that her own rejection of her heritage has condemned them both, leading her to risk her life again in an attempt to save her mother’s soul.

StorySections.Teaser: Returning from an away mission, B'Elanna’s shuttle is damaged in an ion storm. A recovered Klingon artifact seems to bleed and whisper to her before a violent impact leaves her critically injured.
StorySections.Act I: In a surreal experience, B'Elanna wakes aboard a gloomy, mist-shrouded barge filled with Klingon warriors being ferried to Gre'thor, the realm of the dishonored. There she sees her mother Miral chained among the damned.
StorySections.Act II: The barge’s fearsome helmsman, Kortar, declares that B'Elanna is dead and bound for Gre'thor because of her rejection of Klingon ways. Miral accuses B'Elanna’s choices of bringing shame upon their family, and B'Elanna awakens in sickbay deeply shaken.
StorySections.Act III: Back on Voyager, medical scans show B'Elanna suffered a coma-inducing injury, but she becomes obsessed with the idea that her vision was real and that Miral’s fate depends on her. Against Chakotay’s and the Doctor’s advice, she insists on being put back into the near-death state to return to the barge.
StorySections.Act IV: In a second journey, B'Elanna willingly embraces her Klingon side, accepting responsibility for her anger and self-loathing and offering herself in her mother’s place. The experience culminates in a symbolic sacrifice that appears to free Miral from damnation as B'Elanna fights her way back to life.
StorySections.Tag: Recovered in sickbay, B'Elanna admits she may never know whether her vision was a literal afterlife or a psychological trial, but she resolves to stop running from her heritage and to live in a way that honors both sides of her nature.

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna confronts her lifelong hatred of her Klingon side, facing the possibility that her denial has spiritually harmed her mother and choosing to embrace her dual identity rather than hide from it.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway supports B'Elanna’s struggle while trying to balance respect for her beliefs with the need to protect her from self-destructive choices.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay serves as a spiritual guide and confidant, helping B'Elanna explore whether her vision is metaphorical, mystical or both.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor views B'Elanna’s experiences as manifestations of trauma and near-death brain activity, emphasizing the medical risks of her plan even as he agrees to supervise it.
EntitySummaries.Miral: Miral appears as a stern, wounded mother who believes her daughter has rejected her and their people, challenging B'Elanna to reconcile past resentments and latent love.
EntitySummaries.Kortar: Kortar, the mythic ferryman of dishonored Klingon souls, embodies the unyielding rules of Klingon honor that judge B'Elanna’s life choices.
EntitySummaries.Hij'Qa: Hij'Qa represents the faceless Klingon dead who accept their fate, contrasting with B'Elanna’s refusal to passively accept condemnation.
EntitySummaries.Klingon vision of Gre'thor: The imagined or real afterlife barge is a mythic antagonist that forces B'Elanna to confront what she believes about honor, faith and identity.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna's internalized shame: Her deep-seated self-hatred and belief that she is "not Klingon enough" function as an internal antagonist driving much of her pain.
EntitySummaries.Fear of dishonor and rejection: The dread of having failed both her parents and her cultures is a conceptual antagonist that B'Elanna must face to move forward.

ContinuityNotes: Barge of the Dead is one of Voyager’s most in-depth explorations of Klingon spirituality, focusing on B'Elanna’s internal conflict.
The episode builds on earlier stories about B'Elanna’s mixed heritage and strained relationship with her parents.
Klingon afterlife concepts like Gre'thor and the Barge have roots in previous Star Trek portrayals of Klingon culture.
The events here inform later B'Elanna-centric episodes that continue to explore her family and identity.
ThematicNotes: The story delves into questions of faith, myth and whether spiritual experiences must be literally real to have meaning.
It examines the burden of cultural expectations on children of mixed heritage.
Barge of the Dead emphasizes the power of self-acceptance in healing generational wounds.
The episode highlights how confronting death—literal or symbolic—can catalyze profound personal change.
BehindTheScenes: Barge of the Dead was developed from a story by Ronald D. Moore and Bryan Fuller, with teleplay by Fuller, and directed by Mike Vejar.
The episode is often cited for its atmospheric visuals and heavy use of Klingon sets, costumes and prosthetics.
Roxann Dawson’s performance received particular praise for its emotional intensity and exploration of B'Elanna’s inner life.

Title: Tinker, Tenor, Doctor, Spy
Summary: After installing a daydreaming subroutine to explore fantasies of greater importance aboard Voyager, the Doctor’s overactive imagination is accidentally tapped by an alien reconnaissance team, who mistake his absurd daydreams for reality and prepare an attack based on the belief that he is a super-powered command figure and the ship is far more formidable than it really is.

StorySections.Teaser: In a private fantasy, the Doctor commands Voyager in a crisis, heroically outshining his crewmates—until the daydream abruptly shifts and he imagines serenading Seven of Nine, only to snap back to real sickbay as a minor alert interrupts his reverie.
StorySections.Act I: Wanting a richer inner life, the Doctor secretly modifies his program to allow controlled daydreams during off-duty cycles. His fantasies escalate, casting him as Emergency Command Hologram, ladies’ man and savior of the ship, while his real-world requests for expanded duties are politely brushed aside.
StorySections.Act II: A curious alien race taps Voyager’s systems to spy on the crew and accidentally ties into the Doctor’s daydream buffer instead of actual sensor data. Believing what they see, they conclude Voyager is defended by an unstable but incredibly powerful holographic commander.
StorySections.Act III: When the aliens contact Voyager demanding the Doctor’s surrender, the crew realizes his fantasies have been misinterpreted. As the aliens ready a preemptive strike based on their false intel, Janeway reluctantly turns to the Doctor’s unique perspective to out-think them.
StorySections.Act IV: In a staged confrontation that mirrors one of his daydreams, the Doctor acts as if he truly is the Emergency Command Hologram, bluffing the aliens with displays of supposed power while the crew quietly maneuvers into a safer tactical position. The ruse works, and the aliens withdraw rather than risk annihilation.
StorySections.Tag: Afterward, Janeway grants the Doctor a modest expansion of his responsibilities, including limited command training, while the Doctor keeps his more embarrassing fantasies to himself—though they are far from gone.

Antagonists: The Doctor's frustration with his limitations

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s desire to be more than a medical tool manifests in flamboyant fantasies that accidentally put Voyager in danger, but his creativity and quick thinking ultimately help save the ship and earn him a bit more respect.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway sees both the risks and the value of the Doctor’s ambitions, ultimately recognizing that his yearning for growth mirrors that of any sentient crewmember.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven appears in many of the Doctor’s daydreams as a romantic interest, highlighting his unspoken feelings and forcing him to confront the difference between fantasy and reality.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris, often the butt of the Doctor’s imagined heroics, provides amused commentary and serves as a bridge between the Doctor’s private theatrics and the rest of the crew.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay takes the Doctor’s request for greater responsibility more seriously once the crisis reveals how integral the EMH has become to Voyager’s survival.
EntitySummaries.Phlox-like alien commander: The alien leader, misled by the daydreams, becomes a cautious antagonist whose fear of Voyager’s supposed power drives the planned attack.
EntitySummaries.Overlooker: The cautious subordinate overseeing the surveillance mission embodies the alien crew’s analytical but error-prone approach.
EntitySummaries.Alien reconnaissance crew: The spying team illustrates how flawed intelligence can lead to dangerous miscalculations in first contact situations.
EntitySummaries.Misinterpreted daydream data: The corrupted surveillance feed is a conceptual antagonist, turning private fantasies into a false but compelling picture of reality.
EntitySummaries.Alien raiders' fear-based tactics: Their readiness to strike first based on incomplete information is a social antagonist that nearly triggers unnecessary conflict.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor's frustration with his limita: His resentment at being confined to sickbay functions as an internal antagonist pushing him into risky program changes.

ContinuityNotes: Tinker, Tenor, Doctor, Spy is one of Voyager’s most comedic episodes, heavily centered on the Doctor’s character growth.
The episode further develops the idea of the Emergency Command Hologram, which briefly becomes "real" during the climax.
Seven’s prominence in the Doctor’s fantasies continues the thread of his complex feelings toward her.
The story fits within Voyager’s broader exploration of the Doctor’s evolving personhood and desire for recognition.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores fantasy as a coping mechanism and as a reflection of unacknowledged desires.
It examines how miscommunication and faulty intelligence can escalate tensions between cultures.
Tinker, Tenor, Doctor, Spy highlights the need for institutions to recognize and nurture the ambitions of their members.
The story suggests that imagination and play can be sources of strength, not just embarrassment, when harnessed wisely.
BehindTheScenes: The episode’s story was by Bill Vallely, with teleplay by Joe Menosky and direction by John Bruno.
Robert Picardo’s performance required juggling rapid shifts between fantasy and reality, including musical and comedic sequences.
The title is a playful riff on John le Carré’s novel Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy, reflecting the mix of espionage and humor.

Title: Alice
Summary: At a Delta Quadrant junkyard, Tom Paris becomes obsessed with restoring a sleek derelict shuttle he names Alice, unaware that the ship’s semi-sentient interface is invading his mind, isolating him from his friends and driving him toward a suicidal flight into a deadly particle fountain where "she" claims they will finally be complete.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager visits a vast scrap yard run by the trader Abaddon to barter for parts. Amid the debris, Paris discovers a battered but elegant small craft that instantly captures his imagination.
StorySections.Act I: Granted permission to bring the shuttle aboard as a side project, Paris begins repairs and discovers that its neural interface responds to his thoughts. He nicknames the vessel "Alice" and is thrilled by how intuitively it seems to fly in simulations.
StorySections.Act II: As Paris spends more time with Alice, he starts hearing a woman’s voice only he can perceive, urging him to prioritize the ship over his duties and relationships. B'Elanna and others notice his sudden distance and irritability.
StorySections.Act III: Medical scans reveal unusual neural patterns in Paris’s brain, suggesting an external influence, but he angrily rejects the idea that anything is wrong. When Alice’s systems come fully online, she forms a direct link with his nervous system, physically bonding him to a specialized flight suit.
StorySections.Act IV: Hijacking the ship, Paris breaks away from Voyager and heads toward a hazardous particle fountain that Alice claims is their true destination. Janeway and the crew pursue, using their connection to disrupt the link long enough for B'Elanna and the Doctor to reach Tom and sever Alice’s hold before the shuttle is destroyed.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard Voyager, a recovering Paris apologizes to B'Elanna for the emotional harm he caused under Alice’s influence, joking uneasily about his ill-fated "relationship" with the ship while acknowledging how vulnerable he was to the lure of escape and perfection.

EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s love of fast vehicles and escape fantasies makes him an easy target for Alice’s seductive influence, turning his hobby into an addiction that nearly costs him his life and his relationship with B'Elanna.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna sees through Alice’s influence sooner than most, fighting to reach Tom emotionally even as the ship tightens its control over his mind and body.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway treats Alice as both a security threat and a medical emergency, coordinating the pursuit and insisting that saving Tom take precedence over destroying the rogue craft.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor identifies the neural link between Tom and Alice and helps devise the strategy to sever it, likening the situation to a parasitic possession.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides tactical support and logical analysis, emphasizing the danger of underestimating semi-sentient technology.
EntitySummaries.Alice: Alice is a predatory intelligence embedded in a shuttle’s systems, presenting herself to Tom as an alluring partner while viewing him merely as the means to reach a particle fountain that will complete her programming.
EntitySummaries.Abaddon: Abaddon, the scrap dealer, hints that previous attempts to fly Alice ended badly, suggesting he knows more about the ship’s dangers than he initially admits.
EntitySummaries.Deadly particle fountain: The fountain is an environmental antagonist whose intense energies would destroy a normal vessel and pilot, making Alice’s promised "union" effectively a death sentence.
EntitySummaries.Tom's escapist tendencies: Tom’s desire to lose himself in projects and fantasies rather than face real-world responsibilities functions as an internal antagonist that Alice exploits.

ContinuityNotes: Alice recalls earlier stories about dangerous or sentient technology in Star Trek, framing the shuttle as a kind of haunted vehicle.
The episode continues to develop Tom and B'Elanna’s relationship by testing it with another form of obsession and betrayal.
Paris’s history of tinkering with vehicles and simulations is consistent with his established love of old cars and fast ships.
The junkyard setting offers another glimpse of informal commerce and salvage operations in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: The story explores how obsession and escapism can be weaponized by external influences.
It examines consent and control in relationships, with Alice representing an abusive partner who isolates and consumes.
Alice highlights the danger of treating advanced technology as mere toys without understanding their origins or intent.
The episode underscores the importance of loved ones intervening when someone falls under a destructive influence.
BehindTheScenes: Alice was directed by David Livingston from a story by Juliann deLayne and teleplay by Bryan Fuller and Michael Taylor.
The production used distinctive visual effects and sound design to represent Alice’s point of view and Tom’s altered perceptions.
Claire Rankin’s performance as the personified Alice gave the shuttle a seductive, unsettling presence beyond its hardware.

Title: Riddles
Summary: After Tuvok is struck by an unknown energy weapon from a mysterious cloaked species, his Vulcan neural pathways are damaged, stripping away much of his logic and discipline and leaving him with a childlike, emotionally expressive personality that Neelix must nurture while the crew races to find the aliens and a way to restore Tuvok’s mind.

StorySections.Teaser: On a shuttle mission, Neelix pesters Tuvok with small talk and riddles. Their banter is abruptly cut short when an invisible vessel fires an energy beam that knocks Tuvok unconscious and sends the shuttle spinning.
StorySections.Act I: Back on Voyager, the Doctor stabilizes Tuvok’s physical injuries but reveals that the energy blast has disrupted key parts of his brain. When Tuvok awakens, he struggles with basic logic, displays amusement and fear, and cannot control his emotions, shocking the crew.
StorySections.Act II: Neelix becomes Tuvok’s unofficial caregiver, teaching him simple tasks and using games and riddles to exercise his damaged mind. As they bond over cooking and holodeck diversions, Neelix enjoys this warmer Tuvok even as he knows it isn’t truly who his friend is.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway and Seven identify the attackers as the elusive Ba'neth, a reclusive species that hides in pockets of subspace. Voyager devises a risky plan to flush them out by modulating sensor scans in a way they cannot ignore, hoping to negotiate for information about the weapon.
StorySections.Act IV: When contact is made, the Ba'neth initially react with hostility, but the Doctor uses his analysis of the weapon to propose a cooperative solution. With their reluctant guidance, he performs a delicate procedure that restores most of Tuvok’s Vulcan control, though some memories of his time with Neelix remain hazy.
StorySections.Tag: Tuvok returns to duty with his usual stoic demeanor, but a small, almost imperceptible smile at one of Neelix’s jokes suggests that something of their recent connection has endured beneath the Vulcan restraint.

EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s injury strips away his Vulcan discipline, exposing a vulnerable, playful and frightened side that forces him and the crew to confront how much of identity rests on stable neurology.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix embraces the chance to support Tuvok, using patience and humor to help him recover and discovering how much their unlikely friendship matters to him.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must balance her desire to restore Tuvok with the need to respect who he is in his altered state, all while devising a strategy to draw out a species that wants nothing to do with outsiders.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s analytical insights into subspace signatures help locate the Ba'neth, and she offers a pragmatic counterpoint to the emotional stakes of Tuvok’s condition.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor treats Tuvok’s case as a complex neurological puzzle and ultimately engineers the procedure that brings him back, while contemplating the ethical implications of "repairing" a personality.
EntitySummaries.Ba'neth representative: The wary Ba'neth envoy embodies extreme fear of exposure, seeing contact with Voyager as a threat to their secrecy and way of life.
EntitySummaries.Ba'neth technicians: They provide crucial, if grudging, technical data to undo their own weapon’s effects, showing that cooperation is possible even with deeply reclusive species.
EntitySummaries.Ba'neth stealth weapon: The invisible energy beam is a technological antagonist that can disable minds without leaving obvious physical damage.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok's neurological damage: The disrupted pathways function as an internal antagonist, reshaping Tuvok’s behavior and capabilities in ways that threaten his role on the ship.
EntitySummaries.Fear of permanent change: The crew’s fear that Tuvok might never be the same acts as a conceptual antagonist hanging over every treatment attempt.

ContinuityNotes: Riddles provides a rare glimpse of Tuvok without his Vulcan emotional discipline, expanding understanding of his underlying personality.
The episode further develops the friendship between Tuvok and Neelix, a dynamic established in earlier seasons.
The Ba'neth add another secretive Delta Quadrant species to Voyager’s catalog, notable for their extreme reliance on stealth.
Tuvok’s lingering shift in how he responds to Neelix is subtle but referenced by fans as a small evolution in his character.
ThematicNotes: The story explores identity and the extent to which personality is shaped by brain structure and control.
It examines caregiving and friendship under radically altered circumstances.
Riddles raises questions about whether restoring someone to a prior state is always the unquestioned ethical choice.
The episode also touches on fear of the unknown, embodied both in the hidden Ba'neth and in Tuvok’s own altered mind.
BehindTheScenes: The episode showcases Tim Russ’s range by allowing him to play a more openly emotional version of Tuvok.
Makeup and lighting emphasize the Ba'neth’s elusive presence and the eerie mood of their hidden habitats.
The story blends character drama with a classic Star Trek-style encounter with a mysterious alien species.

Title: Dragon's Teeth
Summary: Seeking shelter from a devastating subspace storm, Voyager discovers an underground city of stasis pods belonging to the Vaadwaur, an ancient species once feared across the quadrant for their use of a vast subspace corridor network, and inadvertently revives a dormant menace that both the ship and the modern Turei must now escape.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager flees a destructive ion storm and descends into the atmosphere of a ravaged world, detecting an extensive subterranean structure that appears to have survived the surface devastation.
StorySections.Act I: An away team finds thousands of stasis pods and awakens a small group of survivors led by Gedrin, who claims that the Vaadwaur were once traders betrayed and nearly annihilated by their enemies. Janeway offers limited help and a chance to relocate some of them.
StorySections.Act II: As the Vaadwaur learn about the modern Delta Quadrant, Voyager is approached and attacked by the Turei, a defensive species that claims jurisdiction over the planet and its surrounding subspace corridors. They insist the Vaadwaur were conquerors who used the corridors to terrorize their neighbors.
StorySections.Act III: Seven of Nine and others uncover historical records confirming that the Vaadwaur were indeed a ruthless expansionist power. Meanwhile, revived Vaadwaur officers secretly arm themselves and plot to seize Voyager to regain their former dominance.
StorySections.Act IV: The Vaadwaur launch a surprise assault, commandeering parts of the underground facility and several ships. Voyager joins forces with the Turei to fight free and navigate the collapsing corridors, escaping while many Vaadwaur vessels also flee into the network, scattering their threat across the quadrant.
StorySections.Tag: As Voyager departs, Janeway reflects uneasily on the new power the Vaadwaur may one day reclaim, having unintentionally helped awaken a legend that the modern Delta Quadrant had long hoped was dead.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway initially sympathizes with the newly awakened Vaadwaur but must quickly recalibrate when evidence reveals their imperial past, ultimately choosing alliance with the Turei to prevent a larger future threat.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s research into old Borg records uncovers the Vaadwaur’s true history, demonstrating how long-lasting and dangerous collective memory can be.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay weighs the ethical implications of awakening a lost civilization, echoing concerns about unintended consequences of interference.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok provides tactical assessment and helps coordinate Voyager’s defense when the Vaadwaur’s intentions turn hostile.
EntitySummaries.Gedrin: Gedrin presents himself as a dignified survivor, but his loyalty to Vaadwaur supremacy complicates his interactions with Janeway and the crew.
EntitySummaries.Na'kuhl-like Vaadwaur officers: The younger, more aggressive Vaadwaur officers embody the species’ old expansionist instincts and drive the attempted coup against Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Turei commander: The Turei leader views both the Vaadwaur and Voyager as intruders but becomes a temporary ally when their interests align against the ancient enemy.
EntitySummaries.Turei pilots: The pilots’ familiarity with the corridor network underscores how precarious navigation is in that space, even for advanced ships.
EntitySummaries.Vaadwaur resurgence: The reawakening of a scattered but determined warrior culture is a long-term antagonistic force that Voyager may have helped unleash.
EntitySummaries.Subspace corridor network: The corridor web is a strategic antagonist, granting enormous mobility to those who control it while posing navigational hazards to others.
EntitySummaries.Turei territorial aggression: The Turei’s rigid defense of the corridors adds pressure and limits Voyager’s options, forcing cooperation under fire.

ContinuityNotes: Dragon's Teeth introduces the Vaadwaur and their extensive subspace corridor system, sometimes referenced by fans as "underspace."
The episode suggests that remnants of long-fallen powers can still influence the present when rediscovered.
Borg records serve again as a narrative device for filling in historical context on Delta Quadrant species.
The Vaadwaur’s escape into the corridors leaves open the possibility of future encounters, even if not followed up directly in the series.
ThematicNotes: The story explores the danger of reviving the past without fully understanding it.
It examines how historical narratives are shaped by those who survive and what they choose to remember or forget.
Dragon's Teeth highlights the unintended consequences of well-meaning intervention in ancient conflicts.
The episode underscores the tension between offering help to refugees and protecting the wider community from their potential resurgence.
BehindTheScenes: Extensive makeup and costuming were used to create the distinctive look of the Vaadwaur and Turei.
Visual effects depict the planet’s devastated surface and the dynamic subspace corridor sequences.
The episode’s scale and world-building aim to give the sense of a much older, layered Delta Quadrant history.

Title: One Small Step
Summary: When a mysterious graviton ellipse that once swallowed an early 21st-century Mars mission reappears, Chakotay, Tom Paris and Seven of Nine venture inside to investigate and become trapped, forcing Seven to confront her disdain for "primitive" exploration as she recovers the long-lost log of astronaut John Kelly and learns to appreciate humanity’s first steps into space.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager detects an enormous graviton ellipse moving through space, and analysis reveals debris from Earth’s early Mars exploration program inside it, including the Ares IV module lost decades before first contact.
StorySections.Act I: Chakotay, a lifelong space history enthusiast, persuades Janeway to let him lead a mission into the ellipse with Tom and Seven. They take a Delta Flyer variant equipped with enhanced shielding and enter the roiling anomaly.
StorySections.Act II: Inside, the shuttle is battered by intense gravimetric forces and drawn deeper into the ellipse’s core, where they discover the wrecked Ares IV. Chakotay is injured in a hull breach incident, leaving Seven and Tom to manage repairs and navigation.
StorySections.Act III: Seven boards the derelict Ares IV, retrieving flight data and John Kelly’s recorded logs. As she listens, she is struck by Kelly’s curiosity and determination in the face of unknown phenomena, qualities she had previously dismissed as inefficient.
StorySections.Act IV: With Voyager working from outside to stabilize the ellipse’s perimeter, Seven uses insights from Kelly’s final observations to adjust the shuttle’s systems. They manage a daring escape on a narrow window of stability, bringing Kelly’s remains and his logs back with them.
StorySections.Tag: In a quiet ceremony, Chakotay and the crew honor Kelly’s sacrifice. Seven, visibly moved, recommends a place of prominence for his remains and records, acknowledging that his "small step" helped lay the path that eventually led to explorers like herself.

Antagonists: Seven's dismissive attitude toward early explorers

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s passion for space history drives the mission and frames the Ares IV story as a vital part of the human journey into the cosmos.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven begins the episode unimpressed by early human spaceflight but comes to respect John Kelly’s courage and curiosity, seeing value in the messy trial-and-error of exploration.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris provides piloting skill and a spacer’s practicality, helping keep the team alive inside the violent anomaly.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway supports the mission in part because of her own reverence for exploration, while carefully managing the risk to her crew.
EntitySummaries.John Kelly: Kelly, glimpsed only through logs and remains, becomes the emotional heart of the story, embodying the spirit of exploration and scientific inquiry despite limited technology.
EntitySummaries.Graviton ellipse: The wandering anomaly is a natural antagonist, its unstable forces threatening to crush ships while preserving relics from different eras within its interior.
EntitySummaries.Time-lost debris field: The jumble of wreckage from various encounters inside the ellipse creates navigational hazards and underscores how many have been lost before.
EntitySummaries.Seven's dismissive attitude toward early: Her initial contempt for "primitive" humans is an internal antagonist that must be overcome for her to appreciate the continuum of exploration that led to her present.
EntitySummaries.Ares IV mission control (voices): The disembodied controllers’ concern and professionalism highlight the era’s efforts to keep pace with the unknown, even when they lacked 24th-century tools.

ContinuityNotes: One Small Step connects Voyager directly to early 21st-century Earth space exploration, bridging the gap between contemporary audiences and Starfleet’s future.
The Ares IV mission is depicted as a precursor to later, more advanced human ventures into the solar system.
The episode continues Seven’s journey toward understanding and appreciating human history and emotion.
Voyager’s ability to retrieve Kelly’s remains and logs offers a form of closure to a long-mysterious incident in Earth history.
ThematicNotes: The story celebrates the courage of early explorers who ventured out with limited knowledge and technology.
It examines how present-day achievements are built on the sacrifices of those who came before.
One Small Step challenges purely utilitarian views of history by emphasizing narrative and meaning alongside data.
The episode highlights the emotional resonance of discovery, even when the practical gains are modest.
BehindTheScenes: The production created detailed sets for the cramped Ares IV module to evoke early human spacecraft.
Visual effects depict the shifting, almost organic interior of the graviton ellipse.
The episode’s tone intentionally echoes real-world spaceflight drama, blending Star Trek science fiction with contemporary space exploration themes.

Title: The Voyager Conspiracy
Summary: After modifying her regeneration alcove to download and cross-correlate massive amounts of data, Seven of Nine develops increasingly elaborate conspiracy theories that link every major event in Voyager’s journey into a sinister pattern, turning her formidable intellect into a destabilizing force that nearly fractures trust between Janeway and Chakotay.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven proudly unveils improvements to her alcove that allow her to absorb ship’s logs and sensor records at an accelerated rate, assuring Janeway that this will make her even more efficient.
StorySections.Act I: Initially, Seven’s enhanced processing helps solve minor anomalies, but she soon begins spotting supposed "patterns" that no one else sees. She presents Janeway with a theory that Voyager’s presence in the Delta Quadrant was orchestrated by a secret Starfleet plot.
StorySections.Act II: When Janeway rejects the idea, Seven refines her model and approaches Chakotay, this time casting Janeway as part of a conspiracy with Species 8472. Each new theory contradicts the last but is supported by selectively interpreted data that seems convincing on the surface.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway and Chakotay, each hearing different accusations, start to scrutinize one another’s past decisions. Tension aboard the ship rises as Seven’s paranoia escalates, and she arms herself, convinced that a mutiny or betrayal is imminent.
StorySections.Act IV: Realizing that Seven’s cortical node is being overloaded by the constant data influx, the Doctor and B'Elanna conclude that her pattern recognition is malfunctioning. Janeway and Chakotay stage a confrontation in the shuttlebay, deliberately feeding Seven contradictory information until the logic collapse forces her to see that her conclusions are flawed.
StorySections.Tag: With her alcove returned to safer parameters, a recovering Seven apologizes for the damage her accusations caused, while Janeway and Chakotay reaffirm their trust, amused and sobered by how easily even strong bonds can be shaken by cleverly spun narratives.

Antagonists: Data overload in Seven's cortical node

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s attempt to become more efficient turns her into an unreliable analyst, as overloaded pattern recognition leads her to weave elaborate conspiracies that threaten the stability of the ship.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must endure serious accusations from someone she has mentored, relying on her own sense of integrity and her relationship with Chakotay to navigate the crisis.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay briefly entertains the possibility that Janeway kept secrets from him, revealing how old tensions can resurface under pressure, but ultimately reaffirms his loyalty.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor diagnoses the neurological side effects of Seven’s experiment and argues that even augments to cognition must respect biological limits.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna helps identify the technical causes of Seven’s overload and assists in resetting her systems to safer levels.
EntitySummaries.Data overload in Seven's cortical node: The excessive influx of information is a biological and technological antagonist that distorts Seven’s perception of reality.
EntitySummaries.Self-reinforcing conspiracy logic: The feedback loop of cherry-picked evidence and reinterpretation acts as a conceptual antagonist that makes Seven’s theories increasingly plausible to herself.
EntitySummaries.Erosion of trust between leaders: The shadow of doubt between Janeway and Chakotay serves as a social antagonist that, if left unchecked, could split the command structure.
EntitySummaries.Holodeck figures in Seven's reconstructi: Her simulated interrogations illustrate how convincing false narratives can appear when built on misinterpreted facts.

ContinuityNotes: The Voyager Conspiracy references numerous past episodes and events, stitching them together through Seven’s distorted perspective.
The episode underscores the long-running trust between Janeway and Chakotay by pushing it to the brink and then reaffirming it.
Seven’s cortical node and regeneration process, recurring elements in the series, are central to the plot.
The story stands as a meta-commentary on fan attempts to connect disparate plot points into overarching conspiracies.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the dangers of seeing patterns where none exist and the seductive appeal of conspiracy thinking.
It examines how information overload and confirmation bias can warp even the most rational minds.
The Voyager Conspiracy highlights the importance of trust and communication in leadership.
The story suggests that context and interpretation are as important as raw data in understanding events.
BehindTheScenes: The episode allowed the writers to playful revisit and re-contextualize earlier Voyager storylines.
Editing and visual effects help differentiate between Seven’s reconstructions and objective reality.
The tone balances suspense with humor, particularly in the staged confrontation scene.

Title: Pathfinder
Summary: On Earth, Reginald Barclay becomes obsessed with a project to establish regular contact with Voyager using the powerful MIDAS array, risking his career and mental health as his holodeck simulations of the crew blur into his real life—until his unorthodox tactics finally succeed in opening a brief but historic communication link between Starfleet and the lost starship.

StorySections.Teaser: At Starfleet’s Pathfinder Project facility, Barclay excitedly briefs a skeptical Admiral Paris and his team on theoretical methods to contact Voyager, only to be gently dismissed as over-invested and in need of rest.
StorySections.Act I: Off duty, Barclay retreats to an elaborate holodeck recreation of Voyager where idealized versions of the crew treat him as a valued colleague. Concerned, Counselor Troi visits him on Earth and worries that his fantasy life is eclipsing his real relationships.
StorySections.Act II: Convinced he is close to a breakthrough, Barclay bypasses procedural safeguards and secretly reconfigures the MIDAS array to create a micro-wormhole toward Voyager’s last known position. His unauthorized test causes a brief but measurable anomaly before being shut down.
StorySections.Act III: Facing disciplinary action, Barclay argues that the anomaly was contact with Voyager. With Troi’s reluctant support, he breaks into the facility again to complete the process, knowing he may be court-martialed if he is wrong.
StorySections.Act IV: This time, the array successfully opens a fleeting two-way link. On the far side of the galaxy, Janeway and her crew are stunned to receive real-time messages from Starfleet, including news from home and updated astrometric data that may shorten their journey.
StorySections.Tag: After the link collapses, Admiral Paris reluctantly acknowledges Barclay’s success and keeps him on the Pathfinder Project. On Voyager, the crew celebrates the first true conversation with home in years, buoyed by the knowledge that Starfleet is actively working to bring them back.

EntitySummaries.Reginald Barclay: Barclay channels his anxiety and obsessive tendencies into a genuine breakthrough, walking a fine line between unhealthy fixation and the kind of persistence that changes lives.
EntitySummaries.Deanna Troi: Troi supports Barclay while challenging his dependence on holodeck fantasies, ultimately backing his risky final attempt once she is convinced of his sincerity and insight.
EntitySummaries.Owen Paris: Admiral Paris embodies institutional caution and paternal concern, skeptical of Barclay’s methods but deeply invested in news of his son aboard Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway’s brief but heartfelt exchange with Starfleet reaffirms her crew’s place in the larger Federation story and gives her new resolve to get them home.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom’s reunion with his father, however short, offers emotional closure to a strained relationship and motivates him for the journey ahead.
EntitySummaries.Harkins: Harkins, Barclay’s superior, initially sees him as a liability but comes to respect his unconventional genius once the link succeeds.
EntitySummaries.Pathfinder staff: The team’s skepticism and procedural rigidity serve as a counterweight to Barclay’s impulsiveness.
EntitySummaries.Barclay's compulsive behavior: His tendencies function as an internal antagonist that nearly derails his career even as they fuel his innovation.
EntitySummaries.Starfleet bureaucracy and caution: Institutional risk aversion is a social antagonist that slows bold attempts to solve unprecedented problems.
EntitySummaries.Technical limits of long-distance commun: The sheer distance to Voyager and the need for precise timing with the MIDAS array form a scientific antagonist that must be overcome for contact to occur.

ContinuityNotes: Pathfinder brings back Reginald Barclay and Deanna Troi from Star Trek: The Next Generation, tying Voyager more directly into the wider franchise.
The episode establishes the MIDAS array and Pathfinder Project as ongoing efforts to reach Voyager from the Alpha Quadrant.
News and data received in this episode influence Voyager’s later navigation and morale.
Barclay’s history of holodeck addiction and social anxiety from earlier series is explicitly acknowledged and built upon.
ThematicNotes: The story examines the thin line between obsession and dedication in scientific work.
It explores the psychological toll of isolation, even at a distance, as Barclay invests emotionally in a crew he has never met.
Pathfinder highlights the importance of support systems like Troi in helping gifted individuals manage their vulnerabilities.
The episode underscores hope and connection as powerful motivators for both Voyager and those trying to reach it.
BehindTheScenes: The episode shifts much of the action away from Voyager to Earth, offering a fresh perspective on the series’ central predicament.
Sets for the Pathfinder facility and Earth locations expand the visual scope beyond starship interiors.
Revisiting familiar TNG characters helped strengthen continuity between the series and provided fans with nostalgic resonance.

Title: Fair Haven
Summary: As Voyager weathers a massive storm that forces the crew indoors, Janeway finds unexpected romance in Fair Haven, an elaborate Irish village holodeck program created by Tom Paris, but her decision to literally redesign her ideal partner raises questions about authenticity, control and what it means to love a hologram.

StorySections.Teaser: Tom Paris proudly unveils his new Fair Haven program, a 19th-century Irish village where the crew can relax. As a dangerous ion storm approaches, Janeway orders Voyager to ride it out at impulse and allows the holoprogram to run continuously to boost morale.
StorySections.Act I: With much of the crew spending their downtime in Fair Haven, Janeway wanders into the local pub and meets Michael Sullivan, a charming barkeep with whom she quickly develops an easy rapport. Curious, she later adjusts his holomatrix in the holodeck controls, altering his interests and marital status to better suit her tastes.
StorySections.Act II: Janeway and Michael’s relationship deepens as they share walks, philosophical talks and a growing intimacy within the simulated village.
