Neelix and others notice the captain’s frequent visits, while the Doctor gently questions the emotional risks of investing so heavily in a holographic lover.
StorySections.Act III: As the storm intensifies and Voyager takes damage, power fluctuations threaten the stability of the Fair Haven program. Janeway is forced to confront how much she depends on the fantasy and whether her edits to Michael have reduced him to a reflection of her own desires.
StorySections.Act IV: When program corruption injures Michael and destabilizes parts of the village, Janeway orders B'Elanna to repair the simulation but chooses not to reset Michael’s personality to her custom specifications. Instead, she resolves to interact with him as he was originally programmed, imperfections and all, if she returns to the program.
StorySections.Tag: With the storm past and the ship back on course, Janeway stands outside the holodeck doors, hesitating before re-entering Fair Haven—acknowledging both the comfort it offers and the uneasy line it draws between real and simulated relationships.

Antagonists: Ethical ambiguity of editing a partner
Ion storm threatening Voyager and the program

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway grapples with the tension between her responsibilities as captain, her isolation in the Delta Quadrant and her desire for companionship, using a holodeck romance to explore needs she cannot safely satisfy with her crew.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris serves as Fair Haven’s proud creator, thrilled that the crew—and especially the captain—enjoy his program, while dimly aware that its realism complicates the line between recreation and real emotional attachment.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor offers wry but sincere counsel to Janeway, treating her relationship with Michael as a legitimate emotional bond and questioning the morality of altering someone—even a hologram—to be the "perfect" partner.
EntitySummaries.Michael Sullivan: Michael is a sophisticated holographic bartender whose charm and warmth appeal to Janeway; his malleable nature highlights how easily a simulated person can be shaped to someone else’s ideal.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix monitors crew morale and notices Janeway’s renewed energy, seeing Fair Haven as both a social hub and a potential crutch.
EntitySummaries.Janeway's loneliness: Her isolation as a distant-starship captain functions as an internal antagonist pushing her toward a relationship that can be switched off at will.
EntitySummaries.Ethical ambiguity of editing a partner: The ease with which Janeway customizes Michael’s traits becomes a conceptual antagonist, undercutting the sense of mutual agency that underpins genuine relationships.
EntitySummaries.Ion storm threatening Voyager and the pr: The storm is an environmental antagonist that forces the crew into Fair Haven and later threatens to destroy Janeway’s carefully constructed refuge.
EntitySummaries.Seamus Driscol: Seamus provides comic relief and local color in Fair Haven, emphasizing the depth of Paris’s world-building.
EntitySummaries.Maggie O'Halloran: Maggie’s flirtations with other crew members reinforce how alive and interactive the holodeck village feels to its visitors.

ContinuityNotes: Fair Haven expands on Voyager’s frequent use of sophisticated holodeck programs as long-term social spaces rather than brief diversions.
The episode deepens Janeway’s characterization by explicitly addressing her loneliness and reluctance to engage romantically with her crew.
Fair Haven and its villagers will return in the later episode "Spirit Folk," continuing this particular holodeck setting.
The story echoes earlier Star Trek episodes involving holographic or artificial partners, but from a starship captain’s perspective.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the ethics of customizing partners and whether love can flourish when one party has complete control over the other’s traits.
It examines how isolation and command responsibility shape romantic choices.
Fair Haven reflects on the appeal and limitations of escapist fantasy, even when it feels emotionally real.
The story raises questions about consent and authenticity in relationships with artificial beings.
BehindTheScenes: Fair Haven was written by Robin Burger and directed by Allan Kroeker.
Exterior village scenes were filmed on a Universal Studios backlot dressed as a 19th-century Irish town.
Kate Mulgrew later commented that she had mixed feelings about Janeway’s holoromance, though she appreciated the attempt to give the captain a love story.

Title: Blink of an Eye
Summary: Voyager becomes trapped in the orbit of a mysterious planet where time moves vastly faster on the surface than in space, allowing the crew to watch an entire civilization evolve from superstition to spaceflight in what feels like hours while the world below mythologizes the "sky ship" that shakes their sky.

StorySections.Teaser: Investigating a strange world surrounded by a temporal distortion field, Voyager is pulled into orbit and locked in place. Seismic tremors ripple through the ship every time the planet quakes, while the crew notices rapid atmospheric changes far below.
StorySections.Act I: Sensors reveal that time is passing thousands of times faster on the surface. From Voyager’s perspective, the planet’s primitive culture develops cities and technology at a breathtaking pace, and the crew realizes their presence is influencing folklore and scientific inquiry on the world below.
StorySections.Act II: On the planet, generations of observers struggle to explain the persistent "sky ship" that causes tremors and inspirations. Religious sects and early astronomers argue over its meaning until more advanced scientists begin to formulate accurate theories about an object in synchronous orbit.
StorySections.Act III: To better understand and mitigate their impact, the Doctor is transmitted briefly to the surface, spending years there while only minutes pass on Voyager. He returns with personal memories of life among the people, including friendships and the gradual demystification of the "sky ship."
StorySections.Act IV: As the civilization reaches spaceflight, a pair of astronauts launches to meet Voyager, determined to solve the centuries-old mystery. Janeway works with them to find a way to break free of the temporal snare without devastating the planet, ultimately using their advanced understanding of local physics to slingshot Voyager away.
StorySections.Tag: Watching the planet recede, the crew reflects on having witnessed an entire world’s history in compressed time, while the explorers below continue their own journey, now knowing that the "sky ship" was real and briefly a partner in their ascent.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must contend with the unintended, long-term cultural contamination caused simply by Voyager’s presence, trying to honor the Prime Directive under impossible conditions.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor experiences years among the planet’s people, gaining a deep personal connection to their culture and becoming a living bridge between the two worlds.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven analyzes the rapid societal changes below and offers detached but insightful commentary on cultural evolution and technological progress.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay frames the situation in anthropological terms, fascinated by the opportunity to witness history at fast-forward speed while mindful of the crew’s ethical responsibility.
EntitySummaries.Planetary astronauts: The astronauts represent the culmination of their world’s curiosity and determination, willing to risk their lives to confront the mystery that has shaped their civilization’s legends.
EntitySummaries.Temporal distortion field: The time differential surrounding the planet is a physical antagonist and narrative engine, driving both the scientific puzzle and the moral dilemma.
EntitySummaries.Cultural myths about the \"sky ship\": Evolving myths and theories about Voyager act as a conceptual antagonist, affecting how generations interpret unexplained phenomena.
EntitySummaries.Risk of catastrophic seismic disruption: Voyager’s presence threatens to destabilize the planet’s crust, adding an environmental antagonist that demands a timely solution.

ContinuityNotes: Blink of an Eye is frequently cited as one of Voyager’s standout episodes for its high-concept science fiction premise.
The episode showcases the Prime Directive’s complexities when a ship cannot simply leave or remain unnoticed.
The Doctor’s years-long sojourn on the surface add unseen depth to his character history.
The story fits within Star Trek’s broader tradition of exploring accelerated or altered time frames and their impact on societies.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines how legends and scientific understanding evolve around persistent but poorly understood phenomena.
It highlights the reciprocal relationship between explorers and the cultures they encounter, even unintentionally.
Blink of an Eye celebrates curiosity as a driving force of civilization, embodied in the planet’s astronomers and astronauts.
The story underscores the ethical weight of observation, suggesting that simply watching can change what is observed.
BehindTheScenes: Blink of an Eye was praised for its ambitious concept and the challenge of depicting centuries of development in a single hour.
Visual effects and production design had to evolve the planet’s architecture and technology across multiple eras.
The episode has often been highlighted in critical retrospectives as one of Voyager’s best installments.

Title: Virtuoso
Summary: Voyager encounters the hyper-advanced but emotionally tone-deaf Qomar, who become infatuated with the Doctor’s singing when they discover music for the first time, catapulting him to celebrity status and tempting him to leave the ship for a society that values him solely as an entertainer.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager lends aid to a damaged Qomar vessel whose arrogant crew openly derides the organics and the Doctor alike—until a casual demonstration of his vocal abilities stops them in astonished silence.
StorySections.Act I: Intrigued by the entirely new concept of music, the Qomar invite the Doctor to perform for larger audiences. As he dazzles them with arias and standards, they begin to treat him as a cultural revelation and request that he compose original pieces.
StorySections.Act II: The Doctor’s fame explodes on the Qomar homeworld. He is mobbed by adoring fans, showered with praise and offered a permanent position as their leading musical figure. Back on Voyager, he adopts diva-like behavior, clashing with Janeway and neglecting his medical duties.
StorySections.Act III: Believing he has finally found a place where he is fully appreciated, the Doctor considers resigning from Voyager to live among the Qomar. However, he gradually realizes they care only about his utility as a vocal instrument, not as a person, and that they plan to replace him with a purpose-built hologram once they have learned enough.
StorySections.Act IV: Stung by the Qomar’s casual dismissal, the Doctor returns to Voyager, humbled but wiser about the nature of admiration and the kind of recognition he truly wants. The crew welcomes him back, teasing him gently while affirming his value as more than a performer.
StorySections.Tag: In a small concert for the crew, the Doctor sings again—not for fame or alien adoration, but for friends who appreciate both his voice and his often complicated personality.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor revels in a sudden explosion of fame and validation, only to learn that adoration based solely on performance is hollow if his personhood is not respected.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway struggles to rein in the Doctor’s excesses while recognizing his right to pursue new opportunities, ultimately glad when he chooses to stay of his own free will.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven offers blunt observations about the Doctor’s behavior and the Qomar’s attitudes, cutting through flattery with clear-eyed logic.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry participates in musical performances and provides a more grounded perspective on artistic expression aboard Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Qomar scientists: The Qomar view music purely as a fascinating new form of data, valuing efficiency and novelty over emotional nuance.
EntitySummaries.Tincoo: Tincoo, a Qomar researcher, admires the Doctor’s art but treats him as a prototype to be improved upon rather than an individual with feelings.
EntitySummaries.Qomar utilitarian worldview: Their reduction of art and artists to mere tools is a conceptual antagonist that clashes with Federation values.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor's swelling ego: His vanity functions as an internal antagonist, nearly costing him his role and relationships on Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Disposable view of sentient holograms: The Qomar’s plan to build a better singing program exposes a wider disregard for the Doctor’s status as a sentient being.

ContinuityNotes: Virtuoso further develops the Doctor’s artistic pursuits and ongoing quest for recognition as more than a medical program.
The episode revisits Voyager’s shipboard musical culture, including prior references to the Doctor’s performances.
The Qomar never reappear on-screen, but their encounter marks a major emotional milestone for the Doctor.
The story builds on longstanding themes about holographic rights and identity introduced earlier in Voyager and The Next Generation.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the difference between shallow celebrity and deeper respect for personhood.
It examines how ego and the desire for validation can distort priorities.
Virtuoso highlights cultural gaps in understanding art and emotion.
The story underscores that genuine appreciation involves seeing the whole person, not just their talents.
BehindTheScenes: Virtuoso was directed by Les Landau, with a teleplay by Raf Green and Kenneth Biller.
The episode gave Robert Picardo extensive opportunities to showcase his singing abilities.
Sets and visual designs for the Qomar emphasized sleek minimalism to reflect their highly technical society.

Title: Memorial
Summary: After an away team returns from a routine mission, Chakotay, Paris, Kim and Neelix begin suffering vivid, shared flashbacks of participating in a brutal massacre on an alien colony, leading the crew to discover a powerful psychogenic transmitter designed to force passersby to relive the atrocity as a warning to future generations.

StorySections.Teaser: Back aboard Voyager after a two-week survey mission, Paris experiences a disturbing nightmare of fighting in a chaotic battle, while Kim suffers a panic attack during a simple engineering task, hinting that something went wrong planetside.
StorySections.Act I: Chakotay, Neelix and the others all begin having intrusive, hyper-real memories of being soldiers in unfamiliar uniforms, firing on terrified civilians in a crowded settlement. The experiences feel like guilt-ridden recollections rather than random hallucinations.
StorySections.Act II: Medical scans show no obvious infection, but the Doctor notes neurological patterns consistent with post-traumatic stress. The away team’s accounts sync up into a single, coherent narrative of a military operation gone horribly wrong.
StorySections.Act III: Determined to understand what happened, Janeway takes Voyager back to the planet. There they find a large monument radiating a low-level psychogenic field that implants the massacre memories into anyone who comes within range, making them "witnesses" to an atrocity that occurred long ago.
StorySections.Act IV: Chakotay is outraged that the memorial forces trauma onto unsuspecting travelers, while others argue that its impact may prevent future genocides. Janeway chooses to repair and replenish the memorial’s power cells but add a warning beacon so that those who approach can make an informed choice.
StorySections.Tag: The affected crew members hold a quiet remembrance ceremony, acknowledging that the memories are not theirs yet have nonetheless changed them, leaving them more aware of the cost of war and the weight of historical violence.

EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay feels intense guilt and anger from the implanted memories, leading him to question the morality of a memorial that inflicts suffering in the name of education.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris struggles with the vivid sensations of having pulled the trigger on civilians, forcing him to confront how easily ordinary people can become instruments of atrocity.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Kim’s anxiety and breakdowns highlight how unprepared he is for war’s psychological toll, even when experienced secondhand.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix, himself a survivor of past war trauma, is shaken by the memories but also sees value in ensuring such horrors are never forgotten.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway weighs the memorial’s purpose against its methods and ultimately opts for informed consent, preserving the warning while mitigating its most coercive element.
EntitySummaries.Psychogenic memorial field: The field is a technological antagonist that overrides autonomy by forcing visitors to relive pain they never personally caused.
EntitySummaries.Lingering trauma of the massacre: The enduring emotional weight encoded in the memorial acts as a conceptual antagonist that reaches across time.
EntitySummaries.Debate over imposed remembrance: The ethical conflict within the crew about whether such a memorial is justified serves as a social antagonist driving much of the episode’s tension.
EntitySummaries.Saavedra: Saavedra and other figures glimpsed in the flashbacks personalize the otherwise abstract massacre.

ContinuityNotes: Memorial is one of Voyager’s more explicit explorations of war crimes and post-traumatic stress.
The episode reinforces Chakotay’s role as a moral voice on issues of violence and coercion.
Neelix’s reactions resonate with prior references to his traumatic experiences during the Haakonian conflict.
Voyager’s decision to repair the memorial ensures that future travelers may also encounter its warning, albeit with advance notice.
ThematicNotes: The episode interrogates how societies should remember atrocities and whether enforced empathy justifies psychological harm.
It explores the nature of guilt, responsibility and moral injury, even when the memories are artificially implanted.
Memorial emphasizes the importance of bearing witness to history rather than turning away from uncomfortable truths.
The story highlights the tension between honoring victims and respecting the autonomy of the living.
BehindTheScenes: Memorial was written by Brannon Braga (story) and Robin Burger (teleplay), directed by Allan Kroeker.
The episode’s flashback sequences use desaturated colors and handheld camerawork to evoke the chaos of battle.
Critics have noted the episode’s resonance with real-world discussions of war memorials and trauma.

Title: Tsunkatse
Summary: During shore leave aboard a Norcadian pleasure ship, Seven of Nine and Tuvok are abducted by promoters of the brutal arena sport Tsunkatse, forcing Seven to fight televised matches under the ruthless training of a Hirogen hunter while Voyager struggles to rescue her without playing into the spectators’ thirst for blood.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager joins a massive Norcadian game vessel for shore leave, where crew members explore local entertainments. A scouting trip by Seven and Tuvok is interrupted when they vanish from transporter range.
StorySections.Act I: Seven awakens in a holding cell with Tuvok gravely injured and is told by Penk, the promoter of Tsunkatse, that she must compete in the arena to secure medical care for her friend. She reluctantly agrees to train under a seasoned Hirogen fighter.
StorySections.Act II: The Hirogen mentor pushes Seven through grueling combat drills, teaching her to rely on instinct rather than analysis. Meanwhile, Voyager discovers that Tsunkatse matches are broadcast live across the region, turning Seven’s predicament into popular entertainment.
StorySections.Act III: As Seven is forced into her first match and begins to win, ratings soar. The crew considers using the broadcasts to track her location, but doing so risks legitimizing the bloodsport and endangering other captives. Seven struggles with the conflict between her drive to survive and her refusal to become a killer.
StorySections.Act IV: In a climactic match, Seven learns that she is scheduled to fight the very Hirogen who trained her. Refusing to deliver a killing blow, she instead turns her skills against Penk’s control systems. Voyager and a Hirogen vessel intervene, disabling the arena’s power grid and freeing the captives while the audience watches their spectacle collapse.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard Voyager, Seven admits to lingering unease about how close she came to embracing the thrill of combat, while Tuvok reassures her that choosing mercy in the end affirmed her humanity rather than undermined it.

Antagonists: Seven's fear of losing her humanity

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced into a gladiatorial role that threatens to awaken the predatory instincts she honed as a Borg, making her question what it means to fight for survival without becoming a killer.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s injuries keep him sidelined, but his calm presence and philosophical counsel anchor Seven’s struggle with violence and self-control.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must decide how far to go in confronting a widely accepted local entertainment to save one crewmember, ultimately choosing direct intervention despite political fallout.
EntitySummaries.Penk: Penk is a charismatic but ruthless promoter who treats sentient beings as commodities to boost ratings, embodying the greed and amorality behind Tsunkatse.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen fighter: The Hirogen mentor is both adversary and ally, teaching Seven to fight even as he remains a captive of the same system; his final bout with her becomes a test of both their values.
EntitySummaries.Penk's exploitative Tsunkatse empire: The commercial apparatus of Tsunkatse is a structural antagonist built on the suffering of unwilling participants.
EntitySummaries.Spectator culture of bloodsport: The cheering crowds and high ratings act as a societal antagonist that normalizes cruelty for entertainment.
EntitySummaries.Seven's fear of losing her humanity: Her internal dread of reverting to a purely predatory mindset functions as an internal antagonist driving her moral choices.

ContinuityNotes: Tsunkatse features the Hirogen, previously encountered as relentless hunters, in a new context as both combatants and victims.
The episode continues Seven’s arc of grappling with violence, autonomy and what separates her from her Borg past.
Voyager’s willingness to intervene in local practices echoes earlier Prime Directive dilemmas involving exploitation and entertainment.
The Norcadian game ship adds to the series’ picture of varied leisure and media cultures in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: The episode critiques bloodsport entertainment and the commodification of violence.
It examines the ethics of fighting for survival within a corrupt system.
Tsunkatse explores the line between training as empowerment and training as conditioning toward brutality.
The story reinforces that mercy and restraint are central to Seven’s evolving sense of self.
BehindTheScenes: Tsunkatse was promoted as a special event episode, featuring a prominent guest appearance by a professional wrestler as the Hirogen fighter.
The production emphasized arena-style lighting, crowds and choreography to sell the sporting spectacle.
The episode’s blend of action and character insight makes it a frequently discussed entry in Voyager’s later seasons.

Title: Collective
Summary: When the Delta Flyer responds to a distress call and is captured by a damaged Borg cube crewed only by inexperienced adolescent drones, Voyager must negotiate for the hostages’ release while Seven of Nine tries to teach the frightened "Collective" what it means to exist outside the Borg.

StorySections.Teaser: On a Delta Flyer mission, Chakotay, Paris, Kim and Neelix answer a faint distress signal and are abruptly intercepted by a Borg cube. The cube’s interior appears oddly quiet and partially offline as the Flyer is brought into a hangar bay.
StorySections.Act I: Boarding parties from the cube capture the away team and attempt, unsuccessfully, to assimilate them. Voyager’s scans reveal that most of the adult drones aboard are dead from some unknown catastrophe, leaving only a handful of partially matured drones connected to a weakened collective matrix.
StorySections.Act II: Seven beams over and discovers that the ship is effectively being run by five adolescent drones who have never known life outside the Borg. Led by the rigid First, they demand Voyager’s defection and technology in exchange for the prisoners, convinced that reintegration with the main Collective is imminent.
StorySections.Act III: As Seven interacts with the young drones, she learns that the cube was infected by a pathogen that killed most of the crew and severed its link to the Collective. The surviving youngsters are terrified of being alone, clinging to Borg doctrine as their only identity. Seven begins to earn the trust of a few, especially the more curious Second, by sharing her own experience of becoming an individual.
StorySections.Act IV: When it becomes clear that the main Collective has written off the damaged cube and that the pathogen will eventually kill the remaining drones, Seven and Janeway offer the youths asylum on Voyager. A violent clash with the fanatical First leads to his death, and the remaining four—later named Icheb, Mezoti and the twins Azan and Rebi—tentatively accept life aboard Voyager as ex-drones.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, the former Borg children are assigned quarters and tentative guardians, taking their first hesitant steps into individuality while Seven faces the daunting role of mentor and surrogate parent.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven recognizes aspects of her own past in the stranded Borg children and becomes determined to guide them toward individuality, stepping into a reluctant but vital parental role.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay, held hostage on the cube, demonstrates calm leadership and trust in Seven’s ability to defuse a volatile situation.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris provides moral support and occasional levity under duress, relying on Seven and Voyager to find a nonlethal solution.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Kim, also a captive, navigates the tension between resisting their captors and recognizing the drones’ obvious inexperience and fear.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix offers empathy and practical help, later becoming one of the more approachable adult figures in the former drones’ new lives.
EntitySummaries.Icheb: Icheb, the brightest and most inquisitive of the group, begins to question the Borg worldview and will later become Seven’s primary protégé.
EntitySummaries.Mezoti: Mezoti shows a quick, suspicious intelligence, simultaneously wary of Voyager’s crew and drawn to their warmth.
EntitySummaries.Azan: Azan, one of the twins, clings closely to his brother and the group identity, needing time to accept the idea of separation.
EntitySummaries.Rebi: Rebi mirrors Azan’s dependence, highlighting how deeply the collective mindset has shaped their sense of self.
EntitySummaries.First (unnamed Borg leader): The First clings fanatically to Borg doctrine and authority, serving as a tragic figure unable to adapt who becomes an obstacle to the group’s survival.
EntitySummaries.Isolated Borg juvenile collective: The children’s micro-collective is a social antagonist, enforcing conformity and suppressing emerging individuality.
EntitySummaries.Deadly pathogen on the cube: The infection that killed the adult drones is a biological antagonist driving the urgency of the situation.
EntitySummaries.Fear of individuality: The children’s terror at losing their collective identity functions as an internal antagonist each must overcome.

ContinuityNotes: Collective introduces the Borg children—most notably Icheb—who become recurring characters and an ongoing responsibility for Seven and Voyager.
The episode continues Voyager’s exploration of life after assimilation, this time focusing on adolescents.
The damaged cube and severed link highlight that the Collective is not infallible and that drones can be left stranded.
Icheb’s presence will play a significant role in later episodes involving the Borg and Seven’s personal growth.
ThematicNotes: The story examines the difficulty of transitioning from a totalizing collective identity to individual personhood.
It explores surrogate parenthood and mentorship, particularly for trauma survivors.
Collective underscores that indoctrination can persist even when the institution enforcing it collapses.
The episode suggests that empathy and patience are critical in helping former adversaries become allies.
BehindTheScenes: Collective was directed by Allison Liddi-Brown and helped set up new recurring cast members as the Borg children.
The production designed smaller Borg costumes and makeup to emphasize the youth of the drones.
The episode continued Voyager’s ongoing use of the Borg as a source of both threat and character drama.

Title: Spirit Folk
Summary: Prolonged use and frequent interruptions of the Fair Haven holoprogram cause its characters to gain enhanced self-awareness, leading the villagers to suspect witchcraft when they notice Voyager’s crew manipulating their world and forcing Janeway to protect her secret romance while averting a full-blown holodeck uprising.

StorySections.Teaser: Fair Haven is running almost constantly to keep crew morale high, with officers and crew dropping in and out mid-scene as ship’s duties call. Subtle program glitches begin to appear as the holodeck’s safeties and narrative buffers strain under the load.
StorySections.Act I: Seamus and other villagers notice that some customers seem to vanish or change clothes instantly. When Paris pauses and restarts the program for an engineering adjustment, Fair Haven characters retain fragmented memories and begin speculating about sorcery and changelings.
StorySections.Act II: Michael Sullivan grows suspicious of Janeway when he catches glimpses of her altering the environment and ignoring physical laws. Meanwhile, program subroutines start cross-referencing strange data about Voyager, giving the villagers half-formed notions of a larger reality beyond their town.
StorySections.Act III: A group of fearful villagers kidnaps the Doctor, convinced he is a magical spirit, and attempts to drown him to prove he is not human. Holodeck malfunctions prevent an immediate shutdown, trapping the EMH and crew members inside as tensions escalate toward a witch trial.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway enters the program openly as herself, explaining to Michael and the others that they are part of a simulation while still treating them with respect. By negotiating rather than forcibly resetting the program, she calms the villagers, rescues the Doctor and preserves Fair Haven as a less-naïve but still welcoming refuge.
StorySections.Tag: Later, Janeway and Michael share a quieter moment in the village, acknowledging the strange nature of their connection while agreeing to continue it with more honesty on both sides.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must confront the consequences of treating Fair Haven as both a holiday and a hiding place, learning that even simulated relationships demand honesty when their participants gain awareness.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s near-drowning underscores that his mobile emitter makes him vulnerable in new ways, even inside holodeck fantasies.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris is forced to reckon with the unintended side effects of leaving his program running so often, as Fair Haven’s gradual awakening creates unpredictable emergent behavior.
EntitySummaries.Michael Sullivan: Michael evolves from a charming but scripted bartender into a more self-aware figure who questions his reality and his relationship with Janeway.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix mediates between nervous crew and nervous villagers, trying to maintain Fair Haven’s role as a place of comfort.
EntitySummaries.Holodeck instability: The overloaded program itself is a technological antagonist, blurring boundaries between fiction and self-awareness.
EntitySummaries.Villagers' fear of the unknown: Their superstition and suspicion form a social antagonist that threatens violence against perceived witches and spirits.
EntitySummaries.Janeway's secrecy about the program: Her reluctance to treat Michael as a fully aware being functions as an internal antagonist that complicates the situation.
EntitySummaries.Seamus Driscol: Seamus amplifies local paranoia, turning oddities into tales of fairy magic and devils.
EntitySummaries.Maggie O'Halloran: Maggie represents the ordinary townsfolk caught between curiosity and fear as Fair Haven’s illusions break down.

ContinuityNotes: Spirit Folk is a direct follow-up to Fair Haven, revisiting the Irish holodeck village and Janeway’s relationship with Michael Sullivan.
The episode continues Star Trek’s tradition of exploring what happens when artificial characters gain self-awareness.
Holodeck safety and narrative subroutines are again shown to be vulnerable to prolonged, intensive use.
Spirit Folk further cements Fair Haven as a recurring social hub for Voyager’s crew.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the ethics of interacting with increasingly self-aware simulated beings.
It examines how secrecy and denial can backfire when others begin to perceive truths on their own.
Spirit Folk uses folklore and superstition as metaphors for grappling with new realities and technologies.
The story highlights that comfort fantasies can become complicated when the "characters" push back.
BehindTheScenes: Spirit Folk leans into lighter, whimsical tones while still touching on serious questions about artificial consciousness.
The production reused and expanded the Fair Haven village sets from the earlier episode.
Irish stereotypes and accents were played broadly, leading to mixed reactions from some viewers.

Title: Ashes to Ashes
Summary: A woman claiming to be the long-dead Ensign Lyndsay Ballard returns to Voyager in an alien-altered body, insisting that she remembers her life on the ship and her close friendship with Harry Kim, forcing the crew to question her identity as her new species exerts a powerful pull to reclaim her.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager receives a hail from an unfamiliar vessel whose pilot addresses Janeway and Harry Kim by name, requesting permission to come aboard. She identifies herself as Lyndsay Ballard, an officer killed on a mission years earlier.
StorySections.Act I: The woman’s DNA shows a complex hybrid of human and Kobali signatures. She explains that the Kobali recovered her corpse, resurrected her using their reproductive process and raised her as one of their own until she fled to return to Voyager.
StorySections.Act II: Harry is overjoyed to have his friend back and helps her reintegrate into shipboard life, but Ballard struggles with memories that don’t quite align and instincts and cravings from her Kobali physiology. Her altered appearance and behavior make it difficult for some crew members to fully accept her.
StorySections.Act III: A Kobali warship arrives, with Ballard’s "father" pleading for her to return to the family and culture that nurtured her after resurrection. Torn between her human past and Kobali present, Ballard lashes out at both sides, feeling that she no longer truly belongs anywhere.
StorySections.Act IV: Realizing that her body and psyche are inexorably shifting toward Kobali norms, Ballard chooses to go back with her Kobali family despite Harry’s pleas. Voyager honors her decision, and she departs in a bittersweet farewell, acknowledging that what they shared on Voyager will always be part of her, even if she cannot stay.
StorySections.Tag: Harry quietly places a photo of the original Lyndsay Ballard among his mementos, reflecting on the complicated nature of loss, identity and the impossibility of fully reclaiming the past.

EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry seizes on Ballard’s return as a chance to undo a painful loss, only to learn that love and loyalty cannot override the profound changes she has undergone.
EntitySummaries.Lyndsay Ballard / Jhet'leya: Ballard is caught between two selves and two families, embodying the struggle of someone who has fundamentally changed yet still longs for the life she left behind.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway supports Ballard’s autonomy, refusing to treat her as a reclaimed Starfleet asset and honoring her right to choose where she belongs.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven offers perspective as someone who has undergone a radical transformation of identity, recognizing the difficulty of reconciling conflicting loyalties.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor analyzes Ballard’s hybrid physiology and warns that her biology is pulling her inexorably toward a Kobali existence, complicating any attempt to live as human.
EntitySummaries.Conflicting identities (Human vs. Kobali: The clash between Ballard’s human memories and Kobali nature acts as an internal antagonist driving her emotional turmoil.
EntitySummaries.Kobali cultural expectations: Her adoptive family’s insistence on reclaiming her functions as a social antagonist, even as it stems from genuine love and need.
EntitySummaries.Harry's difficulty letting go: Harry’s reluctance to accept that Ballard cannot simply resume her old life is an emotional antagonist that deepens the tragedy for them both.
EntitySummaries.Kobali \"father\": Her Kobali parent represents a sincere but uncompromising attachment, unwilling to lose his daughter a second time.

ContinuityNotes: Ashes to Ashes expands the lore of the Kobali, an alien species that reproduces by reanimating the dead of other races.
The episode retroactively introduces Lyndsay Ballard as a former Voyager crewmember to explore Harry Kim’s emotional life.
Themes of transformed identity parallel storylines about Seven and other characters who have undergone radical change.
The events are self-contained but contribute to the broader tapestry of Voyager’s encounters with unusual reproductive and cultural practices.
ThematicNotes: The story explores identity, belonging and the limits of reclaiming a past self after profound transformation.
It examines grief and the emotional complexities of getting a loved one "back" in altered form.
Ashes to Ashes raises questions about bodily autonomy and cultural claims over individuals.
The episode underscores that sometimes love means letting someone go where they truly belong.
BehindTheScenes: Ashes to Ashes was directed by Terry Windell and features a heavy prosthetic design for the Kobali.
The episode provided a rare Harry Kim-centric emotional storyline in later Voyager seasons.
Designers created a distinct look for the Kobali that emphasized their funerary and resurrection-based culture.

Title: Child's Play
Summary: Voyager locates the biological parents of Icheb, the oldest of the Borg children, and returns him to their agricultural world, only to uncover that his people previously engineered him as a living weapon against the Borg and now expect him to continue that role, forcing a painful custody battle between his birth family and Seven of Nine.

StorySections.Teaser: The crew is surprised when a subspace message arrives from a distant colony claiming to be Icheb’s homeworld. Genetic matching confirms the link, and Janeway informs Icheb that his parents are alive and want him returned.
StorySections.Act I: Icheb struggles with the news, torn between curiosity about his origins and loyalty to Seven and Voyager. Upon arrival at the Brunali world, his parents greet him warmly and share stories of the child he once was before assimilation.
StorySections.Act II: Seven is reluctant to let Icheb go, fearing that he will be isolated and deprived of the opportunities he has aboard Voyager. Nevertheless, she tries to support his decision as he chooses to stay temporarily to reconnect with his family and culture.
StorySections.Act III: Subtle inconsistencies in the parents’ stories and an unusual genetic marker in Icheb’s Borg implants raise the Doctor’s and Seven’s suspicions. Investigation reveals that the Brunali engineered Icheb with a pathogen that, when assimilated, would sabotage Borg technology—a strategy that led directly to his capture.
StorySections.Act IV: Horrified to discover that his parents plan to send him near a transwarp conduit again in hopes of striking another blow against the Borg, Icheb rejects their plan. Seven and the away team intervene, rescuing him from a shuttle rigged for sacrifice and bringing him back to Voyager, where he chooses to remain.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard ship, Icheb begins to rebuild his life with renewed appreciation for Seven’s fierce protectiveness, while Seven wrestles with her anger toward the Brunali and her growing sense of maternal responsibility.

EntitySummaries.Icheb: Icheb learns that he was created and sacrificed as a weapon, forcing him to decide whether biological ties outweigh the ethical betrayal of his parents’ choices.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s protective instincts crystallize into a quasi-maternal bond as she fights to keep Icheb from being used again as a tool against the Borg.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway navigates the delicate balance between respecting parental rights and protecting a minor from being weaponized, ultimately supporting Icheb’s decision to return to Voyager.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor uncovers the biotechnological modifications in Icheb’s genome and argues strongly against his exploitation as a living weapon.
EntitySummaries.Icheb's parents: Icheb’s Brunali parents inhabit a morally gray role, sincerely loving their son yet believing that sacrificing him is justified to protect their people from further Borg attacks.
EntitySummaries.Brunali bioweapon plan: The strategy of engineering children as anti-Borg devices serves as a conceptual antagonist highlighting the extreme measures taken by desperate societies.
EntitySummaries.Icheb's engineered biology: His altered genetic makeup is a biological antagonist that both attracted the Borg and makes him a target for renewed sacrifice.
EntitySummaries.Seven's fear of losing Icheb: Her internal fear of abandonment and failure as a caregiver functions as an emotional antagonist influencing her decisions.
EntitySummaries.Brunali villagers: The broader community’s silent acceptance of the plan underscores the communal nature of the ethical compromise.

ContinuityNotes: Child's Play deepens Icheb’s backstory and solidifies his role as a central member of Voyager’s extended family.
The episode further develops Seven’s arc as a guardian to the Borg children and her capacity for maternal affection.
The Brunali’s use of biotech against the Borg adds to the franchise’s array of anti-Borg strategies.
Icheb’s origins have ramifications for later stories involving his relationship with Seven and the Borg.
ThematicNotes: The story examines the ethics of using children as weapons, even in the face of existential threats.
It explores questions of family, loyalty and the meaning of parenthood beyond genetics.
Child's Play highlights how trauma can drive communities to rationalize morally questionable actions.
The episode underscores the idea that chosen families can provide safer, healthier environments than biological ones in some circumstances.
BehindTheScenes: Child's Play continues the narrative threads established in Collective by focusing on Icheb.
The episode uses a pastoral planet setting to contrast the Brunali’s seemingly peaceful life with their desperate bioweapon strategy.
Performances emphasize the emotional conflict between gratitude for survival and anger at parental betrayal.

Title: Good Shepherd
Summary: Concerned that some of Voyager’s least integrated crew members are slipping through the cracks, Janeway personally leads an away mission with three underperforming "problem" officers, only for their shuttle to be damaged by a mysterious dark-matter anomaly that forces all of them to confront their fears, limitations and potential.

StorySections.Teaser: Reviewing crew performance records, Janeway notices a handful of officers with chronically poor evaluations and minimal social engagement. Determined not to lose anyone in her "flock," she decides to take them on a survey mission aboard the Delta Flyer.
StorySections.Act I: The chosen trio—Tal Celes, Mortimer Harren and William Telfer—each display their quirks and anxieties as they reluctantly join the captain. Celes doubts her competence, Harren resents being dragged from his theoretical research and Telfer is a hypochondriac convinced the mission will go wrong.
StorySections.Act II: The Delta Flyer encounters a strange object emitting unusual readings. An impact damages the shuttle and leaves it adrift in a region filled with dark-matter anomalies. Telfer experiences a terrifying close encounter with an invisible entity that seems to pass through solid matter.
StorySections.Act III: As systems fail and tempers flare, Janeway pushes each officer to rise above their self-imposed limitations: she encourages Celes to trust her instincts with complex sensor work, challenges Harren’s cynical detachment and helps Telfer distinguish real threats from imagined ones.
StorySections.Act IV: The dark-matter creature attacks the Flyer again, forcing the crew into a risky plan that requires everyone’s contribution. Harren volunteers for a potentially deadly manual repair outside the shuttle, symbolically stepping out of his isolated comfort zone. Working together, they repel the entity long enough for Voyager to lock onto them and beam them to safety.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, Janeway updates their records with more hopeful evaluations. While none of the three becomes a stellar officer overnight, each has taken concrete steps toward belonging and growth, vindicating the captain’s hands-on approach.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway acts as a literal and metaphorical shepherd, refusing to write off underperforming crew and instead investing her time and vulnerability to help them grow.
EntitySummaries.Tal Celes: Celes, a Bajoran sensor analyst, struggles with imposter syndrome and technical errors but proves capable under pressure when given trust and guidance.
EntitySummaries.Mortimer Harren: Harren, an intellectual recluse who disdains practical work, confronts the reality that staying aloof does not exempt him from responsibility to others.
EntitySummaries.William Telfer: Telfer’s hypochondria and anxiety are challenged by genuine danger, pushing him to distinguish between imagined and real threats and to act bravely when it counts.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay provides a sounding board for Janeway’s concerns about leadership and crew cohesion, supporting her unconventional mentoring mission.
EntitySummaries.Dark-matter lifeform: The largely unseen entity is a mysterious environmental antagonist that forces the crew out of complacency and into cooperative problem-solving.
EntitySummaries.Crewmembers' self-doubt and isolation: Their internal barriers serve as psychological antagonists that Janeway must address to unlock their potential.
EntitySummaries.Harsh conditions in anomaly region: The dangerous space environment raises the stakes and limits easy technical solutions.

ContinuityNotes: Good Shepherd highlights that Voyager’s crew includes more than just the main bridge officers, giving depth to life among lower-deck personnel.
The episode reinforces Janeway’s hands-on leadership style and sense of personal responsibility for every member of her crew.
Tal Celes, Harren and Telfer appear only briefly elsewhere, but their introduction underscores the ship’s varied backgrounds.
Dark-matter phenomena are a recurring scientific curiosity in Star Trek, here tied to a character-focused story.
ThematicNotes: The story emphasizes mentorship, second chances and the value of investing in people who struggle.
It explores different forms of fear—of failure, of connection, of physical harm—and how they can be overcome.
Good Shepherd underscores that leadership involves more than commanding the best and brightest; it includes lifting up those who lag behind.
The episode suggests that growth is incremental and messy but worth pursuing.
BehindTheScenes: Good Shepherd was directed by Winrich Kolbe and written by Dianna Gitto and Joe Menosky.
The episode’s focus on lower-ranking crew echoes The Next Generation’s "Lower Decks" and anticipates later series exploring similar perspectives.
Visual effects depict the eerie behavior of the dark-matter entity interacting with the shuttle.

Title: Live Fast and Prosper
Summary: Voyager discovers that a trio of con artists has been traveling the sector impersonating Janeway, Chakotay and Tuvok, using the ship’s good name to swindle desperate worlds, forcing the real crew to repair their reputation and outwit the impostors who have studied them a little too well.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager is hailed by an angry alien captain who accuses Janeway of cheating him in a dilithium exchange and threatens retaliation. Confused, the crew traces reports of a "Federation" ship and crew that sound suspiciously like distorted versions of themselves.
StorySections.Act I: Investigating the accusations, Janeway and her officers learn that a small freighter has been masquerading as Voyager, with its crew posing as Janeway, Chakotay and Tuvok to extort cargo and favors from vulnerable colonies. Neelix reveals that some months earlier he encountered a ragged crew he told stories about Voyager to, unintentionally giving them raw material for their scam.
StorySections.Act II: The impostors—Dala as "Captain Janeway," Mobar as "Tuvok" and Zar as "Chakotay"—stage another con, promising protection and relocation to refugees in exchange for their valuables. Janeway sets a trap by allowing rumors of a rich supply depot to circulate, drawing the fakes into range while she quietly prepares countermeasures.
StorySections.Act III: Janeway fakes a disagreement with her own crew and pretends to defect, presenting herself to the impostors as a disgruntled captain willing to share inside information. Dala, suspicious but greedy, brings her aboard their freighter, where Janeway subtly sows discord among the con artists and learns the extent of the damage they have done in Voyager’s name.
StorySections.Act IV: When the con artists realize they have been duped, they attempt to flee with a hold full of stolen goods and refugees who think they are being resettled. Voyager disables the freighter’s engines and recovers the stolen cargo, while Janeway persuades Dala to turn state’s evidence and help make amends in exchange for leniency.
StorySections.Tag: Later, Janeway reflects dryly on having an imposter career as a criminal legend, while Neelix resolves to be more careful about the stories he tells strangers regarding the ship’s exploits.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway is forced to confront how her ship’s legend can be twisted, using her strategic skills and dry sense of humor to turn the tables on those misusing her name.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay provides steady tactical support and serves as a foil to the fake "Chakotay," highlighting the difference between genuine leadership and opportunistic mimicry.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok investigates the impostors’ methods and endures the indignity of seeing a bumbling criminal attempt to imitate his Vulcan demeanor for profit.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix feels guilty for having inadvertently inspired the con artists, illustrating how stories shared in good faith can have unintended consequences.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris aids in the sting operation and supplies insight into how small-time grifters think, drawing on his own less-than-spotless past.
EntitySummaries.Dala: Dala is a clever, adaptable con artist whose willingness to impersonate a starship captain makes her both a nuisance and, under pressure, a surprisingly sympathetic figure.
EntitySummaries.Mobar: Mobar, posing as "Tuvok," delights in the false prestige of playing a Vulcan officer but crumbles quickly when genuinely threatened.
EntitySummaries.Zar: Zar plays the fake "Chakotay" and serves as muscle for the operation, more concerned with immediate profit than long-term consequences.
EntitySummaries.Defrauded alien captain: The angry merchant captain represents the many victims whose trust in Voyager has been shaken by the impostors’ schemes.
EntitySummaries.Refugee colonists: The vulnerable colonists highlight how easily those in desperate situations can be exploited by promises of safety and transport.
EntitySummaries.Dala's con operation: The ongoing scam functions as a social antagonist that spreads distrust of Voyager throughout the region.
EntitySummaries.Damaged reputation of Voyager: The tarnished image of the ship is a conceptual antagonist that complicates every new first contact.
EntitySummaries.Desperation of exploited refugees: Their vulnerability acts as an environmental and emotional antagonist, motivating Janeway to shut down the scam quickly.

ContinuityNotes: Live Fast and Prosper plays with Voyager’s reputation in the Delta Quadrant, showing that news of the ship’s exploits has spread in distorted form.
The episode gives Neelix a measure of responsibility for the situation, connecting his role as ship’s morale officer and storyteller to broader consequences.
Impersonation and identity fraud are recurring motifs in Star Trek, here approached in a light but consequential way.
The story underscores that Federation ideals can be co-opted by less scrupulous figures when local populations lack context.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores reputation and how easily heroic narratives can be twisted for selfish gain.
It examines trust and the difficulty of repairing it once it has been abused.
Live Fast and Prosper highlights the difference between surface imitation of ideals and the harder work of actually living by them.
The story gently critiques opportunism in crisis, showing how con artists prey on the desperate.
BehindTheScenes: Live Fast and Prosper provided the cast an opportunity to portray exaggerated, comic versions of their characters through the impostors.
The episode’s tone leans into caper and heist tropes while still acknowledging serious consequences.
Costuming and makeup subtly differentiate the impostor "uniforms" from genuine Starfleet attire, emphasizing their second-hand nature.

Title: Muse
Summary: After a shuttle crash strands B'Elanna Torres on a pre-industrial world, she becomes the secret inspiration for Kelis, a struggling playwright who uses her logs and stories about Voyager to craft politically charged dramas for a warlord, forcing her to bend the Prime Directive through art to avert a looming war.

StorySections.Teaser: In an open-air theater on a bronze-age world, a troupe performs a stylized play featuring "Voyager" and "the Sky Ship" to an audience that includes a discerning warlord who demands more inspiring material from the nervous playwright Kelis.
StorySections.Act I: Flashbacks reveal that Kelis discovered Torres unconscious in her crashed shuttle in the mountains. Nursing her back to health in secret, he became fascinated by her logs and began weaving her accounts of Starfleet, Janeway and the ship’s values into his plays.
StorySections.Act II: As Torres slowly repairs her shuttle and hides her technology, Kelis struggles to satisfy the warlord’s desire for a play that will justify continued conflict with a rival state. Torres urges him to use the story of Voyager to promote diplomacy instead, effectively turning his theater into a vehicle for de-escalation.
StorySections.Act III: The warlord grows suspicious of the increasingly subversive themes and demands a spectacle that glorifies conquest. Kelis risks his life and livelihood by revising the play to emphasize sacrifice, understanding and the futility of endless war, while Torres prepares for a risky launch that may expose her presence.
StorySections.Act IV: On the night of the performance, Kelis’s staging of a dramatic "Prime Directive" choice and Janeway-like leadership moves the warlord and the crowd, nudging them toward negotiation rather than attack. Torres departs in her repaired shuttle just as Voyager arrives, leaving Kelis with enough vague truth to continue his art without further contamination.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard Voyager, Torres reflects on the odd experience of becoming a mythic figure in someone else’s culture, while on the planet Kelis begins drafting new plays that blend inspiration from the "sky people" with his world’s own evolving values.

Antagonists: Kelis's need to please a dangerous patron

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres must hide her true nature while using story and suggestion instead of technology or weapons to prevent bloodshed, revealing a more reflective side of her character.
EntitySummaries.Kelis: Kelis is an ambitious but compassionate playwright whose discovery of Voyager turns him into a conduit for Federation ideals in a society on the brink of war.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway appears primarily as a character in Kelis’s plays, an idealized figure whose decisions embody Starfleet ethics for the local audience.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Kim’s fate in the shuttle crash drives Torres’s urgency; his unseen survival becomes part of the tension surrounding her stranded status.
EntitySummaries.The Warlord: The warlord represents the capricious demands of power, craving narratives that justify his ambitions but ultimately susceptible to stories that appeal to honor and legacy.
EntitySummaries.Impending war between city-states: The looming conflict is a political antagonist that frames the stakes of Kelis’s next play.
EntitySummaries.Prime Directive constraints: The need to avoid overt interference functions as a conceptual antagonist that forces Torres to rely on art rather than direct action.
EntitySummaries.Kelis's need to please a dangerous patro: His dependence on the warlord’s favor is a social antagonist that complicates his willingness to stage subversive themes.
EntitySummaries.Lanya: Lanya, Kelis’s lead actress, risks herself alongside him to stage the controversial play and embodies the troupe’s commitment to art that matters.

ContinuityNotes: Muse spotlights B'Elanna Torres in a quieter, character-driven setting far from Voyager’s usual technology.
The episode offers a meta-commentary on Star Trek itself as a form of theater presenting ethical dilemmas to an audience.
Prime Directive concerns arise in a non-typical way, centering on the cultural impact of stories rather than technology.
The play-within-a-play device recalls similar theatrical explorations in other Trek series.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the power of art and storytelling to influence politics and morality.
It examines how myths about explorers can shape cultures that have never met them directly.
Muse reflects on the responsibility of artists when their work may inspire either war or peace.
The story suggests that ideas can travel farther and endure longer than ships or weapons.
BehindTheScenes: Muse uses minimal sets and theatrical staging to create a distinctive visual style compared to typical shipboard episodes.
Roxann Dawson’s performance emphasizes Torres’s weariness and adaptability away from her usual engineering context.
The episode has been discussed by fans and critics as a self-reflective piece on the role of science fiction television.

Title: Fury
Summary: An older, embittered Kes unexpectedly returns to Voyager, violently breaching its shields and allying with the Vidiians in a time-travel scheme to alter the ship’s past and free her younger self from the pain of the journey, forcing Janeway to counter her former crewmate without destroying the woman she once cared for.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager detects an incoming small vessel on a collision course. The pilot beams aboard in a surge of energy that tears through the ship’s corridors—revealing a drastically aged and furious Kes who begins attacking systems and crew without explanation.
StorySections.Act I: The older Kes storms through engineering, drawing on overwhelming telekinetic powers to sabotage Voyager’s warp core. She sends a subspace message to the Vidiians and uses the warp core to trigger a temporal rift, hurling herself and the ship’s timeline back to Voyager’s first year in the Delta Quadrant.
StorySections.Act II: In the altered past, the newly arrived "future" Kes secretly boards the earlier version of Voyager, where Neelix and the younger Kes are still adjusting to life on the ship. Disguising her identity, she feeds information to the Vidiians to help them ambush Voyager and capture crew for organ harvesting.
StorySections.Act III: Tuvok experiences disturbing temporal flashes that hint at the changed timeline and the older Kes’s presence. In the original time frame, a recorded message from a more lucid Kes reaches Janeway, warning her about what she is going to do and begging her past self to stop the cycle of anger.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway and Tuvok in the past piece together the truth and confront the older Kes, reminding her of who she was and what she valued. Faced with her own recorded plea and Janeway’s willingness to sacrifice to help her, Kes relents, undoing the temporal damage and returning herself to a course that avoids the destructive future.
StorySections.Tag: In the restored present, Voyager resumes its journey with a renewed, if bittersweet, understanding of how difficult Kes’s evolution has been and how fragile even the deepest bonds can become under strain.

EntitySummaries.Kes: Kes appears in both young and older forms, embodying the tension between the hopeful Ocampan who joined Voyager and a version warped by isolation and regret.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must treat a former friend as a threat while still reaching for the compassion and understanding that once defined their relationship.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s latent telepathic sensitivity makes him the first to sense the temporal disturbance, and he serves as a stabilizing presence for both Janeway and Kes.
EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix is shaken by the idea that Kes could come to hate their time together, underscoring the emotional cost of her departure from the ship.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris participates in the defensive efforts against the Vidiians and serves as a reminder of Voyager’s early struggles in the Delta Quadrant.
EntitySummaries.Older Kes: The older Kes is a tragic antagonist whose anger and power threaten the ship even as they stem from genuine pain and disillusionment.
EntitySummaries.Younger Kes: The younger Kes represents the path not yet fully chosen, a reminder of the potential that still exists within her future self.
EntitySummaries.Vidiian commander: The Vidiian leader seizes on Kes’s information as a chance to harvest valuable organs from Voyager’s crew.
EntitySummaries.Vidiian soldiers: They carry out the boarding actions and reinforce the ever-present threat the Vidiians posed in the early seasons.
EntitySummaries.Kes's future bitterness: Her festering resentment acts as an internal antagonist that drives the entire crisis.
EntitySummaries.Temporal disruption of Voyager's past: The altered timeline is a structural antagonist that threatens to erase the crew’s shared history.
EntitySummaries.Vidiian hunting party: Their opportunistic brutality provides an external, physical antagonist intertwined with Kes’s scheme.

ContinuityNotes: Fury brings Kes back to the series after her departure in "The Gift," revisiting her Ocampan evolution and relationship with Voyager.
The episode returns to Voyager’s early encounters with the Vidiians, visually and narratively echoing first-season storylines.
Tuvok’s temporal flashes recall his susceptibility to visions and altered states in prior episodes.
The story acknowledges the emotional fallout from Kes’s departure and the difficulty of her ascension beyond corporeal life.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how unresolved pain and alienation can twist fond memories into sources of resentment.
It examines the danger of trying to rewrite the past to avoid future suffering.
Fury highlights the challenge of recognizing oneself in a future you no longer understand or like.
The story emphasizes the power of compassion and remembrance in bringing someone back from the brink.
BehindTheScenes: Fury marked Jennifer Lien’s return to Voyager in a darker, more antagonistic role.
Production recreated early-season sets, costumes and hairstyles to portray the flashback period convincingly.
The episode divided fan opinion due to its portrayal of Kes’s fate, sparking ongoing discussion about character continuity.

Title: Life Line
Summary: When a data transmission from Starfleet reveals that the Doctor’s creator, Dr. Lewis Zimmerman, is terminally ill at Jupiter Station, the EMH is sent across the galaxy via a squeezed holo-matrix to treat the man who designed him, only to find a brilliant, bitter patient who would rather die than be saved by his own flawed creation.

StorySections.Teaser: During the latest communication window through the MIDAS array, Voyager receives a packet containing news, letters and a short, grainy message showing a very ill Dr. Lewis Zimmerman collapsing in his lab as colleagues call for help.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor is stunned to learn that Zimmerman is suffering from a degenerative condition that defies standard treatments. Barclay and Troi on Earth propose transmitting the EMH’s program to Jupiter Station as a long-shot specialist consultation, despite the risks of compressing his matrix for the long journey.
StorySections.Act II: Arriving at Jupiter Station, the Doctor is delighted and intimidated to meet his creator, only to be met with hostility. Zimmerman blames the EMH Mark I line for his professional humiliation and scoffs at the idea that a "mere program" could cure him.
StorySections.Act III: Troi mediates as the two clash over bedside manner, legacy and personhood. The Doctor struggles to diagnose the illness while fending off Zimmerman’s taunts and attempts to delete him. Meanwhile, Barclay and station staff work to stabilize the Doctor’s occasionally glitching matrix.
StorySections.Act IV: Realizing that Zimmerman’s illness responds to a tailored treatment combining holo-imaging and targeted therapy, the Doctor insists on continuing despite Zimmerman’s sabotage. A shared moment of vulnerability—acknowledging their mutual loneliness and need for recognition—finally convinces Zimmerman to accept help, and the treatment succeeds.
StorySections.Tag: As the communication window closes and the Doctor is transmitted back to Voyager, Zimmerman records a testimonial affirming the EMH’s worth, ensuring that his once-disparaged creation will be remembered as more than a failed prototype.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor confronts his origins and insecurities as he fights to save the life of the man who sees him as a failure, ultimately asserting his own worth as a physician and individual.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Lewis Zimmerman: Zimmerman is a brilliant but cantankerous scientist whose failing health forces him to confront the human consequences of his work and the legacy of the EMH program.
EntitySummaries.Reginald Barclay: Barclay champions the Doctor’s capabilities and engineers the complicated transmission, once again serving as a bridge between Voyager and Starfleet.
EntitySummaries.Deanna Troi: Troi acts as counselor to both Zimmerman and the Doctor, helping them navigate their bruised egos and unresolved emotional issues.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway approves the risky plan to send her chief medical officer across the galaxy, trusting in his skills and the relationships forged through Pathfinder.
EntitySummaries.Zimmerman's pride and bitterness: Zimmerman’s refusal to admit vulnerability or acknowledge the EMH as more than a tool is a psychological antagonist that nearly costs him his life.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor's identity insecurity: His fear of being dismissed as a flawed prototype functions as an internal antagonist he must overcome to stand his ground.
EntitySummaries.Technical limits of long-distance holo-t: The danger of corruption or loss during transit acts as a technological antagonist and ticking clock.
EntitySummaries.Haley (holographic assistant): Haley, Zimmerman’s holographic aide, quietly demonstrates that he has long relied on artificial companions even as he disparages them.

ContinuityNotes: Life Line is a sequel of sorts to "Pathfinder," again featuring Barclay and Troi and expanding on the Earth-side efforts to help Voyager.
The episode deepens the Doctor’s backstory by finally introducing his creator and exploring the EMH Mark I program’s mixed reputation.
Zimmerman had been previously glimpsed in Deep Space Nine, tying together strands from multiple series.
The events reinforce the growing recognition of holographic sentience and rights across the Federation.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores creator–creation dynamics, including pride, disappointment and unexpected mutual respect.
It examines issues of legacy and what it means to be considered a "failed" project or a success.
Life Line highlights the importance of accepting help and acknowledging emotional needs, even for brilliant minds.
The story underscores that compassion and persistence are as crucial to healing as technical skill.
BehindTheScenes: Life Line gave Robert Picardo a dual role, portraying both the Doctor and Dr. Zimmerman.
The episode offered another crossover with The Next Generation era through Troi and Barclay’s appearances.
Sets for Jupiter Station and Zimmerman’s lab were designed to reflect a cluttered, overworked genius’s environment.

Title: The Haunting of Deck Twelve
Summary: During a shipwide power-down, Neelix gathers the Borg children in a darkened cargo bay and tells a "ghost story" about an alien energy lifeform that once haunted Voyager’s systems, gradually revealing that his spooky tale is really a dramatized account of a past encounter with a misunderstood being they nearly destroyed.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager enters a nebula that requires shutting down most nonessential systems, leaving large sections of the ship dark. Neelix escorts the Borg children to safety and, to keep them calm, offers to tell a scary story about why Deck Twelve is "haunted."
StorySections.Act I: Neelix describes a time when the ship picked up a strange, invisible presence after leaving another nebula. Systems failed unpredictably, lights flickered and crew members reported eerie sensations, all of which he presents as signs of a restless "ghost."
StorySections.Act II: As his story continues, it becomes clear that the "haunting" was actually caused by a non-corporeal energy lifeform accidentally trapped in Voyager’s environmental systems. The entity lashed out in self-defense as engineering crews tried to purge what they thought was a dangerous anomaly.
StorySections.Act III: Neelix explains how the crew’s attempts to expel the presence almost destroyed it, prompting guilt and a redoubled effort to communicate. Seven and the Doctor eventually recognized patterns in the disturbances and helped Janeway establish a rudimentary dialogue with the frightened being.
StorySections.Act IV: The crew discovered that the entity considered the nebula its home and had been unwillingly displaced. They modified systems to safely release it back into its environment, ending the "haunting." Neelix concludes his tale just as power fully shuts down around them, spooking the children—until the lights return and Janeway confirms that everything is under control.
StorySections.Tag: After the ship exits the nebula and power is restored, the Borg children pretend not to have been scared, while Neelix smiles, satisfied that his story both entertained and taught a lesson about compassion for the unknown.

Antagonists: Fear of the dark and unknown

EntitySummaries.Neelix: Neelix uses storytelling to soothe and educate the children, reframing a dangerous encounter as a ghost story with an ultimately empathetic twist.
EntitySummaries.Icheb: Icheb feigns skepticism but is clearly engaged, using the story to puzzle out the logical explanation behind the "haunting."
EntitySummaries.Mezoti: Mezoti oscillates between bravado and unease, revealing how even former drones can be spooked by the unknown.
EntitySummaries.Azan: Azan clings to his brother and pays close attention, demonstrating the twins’ mutual reliance as they process new experiences.
EntitySummaries.Rebi: Rebi’s cautious questions help Neelix clarify the moral of the story about understanding unfamiliar forms of life.
EntitySummaries.Naomi Wildman: Naomi, sometimes included in the children’s group, serves as a point of identification for younger viewers and reacts enthusiastically to Neelix’s tale.
EntitySummaries.Energy lifeform: The entity is an initially frightening but ultimately sympathetic presence that behaves aggressively only out of fear and displacement.
EntitySummaries.Misunderstood energy entity: As an antagonistic force, the being represents how lack of communication can turn simple survival instincts into perceived malice.
EntitySummaries.Fear of the dark and unknown: The children’s anxiety in the powerless ship functions as a psychological antagonist that Neelix’s story helps them confront.
EntitySummaries.Nebula's disruptive environment: The volatile nebula both necessitates the power-down and once served as the energy being’s natural habitat.

ContinuityNotes: The Haunting of Deck Twelve uses a frame story to present a past "unseen" adventure of Voyager.
The episode continues the development of the Borg children’s relationships with Neelix and the rest of the crew.
It reinforces Star Trek’s recurring theme that seemingly hostile entities are often misunderstood lifeforms.
The structure echoes earlier Trek episodes that use campfire-style storytelling as a narrative device.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how stories can make frightening experiences manageable for children.
It emphasizes empathy toward unfamiliar lifeforms, even when their actions are initially threatening.
The Haunting of Deck Twelve highlights the difference between superstition and scientific understanding.
The story suggests that fear can be transformed into curiosity through narrative framing.
BehindTheScenes: The episode’s title and structure pay homage to classic ghost stories and bottle episodes.
Lighting and sound design play a major role in creating the spooky atmosphere aboard the darkened ship.
The production offered the child actors playing the Borg kids more ensemble time and character moments.

Title: Unimatrix Zero, Part I
Summary: Seven of Nine begins experiencing vivid dreamlike visits to "Unimatrix Zero," a hidden virtual sanctuary where certain Borg drones retain individuality while regenerating, and Janeway seizes the chance to help them form a resistance movement from within the Collective—even if it means deliberately allowing herself and two senior officers to be assimilated.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven awakens from a strange dream of walking in a forest among unassimilated individuals who seem to know her, dismissing it as an anomaly until she later falls asleep and returns to the same place, where they insist she has been there many times before.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor confirms that Seven is entering an unusual REM state during regeneration, projecting her consciousness into a shared mental space accessed by a small fraction of drones with a rare genetic trait. The inhabitants call it Unimatrix Zero and explain that, outside it, they are ordinary Borg with no memory of their time there.
StorySections.Act II: As a massive Borg tactical cube pursues and assimilates a new species, Voyager intercepts clues about drones who become "malfunctioning" after emerging from regeneration. Janeway realizes these are Unimatrix Zero denizens increasingly unable to forget their individuality and sees an opportunity to undermine the Collective from within.
StorySections.Act III: Within Unimatrix Zero, Seven reconnects with Axum, a former fellow drone who claims they once shared a deep bond in the sanctuary. He and others beg her to help them preserve their identities in the waking world, as the Borg Queen has discovered the phenomenon and is working to eradicate it.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway devises a risky plan to infect Unimatrix Zero with a nanovirus that will allow its members to retain their memories when awake, effectively turning them into embedded resistance cells. To upload the virus, Janeway, Tuvok and B'Elanna must be partially assimilated on a Borg vessel, carrying the program into the Collective itself.
StorySections.Tag: The episode ends on a cliffhanger as Janeway, Tuvok and B'Elanna, now in Borg armor, stand among other drones while the Borg Queen becomes aware that something is amiss, setting the stage for a larger internal revolt.

Antagonists: The Borg Collective's suppression of individuality

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced to confront a past she does not remember and the possibility that she once had a rich inner life even as a drone, reigniting questions about identity and lost time.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway embraces a bold, dangerous strategy, willing to risk assimilation to ignite a rebellion that could save countless drones and weaken one of Starfleet’s deadliest enemies.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok agrees to join the infiltration mission despite the particular risks assimilation poses to his Vulcan mind and disciplined sense of self.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres brings her engineering expertise to the plan while confronting her own fears about losing autonomy to the Collective.
EntitySummaries.Borg Queen: The Queen views Unimatrix Zero as a dangerous flaw in the hive and moves ruthlessly to eradicate it, embodying the Collective’s drive for absolute control.
EntitySummaries.Axum: Axum serves as Seven’s guide and emotional anchor within Unimatrix Zero, reconnecting her to relationships she never knew she had.
EntitySummaries.Unimatrix Zero denizens: The scattered drones who share the sanctuary are potential revolutionaries, desperate to preserve their individuality beyond the dream-like refuge.
EntitySummaries.Assimilated alien drones: Newly assimilated individuals highlight the ongoing horror of the Borg even as cracks appear in their unity.
EntitySummaries.The Borg Collective's suppression of ind: The hive mind’s constant suppression of self is a conceptual antagonist that Unimatrix Zero directly challenges.
EntitySummaries.Risk of deliberate assimilation: The plan to be assimilated for strategic gain is a structural antagonist that tests the crew’s courage and trust in one another.
