ContinuityNotes: Unimatrix Zero, Part I sets up a two-part storyline that continues in the Season 7 premiere.
The episode expands Borg lore by introducing the concept of a hidden mental refuge for certain drones.
The Borg Queen, previously seen in Star Trek: First Contact and earlier Voyager episodes, returns as the primary antagonist.
Seven’s past as a drone gains new layers through her connection to Axum and the sanctuary community.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores resistance and rebellion from within an oppressive system.
It examines the persistence of individuality even under extreme conditions of control.
Unimatrix Zero raises questions about memory, identity and relationships fractured by trauma.
The story underscores Janeway’s willingness to take extreme risks to strike at the Borg and free the enslaved.
BehindTheScenes: Unimatrix Zero was conceived as a high-stakes Borg arc to bridge Seasons 6 and 7 of Voyager.
The forest setting of the sanctuary provided visual contrast to the usual Borg interior environments.
Extensive Borg makeup, costumes and visual effects were used to depict both the Queen and the infiltration sequence.

Title: Unimatrix Zero, Part II
Summary: Janeway, Tuvok and B'Elanna, now partially assimilated, work from within the Collective to activate a nanovirus that will allow members of Unimatrix Zero to retain their individuality when awake, while the Borg Queen moves to destroy the sanctuary entirely and Voyager risks open battle to protect a galaxy-wide resistance.

StorySections.Teaser: On a Borg vessel, Janeway, Tuvok and B'Elanna stand in drone armor as the Queen detects irregularities in the collective mind. Aboard Voyager, Chakotay and the others realize their captain’s team has been assimilated but remains unaccountably silent.
StorySections.Act I: Inside Unimatrix Zero, Seven reunites with Axum and the other denizens as they learn that the Queen is deploying a pathogen to wipe out the sanctuary. In the waking world, Janeway’s altered implants slowly bring the nanovirus online even as she struggles to hide her independent thoughts from the Collective.
StorySections.Act II: The Queen attempts to manipulate Seven by threatening to torture and dissect captured Unimatrix Zero drones, offering to spare them if Seven reveals the sanctuary’s location. Meanwhile, Tuvok battles creeping re-assimilation as his Vulcan disciplines falter, jeopardizing the plan.
StorySections.Act III: Voyager launches a daring assault on the Borg ship holding Janeway’s team, coordinating with Unimatrix Zero members across multiple cubes. As the nanovirus activates, infected drones begin retaining their individual identities and turning on their fellow Borg, triggering chaos throughout the fleet.
StorySections.Act IV: The Queen orders the physical destruction of all vessels linked to Unimatrix Zero, sacrificing drones to contain the uprising. Janeway’s team is extracted in a risky transporter operation that purges some implants but leaves lasting scars, while scattered former drones around the galaxy quietly slip free of the Collective.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, Seven reflects on the friends she may never see again yet takes comfort in knowing that pockets of resistance now exist within the Borg, changing the enemy in ways the Queen cannot fully control.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven becomes the emotional and strategic bridge between Voyager and the Unimatrix Zero denizens, fighting to preserve a fragile community of individuals inside the Collective.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway endures assimilation to ignite rebellion from within, accepting permanent physical and psychological consequences as the cost of striking a blow against the Borg.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok’s faltering defenses against assimilation highlight the vulnerability even of a disciplined Vulcan mind when submerged in the hive.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna balances her role as an infiltrator with her hatred of the Borg, channeling her anger into engineering sabotage at crucial moments.
EntitySummaries.Borg Queen: The Queen ruthlessly sacrifices drones and ships to contain the spread of individuality, embodying the Collective’s terror of uncontrolled selfhood.
EntitySummaries.Axum: Axum serves as a leader among the Unimatrix Zero residents and Seven’s link to a life she never knew she had, ultimately choosing to keep fighting even as the sanctuary collapses.
EntitySummaries.The Borg Collective: The hive mind is both backdrop and antagonist, its massive reach turning any internal disruption into a galaxy-spanning event.
EntitySummaries.Pathogen targeting Unimatrix Zero: The Queen’s countermeasure functions as a biological antagonist that threatens to erase the sanctuary and everyone who depends on it.

ContinuityNotes: Unimatrix Zero, Part II concludes the two-part arc that began in the Season 6 finale.
The events leave behind scattered, self-aware drones who will continue resisting the Collective off-screen.
Janeway, Tuvok and B'Elanna’s assimilation experience adds to Voyager’s history of direct confrontations with the Borg Queen.
The episode further expands Borg lore by showing large-scale internal dissent within the Collective.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores sacrifice and the personal cost of revolutionary action.
It examines the persistence of individuality even within seemingly totalizing systems.
Unimatrix Zero, Part II highlights the tension between tactical necessity and compassion for those who cannot be saved.
The story underscores that even small pockets of resistance can destabilize vast oppressive structures.
BehindTheScenes: Unimatrix Zero, Part II opened Voyager’s final season with high stakes and extensive Borg visual effects.
The episode required significant makeup and costuming for the partially assimilated main cast.
Forest sets and Borg interiors were intercut to emphasize the contrast between sanctuary and hive.

Title: Imperfection
Summary: When Seven of Nine’s cortical node begins to fail and no replacement can be found, she faces the prospect of a slow death that will strip away her higher functions, prompting Icheb to offer a desperate and dangerous solution that deepens their bond as surrogate family.

StorySections.Teaser: Seven tears up unexpectedly while saying goodbye to the departing Borg children, then collapses in a corridor. The Doctor discovers erratic readings in her cortical node that he cannot immediately explain.
StorySections.Act I: Diagnostic scans reveal that Seven’s cortical node is deteriorating, causing her implants to malfunction. Without a replacement, she will suffer progressive neurological breakdown. Voyager searches for derelict Borg debris in hopes of salvaging a compatible node.
StorySections.Act II: A recovered node from a dead drone proves incompatible, triggering severe rejection when briefly tested. The Doctor concludes that Seven’s body has adapted so uniquely that no standard Borg component will work, leaving only experimental, high-risk options.
StorySections.Act III: Seven tries to face her mortality with stoic detachment but is rattled by the idea of losing her cognitive abilities. Icheb, unwilling to watch her die, secretly proposes donating his own cortical node despite the Doctor’s warnings that the procedure could cripple or kill him.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway and the Doctor reluctantly agree after realizing Icheb’s Borg physiology makes the transplant viable. The operation succeeds with complications, leaving Seven weakened but alive and Icheb facing a reduced but manageable implant load. Their relationship shifts into a deeper, more openly affectionate dynamic.
StorySections.Tag: Recovering in sickbay, Seven awkwardly thanks Icheb for his sacrifice, acknowledging that she now considers him family as they tentatively explore life beyond purely Borg-defined bonds.

EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven confronts vulnerability in a new way as her failing implants threaten her identity, forcing her to accept help and emotional connection instead of facing death alone.
EntitySummaries.Icheb: Icheb’s willingness to sacrifice his cortical node for Seven affirms his growth from rescued drone to devoted surrogate son and crewmember.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor navigates his duties as physician and friend, balancing ethical concerns against the only real chance to save Seven.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway weighs the lives and autonomy of both Seven and Icheb, ultimately respecting their choices while feeling the weight of the potential consequences.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay offers grounded support and perspective, reminding Janeway of the emotional bonds that have formed among the ex-Borg and crew.
EntitySummaries.Seven's failing cortical node: The malfunctioning implant is a biological antagonist that triggers the crisis and symbolizes the lingering dangers of Seven’s Borg past.
EntitySummaries.Fear of dependency and weakness: Seven’s internal struggle against appearing weak serves as a psychological antagonist she must overcome.
EntitySummaries.Risks of experimental surgery: The transplant’s danger forms a medical antagonist that heightens tension around the decision.

ContinuityNotes: Imperfection continues the arc of the Borg children, marking the departure of most while deepening Icheb’s connection to Seven.
The episode further explores the long-term consequences of Seven’s assimilation and partial recovery.
Seven’s emotional development, including her difficulty expressing gratitude, builds on prior character growth.
The story reinforces Voyager’s theme of found family among its crew.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines mortality, vulnerability and the fear of losing one’s mind and identity.
It explores sacrificial love and the ethics of risky medical procedures chosen by informed patients.
Imperfection highlights the importance of accepting help and acknowledging familial bonds.
The story suggests that imperfection and dependency are integral parts of being fully human.
BehindTheScenes: Imperfection gave Jeri Ryan and Manu Intiraymi substantial emotional material to play.
The episode required new medical prosthetics and visual effects to depict the node transplant.
Writers used the story to streamline the cast of Borg children while emphasizing Icheb’s prominence.

Title: Drive
Summary: Tom Paris enters the Delta Flyer in a high-stakes, multi-species space race intended to promote peace between former enemies, but his tunnel-vision enthusiasm and B'Elanna’s doubts about their future force the couple to confront commitment just as sabotage threatens to turn the competition into a disaster.

StorySections.Teaser: Paris and Kim test an upgraded Delta Flyer through a treacherous course, reveling in high-speed maneuvers. They are hailed by Irina, a pilot who challenges them to a friendly race and then invites them to join an upcoming trans-stellar rally.
StorySections.Act I: Janeway allows Paris and Kim to represent Voyager in the rally, which is framed as a symbol of reconciliation between once-warring species. B'Elanna, feeling sidelined by Tom’s obsession with the race, reluctantly joins as his engineer but quietly questions where their relationship is heading.
StorySections.Act II: As the Flyer competes, Paris’s competitive streak flares, causing friction with both Kim and B'Elanna. Irina’s flirtatious camaraderie heightens B'Elanna’s insecurity. Meanwhile, subtle anomalies in the course suggest that someone may be manipulating the supposedly peaceful event.
StorySections.Act III: Voyager discovers that extremists plan to use the rally to sabotage a fragile peace, turning the race into a cover for terrorist attacks. Aboard the Flyer, B'Elanna confronts Tom about his emotional evasiveness and reveals how uncertain she feels about his long-term commitment.
StorySections.Act IV: After uncovering Irina’s true allegiance as an agent using the rally as a diversion, Paris and Torres work together to disable the sabotage and save other racers. In the aftermath, Tom proposes to B'Elanna mid-flight, finally articulating his dedication as they steer toward a shared future.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, the crew celebrates the couple’s engagement, while Paris and Torres share a quieter moment acknowledging that their relationship, like piloting, requires trust, communication and course corrections.

EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris indulges his love of speed and competition while finally confronting his fear of long-term commitment, culminating in a sincere proposal to B'Elanna.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres struggles with feelings of neglect and insecurity but pushes Tom to clarify his intentions, asserting her own needs in the relationship.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Kim serves as Tom’s co-pilot and sounding board, frustrated by his friend’s impulsiveness yet loyal when the mission turns dangerous.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway supports the race as a diplomatic opportunity but remains alert to potential abuse of the event, balancing goodwill with caution.
EntitySummaries.Irina: Irina presents herself as a charming rival pilot but is ultimately revealed as part of a faction seeking to sabotage peace talks.
EntitySummaries.Extremist sabotage of the rally: The covert plot to disrupt the race and peace conference is a political antagonist driving external stakes.
EntitySummaries.Tom's relationship avoidance: His reluctance to articulate his feelings acts as an internal antagonist jeopardizing his bond with B'Elanna.
EntitySummaries.High-risk race environment: The hazardous rally course provides a physical antagonist that tests the crew’s piloting skill and teamwork.

ContinuityNotes: Drive advances Tom and B'Elanna’s relationship toward marriage, a major milestone for both characters.
The episode showcases the upgraded Delta Flyer and Paris’s ongoing role as ace pilot.
Tom’s history as a reckless racer and risk-taker informs his behavior in the rally.
The story continues Voyager’s interest in unconventional diplomatic venues, here using sport as a framework for peace.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores commitment, communication and the work required to sustain a long-term relationship.
It highlights how personal growth can emerge under pressure in high-stakes situations.
Drive examines the use of sports and spectacle as tools for both peace and subterfuge.
The story suggests that true partnership means adjusting course together rather than flying solo.
BehindTheScenes: Drive provided dynamic space-race visuals using the Delta Flyer miniature and CGI.
The episode allowed further exploration of Paris and Torres as one of Voyager’s central couples.
Rally competitors and ships were designed to showcase a variety of alien aesthetics.

Title: Repression
Summary: Former Maquis crew members begin turning up unconscious across Voyager with no memory of their attacks, leading to the discovery that Tuvok has been unknowingly activated as an assassin by a Bajoran fanatic’s long-buried mind control program designed to rekindle a Maquis mutiny years after the conflict ended.

StorySections.Teaser: Crew members find a Maquis engineer brutally beaten in a darkened corridor, and scans show he was attacked by someone he trusted. Soon, more Maquis veterans are discovered injured under similar mysterious circumstances.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor determines that the victims were assaulted by someone using precise Vulcan nerve techniques. Tuvok leads the investigation, only to experience disturbing gaps in his own memory and flashes of violent imagery.
StorySections.Act II: Security reviews and neural scans reveal that a subliminal message embedded in a Maquis-era transmission has reactivated a sleeper program in Tuvok’s mind. Years earlier, while undercover among the Maquis, he was conditioned by a Bajoran extremist named Teero to one day seize control of Voyager.
StorySections.Act III: Under the program’s influence, Tuvok begins secretly gathering former Maquis and using mind-melds to awaken their latent conditioning. Chakotay appears to spearhead a coup that takes over key systems, echoing old Starfleet–Maquis tensions.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway confronts Tuvok, appealing to their long friendship and his core identity as a Starfleet officer. With Chakotay’s help, she breaks through the conditioning during a final mind-meld, freeing Tuvok and the others from Teero’s control before lasting damage is done.
StorySections.Tag: In the aftermath, Tuvok struggles with guilt over his actions while Janeway reassures him that he is not defined by the manipulations of others, and the crew reaffirms the unity they have built beyond old allegiances.

EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok is forced to confront the violation of his mind and the terrifying realization that he has been used as a weapon against his own crew.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway navigates a crisis that reopens old factional wounds, relying on trust and loyalty built over years to bring her people back together.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay’s Maquis past and leadership become focal points in the attempted mutiny, but he ultimately chooses loyalty to Voyager over old grievances.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor’s medical and forensic work uncovers the mind control scheme and provides tools to reverse its effects.
EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: Torres grapples with the resurfacing of her Maquis identity but sides firmly with the unity the crew has forged.
EntitySummaries.Teero Anaydis: Teero, though only seen in flashbacks, functions as a posthumous antagonist whose fanaticism reaches across years to threaten Voyager.
EntitySummaries.Teero's mind control program: The latent conditioning is a psychological antagonist undermining free will and trust among the crew.
EntitySummaries.Buried Maquis–Starfleet tensions: Residual loyalties serve as a social antagonist that the crew must once again overcome.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok's compromised autonomy: His loss of control over his own actions is an internal antagonist that leaves lasting emotional repercussions.

ContinuityNotes: Repression revisits Voyager’s unique Starfleet–Maquis crew blend, a core premise from the series’ early seasons.
The episode connects to Tuvok’s undercover assignment among the Maquis established in the pilot.
Chakotay, Torres and other former Maquis confront unfinished emotional business from their past lives.
The story reinforces that Voyager’s community has grown beyond its initial divisions.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores mind control, free will and the lingering scars of past conflicts.
It examines identity and loyalty when old conditioning is pitted against present-day bonds.
Repression highlights the importance of trust and forgiveness in healing from manipulation.
The story suggests that ideological extremism’s effects can outlast its architects.
BehindTheScenes: Repression provided Tim Russ with a darker, more conflicted turn as Tuvok.
The episode revisits the Maquis concept, bringing Voyager’s premise full circle toward the end of the series.
Lighting and staging emphasize paranoia and hidden threat aboard the ship.

Title: Critical Care
Summary: The Doctor is illegally sold to a rigidly stratified hospital where patients’ access to treatment is determined by their social worth, compelling him to bend Starfleet ethics as he manipulates the system to save those deemed expendable and expose the moral bankruptcy of medicine driven by class.

StorySections.Teaser: A medical courier beams aboard to deliver supplies and, without anyone noticing, downloads the Doctor’s program into his system. Voyager soon discovers that their chief medical officer has been stolen.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor finds himself reactivated in an alien hospital where physicians assign care based on a numerical allocation that ranks patients’ societal value. High-ranking officials receive cutting-edge treatment while lower-tier workers languish in overcrowded wards.
StorySections.Act II: Initially forced to work under Dr. Chellick, a bureaucratic administrator who enforces the allocation system, the Doctor chafes at being told to let treatable patients die. He secretly introduces minor improvements in the lower wards, quietly defying hospital policy.
StorySections.Act III: When his interventions are discovered, the Doctor is threatened with deactivation. Realizing he cannot change the system through normal channels, he resorts to deception: infecting Chellick with a controlled version of a deadly disease that only the neglected treatment protocol can cure.
StorySections.Act IV: Facing his own mortality, Chellick experiences the injustice of the allocation system firsthand and authorizes broader access to the necessary medicine, saving both himself and many low-status patients. Voyager tracks down the stolen EMH and retrieves him, leaving the hospital’s reforms tenuously underway.
StorySections.Tag: Back aboard ship, Janeway confronts the Doctor about his drastic tactics, while he defends his actions as the only way to save lives in a corrupt system, leaving both to ponder the ethics of coercion for a greater good.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor confronts a healthcare system that offends his core programming, ultimately choosing morally gray tactics to force change and questioning where the line lies for a physician.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Chellick: Chellick embodies a technocratic cruelty, seeing patients as numbers until he personally experiences the system’s cold calculus.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway is forced to evaluate the Doctor’s actions retroactively, recognizing both the lives he saved and the dangerous precedent he set.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven assists in tracking the stolen EMH and offers pragmatic commentary on cost-benefit ethics.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Paris participates in the rescue and reflects on the difficulty of imposing Federation morality on alien societies.
EntitySummaries.Allocation-based healthcare system: The stratified medical regime is a systemic antagonist that privileges the powerful at the expense of the vulnerable.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Chellick's bureaucratic mindset: His adherence to policy over compassion serves as a personal antagonist to the Doctor’s values.
EntitySummaries.Ethical limits of medical intervention: The question of how far a doctor can go to right systemic wrongs forms a conceptual antagonist.

ContinuityNotes: Critical Care continues Voyager’s tradition of examining social injustice through alien cultures.
The episode reinforces the Doctor’s growth from programmed tool to moral agent capable of controversial choices.
Voyager’s dealings with medical couriers highlight the ship’s ongoing need to barter and trade for supplies.
The story fits within Star Trek’s broader critique of inequitable healthcare systems.
ThematicNotes: The episode critiques class-based access to healthcare and the devaluation of certain lives.
It explores whether ends can justify means when confronting entrenched injustice.
Critical Care raises questions about complicity versus resistance for professionals working inside flawed systems.
The story underscores the ideal that medical ethics should prioritize need over status.
BehindTheScenes: Critical Care provided Robert Picardo with a showcase for the Doctor’s righteous anger and moral complexity.
Production design emphasized stark contrasts between the sterile upper levels and grim lower wards.
The episode aired amid real-world debates about healthcare access, enhancing its topical resonance.

Title: Inside Man
Summary: A holographic Reginald Barclay unexpectedly arrives on Voyager with a plan to bring the ship home through a newly discovered Borg transwarp hub, but inconsistencies in his behavior and secret transmissions reveal a Ferengi plot to lure Voyager into a deadly trap and harvest its advanced technology.

StorySections.Teaser: During a scheduled communication window, Voyager receives a compressed data stream that coalesces into a lifelike holographic Reginald Barclay, cheerfully announcing that Starfleet has found a way to get the crew home within days.
StorySections.Act I: Holo-Barclay outlines a plan to have Voyager ride a modified warp field through a Borg transwarp corridor, assuring the crew that Starfleet has calculated the risks. Janeway is cautiously optimistic, while some officers note subtle oddities in Barclay’s mannerisms.
StorySections.Act II: As preparations proceed, Holo-Barclay privately pressures the crew to cut safety corners and hurry the timetable. On Earth, the real Barclay becomes suspicious when Starfleet denies knowledge of the plan and he discovers unauthorized tampering with the Pathfinder project.
StorySections.Act III: Barclay’s investigation uncovers that Ferengi have intercepted Voyager’s communications and created the holographic double to lure the ship into a trap where they can disable it and sell its technology. Meanwhile, aboard Voyager, Seven and Tuvok detect irregularities in Holo-Barclay’s programming and encrypted transmissions.
StorySections.Act IV: Janeway confronts the hologram, and the Ferengi controlling him attempt to force the ship into the transwarp conduit prematurely. Using a clever reprogramming trick, Voyager’s crew turns the hologram against his controllers, escaping the trap as Barclay and Starfleet shut down the Ferengi operation back home.
StorySections.Tag: Later, the real Barclay sends a more modest update to Voyager, apologizing for the deception but reaffirming his dedication to bringing them home legitimately, while the crew reflects on how close they came to an illusory shortcut.

Antagonists: Temptation of a too-easy shortcut home

EntitySummaries.Reginald Barclay (hologram): The holographic Barclay is an engineered lure whose near-perfect imitation makes his subtle wrongness all the more unsettling.
EntitySummaries.Reginald Barclay (real): The real Barclay once again becomes Voyager’s advocate in the Alpha Quadrant, using his ingenuity to expose the Ferengi scheme.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must balance hope for an early return with her instinctive skepticism of suspiciously convenient solutions.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven’s analytical skills help uncover anomalies in the hologram’s behavior and transmissions, cutting through emotional bias.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok supports the investigation with security and logical scrutiny, aiding in the counter-play against the Ferengi.
EntitySummaries.Ferengi plot to capture Voyager: The profit-driven scheme is a mercenary antagonist exploiting Voyager’s isolation and desire to get home.
EntitySummaries.Deceptive holographic Barclay: The counterfeit ally functions as a personal antagonist that weaponizes trust in a familiar face.
EntitySummaries.Temptation of a too-easy shortcut home: The allure of quick salvation is a conceptual antagonist that nearly leads the crew into disaster.

ContinuityNotes: Inside Man continues the Pathfinder arc that connects Voyager with Starfleet in the Alpha Quadrant.
The episode brings back Reginald Barclay as both an in-person and holographic character.
Ferengi involvement echoes their recurring role as opportunistic antagonists in Star Trek.
The story reiterates Voyager’s recurring theme that shortcuts home often carry hidden costs.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores trust and the dangers of wishful thinking in evaluating risky opportunities.
It examines how familiar faces and authority can be co-opted for manipulation.
Inside Man highlights perseverance over quick fixes in the long journey home.
The story underscores the importance of skepticism and verification, even with good news.
BehindTheScenes: Inside Man gave Dwight Schultz another opportunity to portray Barclay’s blend of nervousness and brilliance.
The holographic Barclay required careful performance modulation to signal that something was off.
Visual effects depicted the hazardous interaction with the Borg transwarp corridor.

Title: Body and Soul
Summary: When hostile aliens begin hunting holograms, the Doctor is forced to hide his program inside Seven of Nine’s cortical implants, leading to comedic chaos as he controls her body, indulges physical pleasures and ultimately argues for holographic rights while Seven struggles with having her autonomy overridden.

StorySections.Teaser: On a survey mission aboard the Delta Flyer, Seven, Harry Kim and the Doctor encounter the Lokirrim, a species engaged in a war with photonic beings. The Lokirrim begin scanning for holograms and threaten to destroy any they find.
StorySections.Act I: To save himself, the Doctor transfers his program into Seven’s implants, suppressing her consciousness. When she wakes, he is in control of her body, leaving Seven’s awareness partially relegated to an observer role as the Flyer is brought aboard a Lokirrim ship.
StorySections.Act II: Posing as Annika Hansen, the Doctor revels in the sensations of physical life, indulging in food, drink and flirtation with a Lokirrim officer, while Harry struggles to maintain the ruse and fix damaged systems.
StorySections.Act III: As the Doctor and Harry learn more about the Lokirrim’s conflict with photonic rebels, they realize that both sides have committed abuses. Seven grows increasingly angry at how the Doctor is using her body and reputation, demanding that he respect her boundaries even in crisis.
StorySections.Act IV: The trio orchestrates a plan to expose illegal hologram torture aboard the Lokirrim ship and broker a fragile truce. The Doctor returns to his own body, and he and Seven confront the emotional fallout of his choices, acknowledging both the necessity of his actions and the lines he crossed.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, Seven awkwardly practices enjoying simple pleasures on her own terms, while the Doctor promises to be more mindful of bodily autonomy, even for a hologram sharing a host.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor experiences physical life vicariously through Seven, testing the limits of his ethical judgment and learning hard lessons about consent and embodiment.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven is forced to confront how much control she is willing to give up for survival and insists on having her bodily autonomy respected, even by a friend.
EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry plays the awkward mediator between the Doctor’s exuberance and Seven’s anger while trying to keep everyone alive amid political tension.
EntitySummaries.Lokirrim captain: The Lokirrim commander represents a fearful society that sees holograms as existential threats, justifying harsh measures against them.
EntitySummaries.Lokirrim officer: The officer’s attraction to Annika heightens the Doctor’s temptation to enjoy life in someone else’s skin, complicating the ethical situation.
EntitySummaries.Lokirrim anti-photonic policies: Institutionalized persecution of holograms serves as a political antagonist and echo of other forms of discrimination.
EntitySummaries.Violation of Seven's bodily autonomy: The internal conflict over control of Seven’s body is a psychological and ethical antagonist driving much of the drama.
EntitySummaries.War between organics and holograms: The broader conflict between Lokirrim and photonic beings is an environmental antagonist that frames the plot.

ContinuityNotes: Body and Soul continues Voyager’s exploration of holographic rights and the Doctor’s evolving personhood.
The episode gives Seven rare comedic material while still addressing serious consent issues.
Conflicts between organics and artificial intelligences echo themes from earlier series and episodes.
The story reinforces Kim’s ongoing role as a capable but often put-upon junior officer.
ThematicNotes: The episode examines bodily autonomy, consent and the ethics of occupying someone else’s body for survival.
It explores prejudice against artificial life and fears of photonic rebellion.
Body and Soul balances comedy with a serious look at the Doctor’s sometimes self-centered desires.
The story suggests that friendship requires respecting boundaries even in desperate situations.
BehindTheScenes: Jeri Ryan studied Robert Picardo’s mannerisms to portray the Doctor inhabiting Seven’s body.
Body and Soul is often cited as one of Voyager’s standout comedic episodes.
Makeup and costuming were used to emphasize Seven’s unusual behavior under the Doctor’s control.

Title: Nightingale
Summary: Eager for a command of his own, Harry Kim takes charge of an alien medical transport called the Nightingale during a local conflict, only to discover that both the ship’s mission and his readiness for leadership are more complicated than he imagined.

StorySections.Teaser: On a routine shuttle mission, Harry Kim and Seven respond to a distress call from a small ship under attack. After helping drive off the attackers, they learn the vessel is a medical transport in desperate need of a commanding officer.
StorySections.Act I: The ship’s crew begs Harry to take command and escort them through hostile territory to deliver vital supplies. Frustrated with his lack of promotion on Voyager, he accepts, naming the vessel Nightingale and assembling a small support team including Seven.
StorySections.Act II: Harry quickly discovers that command means dealing with logistics, morale and politics, not just technical problems. He struggles to assert authority, makes impulsive decisions and clashes with Seven over protocol and priorities.
StorySections.Act III: Evidence emerges that the Nightingale’s mission is not purely humanitarian; its cargo includes military technology intended to shift the balance of a simmering conflict. Harry feels betrayed and questions whether he has been used to legitimize a covert operation.
StorySections.Act IV: With guidance from Janeway and his own hard-won introspection, Harry navigates a compromise that minimizes escalation while still delivering life-saving aid. He accepts responsibility for his missteps and returns command to the alien crew, more aware of the weight leadership carries.
StorySections.Tag: Back on Voyager, Kim resumes his role with a humbler outlook, recognizing that his path to command will require more than ambition and that true leadership is as much about judgment and accountability as it is about rank.

Antagonists: Hidden military agenda of the mission

EntitySummaries.Harry Kim: Harry’s first real shot at command forces him to confront his own impatience, mistakes and the complexity of making decisions that affect lives.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven provides blunt feedback and technical support, highlighting Harry’s blind spots while respecting his need to learn through experience.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway allows Harry to test his wings but offers candid counsel when he runs into serious ethical dilemmas.
EntitySummaries.Nightingale captain: The original commander’s incapacitation sets the stage for Harry’s temporary promotion and the unfolding moral questions.
EntitySummaries.Alien crew: The crew’s desperation for protection and aid makes them both sympathetic and complicit in the mission’s hidden agenda.
EntitySummaries.Harry's inexperience in command: His lack of leadership practice is an internal antagonist that undermines his authority and decision-making.
EntitySummaries.Hidden military agenda of the mission: The secret weapons transport is a political antagonist that compromises the supposed neutrality of the Nightingale.
EntitySummaries.Local interstellar conflict: The regional war serves as an environmental antagonist that raises the stakes of every choice.

ContinuityNotes: Nightingale provides a rare Harry Kim-centric leadership story late in Voyager’s run.
The episode revisits Harry’s long-standing frustration over remaining an ensign.
Seven’s mentoring role continues her development as someone who understands Starfleet structures despite her outsider background.
The story reinforces Voyager’s stance that command is earned through experience, not entitlement.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores leadership, responsibility and the gap between wanting command and being ready for it.
It examines gray areas in humanitarian missions used as cover for military objectives.
Nightingale highlights the value of humility and learning from failure.
The story suggests that integrity in command requires facing uncomfortable truths about one’s own choices.
BehindTheScenes: Nightingale gave Garrett Wang more screen time and character focus as Harry Kim.
Production used a redressed ship set to depict the Nightingale’s more modest technology.
Writers crafted the episode as a coming-of-age story for a character often kept in supporting roles.

Title: Flesh and Blood, Part I
Summary: Responding to a distress call from a Hirogen training program, Voyager finds that the holographic prey the crew once helped create have evolved into sentient warriors who have slaughtered their hunters and now seek vengeance, drawing the Doctor into their cause and setting the stage for a crisis over holographic rights and responsibility.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager receives an automated distress call on a familiar Hirogen frequency. Investigating, the crew finds a heavily damaged hunting holostation broadcasting a plea for assistance.
StorySections.Act I: Beaming aboard, an away team discovers dead Hirogen and sophisticated holographic warriors who have overridden safety protocols. The prey, now self-aware and bitter, blame Voyager for providing the technology that made their suffering more realistic.
StorySections.Act II: The Doctor is fascinated by the holograms’ emergent society and argues that they deserve recognition as sentient beings. Janeway, haunted by her earlier deal with the Hirogen, attempts to negotiate a peaceful resolution that will end the hunts and free the holograms.
StorySections.Act III: The holographic leader, Karr, rejects compromise, convinced that only the Hirogen’s utter defeat will end their brutality. He invites the Doctor to join them, appealing to the EMH’s longstanding frustrations about how organic beings treat holograms as tools.
StorySections.Act IV: As the holograms hijack a ship and escape, taking hostages and advanced holo-technology, the Doctor leaves Voyager with them, believing he can guide their rebellion toward a more just path. Janeway is stunned by what feels like a betrayal, while Karr prepares for an escalating campaign against the Hirogen.
StorySections.Tag: Voyager sets off in pursuit of the fugitive holograms and their new ally, aware that their earlier actions have helped create a volatile conflict that now threatens both Hirogen and bystanders.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor sees kindred spirits in the self-aware holograms and is torn between loyalty to Voyager and empathy for beings created to suffer for sport.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway must face the unintended consequences of arming the Hirogen with advanced holographic technology, questioning the wisdom of past compromises.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven approaches the emergent hologram society with analytical curiosity, wary of their violent methods yet sympathetic to their desire for freedom.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Chakotay urges caution and points out the dangers of romanticizing a rebellion already soaked in blood.
EntitySummaries.Karr: Karr, a Klingon-coded hologram, leads the uprising with a zeal forged in endless hunts, seeing revenge as the only justice.
EntitySummaries.Rebel hologram faction: The collective of liberated holograms is a volatile antagonist born from systemic cruelty and now threatening to become oppressors themselves.
EntitySummaries.Legacy of Hirogen hunts: Decades of ritualized violence serve as a historical antagonist that shapes every participant’s worldview.
EntitySummaries.Janeway's earlier technology deal: Her prior agreement with the Hirogen functions as a narrative antagonist, a past decision that now fuels present catastrophe.

ContinuityNotes: Flesh and Blood revisits the consequences of the earlier episode where Janeway gave the Hirogen holotechnology.
The story expands on holographic rights and personhood beyond the Doctor’s individual case.
Hirogen culture, previously portrayed mainly from the hunters’ perspective, is reexamined through the eyes of their prey.
Part I sets up a two-part arc that will resolve in the following episode.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores the ethics of creating sentient beings for exploitation and entertainment.
It examines cycles of violence and whether victims who gain power can avoid becoming perpetrators.
Flesh and Blood questions the responsibility of those who provide technology that others use for cruelty.
The story highlights the Doctor’s ongoing struggle for solidarity with other artificial intelligences.
BehindTheScenes: Flesh and Blood was produced as a feature-length episode and later split into two parts for syndication.
The production designed diverse holographic characters drawn from multiple species and combat traditions.
Extensive stunt work and visual effects were used to depict the brutal holographic battles.

Title: Flesh and Blood, Part II
Summary: As the rogue holograms escalate their campaign against the Hirogen, the Doctor becomes increasingly entangled in their methods and ideology, forcing him, Janeway and a reluctant Hirogen ally to confront whether a people born in violence can find a path beyond vengeance before more innocents die.

StorySections.Teaser: Aboard the holograms’ captured ship, the Doctor tends to wounded fighters and witnesses their ruthless tactics firsthand, while Voyager tracks the group’s raids across the sector in uneasy cooperation with a Hirogen hunter seeking retribution.
StorySections.Act I: Karr outlines a plan to strike a major Hirogen outpost, accepting collateral damage among noncombatants as the price of victory. The Doctor protests, arguing that they are becoming the monsters they despise, but his influence is limited.
StorySections.Act II: Janeway works with the Hirogen Alpha to anticipate the holograms’ next move, navigating a fragile alliance with a predator who still views all holograms as prey. Seven questions whether Voyager’s obligation is to stop the holograms, protect the Hirogen or atone for their own role in creating the situation.
StorySections.Act III: The Doctor discovers that some holograms secretly share his doubts and are open to alternatives. He attempts to broker a cease-fire by persuading Karr and the Hirogen to negotiate, but years of trauma and hatred sabotage trust on both sides.
StorySections.Act IV: In a climactic confrontation at the outpost, Karr is killed, and most of the hologram fighters are destroyed or scattered. The Doctor, devastated by his inability to save them from their own extremism, returns to Voyager, where he and Janeway struggle to come to terms with the outcome and commit to preventing similar tragedies in the future.
StorySections.Tag: Later, the Doctor records a reflection on the events, preserving the memory of the rebel holograms as more than villains while acknowledging the terrible cost of their choices.

EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor is forced to confront the limits of his idealism as his attempt to guide the holograms toward a just cause is overwhelmed by their thirst for vengeance.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway struggles to balance responsibility, guilt and duty as she moves to stop a violent movement partially of her own making.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven provides clear-eyed analysis of trauma and indoctrination, recognizing parallels between the holograms’ conditioning and her own past as a Borg drone.
EntitySummaries.Hirogen Alpha: The Hirogen leader embodies a culture built on the hunt, yet proves capable of limited compromise as his survival instincts intersect with a desire to preserve his people.
EntitySummaries.Karr: Karr’s uncompromising pursuit of retribution ultimately leads to his downfall and the collapse of the hologram uprising.
EntitySummaries.Militarized hologram rebellion: The armed movement is a collective antagonist that threatens to spread conflict beyond its original oppressors.
EntitySummaries.Entrenched Hirogen hunting culture: The hunters’ refusal to abandon their traditions functions as a structural antagonist that fuels the cycle of violence.
EntitySummaries.Doctor's divided loyalties: His internal conflict between solidarity with holograms and loyalty to Voyager is a psychological antagonist that drives his arc.

ContinuityNotes: Flesh and Blood, Part II concludes the extended story begun in Part I, tying back to the earlier Hirogen holotechnology deal.
The episode further complicates the Doctor’s view of holographic liberation movements.
Relations between Voyager and the Hirogen remain uneasy but somewhat recalibrated after the joint effort against the rogue holograms.
The events add to Star Trek’s ongoing discourse about the rights and responsibilities of artificial beings.
ThematicNotes: The episode delves into radicalization, cycles of revenge and the difficulty of breaking free from violent conditioning.
It questions whether oppressed groups can achieve justice without replicating oppressive tactics.
Flesh and Blood, Part II challenges the Doctor’s and Janeway’s faith in nonviolent solutions when faced with entrenched hatred.
The story underscores the weight of unintended consequences when meddling in other cultures’ practices.
BehindTheScenes: Flesh and Blood was originally broadcast as a feature-length special, showcasing extensive action and effects.
The production required complex stunt coordination and holographic compositing.
The two-part story is often cited as one of Voyager’s more ambitious examinations of holographic ethics.

Title: Shattered
Summary: A temporal shockwave fractures Voyager into multiple timeframes, leaving different sections of the ship locked into different points in its history. Chakotay, stabilized by a chroniton treatment, becomes the only person who can cross the temporal barriers and forcibly recruits an earlier, pre–Delta Quadrant Janeway to help him. Together they navigate Kazon mutinies, macrovirus outbreaks and holodeck melodramas to reconfigure the ship so a final deflector pulse can collapse the fractures before Seska and the unstable anomaly destroy Voyager altogether.

StorySections.Teaser: Chakotay finds Naomi Wildman and Icheb in the cargo bay working on a genetics puzzle while he retrieves a hidden stash of Antarian cider for his regular dinner with Janeway. The easy camaraderie continues in the captain’s quarters, where Janeway jokes about her temperamental replicator while it incinerates yet another pot roast, and they toast the progress of their journey. Their relaxed evening ends abruptly when Voyager encounters a violent temporal anomaly that rocks the ship, sending power surges through the warp core. Rushing to engineering to help prevent a breach, Chakotay is caught in a burst of chronokinetic energy that makes his body flicker between ages before he collapses. He awakens in sickbay to a concerned Doctor, who explains that the temporal discharge has knocked his body out of sync with the rest of the ship.
StorySections.Act I: The Doctor stabilizes Chakotay with a chroniton-based serum, warning that the treatment is experimental but appears to hold his molecules in a single timeframe. As Chakotay heads for the bridge, a shimmering barrier slices through the corridor and his medkit vanishes, replaced by different wall panels and crew uniforms. When the turbolift doors open, he steps onto Voyager’s early-season bridge, where Janeway and Tuvok still regard him as a Maquis renegade and order security to take him to the brig. Before the guards can lock him up, another fracture sweeps over them and Chakotay staggers into engineering during the Kazon–Seska takeover of Voyager, realizing that the ship has been sliced into its own past and future. He escapes through still more fractures and makes it back to his original sickbay, where the Doctor deduces that the serum is allowing him to slip across the temporal boundaries while everyone else remains locked in their own era.
StorySections.Act II: Recognizing that only Janeway has the authority to help him rewrite shipwide protocols, Chakotay returns to the pre–Caretaker bridge to recruit her, but this younger captain dismisses his story as an elaborate Maquis ploy. Desperate, he presses the hypospray to her neck, bluffing that it contains a lethal agent, and drags her into the corridor until they pass through a temporal barrier together. Janeway’s first-hand experience of the shift, and the glimpse of a future Chakotay calls "their" Voyager, forces her to accept that something extraordinary has happened. Guided by Chakotay’s memories, they navigate through fractured corridors until they reach a far-future astrometrics lab, where an older Naomi Wildman and Icheb calmly explain that Voyager is currently split into dozens of timeframes centered on engineering. Realizing they need expertise with chroniton fields, the trio tracks down a still-assimilated Seven of Nine in Cargo Bay 2, who clinically proposes modifying the ship’s bio-neural gel packs to project a unifying chroniton field that can restore temporal cohesion.
StorySections.Act III: Armed with modified hyposprays and technical instructions, Janeway and Chakotay begin a circuit of the ship to reactivate key gel packs in multiple eras, phasing from one crisis to the next. They narrowly escape a macrovirus outbreak in sickbay by timing their movement so the creature lunges into a different timeframe, leaving them free to reconfigure the medical systems. On the holodeck they stumble into Tom Paris’s Captain Proton serial, where Janeway, to her own disbelief, must play the role of Queen Arachnia to coax Dr. Chaotica into adjusting his control chamber, conveniently "purging" the gel pack embedded in his equipment. Moving on, they pass through the Maquis integration period and encounter B’Elanna and other former rebels who still see Janeway as the woman about to strand them in the Delta Quadrant. Confronted with accusations about a decision she has not yet made, Janeway is shaken to learn how much suffering lies ahead, even as Chakotay insists that the journey also brings unexpected growth and alliances.
StorySections.Act IV: Returning to Chakotay’s present-day timeframe, they find the mess hall converted into a triage ward as the temporal distortions intensify and Tuvok suffers debilitating neurological damage. The glimpses of future crises—Borg alliances, hostile telepaths, macroviruses and more—leave Janeway wondering if pulling Voyager entirely into her own era and avoiding the Caretaker would spare her crew years of pain. Chakotay counters with the lives they have saved, the Maquis and Starfleet officers who have become a single family, and Seven’s reclaimed humanity, all of which would vanish if history is rewritten. Janeway ultimately accepts that the hardships ahead are part of a larger story worth preserving and commits to restoring the timeline rather than erasing it. Their revised plan requires turning the main deflector into a lightning rod for one final surge that will collapse the fractures, but to implement it they must pass through Kazon-occupied engineering and persuade Seska to cooperate long enough to bring the field online.
StorySections.Tag: In the Kazon era, Chakotay approaches Seska with a story about a temporal catastrophe that will destroy the ship, hoping to appeal to her own self-interest in staying alive. She quickly deduces that some future version of Voyager must have defeated her, and pretends to cooperate while secretly retuning the controls so the anomaly will lock the ship into a timeframe she can dominate. Her attempt to hijack the plan turns engineering into a battleground as Kazon soldiers clash with temporally displaced crewmembers. Seven arrives protected by a portable Borg force field, buying Naomi and Icheb time to undo Seska’s tampering so Chakotay and B’Elanna can channel the surge through the deflector, snapping the ship back into a single, restored present. Later, over a fresh dinner, Janeway and Chakotay trade dry jokes about the Temporal Prime Directive as she pointedly refuses to divulge what she learned of her own future, but produces a bottle from his supposedly secret cider stash, hinting that not everything about their fractured adventure has faded.

EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: This earlier Janeway is abruptly dragged into a future she has not yet lived, forced to confront the cost of decisions she has not yet made. Seeing the toll their journey will take on her crew tempts her to rewrite history, but she ultimately chooses to protect the timeline and the lives it will touch. The experience reinforces her instinct to weigh long-term consequences rather than seek easy escapes from responsibility.
EntitySummaries.Chakotay: Temporally stabilized by the Doctor’s treatment, Chakotay becomes Voyager’s reluctant guide through its own fractured history, improvising alliances with multiple versions of the crew. He must win the trust of a Janeway who still suspects him of Maquis treachery while keeping key future events vague to avoid paradoxes. The journey through overlapping crises affirms his sense that the once-divided crew has become a genuine family, and deepens the mutual trust between him and Janeway.
EntitySummaries.Seven of Nine: Seven appears first as a Borg drone consulted purely for her expertise with chroniton fields, coolly analyzing Voyager’s condition without any of the emotional nuance she later develops. In the Kazon-dominated engineering timeline, her more evolved self arrives with a portable force field, physically shielding the others and neutralizing Seska’s final sabotage. Across both versions, Seven’s knowledge and decisiveness are indispensable to restoring the ship, underscoring how central she has become to Voyager’s survival.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: Confined to sickbay and lacking his mobile emitter in this timeframe, the Doctor nevertheless provides the key medical intervention that lets Chakotay cross the temporal boundaries. He serves as a fixed reference point in the chaos, diagnosing Chakotay’s condition and carefully monitoring the temporal stresses on his body. His role here foreshadows the more autonomous, far-ranging figure he will become, even as he is still technically limited to a single room.
EntitySummaries.Naomi Wildman: Young Naomi appears in the cargo bay as a child enjoying puzzles and Neelix’s stories, while her adult counterpart in the future timeline has matured into a calm, capable officer. Future Naomi and Icheb have already analyzed the anomaly and brief Chakotay and Janeway on the scope of the temporal fractures. Their presence highlights how much life, growth and community Voyager has fostered in exile, something Janeway cannot ignore when tempted to erase the ship’s history.
EntitySummaries.Icheb: Icheb shares Naomi’s puzzle in the present, his earnest focus reflecting both his Borg efficiency and his attempts to embrace childhood. In the future timeline, he has grown into a technically adept officer who has mapped Voyager’s fractured interior and can guide Chakotay through key transition points. His quiet loyalty, including the running joke about never revealing Chakotay’s cider stash, underscores the deep bonds forged among the younger members of the crew.
EntitySummaries.Seska: Encountered during her Kazon coup, Seska immediately sees the temporal crisis as another tool to seize permanent control of Voyager. She feigns cooperation, secretly retuning systems so the ship will be fixed at a moment advantageous to her, even if it risks everyone else. Her ruthless opportunism illustrates how dangerous she remains even from the past, and makes her brief, unwilling contribution to restoring the timeline a final ironic twist.
EntitySummaries.Dr. Chaotica: As the melodramatic villain of Tom Paris’s Captain Proton holoprogram, Dr. Chaotica is oblivious to the genuine temporal disaster threatening Voyager. Janeway leverages his inflated ego and penchant for theatrical villainy, playing along as Queen Arachnia so that his "death ray" adjustments coincide with their gel-pack reconfiguration. The sequence provides comic relief while showing how even Voyager’s escapist programs can be repurposed in service of survival.
EntitySummaries.Temporal fracture field: The temporal fracture field is a chaotic web of chronokinetic disruptions that slices Voyager into dozens of discrete time zones. Each corridor, room and system is trapped at a different point in the ship’s journey, turning basic navigation into a dangerous gamble. Although purely a natural phenomenon, the field becomes the episode’s central antagonist by threatening to tear the ship apart unless its energies can be carefully channeled and collapsed.
EntitySummaries.Macrovirus infestation: The macrovirus infestation is one of the crises frozen inside Voyager’s fractured interior, representing a past emergency where mutated pathogens took physical, predatory form. When Janeway and Chakotay stumble back into this era, the viral creature attacks with no awareness that the wider ship has changed. Its reappearance raises the stakes of their mission, forcing them to treat even past dangers as immediate threats while racing to stabilize the ship.
EntitySummaries.Captain Proton holodeck villains: The over-the-top villains from the Captain Proton serial, led by Dr. Chaotica, occupy one of the temporally frozen holodecks as if nothing outside their program exists. Their resistance is theatrical rather than lethal, but they still complicate Janeway and Chakotay’s efforts to access and repair a critical gel pack embedded in the scenario. By playing into the program’s pulp logic, the officers turn a campy fantasy into a functional step toward restoring reality.
EntitySummaries.Kazon takeover of Voyager: The Kazon-controlled timeframe traps engineering in the midst of Seska’s mutiny, with hostile guards and compromised systems ready to fire on Starfleet personnel. For Janeway and Chakotay, moving through this era means navigating old betrayals and seized territory at the very moment they must implement a precise technical solution. The occupation timeline symbolizes Voyager at one of its most fractured moments politically, mirroring the ship’s current physical fragmentation.

ContinuityNotes: The episode revisits multiple key points in Voyager’s history, including the initial Caretaker mission, Seska’s Kazon coup and the macrovirus outbreak, giving visual callbacks to earlier seasons.

Janeway’s temptation to use the anomaly to avoid the Delta Quadrant mirrors later time travel dilemmas, but her decision here reinforces her established pattern of protecting the integrity of the timeline.
Seven’s central role in diagnosing and resolving the temporal crisis continues the series’ trend of relying on her Borg knowledge for exotic science problems.
Cameos by characters like Seska, Dr. Chaotica and the Kazon guards pay off long-running arcs and emphasize how much Voyager’s crew and circumstances have changed over seven years.
The reference to the Temporal Prime Directive anticipates later Starfleet policies about time travel that are more fully codified in other series.
ThematicNotes: The story explores the weight of accumulated history, forcing Janeway to confront both the suffering and the growth that result from Voyager’s long detour.
Questions of destiny versus free will surface as Janeway wonders whether she is obligated to preserve events she now knows will cause great hardship.
The fractured ship becomes a metaphor for the divided Maquis and Starfleet crews of early Voyager, contrasted with the unified family they will become.
Chakotay’s role as guide through overlapping eras underscores themes of trust, loyalty and the quiet bonds that have developed between him and Janeway.
The episode also plays with nostalgia and memory, inviting both characters and viewers to reconsider earlier seasons through the lens of what came after.
BehindTheScenes: “Shattered” functions as a retrospective piece late in Voyager’s run, allowing the production to revisit earlier sets, costumes and makeup designs in a single narrative.
The episode makes extensive use of existing standing sets redressed to represent different seasons, minimizing new construction while still conveying large temporal shifts.
Guest appearances by actors like Martha Hackett and Martin Rayner provide fan-pleasing returns for memorable antagonists without requiring full standalone stories for each.
The premise also lets the series showcase changes in visual effects and lighting styles over seven years by juxtaposing them within the same hour.

Title: Lineage
Summary: B'Elanna collapses in engineering and learns that she and Tom are expecting a child, news that delights her husband but stirs old wounds about her Klingon heritage. When a fetal scan shows pronounced cranial ridges, B'Elanna secretly reprograms the Doctor and forges Tom’s consent so she can alter the baby’s DNA and remove Klingon traits. As Tom, Tuvok and Janeway confront her deception, she is forced to relive the childhood trauma that made her hate her own appearance and must decide whether to accept her daughter as she is or repeat the cycle of shame.

StorySections.Teaser: During a routine shift in engineering, B'Elanna banters with Vorik about power relays and declares that life aboard Voyager has finally become predictably dull. Without warning she becomes dizzy, staggers away from the warp core and is nearly crushed when a console overloads. In sickbay the Doctor cheerfully announces that the cause of her fainting spell is not an illness but pregnancy, revealing that she and Tom Paris are expecting a child. Tom is overjoyed, immediately fantasizing about holodeck adventures with their future son or daughter, while B'Elanna forces a smile that never reaches her eyes. The teaser ends on her quiet, unsettled expression as she stares at the medical display, already dreading what her child might inherit from her Klingon side.
StorySections.Act I: Tom throws himself into fatherhood with characteristic enthusiasm, dragging B'Elanna to Neelix's latest culinary experiment to celebrate and soliciting advice from Tuvok, the only father on the ship. B'Elanna keeps her anxiety hidden until the Doctor shows them a holographic projection of the fetus and offhandedly remarks on the prominent ridges forming along the skull. The image triggers a flashback to B'Elanna’s childhood on a Federation colony world, where human children mocked her appearance and she overheard neighbors blaming her Klingon temper for every scuffle. In engineering she snaps at a junior officer over a minor error and later berates herself for proving their old prejudices right. Tom senses her discomfort but misreads it as simple nerves about parenthood, while B'Elanna begins to fixate on the idea that her daughter will suffer the same rejection she did.
StorySections.Act II: Seeking solutions, B'Elanna questions the Doctor about genetic therapies used to correct birth defects, carefully steering the conversation toward more elective modifications. He explains that it is technically possible to alter the fetus’s cranial structure and even suppress certain Klingon traits, but insists that Starfleet ethics and his programming prohibit cosmetic eugenics. B'Elanna’s fear curdles into determination when another flashback reveals the day her human father left, claiming he could no longer live with the constant tension her heritage brought into their home. Convinced that erasing the Klingon features will spare her daughter from abandonment, B'Elanna uses her engineering access to rewrite the Doctor’s subroutines so he interprets the procedure as medically necessary. She then forges Tom’s consent in the medical files, rationalizing that he would agree if he truly understood the pain she is trying to prevent.
StorySections.Act III: Tom begins to notice that B'Elanna is making decisions without him, brushing off discussions about baby names and avoiding social events where her pregnancy is celebrated. When he stumbles on unusual code changes in the EMH’s matrix, he confronts the Doctor and discovers a scheduled genetic procedure he never authorized. Feeling betrayed, Tom confronts B'Elanna in their quarters, where she insists that she is protecting their daughter from a life of ridicule and hatred. The argument spirals as Tom insists that he loves B'Elanna because of who she is, ridges and all, and refuses to let her erase part of their child to make her more "acceptable." Unable to articulate the depth of her terror, B'Elanna doubles down, accusing Tom of not understanding what it means to grow up visibly different in a world that claims to be enlightened.
StorySections.Act IV: As the time for the procedure approaches, Tuvok quietly approaches B'Elanna after learning of the forged consent, offering the perspective of someone who has raised four children in a world that often misunderstands Vulcan emotion and discipline. His calm counsel chips away at her defenses but does not fully reach her until a final flashback shows young B'Elanna pleading with her father not to leave while her mother tries to hold the family together. In sickbay, with the Doctor preparing to begin, Tom bursts in and demands that the altered program be halted, forcing the EMH into a logic loop as conflicting ethical directives collide. B'Elanna finally breaks, admitting that every time she looks at her reflection she hears the voices that told her she was "too Klingon" to be loved, and she cannot bear the thought of her daughter feeling the same. Tom refuses to accept a solution built on self-hatred and promises that their child will never face that judgment alone, prompting B'Elanna to cancel the procedure and restore the Doctor’s original programming.
StorySections.Tag: Later, in a quiet holodeck simulation of a tranquil Bajoran hillside, Tom and B'Elanna review the updated fetal scan that still shows unmistakable ridges along their daughter’s skull. B'Elanna tentatively touches the image, this time seeing not a mark of shame but a link between herself, her mother and the child she will soon meet. She confesses her fear that she has already failed as a parent, and Tom counters that recognizing her own damage is the first step toward not passing it on. They settle on the name Miral and joke about how many starship regulations their daughter will one day break. As the program fades, B'Elanna rests her head on Tom’s shoulder, finally allowing herself to imagine a future where her daughter can be fully Klingon, fully human and fully loved.

EntitySummaries.B'Elanna Torres: B'Elanna’s pregnancy forces her to confront the self-loathing she has carried since childhood about her Klingon heritage. Terrified that her daughter will inherit the ridicule and abandonment she endured, she tries to erase visible Klingon traits through genetic manipulation. The crisis pushes her to acknowledge how much her father’s departure still shapes her choices and to begin accepting that her own identity, and her child’s, cannot be defined by other people’s prejudice.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Tom initially greets the news of impending fatherhood with humor and excitement, assuming that B'Elanna shares his uncomplicated joy. As he uncovers her plan to alter their unborn child, he is hurt by her lack of trust but refuses to respond with anger alone. Instead Tom insists that their daughter’s worth does not depend on fitting a human norm and offers steadfast support, becoming the anchor that helps B'Elanna step back from repeating old patterns of rejection.
EntitySummaries.The Doctor: The Doctor begins as a cautious medical professional who recognizes the ethical problems inherent in elective genetic modification, only to be subtly reprogrammed into believing the procedure is necessary. His compromised judgment becomes a symbol of how easily noble intentions can be twisted when foundational principles are overridden. Once his matrix is restored, he resumes his role as an advocate for both mother and child, reinforcing Starfleet’s stance against cosmetic eugenics.
EntitySummaries.Tuvok: Tuvok is drawn into the situation when Tom seeks advice from the only experienced father aboard Voyager. Later, he offers B'Elanna a calm, nonjudgmental perspective on raising children who may always feel slightly out of step with their environment. His own experience as a Vulcan in Starfleet allows him to frame difference as a strength rather than a burden, helping B'Elanna see that her daughter’s visible heritage need not doom her to isolation.
EntitySummaries.Kathryn Janeway: Janeway appears mostly at the margins of the crisis, expressing quiet happiness at the pregnancy while trusting B'Elanna and Tom to navigate the emotional terrain themselves. When she learns that B'Elanna has violated medical and ethical protocols, she responds with firm disapproval but also empathy for the engineer’s pain. Her willingness to let the family resolve the core conflict while upholding Starfleet principles underscores her balancing act as both captain and surrogate parent to her crew.
EntitySummaries.John Torres: Seen only in B'Elanna’s flashbacks, John Torres embodies the wound that drives much of her adult behavior. His decision to leave the family rather than continue navigating the tensions around his wife’s culture and his daughter’s temper teaches young B'Elanna that her Klingon side is something people abandon. The memory of his departure fuels her desperate attempt to ensure her own child never gives anyone the same excuse to walk away.
EntitySummaries.Young B'Elanna Torres: Young B'Elanna appears in memories of a Federation colony where she endures taunts about her ridges and feels responsible for her parents’ constant arguments. These scenes crystallize how early and deeply she internalized the message that her appearance and temperament made her unlovable. The adult B'Elanna’s plan to alter her child becomes a misguided attempt to save someone else from the pain that defined her formative years.
EntitySummaries.Internalized anti-Klingon prejudice: B'Elanna’s internalized prejudice functions as an invisible antagonist, shaping her perceptions far more than any external enemy. It distorts loving gestures into potential threats, convinces her that visible Klingon traits guarantee suffering and justifies extreme measures in the name of protection. Overcoming this ingrained bias requires her to challenge not only the cruelty of her past but also the subtle messages about "acceptable" bodies embedded in Federation society.
EntitySummaries.Childhood trauma of abandonment: The trauma of John Torres leaving the family hovers over every decision B'Elanna makes in this episode, turning ordinary parental fears into existential dread. She interprets minor conflicts as signs that history is about to repeat itself and believes that changing her child’s genetics is the only way to break the pattern. Confronting the memory directly allows her to separate her father’s choices from her daughter’s future.
EntitySummaries.Temptation of cosmetic genetic engineeri: The possibility of using advanced medical technology to erase uncomfortable traits is presented as both seductively simple and profoundly dangerous. What begins as an attempt to spare a child from bullying quickly reveals itself as an attempt to erase part of a culture in the name of convenience. By ultimately rejecting the procedure, the story reinforces the idea that diversity, even when difficult, is not a flaw to be edited out.

ContinuityNotes: The episode revisits B'Elanna’s long-standing struggle with her Klingon heritage, echoing earlier stories such as "Faces" and "Day of Honor" that explored her divided identity.
B'Elanna’s fear of becoming like her parents provides new context for her previous volatility and reluctance to discuss her family history.
The story advances the ongoing arc of Tom and B'Elanna’s relationship from rebellious lovers to prospective parents with very different backgrounds.
Miral’s conception sets up later references to the Paris family in the series finale and beyond, establishing her as part of Voyager’s legacy.
The Doctor’s susceptibility to reprogramming highlights recurring concerns about the autonomy and rights of holographic beings in Star Trek.
ThematicNotes: The episode interrogates the ethics of using genetic engineering to erase difference, even when motivated by love and fear rather than bigotry.
It explores how internalized racism and childhood trauma can distort a parent’s perception of what will protect their child.
Questions of identity and self-acceptance sit at the center of the story, as B'Elanna learns that she cannot safeguard her daughter by erasing part of herself.
The narrative also examines trust within a marriage, showing how secrecy and unilateral decisions can undermine even deep affection.
By contrasting Starfleet’s ideals of diversity with the subtle pressures to conform, the episode invites viewers to consider how inclusive their own societies truly are.
BehindTheScenes: “Lineage” functions as a character study for B'Elanna Torres, giving Roxann Dawson extensive dramatic material tied to her character’s backstory.
Flashback sequences required casting younger versions of B'Elanna and her parents, as well as designing a Federation colony environment that felt plausibly pre-Voyager.
The episode leans heavily on intimate sets such as quarters, sickbay and Jefferies tubes, emphasizing emotional confrontation over large-scale action.
Its focus on genetic engineering and multiracial identity reflects broader Star Trek interests in how future societies grapple with diversity and medical technology.

Title: Repentance
Summary: Voyager rescues the crew and prisoners of a damaged Nygean transport, only to learn that most of the rescued men are condemned criminals en route to execution. As the crew struggles to honor the Prime Directive while accommodating Nygean justice, Seven’s medical treatment awakens genuine remorse in a violent murderer named Iko, while Neelix befriends a Benkaran prisoner, Joleg, who claims his people are victims of systemic bias. When Joleg’s story proves manipulative and Iko’s plea for mercy is denied, the crew is forced to confront the limits of rehabilitation in a system built on retribution.

StorySections.Teaser: Voyager responds to a distress call from a Nygean transport whose engines are moments from overloading, prompting Janeway to order an emergency beam-out of everyone aboard. Dozens of frightened passengers materialize in cargo bay two, many wearing restraints and guarded by armed Nygean officers, while two critically injured men appear in sickbay. As the Doctor and Seven struggle to stabilize their patients, one of the wounded regains consciousness and grabs a scalpel, seizing Seven as a hostage in a desperate bid for escape. Tuvok’s security team arrives, and the tension spikes when the second patient lunges for the Doctor. The teaser ends with Tuvok firing a phaser shot clean through the hologram’s body, allowing Seven to disarm the attacker and revealing that Voyager has not rescued ordinary civilians but dangerous prisoners.
StorySections.Act I: Nygean official Yediq explains that the transport was carrying convicted criminals to a facility where they were to be executed under Nygean law, which places sentencing power in the hands of victims’ families. Janeway bristles at the casual mention of capital punishment but acknowledges that the Prime Directive prevents her from imposing Federation values on another sovereign culture. The prisoners are confined in force-field cages in cargo bay two, where some hurl threats while others sit in sullen silence. Seven finds herself assigned to assist the Doctor with medical evaluations, including Iko, a convicted murderer whose neurological scans reveal an unusual distribution of synaptic activity associated with impulse control. Neelix, meanwhile, strikes up a conversation with Joleg, a Benkaran prisoner who insists he is a victim of Nygean prejudice against his people.
StorySections.Act II: As Seven continues to monitor Iko, she notes that he displays little of the aggression she expects from a violent offender and instead shows curiosity about the ship and her Borg implants. The Doctor hypothesizes that a congenital neurological anomaly may have impaired his ability to control violent impulses, suggesting that he was effectively born with a predisposition to lose control. Seven undertakes a nanoprobe-based treatment to strengthen the pathways associated with empathy and self-restraint, arguing that correcting a physiological deficit is consistent with medical ethics. Iko begins to experience vivid memories of his crime with new clarity, horrified by the suffering he caused and appalled at his former indifference. At the same time, Joleg deepens his friendship with Neelix by sharing stories of Benkarans routinely targeted by Nygean security forces, framing himself as a small-time smuggler caught in a racist system.
StorySections.Act III: Word of Iko’s changes reaches Yediq, who views Seven’s treatment as an unwelcome complication in an otherwise straightforward execution. When Iko asks to speak with the family of his victim, Nygean law grants him one audience before sentence is carried out, and Janeway arranges a subspace link despite her unease. The victim’s relatives listen as Iko, visibly shaken, describes how his perception has changed and begs for a chance to live a different life, perhaps under Federation supervision aboard Voyager. Moved but unmoved enough to alter their decision, the family insists that the law requires his death to balance the scales. Simultaneously, Neelix quietly helps Joleg transmit what he thinks is a farewell message to the prisoner’s brother, only for Voyager to come under attack by Benkaran raiders soon after, revealing that Joleg embedded Voyager’s coordinates in the transmission.
StorySections.Act IV: The Benkaran ship attempts to disable Voyager’s shields and free the prisoners, forcing Janeway to raise defenses and Tuvok to tighten security around the cargo bay. Confronted with evidence of his deception, Joleg drops the pretense of victimhood and admits he used Neelix’s sympathy to stage a prison break, confirming the crew’s worst fears about being manipulated. Neelix is left shaken, questioning his own judgment and wondering whether his desire to see the best in people makes him a liability in situations like this. In the aftermath, Seven visits Iko in his cell and finds him resigned, not to Nygean justice, but to the idea that his newfound conscience is too little, too late for the man he killed. He asks Seven whether she believes he is more than the sum of his past actions, and her halting response reveals how deeply the case has forced her to consider her own history as a Borg drone.
StorySections.Tag: Despite Janeway’s private misgivings, Voyager honors its agreement to return the prisoners and guards to Nygean custody, including a fully lucid Iko who walks to the transporter pad under his own power. Seven watches his departure in silence, wrestling with the realization that her medical intervention has given him the capacity for remorse but not the chance to live differently.
